# 2.3 Homology theories for manifolds 

The value of factorization homology over an $n$-manifold $M$ of an $n$-disk algebra $A$ is a sort of average, indexed by $n$-disks embedded in $M$, of the value of $A$ on such $n$-disks. We make this definition precise, as well as observe a property of this definition for which it is universal, by defining factorization homology as left Kan extension of an $n$-disk algebra $A: \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$ along the inclusion $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{M f l d}_{n}$.

Throughout this entire section, we fix a space $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ over $\mathrm{BO}(n)$ as well as a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$ that is $\otimes$-presentable in the following sense.
Definition 2.3.1. A symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$ is $\otimes$-presentable if it satisfies both of the following conditions.

- The underlying $\infty$-category of $\mathcal{V}$ is presentable: $\mathcal{V}$ admits colimits and every object is a filtered colimit of compact objects. ${ }^{8}$
- The symmetric monoidal structure of $\mathcal{V}$ distributes over colimits: for each object $V \in \mathcal{V}$, the functor $V \otimes-: \mathcal{V} \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$ carries colimit diagrams to colimit diagrams.
Example 2.3.2. Let $\mathcal{S}$ be a presentable $\infty$-category. Consider the Cartesian symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $(\mathcal{S}, \times)$, in which the symmetric monoidal structure is categorical product. Provided $\mathcal{S}$ is Cartesian closed, then this symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category is $\otimes$ presentable. In particular, (Spaces, $\times$ ) is $\otimes$-presentable; for $\mathcal{X}$ any $\infty$-topos, then $(\mathcal{X}, \times)$ is $\otimes$-presentable; also, $\left(\right.$ Cat $\left._{\infty}, \times\right)$ is $\otimes$-presentable.
Example 2.3.3. Let $R$ be a commutative ring. The symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{R}, \otimes_{R}\right)$ of $R$-modules with tensor product over $R$ is $\otimes$-presentable. Note, however, that its opposite $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{R}^{\text {op }}, \otimes_{R}\right)$ is not $\otimes$-presentable.
Remark 2.3.4. The results in $\S 2.3$ (in particular, the Eilenberg-Steenrod axioms for factorization homology) only require that the symmetric monoidal structure of $\mathcal{V}$ distributes over sifted colimits. (This generality is established as a special case of $\S 2$ of [8].) However, the calculations of $\S 2.5$ onwards require the symmetric monoidal structure to distribute over all colimits, so for simplicity of exposition we enforce this stronger hypothesis throughout.


### 2.3.1 Disk algebras

$$
\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{D} i s k_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V}):=\operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\mathcal{D} i s k_{n}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right)
$$

Definition 2.3.7. Let $M$ be a $B$-framed $n$-manifold. Let $A$ be a $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$-algebra in $\mathcal{V}$. The factorization homology (of $M$ with coefficients in $A$ ) is the object in $\mathcal{V}$ given either as the colimit (provided it exists), or the coend (provided it exists):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{M} A & :=\operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B} \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}\right) \\
& \simeq \mathbb{E}_{M} \bigotimes_{\mathcal{D i s k}_{M}^{B}} A
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 2.3.8. We comment on the two equivalent expressions defining factorization homology: as a colimit indexed by an overcategory and as a coend. This is analogous to the familiar fact that, for $X_{\bullet}: \Delta^{\text {op }} \rightarrow$ Spaces a simplicial space, its geometric realization can be expressed

$$
\left|X_{\bullet}\right|:=\operatorname{colim}\left(\Delta_{/ X_{\bullet}} \rightarrow \Delta \xrightarrow{\Delta^{\bullet}} \text { Spaces }\right) \simeq X_{\bullet} \bigotimes_{\Delta} \Delta^{\bullet}
$$

as a colimit of topological simplices indexed by the category of simplices in $X_{\bullet}$, or as the standard coend expression which is a quotient of $\coprod_{p \geq 0} X_{p} \times \Delta^{p}$.

The fully faithful symmetric monoidal functor $\iota: \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{M f l d}_{n}^{B}$ gives the restriction functor

$$
\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V}):=\operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right) \leftarrow \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\mathcal{M f l d}_{n}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right): \iota^{*}
$$

The next result, proved in [3], identifies factorization homology as the values of a left adjoint to this restriction functor, provided $\mathcal{V}$ is $\otimes$-presentable.

Proposition 2.3.9. [3] Let $\mathcal{V}$ be $\otimes$-presentable $\infty$-category. The restriction functor $\iota^{*}$ admits a left adjoint,

$$
\iota_{!}: \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V}) \rightleftarrows \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\mathcal{M f l d}_{n}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right): \iota^{*}
$$

over a left adjoint $\iota_{!}: \operatorname{Fun}\left(\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right) \rightleftarrows \operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right): \iota^{*}$. Furthermore, this left adjoint evaluates on a $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}$-algebra $A$ as factorization homology:

$$
\iota_{!}(A): M \mapsto \int_{M} A
$$

Remark 2.3.10. Proposition 2.3.9 implies factorization homology can be expressed as a symmetric monoidal left Kan extension, at least when $\mathcal{V}$ is $\otimes$-presentable. Consequently, the definition of factorization homology given above is equivalent to an operadic left Kan extension (after parsing Definitions 3.1.1.2 and 3.1.2.2 of [43]), which is the definition of factorization homology, or topological chiral homology, given by Lurie [43] (Definition 5.5.2.6).

The next result explains how factorization homology transforms under change of tangential structure.

Proposition 2.3.11. Let $B \xrightarrow{\alpha} B^{\prime}$ be a map between spaces over $\mathrm{BO}(n)$. Let $M=(M, \varphi)$ be a $B$-framed $n$-manifold. Consider the $B^{\prime}$-framed $n$-manifold $\alpha M:=(M, \alpha \varphi)$. Let $A$ be a $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B^{\prime}}$-algebra $A: \operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$. Consider the $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}$-algebra $\alpha A: \operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B} \rightarrow \operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B^{\prime}} \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}$. The canonical morphism in $\mathcal{V}$

$$
\int_{M} \alpha A \xrightarrow{\simeq} \int_{\alpha M} A
$$

is an equivalence.
Proof. Note the canonical commutative diagram among $\infty$-categories:

For formal reasons, the top horizontal functor is an equivalence between $\infty$-categories. It follows that the canonical morphism in $\mathcal{V}$

$$
\int_{M} \alpha A=\operatorname{colim}\left(\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{B} \rightarrow \operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B} \xrightarrow{\alpha A} \mathcal{V}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{colim}\left(\operatorname{Disk}_{n / \alpha M}^{B^{\prime}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B^{\prime}} \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}\right)=\int_{\alpha M} A
$$

# 2.3.2 Factorization algebras 

We now use factorization homology to construct factorization algebras over each $B$ framed $n$-manifold, as in the sense used by Costello-Gwilliam (see Definition 2.3.12). Namely, Proposition 2.3.14 shows that $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}$-algebra $A$ in $\mathcal{V}$ determines a factorization algebra $\mathcal{F}_{A}$ on each $B$-framed $n$-manifold $M$ whose value $\mathcal{F}_{A}(U)$ on an open subset $U \subset M$

is factorization homology of $A$,

$$
\mathcal{F}_{A}(U) \simeq \int_{U} A
$$

over $U$ (with its $B$-framing inherited from that of $M$ ).
For the next definition, for each $n$-manifold $M$, we observe the following multi-category structure on the poset $\operatorname{Opens}(M):=\operatorname{Mfld}_{n / M}$ of open subsets in $M$ ordered by inclusion. Namely, an object is an open subset of $M$, and there is a multi-morphism from $\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ to $V$, which is unique, provided the collection $\left\{U_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ is pairwise disjoint and provided $\bigcup_{i \in I} U_{i} \subset V$. Recall from $\S 2.2 .6$ the definition of (locally constant) Weiss cosheaves.

Definition 2.3.12. [17] Let $\mathcal{V}$ be a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category. Let $M$ be an $n$ manifold. The $\infty$-category of ( $\mathcal{V}$-valued) factorization algebras (on $M$ ) is the full $\infty$ subcategory of algebras in $\mathcal{V}$ over the multi-category $\operatorname{Opens}(M)$ as in the pullback among $\infty$-categories:
![img-19.jpeg](img-19.jpeg)

The $\infty$-category of locally constant factorization algebras is the full $\infty$-subcategory of factorization algebras as in the pullback diagram among $\infty$-categories:
![img-20.jpeg](img-20.jpeg)

Remark 2.3.13. In other words, a factorization algebra is a multi-functor $\mathcal{F}: \operatorname{Opens}(M) \rightarrow$ $\mathcal{V}$ whose restriction to the poset $\operatorname{Opens}(M)$ is a Weiss cosheaf on $M$. Informally, a factorization algebra is likewise a functor $\mathcal{F}: \operatorname{Opens}(M) \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$ from the poset of open subsets of $M$ to the underlying $\infty$-category of $\mathcal{V}$ that satisfies codescent with respect to Weiss covers, together with a system of compatible equivalences in $\mathcal{V}$ : for each finite sequence $\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of pairwise disjoint open subsets of $M$, an equivalence $\mathcal{F}\left(\bigcup_{i \in I} U_{i}\right) \simeq \bigotimes_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}\left(U_{i}\right)$.

Proposition 2.3.14. Let $\mathcal{V}$ be a $\otimes$-presentable $\infty$-category, and let $B$ be a space over $\mathrm{BO}(n)$. For each $B$-framed $n$-manifold $M$, factorization homology defines a functor

$$
\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V}) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Alg}_{M}^{\mathrm{LC}}(\mathcal{V}), \quad A \mapsto\left(U \mapsto \int_{U} A\right)

from $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$-algebras to locally constant factorization algebras on $M$.

$$

Terminology 2.3.16. For $X$ a stratified space, a factorization algebra $\mathcal{F}$ on $X$ is constructible if, for each stratum $X_{p} \subset X$ of $X$, the restricted factorization algebra $\mathcal{F}_{\mid X_{p}}$ on $X_{p}$ is locally constant.

Remark 2.3.17. Let $X$ be a stratified space. Consider the $\infty$-category $\mathcal{B}_{X}$ of singularitytypes in $X$, and stratified open embeddings among them. Consider the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{B}_{X}\right)$ in which an object is a finite-fold disjoint union of objects in $\mathcal{B}_{X}$, and

a morphism between them is a stratified open embedding. Established in [8] is a similar construction to that of Proposition 2.3.14 as it concerns symmetric monoidal functors from $\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{B}_{X}\right)$ to constructible factorization algebras on $X$. See that reference for a thorough development, and $\S 2.8$ of this article for a synopsis.

# 2.3.3 Factorization homology over oriented 1-manifolds with boundary 

We show that factorization homology over a closed interval is a two-sided bar construction.

Recall from $\S 2.2 .8$ the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{M f l d}_{1}^{\partial}$ and its symmetric monoidal full $\infty$-subcategory $\mathcal{D i s k}_{1}^{\partial}$ consisting of finite disjoint unions of Euclidean and half-Euclidean spaces. In this subsection we consider, similarly, the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category and its symmetric monoidal full $\infty$-subcategory,

$$
\operatorname{Disk}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }} \subset \mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}
$$

An object in the latter is a 1-manifold with boundary equipped with an orientation, while such an object belongs to the smaller if each connected component of its underlying 1manifold with boundary is diffeomorphic to Euclidean space or half-Euclidean space. The space of morphisms between two such objects therein is the space of smooth open embeddings that preserve orientations, equipped with the compact-open $C^{\infty}$ topology. The symmetric monoidal structure is disjoint union.

Remark 2.3.18. The 1-manifold with boundary $[-1,1]$, equipped with its standard orientation determined by the non-vanishing vector field $\partial_{t}$, is an object in $\mathcal{M f l d}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}$ that does not belong to $\mathcal{D i s k}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}$.

We next articulate a sense in which $\operatorname{Disk}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}$ is entirely combinatorial.
Definition 2.3.19. [8] Assoc ${ }^{\mathrm{RL}}$ is the $\infty$-operad corepresenting triples $(A ; P, Q)$ consisting of an associative algebra together with a unital right and a unital left module. Specifically, it is a unital multi-category whose space of colors is the three-element set $\{M, R, L\}$, and with spaces of multi-morphisms given as follows. Let $I \xrightarrow{\sigma}\{M, R, L\}$ be a map from a finite set.

- $\operatorname{AssoC}^{\mathrm{RL}}(\sigma, M)$ is the set of linear orders on $I$ for which no element is related to an element of $\sigma^{-1}(\{R, L\})$. In other words, should $\sigma^{-1}(\{R, L\})$ be empty, then there is one multi-morphism from $\sigma$ to $M$ for each linear order on $\sigma^{-1}(M)$; should $\sigma^{-1}(\{R, L\})$ not be empty, then there are no multi-morphisms from $\sigma$ to $M$.
- $\operatorname{AssoC}^{\mathrm{RL}}(\sigma, L)$ is the set of linear orders on $I$ for which each element of $\sigma^{-1}(L)$ is a minimum, and no element is related to an element in $\sigma^{-1}(R)$. In other words, should $\sigma^{-1}(\{R\})$ be empty and $\sigma^{-1}(\{L\})$ have cardinality at most 1 , then there is one multimorphism from $\sigma$ to $M$ for each linear order on $\sigma^{-1}(M)$; should $\sigma^{-1}(\{R\})$ not be empty or $\sigma^{-1}(\{L\})$ have cardinality greater than 1 , then there are no multi-morphisms from $\sigma$ to $M$.

- $\operatorname{Assoc}^{\mathrm{RL}}(\sigma, R)$ is the set of linear orders on $I$ for which each element of $\sigma^{-1}(R)$ is a maximum, and no element is related to an element in $\sigma^{-1}(L)$. In other words, should $\sigma^{-1}(\{L\})$ be empty and $\sigma^{-1}(\{R\})$ have cardinality at most 1 , then there is one multimorphism from $\sigma$ to $M$ for each linear order on $\sigma^{-1}(M)$; should $\sigma^{-1}(\{L\})$ not be empty or $\sigma^{-1}(\{R\})$ have cardinality greater than 1 , then there are no multi-morphisms from $\sigma$ to $M$.

Composition of multi-morphisms is given by concatenating linearly ordered sets.
The next result references the symmetric monoidal envelope of the colored operad Assoc ${ }^{\mathrm{RL}}$. It is initial among symmetric monodal $\infty$-categories equipped with an Assoc ${ }^{\mathrm{RL}}$ algebra. In other words, it is a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Env}\left(\operatorname{Assoc}^{\mathrm{RL}}\right)$ corepresenting the copresheaf on the $\infty$-category of symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories

$$
\operatorname{Map}^{\otimes}\left(\operatorname{Env}\left(\operatorname{Assoc}^{\mathrm{RL}}\right),-\right): \operatorname{Cat}_{\infty} \otimes \longrightarrow \text { Spaces, } \quad \mathcal{V} \mapsto\left(\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Assoc }^{\mathrm{RL}}}(\mathcal{V})\right)^{\sim}
$$

whose value on a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category is the moduli space of Assoc ${ }^{\mathrm{RL}}$-algebras in it.

Lemma 2.3.20. Taking connected components defines an equivalence between symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories,

$$
[-]: \operatorname{Disk}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }} \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Env}\left(\operatorname{Assoc}^{\mathrm{RL}}\right)
$$

to the symmetric monoidal envelope, where the values on the symmetric monoidal generators are: $[\mathbb{R}]=M,\left[\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}\right]=R$, and $\left[\mathbb{R}_{\leq 0}\right]=L$.

Proof. Evidently, this defines a symmetric monoidal functor. We now show that it is an equivalence. Because it is so on symmetric monoidal generators, (2.3.1) is essentially surjective on spaces of objects. It remains to show that (2.3.1) is fully faithful. So let $U$ and $V$ be objects in $\operatorname{Disk}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}$. We must show that the map between spaces

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{\text {Disk }_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}}(U, V) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{\operatorname{Env}\left(\operatorname{Assoc}^{\mathrm{RL}}\right)}([U],[V])
$$

is an equivalence. For $V=\bigsqcup_{\alpha \in[V]} V_{\alpha}$ the partition as connected components, direct inspection of the definition of these two symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories yields an identification of this map is as the $[V]$-indexed product of such maps

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Map}_{\text {Disk }_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}}(U, V) \quad \xrightarrow{\simeq} \prod_{[U] \xrightarrow{f}[V]^{\alpha \in[V]}} \operatorname{Map}_{\text {Disk }_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}}\left(U_{\mid f^{-1} \alpha}, V_{\alpha}\right) \\
& \longrightarrow \prod_{[U] \xrightarrow{f}[V]^{\alpha \in[V]}} \operatorname{Map}_{\operatorname{Env}(\text { Assoc }^{\mathrm{RL}})}\left(f^{-1} \alpha,\left[V_{\alpha}\right]\right) \\
& \stackrel{\simeq}{\leftrightharpoons} \operatorname{Map}_{\operatorname{Env}(\text { Assoc }^{\mathrm{RL}})}([U],[V]) .
\end{aligned}
$$

We are therefore reduced to the case that $V$ is non-empty and connected. By direct inspection, the space of morphisms in $\operatorname{Disk}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}$ from $U$ to $V$ is a 0-type. So we are left to show that the map (2.3.2) is a bijection (on connected components). There are three cases to consider.

- In the case that $V \cong(-1,1)$ is oriented-diffeomorphic to an open interval, this 0-type is empty if $U$ has non-empty boundary, and otherwise it is the set of linear orders on the set $[U]$ of connected components.
- In the case that $V \cong[-1,1)$ is oriented-diffeomorphic to a left-closed/right-open interval, this 0-type is empty if $U$ has non-empty outward-pointing boundary, and otherwise it is the set of linear orders on $[U]$ for which each connected component with inward-pointing boundary is a minimum.
- In the case that $V \cong(-1,1]$ is oriented-diffeomorphic to a left-open/right-closed interval, this 0-type is empty if $U$ has non-empty inward-pointing boundary, and otherwise it is the set of linear orders on $[U]$ for which each connected component with outwardpointing boundary is a maximum.

Inspecting Definition 2.3.19, and the description of the symmetric monoidal functor $[-]$ under examination, reveals that the map (2.3.2) between 0-types is an equivalence, as desired.

Example 2.3.21. Note the functor $\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Assoc }}^{\text {aug }}(\mathcal{V}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Assoc } \text { RL }}(\mathcal{V})$ from augmented associative algebras, given by $(A \rightarrow \mathbb{1}) \mapsto(A ; \mathbb{1}, \mathbb{1})$. Concatenating with the equivalence of Lemma 2.3.20 results in a functor $\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Assoc }}^{\text {aug }}(\mathcal{V}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\operatorname{Disk}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}, \mathcal{V}\right)$.

Recall from $\S 2.2 .8$ the $\infty$-operad structure on $\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}$.
Observation 2.3.22. Consider the ordinary category $\mathrm{O}^{\mathrm{RL}}$ in which an object is a finite linearly ordered set $(I, \leq)$ together with a pair of disjoint subsets $R \subset I \supset L$ for which each element in $R$ is a minimum and each element in $L$ is a maximum; and in which a morphism $(I, \leq, R, L) \rightarrow\left(I^{\prime}, \leq^{\prime}, R^{\prime}, L^{\prime}\right)$ is an order preserving map $I \xrightarrow{f} I^{\prime}$ for which $f(R \sqcup L) \subset$ $R^{\prime} \sqcup L^{\prime}$. Concatenating linear orders endows $\mathrm{O}^{\mathrm{RL}}$ with the structure of a multi-category. Note the evident forgetful morphism between multi-categories $\mathrm{O}^{\mathrm{RL}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Env}\left(\right.$ Assoc $\left.^{\mathrm{RL}}\right)$. By direct inspection, the equivalence (2.3.1) lifts to an equivalence between $\infty$-operads:
![img-25.jpeg](img-25.jpeg)

Corollary 2.3.23. Let $(A ; P, Q)$ be an Assoc ${ }^{\mathrm{RL}}$-algebra in $\mathcal{V}$; which is to say an associative algebra $A$ together with a unital left and a unital right $A$-module. Through Lemma 2.3.20, regard $(A ; P, Q)$ as a symmetric monoidal functor $(A ; P, Q): \operatorname{Disk}_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }} \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$. There is a canonical equivalence in $\mathcal{V}$ from the balanced tensor product to factorization homology over the closed interval:

$$
Q \underset{A}{\otimes} P \xrightarrow{\simeq} \int_{[-1,1]}(A ; P, Q)
$$

Proof. Recognize the opposite of the simplex category as the full subcategory $\Delta^{\text {op }} \subset \mathrm{O}^{\mathrm{RL}}$ consisting of those objects $(I, \leq, R, L)$ for which $R \neq \emptyset \neq L$. Adjoining minima and maxima

gives a left adjoint $\mathrm{O}^{\mathrm{RL}} \rightarrow \Delta^{\mathrm{op}}$ to the inclusion. Therefore, the inclusion $\Delta^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow \mathrm{O}^{\mathrm{RL}}$ is final. Concatenating this final functor with the equivalence of Observation 2.3.22 results in a final functor $\boldsymbol{\Delta}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{1 /[-1,1]}^{\partial, \text { or }}$. By inspection, the resulting simplicial object

$$
\operatorname{Bar}_{\bullet}(Q, A, P): \boldsymbol{\Delta}^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow \mathcal{D} \operatorname{isk}_{1 /[-1,1]}^{\partial, \text { or }} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}_{\text {isk }_{1}^{\partial, \text { or }}} \xrightarrow{[-]} \operatorname{Env}\left(\operatorname{Assoc}^{\mathrm{RL}}\right) \xrightarrow{(A ; P, Q)} \mathcal{V}
$$

is identified as the two-sided bar construction, as indicated. We conclude the equivalence in $\mathcal{V}$ :

Note that the given multi-functor $\mathrm{O}^{\mathrm{RL}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Env}\left(\right.$ Assoc ${ }^{\mathrm{RL}}$ ) witness an equivalence $\operatorname{Env}\left(\mathrm{O}^{\mathrm{RL}}\right) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Env}\left(\operatorname{Assoc}^{\mathrm{RL}}\right)$ between symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories. After Observation 2.3.22, this offers the following consequence, which refers to Terminology 2.3.16.

Corollary 2.3.24. Factorization homology defines an equivalence of $\infty$-categories,

$$
\int: \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Assoc } \mathrm{RL}}(\mathcal{V}) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Disk }_{1 /[-1,1]}^{\partial, \text { or }}}(\mathcal{V})
$$

between associative algebra equipped with a unital left and right module and constructible factorization algebras over the closed interval.

# 2.3.4 Homology theories: definition 

We now define homology theories for $B$-framed $n$-manifolds.
Definition 2.3.25 (Collar-gluing). Let $M$ be a $B$-framed $n$-manifold. A collar-gluing of $M$ is a continuous map

$$
f: M \rightarrow[-1,1]
$$

to the closed interval for which the restriction $f_{\mid}: M_{\mid(-1,1)} \rightarrow(-1,1)$ is a smooth fiber bundle. We will often denote a collar-gluing $M \xrightarrow{f}[-1,1]$ simply as the open cover

$$
M_{-} \bigcup_{M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} M_{+} \cong M
$$

where $M_{-}=f^{-1}[-1,1)$ and $M_{+}=f^{-1}(-1,1]$ and $M_{0}=f^{-1}\{0\}$.
Remark 2.3.26. We think of a collar-gluing of $M$ as a codimension-1 properly embedded submanifold $M_{0} \subset M$ whose complement is partitioned by connected components: $M \backslash$ $M_{0}=M_{-} \sqcup M_{+}$. Such data is afforded by gluing two manifolds with boundary along a common boundary. The actual data of a collar-gluing specifies that named just above, in addition to a bi-collaring of the common boundary.

Construction 2.2.40 and the results of $\S 2.3 .3$ give the following.

Corollary 2.3.27. Let $\mathcal{F}: \mathcal{M f l}_{\mathrm{n}}^{B} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}$ be a symmetric monoidal functor. Let $M$ be a $B$ framed $n$-manifold. A collar-gluing $M_{-} \bigcup_{M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} M_{+} \cong M$ determines an associative algebra $\mathcal{F}\left(M_{0}\right)$ together with a unital left module structure on the object $\mathcal{F}\left(M_{+}\right)$and a unital right module structure on $\mathcal{F}\left(M_{-}\right)$, as well as a morphism in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\mathcal{F}\left(M_{-}\right) \bigotimes_{\mathcal{F}\left(M_{0}\right)} \mathcal{F}\left(M_{+}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{F}(M)
$$

Proof. The collar-gluing is a continuous map $M \xrightarrow{f}[-1,1]$. Construction 2.2 .40 gives the the first morphism in the composible sequence of morphisms among of $\infty$-operads:

$$
f_{*} \mathcal{F}: \mathcal{D i s k}_{1 /[-1,1]}^{\partial, \text { or }} \xrightarrow{f^{-1}} \mathcal{M f l}_{\mathrm{n} / M} \rightarrow \mathcal{M} \mathrm{fld}_{n}^{B} \xrightarrow{\mathcal{F}} \mathcal{V}
$$

Through Corollary 2.3.24, this morphism between $\infty$-operads is equivalent to an algebra in $\mathcal{V}$ over the operad Assoc $^{\mathrm{RL}}$. Unwinding that equivalence reveals that its underlying associative algebra is $\mathcal{F}\left(M_{0}\right)$, whose underlying object is the value $\mathcal{F}\left(M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}\right)$ and whose associative algebra structure is given by oriented embeddings among the $\mathbb{R}$-coordinate, and its underlying unital modules are the values $\mathcal{F}\left(M_{ \pm}\right)$. Furthermore, the definition of factorization homology as a colimit supplies the canonical morphism in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\mathcal{F}\left(M_{-}\right) \bigotimes_{\mathcal{F}\left(M_{0}\right)} \mathcal{F}\left(M_{+}\right) \quad \underset{\text { Cor }}{ } \underset{2.3 .23}{\simeq} \int_{[-1,1]} f_{*} \mathcal{F} \quad \longrightarrow \quad \mathcal{F}\left(f^{-1}([-1,1])\right)=\mathcal{F}(M)
$$

Definition 2.3.28. A symmetric monoidal functor $\mathcal{F}: \mathcal{M f l}_{\mathrm{n}}^{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$ satisfies $\otimes$-excision if, for each collar-gluing $M_{-} \bigcup_{M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} M_{+} \cong M$ of $B$-framed $n$-manifolds, the canonical morphism in $\mathcal{V}$,

$$
\mathcal{F}\left(M_{-}\right) \bigotimes_{\mathcal{F}\left(M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}\right)} \mathcal{F}\left(M_{+}\right) \underset{(2.3 .4)}{\simeq} \mathcal{F}(M)
$$

is an equivalence. The $\infty$-category of $\mathcal{V}$-valued homology theories for $B$-framed $n$-manifolds is the full $\infty$-subcategory

$$
\mathbf{H}\left(\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fl}_{\mathrm{n}}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right) \subset \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fl}_{\mathrm{n}}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right)
$$

consisting of those symmetric monoidal functors that satisfy $\otimes$-excision.
Remark 2.3.29. We emphasize that a $\mathcal{V}$-valued homology theory depends on the symmetric monoidal structure $\otimes$ of $\mathcal{V}$. For instance, let $\mathbb{k}$ a field and consider the $\infty$-category $\mathrm{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}$ of $\mathbb{k}$-modules. There are two natural symmetric monoidal structures on $\mathrm{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}$ : direct sum $\oplus$; tensor product $\otimes_{\mathbb{k}}$. As established in $\S 2.5 .1$, a homology theory valued in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \oplus\right)$ evaluates on an $n$-manifold $M$ as the $\mathbb{k}$-chains, $\mathrm{C}_{*}(M ; \mathbb{k})$. On the other hand, in $\S 2.5 .2$, specifically Remark 2.5.17, shows that a homology theory valued in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$ typically does not factor through the forgetful functor $\mathcal{M f l}_{\mathrm{n}} \rightarrow$ Spaces to the underlying homotopy type of manifolds.

# 2.3.5 Pushforward 

We prove that factorization homology satisfies $\otimes$-excision in the sense of Definition 2.3.28. We realize this as an instance of a general construction of a pushforward.

The following result is the technical crux of the later results of this article; through this result one can access the values of factorization homology. We state the the result now, and prove it at the end of this section.

Lemma 2.3.30. ([21], [3]) Let $M$ be a $B$-framed $n$-manifold, and let $A$ be a $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}$-algebra in $\mathcal{V}$, for $\mathcal{V}$ a $\otimes$-presentable $\infty$-category. For each collar-gluing $M_{-} \bigcup_{M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} M_{+} \cong M$, the canonical morphism in $\mathcal{V}$,

$$
\int_{M_{-}} A \bigotimes_{A} \int_{M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} A_{A} \int_{(2.3 .4)} A \underset{(2.3 .4)}{\simeq} \int_{M} A
$$

is an equivalence.
Lemma 2.3.30 specializes to to the following special case of $n=1, B \simeq *$, and $M=S^{1}$, which demonstrates the utility of $\otimes$-excision.

Corollary 2.3.31. ([3], [43]) Let $A$ be an associative algebra in a $\otimes$-presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$. There is a canonical equivalence between objects in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\mathrm{HH}_{\bullet}(A) \simeq \int_{S^{1}} A
$$

between the Hochschild homology of $A$ and factorization homology of $A$ over the circle.
Proof. Consider the collar-gluing $\mathbb{R}^{\text {op }} \bigcup_{\mathbb{R} \text { op } \mathbb{R}} \mathbb{R} \cong S^{1}$, where the 'op' superscripts denote the opposite orientation from the standard orientation on Euclidean space, which is the map prom: $S^{1} \rightarrow[-1,1]$ which projects unit vectors in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ to the first coordinate. Lemma 2.3.30, applied to this collar-gluing, states the last of the equivalences in the sequence of equivalences in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\mathrm{HH}_{\bullet}(A) \simeq A \bigotimes_{A \otimes A^{\text {op }}} A \simeq \int_{\mathbb{R}} A \bigotimes_{A} \int_{\mathbb{R}} A \xrightarrow{\simeq} \int_{S^{1}} A .
$$

The middle equivalence is by inspecting values, while the first is definitional.
The next definition makes use of the multi-functor $f^{-1}: \operatorname{Disk}_{k / N}^{0} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{Hd}_{n / M}^{B}}^{B}$ of Construction 2.2.40 associated to each continuous map $M \rightarrow N$ for which each of the restrictions, $M_{\mid N \backslash \partial N} \rightarrow N \backslash \partial N$ and $M_{\mid \partial N} \rightarrow \partial N$, are smooth manifold bundles.

Definition 2.3.32. [3] Let $M$ be an $B$-framed $n$-manifold, and let $N$ be an oriented $k$ manifold, possibly with boundary. For $f: M \rightarrow N$ a map such that the restrictions of $f$ over both the interior of $N$ and the boundary of $N$ are fiber bundles, then the $\infty$-category

$\mathcal{D i s k}_{f}$ is the limit of the diagram among $\infty$-categories
![img-26.jpeg](img-26.jpeg)
where $\operatorname{Ar}\left(\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n / M}^{B}\right)$ is the $\infty$-category of functors $[1] \rightarrow \mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n / M}^{B}$.
Remark 2.3.33. Informally, an object in the $\infty$-category $\mathcal{D i s k}_{f}$ is a triple $(V, U, \beta)$ for which: $U$ is an open subset of $N$ that is diffeomorphic to a disjoint union of Euclidean spaces; $V$ is an open submanifold of $M$ that is diffeomorphic to a disjoint union of Euclidean spaces; and $\beta$ is an isotopy among embeddings of $V$ into $M$ from the given inclusion to one that factors through $f^{-1} U \hookrightarrow M$.

The following result is stated and proved in $\S 3$ of [3]. Its proof amounts to a partition-ofunity argument (specifically Theorem 1.1 [19] or Theorem A.3.1 [43]), applied to unordered configuration spaces.

Lemma 2.3.34. [3] In the situation of Definition 2.3.32, the functor

$$
\mathrm{ev}_{0}: \mathcal{D i s k}_{f} \rightarrow \mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{B}, \quad(U, V, \beta) \mapsto V
$$

is final.
Lemma 2.3.34 applied to the fold map $M \sqcup M \rightarrow M$ gives the following important technical property to the $\infty$-category of disks in $M$.

Corollary 2.3.35 (Corollary 3.22 in [3], Proposition 5.5.2.16 in [43]). For $M$ a $B$-framed $n$-manifold, the $\infty$-overcategory $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n / M}^{B}$ is sifted.

We now apply Lemma 3.32 to factorization homology in the next result. In the statement of this result we use the notation

$$
f_{*} A: \mathcal{D i s k}_{k / N}^{\partial} \xrightarrow{f^{-1}} \mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n / M}^{B} \xrightarrow{\int A} \mathcal{V}
$$

for the composite functor, where $f^{-1}$ is as in Construction 2.2.40.
Proposition 2.3.36 (Proposition 3.23 in [3]). Fix a map of spaces $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$. Let $M$ be a $B$-framed manifold, and let $A$ be a $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$-algebra in a $\otimes$-presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$. Let $f: M \rightarrow N$ be a continuous map to a smooth $k$-manifold with boundary whose restriction over the boundary and interior of $N$ is a smooth fiber bundle. There is a canonical map in $\mathcal{V}$,

$$
\int_{N} f_{*} A:=\operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{D} \operatorname{isk}_{k / N}^{\partial} \xrightarrow{f_{*} A} \mathcal{V}\right) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \int_{M} A
$$

which is an equivalence.

Proof of Lemma 2.3.30. Let $f: M \rightarrow[-1,1]$ be a collar-gluing. There are canonical morphisms in $\mathcal{V}$

$$
\int_{M_{-}} A \bigotimes_{A} \int_{M_{+}} A \quad \underset{\operatorname{Cor} \underset{2.3 .23}{\simeq}}{ } f_{*} A \int_{[-1,1]} f_{*} A \underset{\operatorname{Prop} 2.3 .36}{\simeq} \int_{M} A
$$

Corollary 2.3.23 states that the first arrow is an equivalence. Proposition 2.3.36 states that the second morphism is an equivalence.

# 2.3.6 Homology theories: characterization 

We characterize factorization homology, analogously to Eilenberg-Steenrod's characterization of homology theories for spaces.

Theorem 2.3.37. [3] Let $\mathcal{V}$ be $\otimes$-presentable $\infty$-category. Let $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ be a map from a space. There is a canonical equivalence between $\infty$-categories,

$$
\int: \operatorname{Alg}_{\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V}) \stackrel{\simeq}{\rightleftarrows} \mathbf{H}\left(\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right): \mathrm{ev}_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}
$$

between $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}$-algebras in $\mathcal{V}$ and homology theories for $B$-framed $n$-manifolds with coefficients in $\mathcal{V}$. This equivalence is implemented by the factorization homology functor $\int$ and the functor of evaluation on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$.

Proof. Proposition 2.3.9 identifies factorization homology as the values of symmetric monoidal left Kan extension, thereby implementing the left adjoint in an adjunction

$$
i_{\mathrm{f}}: \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Disk }_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V}) \rightleftarrows \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n}^{B}, \mathcal{V}\right): i^{*}
$$

The unit of this adjunction is an equivalence because $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\text {fld }_{n}^{B}}^{B}$ is fully faithful, and Kan extension along a fully faithful functor restricts as the original functor.

Now let $\mathcal{F}: \mathcal{M}_{\text {fld }_{n}^{B}}^{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$ be a symmetric monoidal functor. The counit of this adjunction evaluates on $\mathcal{F}$ as a morphism $\int A \rightarrow \mathcal{F}$, where $A=\mathcal{F}_{\mid \mathbb{R}^{n}}$ is the $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}$-algebra defined by the values of $\mathcal{F}$ on disjoint unions of $B$-framed Euclidean $n$-spaces. It remains to verify that this counit is an equivalence. To that end, consider the full $\infty$-subcategory $\mathcal{M} \subset \mathcal{M}_{\text {fld }_{n}^{B}}^{B}$ consisting of those objects $M$ for which this counit $\int_{M} A \xrightarrow{\simeq} \mathcal{F}(M)$ is an equivalence. We wish to show the inclusion $\mathcal{M} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\text {fld }_{n}^{B}}^{B}$ is an equivalence.

Both $\int A$ and $\mathcal{F}$ are symmetric monoidal functors. So the full $\infty$-subcategory $\mathcal{M} \subset$ $\mathcal{M}_{\text {fld }_{n}^{B}}^{B}$ is symmetric monoidal. By definition, $\mathcal{M}$ contains $B$-framed Euclidean spaces. We conclude the containment $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B} \subset \mathcal{M}$.

Now, for each $0 \leq k \leq n$, consider the base change $B_{k}$ of $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ along the map $\mathrm{BO}(k) \times \mathrm{BO}(n-k) \xrightarrow{\oplus} \mathrm{BO}(n)$ then projected $B_{k} \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(k) \times \mathrm{BO}(n-k) \xrightarrow{p \text { inj }} \mathrm{BO}(k)$. We will show, by induction on $k$, that $\mathcal{M}$ contains the image of the evident functor $\mathcal{M}_{\text {fld }_{k}^{B_{k}}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\text {fld }_{n}^{B}}^{B}$. The previous paragraph gives that this is the case for $k=0$.

By assumption, $\mathcal{F}$ satisfies $\otimes$-excision, while Lemma 2.3.30 states that $\int A$ satisfies $\otimes$-excision as well. We conclude that $\mathcal{M}$ is closed under collar-gluings. Therefore $\mathcal{M}$

contains the image of any $B_{k}$-framed $k$-manifold that can be witnessed by a finite iteration of collar-gluings from disjoint unions of $B_{k-1}$-framed $(k-1)$-manifolds. By induction on $k$, we are therefore reduced to showing each $B_{k}$-framed $k$-manifold can be witnessed as a finite iteration of collar-gluings involving $B_{k}$-framed $k$-manifolds in the image of $\mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{k-1}^{B_{k-1}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{k}^{B_{k}} \rightarrow \mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{n}^{B}$.

Well, the reigning assumption that manifolds be finitary guarantees, for each $B_{k}$-framed $k$-manifold $M$, the existence of a compactification $\bar{M}$ of the underlying manifold of $M$ as a smooth $k$-manifold with boundary. Choose a proper Morse function $f: \bar{M} \rightarrow[-R, R]$ for which $f^{-1}(\{ \pm R\})=\partial \bar{M}$. Such a Morse function witnesses $M$ as a finite collar-gluing involving $B_{k}$-framed $k$-manifolds of whose underlying manifold is diffeomorphic to $M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}$ for some $(k-1)$-manifold $M_{0}$. Such a $(k-1)$-manifold is therefore isomorphic to one that is equipped with a $B_{k-1}$-framing.

Remark 2.3.38. In [8] a version of Theorem 2.3.37 is established for structured singular manifolds equipped with a stratified tangential structure - this will be surveyed in $\S 2.8$. The result, as it appears there, is slightly more general than Theorem 2.3.37 above: the assumption that $\mathcal{V}$ be $\otimes$-presentable can be weakened to the assumption that the underlying $\infty$-category of $\mathcal{V}$ is presentable yet the symmetric monoidal structure distributes only over geometric realizations and filtered colimits (i.e., over sifted colimits).

Remark 2.3.39. In [3] a version of Theorem 2.3.37 is established for topological manifolds in place of smooth manifolds. In essence, the only feature of the smooth category used in the proof of Theorem 2.3.37 was the existence of open handlebody decompositions, granted by Morse functions. But such open handlebody decompositions are guaranteed in the topological setting, through the results of [48] for $n=3$, of [50] as it concerns the complement of a point for $n=4$ together with smoothing theory [32], of [50] for $n=5$, and of [32] for $n>5$.

For much of this article, we will primarily concern ourselves with homology theories in the sense of Definition 2.3.28. We point out, however, that there are very interesting functors symmetric monoidal functors $\mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$ that are not $\otimes$-excisive. For instance, as detailed in [12], for $X$ a derived (commutative) stack over a fixed field $\mathbb{k}$, cotensoring to $X$ followed by taking ring of functions defines a symmetric monoidal functor:

$$
\mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{n} \xrightarrow{M \mapsto X^{M}} \operatorname{Stacks}(\mathbb{k}) \xrightarrow{\mathcal{O}} \operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}
$$

As the case $n=1$, the value of this functor on the circle is the Hochschild homology of $X$ : $\mathcal{O}\left(X^{S^{1}}\right) \simeq \mathrm{HH}_{\bullet}(X)$ (compare with Corollary 2.3.31). If $X$ is not affine, the above functor will generically fail to be $\otimes$-excisive. Now, the cotensor $X^{M}$ only depends on the underlying homotopy type of $M$, as we shall see in Proposition 2.5.7. This is a feature of $X$ being a derived commutative stack. Should $X$ be a derived stack over $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}$-algebras as in [20], there is a refined version of the cotensor $X^{M}$ that is sensitive to the manifold structure of $M$. Derived stacks over $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}$-algebras arise as the outcome of deformation quantization of a shifted symplectic derived (commutative) stacks, such as in Rozansky-Witten theory.

# 2.4 Nonabelian Poincaré duality 

Applying Theorem 2.3.37, we offer a slightly different perspective, and proof, of the nonabelian Poincaré duality of Salvatore [51], Segal [56], and Lurie [43], which calculates factorization homology of iterated loop spaces as compactly-supported mapping spaces.

Definition 2.4.1. For a space $B$, Spaces $_{B}:=\left(\right.$ Spaces $\left._{/ B}\right)^{B /}$ is the $\infty$-category of retractive spaces over $B$, i.e., spaces over $B$ equipped with a section. The $\infty$-category Spaces $_{B}^{>n}$ is the full $\infty$-subcategory of Spaces $_{B}$ consisting of those $X \rightleftarrows B$ for which the retraction is $n$-connective, that is, the homomorphism $\pi_{q} X \rightarrow \pi_{q} B$ is an isomorphism for $q<n$ with any choice of base-point of $B$.

Remark 2.4.2. Equivalently, an object $X \in$ Spaces $_{B}^{>n}$ may be thought of as a fibration $X \rightarrow B$ equipped with a section for which, for each $b \in B$, the fiber $X_{b}$ is $n$-connective.

Definition 2.4.3. Fix $X \in$ Spaces $_{B}$. Let $M$ be a manifold, equipped with a map $M \rightarrow B$. The space of compactly supported sections of $X$ over $M$ is the colimit in the $\infty$-category Spaces:

$$
\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(M, X):=\underset{K \stackrel{\subset}{\operatorname{compact}} \operatorname{Map}_{/ B}}{\operatorname{colim}}\left((M \backslash K \rightarrow M),(B \rightarrow X)\right)
$$

where the colimit is indexed by the filtered poset of compact codimension-0 submanifold with boundary in $M$, and where the space indexed by a compact subset $K \subset M$ is the pullback:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Map}_{/ B}((M \backslash K \rightarrow M),(B \rightarrow X)) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{/ B}(M, X) \\
& * \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{/ B}(M \backslash K, B) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{/ B}(M \backslash K, X) .
\end{aligned}
$$

For $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ a map between spaces, note that $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(-, X)$ defines a covariant functor $\mathcal{M} \mathrm{fld}_{n}^{B} \rightarrow$ Spaces. By inspection, this functor carries finite disjoint unions to finite products of spaces, which is to say that $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(-, X)$ is symmetric monoidal with respect to the Cartesian monoidal structure on the $\infty$-category Spaces of spaces. In particular, the restriction

$$
\Omega_{B}^{n} X: \mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n}^{B} \xrightarrow{\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(-, X)} \text { Spaces }
$$

is a symmetric monoidal functor, i.e., a $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$-algebra in Spaces. Each point $* \xrightarrow{\{b\}} B$ determines a $B$-framed $n$-dimensional vector space $(V, b)$, which can be regarded as an object $(V, b) \in \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$. The value of the above functor $\Omega_{B}^{n} X$ on this object is equivalent to the $n$-fold loop space $\Omega^{n} X_{b}$ of the fiber $X_{b}$ of the map $X \rightarrow B$ over $b \in B$.

We introduce the following terminology in order to state Theorem 2.4.5. Consider the base point $* \xrightarrow{\left\{\mathbb{R}^{n}\right\}} \mathrm{BO}(n)$. Each lift of this point $* \xrightarrow{\{b\}} B$, which is a point in the fiber fiber $(B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n))$, canonically determines a symmetric monoidal functor $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$. Thereafter, each symmetric monoidal functor $A: \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B} \rightarrow$ Spaces restricts as an associative

monoid

$$
\pi_{0}(A, b): \mathcal{D i s k}_{1}^{\mathrm{fr}} \xrightarrow{\mathbb{R}^{n-1} \times-} \mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B} \xrightarrow{A} \text { Spaces } \xrightarrow{\pi_{0}} \text { Set. }
$$

We say $A$ is group-like if, for each point $b \in \operatorname{fiber}(B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n))$, this monoid $\pi_{0}(A, b)$ is a group.

Example 2.4.4. In the case $B \simeq *$, a $B$-framing is a framing in the standard sense and $\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}=\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$. A symmetric monoidal functor $A: \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B} \rightarrow$ Spaces is then the data of an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra, and this $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra is group-like in the sense of [45] if and only if $A$ is group-like in the the above sense.

Theorem 2.4.5. [3] Restricting the functor $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}: \operatorname{Spaces}_{B} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\mathcal{M f l d}_{n}^{B}\right.$, Spaces) defines a fully-faithful inclusion

$$
\text { Spaces }_{B}^{>n} \hookrightarrow \mathbf{H}\left(\mathcal{M} \mathrm{fld}_{n}^{B}\right. \text {, Spaces) }
$$

of n-connective retractive spaces over $B$ into homology theories. The essential image consists of those $\mathcal{F}$ for which the restriction $\left.\mathcal{F}_{\text {| Disk }}{ }_{n}^{B}\right)$ is group-like.

Remark 2.4.6. The fully faithfulness of the above functor is given by Theorem 5.1.3.6 of [43]. This is a parametrized form of May's theorem from [45], identifying $n$-connective spaces as $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$-algebras.

The following result is the technical crux in the proof of Theorem 2.4.5; it asserts that, for each $n$-connective retractive space $X \rightleftarrows B$, the assignment of compactly supported sections $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(-, X)$ is $\otimes$-excisive.

Lemma 2.4.7. [3] Let $X \in$ Spaces $_{B}^{>n}$ be an n-connective retractive space over B. Let $M$ be $B$-framed $n$-manifold. For $M^{\prime} \bigcup_{M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} M^{\prime \prime} \cong M$ a collar-gluing, the canonical map between spaces,

$$
\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M^{\prime}, X\right) \times_{\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}, X\right)} \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M^{\prime \prime}, X\right) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(M, X)
$$

from the quotient of the product $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M^{\prime}, X\right) \times \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M^{\prime \prime}, X\right)$ by the diagonal action of $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M_{0} \times\right.$ $\mathbb{R}, X)$, is an equivalence.

Proof given in [3]. Since $M_{0} \hookrightarrow M$ is a proper embedding, a compactly supported section over $M$ can be restricted to obtain a compactly-supported section over $M_{0}$, as well as over $M \backslash M^{\prime}$ and over $M \backslash M^{\prime \prime}$. Namely, there is a diagram among spaces of compactly-supported sections
![img-27.jpeg](img-27.jpeg)

By inspection, the bottom horizontal sequence is a fiber sequence, as is the right vertical sequence, as is the diagonal sequence. Also, the inner square is pullback because

$M^{\prime} \bigcup_{M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} M^{\prime \prime} \cong M$ is a pushout. Because $M_{0} \subset M$ is equipped with a regular neighborhood, these fiber sequences are in fact Serre fibration sequences, and so the inner square is a weak homotopy pullback square. In particular, there is a right homotopy coherent action of $\Omega \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M_{0}, X\right)$ on $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M^{\prime}, X\right)$, a left homotopy coherent action of $\Omega \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M_{0}, X\right)$ on $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M^{\prime \prime}, X\right)$, and a continuous map of topological spaces

$$
\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M^{\prime}, X\right) \underset{\Omega \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M_{0}, X\right)}{\times} \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M^{\prime \prime}, X\right) \longrightarrow \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(M, X)
$$

from the balanced homotopy coinvariants. Because $X \rightarrow B$ is $n$-connective and $M_{0}$ is $(n-1)$-dimensional, the base $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M_{0}, X\right)$ is connected. It follows that the map (2.4.2) is in fact a weak homotopy equivalence. The assertion follows after the canonical identification $\Omega \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M_{0}, X\right) \cong \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}\left(M_{0} \times \mathbb{R}, X\right)$ as group-like $\mathcal{E}_{1}$-spaces.

Theorem 2.3.37 implies the nonabelian Poincaré duality theorem of Salvatore [51], Segal [56], and Lurie [43]. First, recall from (2.4.1) the $\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}$-algebra $\Omega_{B}^{n} X$ determined by a retractive space $X \rightleftarrows B$.

Corollary 2.4.8 (Nonabelian Poincaré duality [3]). Let $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ be a map from a space. Let $X \rightleftarrows B$ be an n-connective retractive space over $B$. For each $B$-framed $n$-manifold $M$, there is a canonical equivalence

$$
\int_{M} \Omega_{B}^{n} X \xrightarrow{\simeq} \Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}(M, X)
$$

from the factorization homology over $M$ of $\Omega_{B}^{n} X$ to the space of compactly-supported sections of $X$ over $M$.

We now explain how this result specializes to familiar Poincaré duality between homology and compactly-supported cohomology. Let $A$ be an abelian group. Consider the product space $X \simeq \mathrm{BO}(n) \times K(A, n)$. Observe that the values of the $n$-disk algebra

$$
\Omega_{\mathrm{BO}(n)}^{n} X: \mathcal{D i s k}_{n} \longrightarrow \text { Spaces, } \quad \bigsqcup_{0 \leq i \leq k} V_{i} \mapsto \prod_{1 \leq i \leq k} \operatorname{Map}_{*}\left(V_{i}^{+}, K(A, n)\right) \underset{\text { noncanonical }}{\simeq} A^{\times k}
$$

are non-canonically identified as products of $A$. Furthermore, the restriction of this $n$-disk algebra along the standard symmetric monoidal functor $\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}} \rightarrow \mathcal{D i s k}_{n}$, which selects Euclidean spaces, is the $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra forgotten from the commutative algebra structure on $A$. The $\mathrm{O}(n)$-action on $A$ is that inherited from the infinite-loop structure of the EilenbergMac Lane spectrum $\mathrm{H} A$ through the $J$-homomorphism. Let $M$ be an $n$-manifold. An $A$ orientation of $M$ defines a natural transformation making the diagram of $\infty$-categories commute:
![img-28.jpeg](img-28.jpeg)
here, the bottom horizontal functor is the symmetric monoidal functor from finite sets with disjoint union, which is the free symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category generated by a point,

determined by the commutative algebra $A$ in the Cartesian symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category Spaces. So choose an $A$-orientation of $M$ (supposing one exists). Corollary 2.4.8 then yields an equivalence between spaces

$$
\int_{M} A_{\langle\overline{2} . \overline{4} .3\rangle} \int_{M} \Omega_{\mathrm{BO}(n)}^{n} X_{\text {Cor }} \underset{\text { 2.4.8 }}{\simeq} \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{c}}(M, K(A, r))
$$

Note that each space in this display is equipped with a base point, and the maps in this display are canonically based maps. As the $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra $A$ is forgotten from a commutative algebra, we recognize $\int_{M} A$ as the free $A$-module in the $\infty$-category Spaces generated by the underlying space of $M$. Therefore, applying homotopy groups to (2.4.4) gives an isomorphism between graded abelian groups,

$$
\overline{\mathrm{H}}_{*}(M ; A) \cong \pi_{*} \int_{M} A \cong \pi_{*} \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{c}}(M, K(A, n)) \cong \overline{\mathrm{H}}_{\mathrm{c}}^{n-*}(M ; A)
$$

from reduced homology to reduced cohomology.
Remark 2.4.9. The factorization homology $\int_{M} \Omega_{B}^{n} X$ is built from configuration spaces of disks in $M$ with labels defined by $X \rightarrow B$, and the preceding result thereby has roots in the configuration space models of mapping spaces dating to the work of Segal, May, McDuff and others in the 1970s; see [53], [45], [46], and [14]. However, the classical configuration-space-with-labels, as described in [14], models a mapping space with target the $n$-fold suspension of $X$, rather than into $X$ itself. Factorization homology thus more closely generalizes the configuration spaces with summable or amalgamated labels of Salvatore [51] and Segal [56].

Proof of Theorem 2.4.5. Corollary 2.4.8 identifies the functor

$$
\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}: \text { Spaces }_{B}^{\geq n} \rightarrow \mathbf{H}\left(\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n}^{B}, \text { Spaces }\right)
$$

as the composition $\Gamma_{\mathrm{c}}:$ Spaces $_{B}^{\geq n} \xrightarrow{\Omega_{B}^{n}} \operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B} \xrightarrow{\int} \mathbf{H}\left(\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n}^{B}\right.$, Spaces). Theorem 2.3.37 gives that $\int$ is fully faithful, so it remains to argue that $\Omega_{B}^{n}$ is fully faithful with essential image the group-like $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{B}$-algebras in spaces. This is immediate because, for instance, Spaces ${ }_{/ B}$ is an $\infty$-topos (Theorem 5.1.3.6 of [43]).

# 2.5 Calculations 

In $\S 2.4$, we identified values of factorization homology of $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}$-algebras in spaces, with its Cartesian monoidal structure, as twisted compactly supported mapping spaces. Here we identify more values of factorization homology of $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}$-algebras in chain complexes, and spectra, notably with monoidal structure given by tensor product - these cases are closest to the physical motivation given in the introduction.

In this section, we fix a map $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ from a space. Two cases of notable interest are $* \xrightarrow{[\mathbb{R}^{n}]} \mathrm{BO}(n)$ and $\mathrm{BO}(n) \xrightarrow{\text { id }} \mathrm{BO}(n)$.

# 2.5.1 Factorization homology for direct sum 

We now show that in the simple case of $\operatorname{Dis}_{n}$-algebras in chain complexes with direct sum, factorization homology recovers ordinary homology.

Fix a presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$, such as the $\infty$-category Spectra of spectra, or the $\infty$ category $\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}$ of chain complexes over a fixed commutative ring $\mathbb{k}$. Coproduct, which in the case that $\mathcal{V}$ is stable is direct sum, endows $\mathcal{V}$ with the coCartesian symmetric monoidal structure: $(\mathcal{V}, \mathrm{II})$. Consider the commutative diagram among $\infty$-categories, in which each functor is implemented by the evident restriction:
![img-29.jpeg](img-29.jpeg)

In this case of a coCartesian symmetric monoidal structure, the downward functor is an equivalence, as indicated. In other words, a $\operatorname{Dis}_{n}{ }^{B}$-algebra in $(\mathcal{V}, \mathrm{II})$ is precisely a functor $B \rightarrow \mathcal{V} .{ }^{9}$

Example 2.5.1. Let $G$ be a topological group equipped with a continuous representation $G \xrightarrow{\rho} \mathrm{GL}(n) \simeq \mathrm{O}(n)$. Then a $\operatorname{Dis}_{n}{ }^{\mathrm{B} G}$-algebra in $(\mathcal{V}, \mathrm{II})$ is a $G$-module $\mathrm{B} G \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$. In the case that $G=e$ is the trivial group, such a $G$-module is simply an object in $\mathcal{V}$.

Through Proposition 2.3.9, which identifies factorization homology as a left adjoint to the top horizontal functor in the preceding diagram, we conclude that factorization is identified as a left adjoint to the downleftward functor, which is restriction along the fully faithful inclusion $B \rightarrow \mathcal{M f l d}_{n}^{B}$ of $B$-framed Euclidean spaces. Left adjoints to restriction functors evaluate as left Kan extensions. The standard formula for left Kan extensions therefore identifies, for each $B$-framed $n$-manifold $M=(M, \varphi)$ and each $\operatorname{Dis}_{n}{ }^{B}$-algebra $B \xrightarrow{V} \mathcal{V}$, the value of factorization homology as the colimit in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\int_{M} V \simeq \operatorname{colim}\left(B_{/ M} \rightarrow B \xrightarrow{V} \mathcal{V}\right)
$$

Corollary 2.2.31 identifies the functor $B_{/ M} \rightarrow B$ appearing in this expression as the given functor $M \xrightarrow{\varphi} B$ from the underlying $\infty$-groupoid, or homotopy type, of $M$ :

$$
\int_{M} V \simeq \operatorname{colim}\left(M \xrightarrow{\varphi} B \xrightarrow{V} \mathcal{V}\right)
$$

Remark 2.5.2. Note that the value of factorization homology in $(\mathcal{V}, \mathrm{II})$ over a $B$-framed manifold $M \xrightarrow{\varphi} B$ only depends on the underlying space of $M$ equipped with its given map to $B$.

Example 2.5.3. Let $G$ be a topological group equipped with a continuous representation $G \xrightarrow{\rho} \mathrm{GL}(n) \simeq \mathrm{O}(n)$. Let $V$ be a $G$-module in $\mathcal{V}$. Let $M$ be an $n$-manifold. A $\mathrm{B} G$-framing

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{9}$ Here and always, the space $B$ is taken as an $\infty$-groupoid and thereafter as an $\infty$-category. In this way, we make sense of a functor $B \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$, which is simply a $B$-indexed local system of objects in $\mathcal{V}$.

on $M$ is a principal $G$-bundle $P \rightarrow M$ equipped with a $\rho$-equivariant map $P \rightarrow \operatorname{Fr}(M)$ over $M$ to the frame-bundle of $M$. Given such a $\mathrm{B} G$-framing on $M$, we identify the factorization homology

$$
\int_{M} V \simeq P \underset{G}{\otimes} V
$$

as the diagonal $G$-quotient of the tensor of $V \in \mathcal{V}$ with the space $P$. In particular, in the case that $G \xrightarrow{\simeq} \mathrm{O}(n)$, the factorization homology is the diagonal $\mathrm{O}(n)$-quotient with the frame-bundle of $M$ tensored with the $\mathrm{O}(n)$-module $V$ in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\int_{M} V \simeq \operatorname{Fr}(M) \underset{\mathrm{O}(n)}{\otimes} V
$$

In the case that $G=e$ is a trivial group, then $V \in \mathcal{V}$ is simply an object and the principal bundle $P \xrightarrow{\simeq} M$ is identical to $M$, so that factorization homology

$$
\int_{M} V \simeq M \otimes V
$$

is simply the tensor of the object $V \in \mathcal{V}$ with the underlying space of $M$.
Example 2.5.4. Suppose $B=*$, so that a $B$-framing on an $n$-manifold is exactly a framing. Suppose $\mathcal{V}=\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}$ is the $\infty$-category of chain complexes over a fixed commutative ring k. As discussed above, a $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \oplus\right)$ is simply a chain complex, $V \in \operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}$. Furthermore, the factorization homology

$$
\int_{M} V \simeq M \otimes V \simeq \mathrm{C}_{*}(M ; V) \in \operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}
$$

is the singular chain complex of $M$ with coefficients in $V$.
Example 2.5.5. Again suppose $B=*$, so that a $B$-framing on an $n$-manifold is exactly a framing. Suppose $\mathcal{V}=$ Spectra is the $\infty$-category of spectra. As discussed above, an $\mathcal{E}_{n^{-}}$ algebra in (Spectra, $\oplus$ ) is simply a spectrum $V \in$ Spectra. Furthermore, the factorization homology

$$
\int_{M} V \simeq M \otimes V \simeq \Sigma_{+}^{\infty} M \wedge V \in \text { Spectra }
$$

is the smash product of $V$ with the suspension spectrum of $M$.
Remark 2.5.6. Taking products with Euclidean spaces defines a sequence of symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories:

$$
\mathcal{M f l d}_{0}^{\mathrm{fr}} \longrightarrow \mathcal{M} \mathrm{fld}_{1}^{\mathrm{fr}} \longrightarrow \cdots \longrightarrow \mathcal{M} \mathrm{fld}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}} \longrightarrow \cdots
$$

Forgetting to underlying spaces defines, for each $k$, a symmetric monoidal functor $\mathcal{M f l d}_{k}^{\mathrm{fr}} \rightarrow$ Spaces $^{\text {fin }}$ to the $\infty$-category of finite spaces (i.e., finite CW complexes) and coproduct among them. Via the canonical equivalence between underlying spaces $M \simeq M \times \mathbb{R}$ for each framed manifold $M$, these forgetful functors assemble as a symmetric monoidal functor from the colimit

$$
\operatorname{colim}_{k \geq 0} \mathcal{M} \mathrm{fld}_{k}^{\mathrm{fr}} \longrightarrow \text { Spaces }^{\text {fin }}
$$

We argue that this symmetric monoidal functor is an equivalence.

- Essentially surjective. Each finite space is equivalent to the underlying space of the geometric realization of a finite simplicial complex. Such a geometric realization can be piecewise-linearly embedded into Euclidean space. A regular open neighborhood of such an embedding is a finitary smooth manifold that is homotopy equivalent to this geometric realization. In this way we conclude that the functor (2.5.1) is essentially surjective.
- Fully faithful. Let $M$ and $N$ be $n$-manifolds. It follows from Whitney's embedding theorem that the map between spaces

$$
\underset{k \geq 0}{\operatorname{colim}} \mathrm{Emb}^{\mathrm{fr}}\left(M \times \mathbb{R}^{k-n}, N \times \mathbb{R}^{k-n}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{\text {Spaces }}(M, N)
$$

is a weak homotopy equivalence.
Through the equivalence (2.5.1), Theorem 2.3.37 applied to $\mathcal{V}=\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \oplus\right)$ recovers to the formulation of the Eilenberg-Steenrod axioms given in the introduction. If one sets $\mathcal{V}$ to be the opposite $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}^{\text {op }}, \oplus\right)$, then one likewise recovers the Eilenberg-Steenrod axioms for cohomology.

# 2.5.2 Factorization homology with coefficients in commutative algebras 

Here, we examine factorization homology of commutative algebras, otherwise known as $\mathcal{E}_{\infty}$-algebras.

Fix a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$ that is $\otimes$-presentable.
There is a canonical identification of the symmetric monoidal envelope of the commutative $\infty$-operad

$$
\operatorname{Env}(\text { Comm }) \simeq \text { Fin }=(\text { Fin, } \amalg)
$$

with the coCartesian symmetric monoidal category of finite sets. ${ }^{10}$ This is to say that restriction along the commutative algebra in Fin whose underlying object is $* \in$ Fin defines an equivalence between $\infty$-categories:

$$
\operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}(\text { Fin, } \mathcal{V}) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V})
$$

So restriction along the symmetric monoidal functor given by taking connected components

$$
[-]: \mathcal{D} i s k_{n}^{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{D} i s k_{n} \xrightarrow{[-]} \text { Fin }
$$

defines a forgetful functor

$$
\text { fgt: } \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V}) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Disk }_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V})
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{10}$ See the discussion just above Lemma 2.3.20 for a quick description of a symmetric monoidal envelope.

Via Corollary 3.2.3.3 of [43], the assumed $\otimes$-presentability of $\mathcal{V}$ implies the $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V})$ is presentable. In particular, it is tensored over the $\infty$-category of spaces:

$$
\text { Spaces } \times \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V}) \xrightarrow{\otimes} \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V}), \quad(X, A) \mapsto \operatorname{colim}\left(X \xrightarrow{!} * \xrightarrow{\{A\}} \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V})\right)
$$

Proposition 2.5.7. The following diagram among $\infty$-categories canonically commutes:
![img-30.jpeg](img-30.jpeg)

In particular, for each $B$-framed $n$-manifold $M$, and each commutative algebra $A$, there is a canonical equivalence

$$
\int_{M} A \simeq M \otimes A
$$

between the factorization homology of $A$ over $M$ and the tensor of the commutative algebra $A$ with the underlying space of $M$.

Proof. Observe the commutative diagram among symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories:
![img-31.jpeg](img-31.jpeg)
in which the bottom two are endowed with their coCartesian symmetric monoidal structures. Restriction defines the commutative diagram among $\infty$-categories of symmetric monoidal functors
![img-32.jpeg](img-32.jpeg)

It follows from Proposition 3.2.4.7 of [43] that the forgetful functor $\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V}) \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$ canonically lifts as a symmetric monoidal functor $\left(\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V}), \mathrm{II}\right) \rightarrow(\mathcal{V}, \otimes)$ from the coCartesian symmetric monoidal structure on $\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V})$. Postcomposing by this symmetric monoidal functor determines the commutative diagram among $\infty$-categories:
![img-33.jpeg](img-33.jpeg)

It follows from $\S 2.5 .1$ that the right downward functor in this diagram is an equivalence. From the same proposition cited in [43] above, the right downward functor preserves colimits.

From $\S 2.5 .1$, we conclude that the left adjoint to the bottom horizontal functor in (2.5.2) is the composite functor

$$
\mathrm{Alg}_{\mathrm{Com}}(\mathcal{V}) \xrightarrow{A \mapsto(X \mapsto X \otimes A)} \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}\left(\text { Spaces, } \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathrm{Com}}(\mathcal{V})\right) \xrightarrow{\text { forget }} \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}(\text { Spaces, } \mathcal{V})
$$

of first tensoring followed by the forgetful functor. Now, taking left adjoints of the horizontal functors results in a lax-commutative diagram among $\infty$-categories:
![img-34.jpeg](img-34.jpeg)

The proof is complete once we show the 2-cell in this diagram is invertible. This 2-cell is invertible if and only if, for each commutative algebra $A \in \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V})$ and each $B$-framed $n$-manifold $M$, the resulting morphism in $\mathcal{V}$,

$$
\int_{M} A \longrightarrow M \otimes A
$$

is an equivalence. (Here, and in what follows, we are not giving notation to the functor fgt.) Because the underlying space of each $B$-framed Euclidean $n$-dimensional space is contractible, this morphism (2.5.4) is an equivalence in such cases. By construction, the tensoring functor Spaces $\xrightarrow{X \mapsto X \otimes A} \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V})$ preserves colimits. Because collar-gluings among $B$-framed $n$-manifolds forget as pushouts among their underlying spaces, it follows that the functor $\mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}_{n}^{B} \xrightarrow{M \mapsto M \otimes A} \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V}) \xrightarrow{\text { forget }} \mathcal{V}$ is $\otimes$-excisive, and in particular it is symmetric monoidal. It follows from Theorem 2.3.37 that the morphism (2.5.4) is an equivalence, as desired.

Proposition 2.5.7, together with the universal property of tensoring over spaces, yields the following.

Corollary 2.5.8. Let $A \in \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V})$ be a commutative algebra in a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category that is $\otimes$-presentable. Let $M$ be a $B$-framed $n$-manifold. There is a canonical commutative algebra structure on the factorization homology $\int_{M} A$. Furthermore, as a commutative algebra, it corepresents the copresheaf

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{\text {Com }}\left(\int_{M} A,-\right): \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V}) \longrightarrow \text { Spaces, } \quad C \mapsto \operatorname{Map}_{\text {Com }}(A, C)^{M}
$$

whose value on a commutative algebra is the the cotensor, or mapping space, of $M$ to the space of morphisms from $A$ to $C$.

Proposition 2.5.7 and Corollary 2.5.8, together with the fact that left adjoints compose, yields the following.

Corollary 2.5.9. In the situation of Corollary 2.5.8, for $V \in \mathcal{V}$ an object with $\operatorname{Sym}(V) \in$ $\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Com }}(\mathcal{V})$ the free commutative algebra on $V$, there is a canonical equivalence between commutative algebras in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\int_{M} \operatorname{Sym}(V) \simeq \operatorname{Sym}(M \otimes V)
$$

Example 2.5.10. In the case that $\mathcal{V}=\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$, Corollary 2.5.9 specializes as an equivalence

$$
\int_{M} \operatorname{Sym}(V) \simeq \operatorname{Sym}\left(\mathrm{C}_{*}(M ; V)\right)
$$

the graded-commutative algebra on the chain complex of singular chains on the underlying space of $M$ with coefficients in $V$.

The next result, proved as Proposition 5.3 in [3], further identifies factorization homology of commutative algebras, in a suitably infinitesimal case: the cohomology of suitably nilpotent spaces. Its proof amounts to using Proposition 2.5.7, then arguing via an EilenbergMoore spectral sequence.
Proposition 2.5.11. [3] Let $M$ be an n-manifold. Let $X$ be a nilpotent space whose first $n$ homotopy groups are finite, $\left|\pi_{i} X\right|<\infty$ for $i \leq n$, and let $\mathbb{k}$ be a commutative ring. There is a natural equivalence of $\mathbb{k}$-modules

$$
\int_{M} \mathrm{C}^{*}(X ; \mathbb{k}) \simeq \mathrm{C}^{*}\left(X^{M} ; \mathbb{k}\right)
$$

between the factorization homology of $M$ with coefficient in the $\mathbb{k}$-cohomology of $X$ and the $\mathbb{k}$-cohomology of the space of maps to $X$ from the underlying space of $M$.
Remark 2.5.12. In the work [25], the authors lay out a similar approach, by way of Hochschild homology-type invariants, to the study of the cohomology of mapping spaces.

# 2.5.3 Factorization homology from Lie algebras 

We now identify factorization homology of $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}$-algebras coming from Lie algebras. The results that follow are closely analogous to those above concerning the factorization homology of $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}$-algebras coming from based topological spaces. For simplicity, we assume our Lie algebras are defined over a fixed field $\mathbb{k}$ of characteristic zero.

As we proceed, we use that the $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Lie }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$ of Lie algebras over $\mathbb{k}$ are cotensored over spaces:
$\operatorname{Spaces}^{\text {op }} \times \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Lie }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right) \xrightarrow{(X, \mathfrak{g}) \mapsto \mathfrak{g}^{X}} \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Lie }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right),(X, \mathfrak{g}) \mapsto \lim \left(X \xrightarrow{\mathfrak{l}} * \xrightarrow{\{\mathfrak{g}\}} \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Lie }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)\right)$.
This limit indeed exists because, for instance, the $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Lie }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$ admits products, cofiltered limits, and totalizations. More explicitly, $\mathfrak{g}^{X} \simeq \mathrm{C}^{*}(X ; \mathfrak{g})=\operatorname{Hom}_{\mathbb{k}}\left(\mathrm{C}_{*}(X ; \mathbb{k}), \mathfrak{g}\right)$, with a canonically inherited Lie algebra structure. For $M$ an $n$-manifold, we define the kernel Lie algebra,
![img-35.jpeg](img-35.jpeg)

where $M^{+}$is the 1-point compactification of $M$. More explicitly, $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{c}}(M, \mathfrak{g}) \simeq \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{e}}^{*}(M ; \mathfrak{g})$, the compactly-supported cochains on $M$ with coefficients in $\mathfrak{g}$. In the case that $M=\mathbb{R}^{n}$, we notate $\Omega^{n} \mathfrak{g}:=\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{c}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, \mathfrak{g}\right)$, and observe that this Lie algebra assembles as a $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}$-algebra,

$$
\Omega^{n} \mathfrak{g}: \operatorname{Disk}_{n} \longrightarrow\left(\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}\right), \times\right)
$$

to the Cartesian symmetric monoidal structure on Lie algebras. Postcomposing this symmetric monoidal functor by that of Lie algebra chains, which indeed carries finite products of Lie algebras to finite tensor products (over $\mathbb{k}$ ) of $\mathbb{k}$-modules, results in a composite symmetric monoidal functor

$$
\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{e}}^{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\Omega^{n} \mathfrak{g}\right): \operatorname{Disk}_{n} \xrightarrow{\Omega^{n} \mathfrak{g}}\left(\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}\right), \times\right) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{e}}^{\mathrm{Lie}}}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \underset{\mathrm{k}}{\otimes}\right)
$$

The next identification is also discussed in [27] and [17], and appears in the present form in [3]. Its proof amounts to applying Lie algebra chains, which is a geometric realizationpreserving functor, to the Poincaré/Koszul duality equivalence $\int_{M} \Omega^{n} \mathfrak{g} \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{c}}(M, \mathfrak{g})$ of [4].

Proposition 2.5.13. Let $M$ be an n-manifold. Let $\mathfrak{g}$ be a Lie algebra over $\mathbb{k}$. There is a canonical identification between $\mathbb{k}$-modules,

$$
\int_{M} \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{e}}^{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\Omega^{n} \mathfrak{g}\right) \simeq \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{e}}^{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{c}}(M, \mathfrak{g})\right)
$$

Remark 2.5.14. Let $\mathfrak{g}$ be a Lie algebra over $\mathbb{k}$. The $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}$-algebra $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{e}}^{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\Omega^{n} \mathfrak{g}\right)$ appearing above has an interesting interpretation, established by Knudsen [35]. There is a forgetful functor from $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebras to Lie algebras,

$$
\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}\right) \longleftarrow \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}\right): \text { fgt. }
$$

For $n=1$, there is the standard forgetful functor; for $n>1$, Kontsevich's formality result (see [37] for a sketched outline, and [39] for a more detailed account) identifies the operad $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{e}}\left(\mathcal{E}_{n} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ in $\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}$ is equivalent to the Poisson operad $\mathrm{P}_{n}$, to which the Lie operad in $\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{R}}$ maps. ${ }^{11}$ (See [16] for an account at the level of homology.) The adjoint functor theorem (Corollary 5.5.2.9 of [42]) applies to this forgetful functor, thereby offering a left adjoint:

$$
\mathrm{U}_{n}: \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}\right) \rightleftarrows \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}\right): \text { fgt. }
$$

In the case $n=1$, this left adjoint $\mathrm{U}_{1}$ agrees with the familiar universal enveloping algebra functor. In general, there is an identification between $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebras,

$$
\mathrm{U}_{n} \mathfrak{g} \simeq \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{e}}^{\mathrm{Lie}}\left(\Omega^{n} \mathfrak{g}\right)
$$

proved by Knudsen [35]. Through this identification, Proposition 2.5.13 can be reformulated as an equivalence of chain complexes over $\mathbb{k}$,
