# 2.5.4 Factorization homology of free $\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}$-algebras 

We now identify the factorization homology of free $\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}$-algebras. The results here are extracted from $\S 5.2$ of [3], $\S 4.3$ of [8], and $\S 2.4$ of [5].

For this section, we fix a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$ that is $\otimes$-presentable. Also, for simplicity restrict our attention to the case the space $B$ is connected, and equipped with a base point. This condition, and structure, on $B$ identify the tangential structure

$$
(B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n))=\left(\mathrm{B} G \xrightarrow{\mathrm{~B} \rho} \mathrm{BO}(n)\right)
$$

as the classifying space of a morphism $\rho: G \rightarrow \mathrm{O}(n)$ between group-objects in Spaces.
For each $B$-framed $n$-manifold $M$, and for each finite cardinality $i \geq 0$, consider the configuration space

$$
\operatorname{Conf}_{i}(M):=\left\{\{1, \ldots, i\} \xrightarrow{c} M \mid c \text { is injective }\right\} \subset M^{\times i}
$$

which is an open subspace of the $i$-fold product of $M$. As an open subspace, it inherits the structure of a smooth $n i$-manifold. The $\mathrm{B} G$-framing on $M$ then determines a $\mathrm{B}\left(\Sigma_{i} \wr G\right)$ framing on $\operatorname{Conf}_{i}(M)$ :
![img-36.jpeg](img-36.jpeg)

This lift of the tangent classifier of $\operatorname{Conf}_{i}(M)$ selects a principal $\Sigma_{i} \wr G$-bundle

$$
\operatorname{Conf}_{i}^{G}(M) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Conf}_{i}(M)
$$

which we refer to as a $G$-framed configuration space. In the extremal case of $G \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathrm{O}(n)$, then we have $\operatorname{Conf}_{i}^{G}(M)=\operatorname{Conf}_{i}(M)$. In the extremal case that $G=e$ is the trivial group then $\operatorname{Conf}_{i}^{G}(M)=\operatorname{Conf}_{i}^{\mathrm{fr}}(M)$ is the framed configuration space, a point in which is an injection $c:\{1, \ldots, i\} \hookrightarrow M$ together with a choice of the basis for each tangent space $T_{c(j)} M$.

The free $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$-algebra functor is the left adjoint

$$
\operatorname{Free}_{n}^{B}: \operatorname{Mod}_{G}(\mathcal{V}):=\operatorname{Fun}(B, \mathcal{V}) \rightleftarrows \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V})
$$

to the restriction along the fully faithful inclusion $B \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{B}$ of the $B$-framed Euclidean spaces.

The next result identifies the factorization homology of free $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{\mathrm{B} G}$-algebras in terms of $G$-framed configuration spaces.

Proposition 2.5.15. Let $\rho: G \rightarrow \mathrm{O}(n)$ be a morphism between group-objects in Spaces. Let $M$ be a $\mathrm{B} G$-framed $n$-manifold. Let $V \in \operatorname{Mod}_{G}(\mathcal{V})$ be a $G$-module in $\mathcal{V}$. There is a canonical equivalence in $\mathcal{V}$,

$$
\int_{M} \operatorname{Free}_{n}^{\mathrm{B} G}(V) \simeq \coprod_{i \geq 0} \operatorname{Conf}_{i}^{G}(M) \underset{\Sigma_{i} i G}{\otimes} V^{\otimes i}
$$

between the factorization homology of the free $\operatorname{Dis}_{\mathrm{isk}_{n}^{\mathrm{B} G}}$-algebra and the coproduct of $G$-framed configuration spaces of $M$ labeled by $V$.

The proof of Proposition 2.5.15, which appears in the above-mentioned citations, amalgamates the following key observations. First, the result is true for $M$ a Euclidean space. Second, a hypercover-type argument (as in Theorem A.3.1 of [43]), applied to $V$-labeled configuration spaces, gives that the right-hand term satisfies $\otimes$-excision.

Using that left adjoints compose, Proposition 2.5.15 applied to a free $G$-module on an object $W \in \mathcal{V}$ gives the following result.

Corollary 2.5.16. In the case that $V \simeq G \otimes W$ is the free $G$-module on an object $W \in \mathcal{V}$, there is a canonical equivalence in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\int_{M} \operatorname{Free}_{n}^{\mathrm{B} G}(G \otimes W) \simeq \coprod_{i \geq 0} \operatorname{Conf}_{i}(M) \underset{\Sigma_{i}}{\otimes} W^{\otimes i}
$$

Remark 2.5.17 (On homotopy invariance). The work of Longoni-Salvatore [41] shows that configuration spaces of a manifold are sensitive to simple-homotopy type of the manifold. Based on Proposition 2.5.15, this has the following consequence, that factorization homology is not a homotopy invariant of manifolds, even in the weakest sense. The strongest form of homotopy invariance for the functor $\int A$, for a fixed $\operatorname{Dis}_{\mathrm{isk}_{n}}$-algebra $A$, would be the structure of a factorization
![img-37.jpeg](img-37.jpeg)
of $\int A$ through the forgetful functor $\mathcal{M} f \mathrm{~d}_{n} \rightarrow$ Spaces. This structure of homotopy invariance is equivalent to the $\operatorname{Dis}_{\mathrm{isk}_{n}}$-algebra $A$ being commutative. Likewise, a strong form of properhomotopy invariance would be a factorization
![img-38.jpeg](img-38.jpeg)
where $(-)^{+}: \mathcal{M f l d}_{n} \rightarrow$ Spaces $_{*}^{\text {op }}$ is 1-point compactification: sending a manifold $M$ to the 1-point compactification $M^{+}$, and an open embedding $M \hookrightarrow N$ to the collapse map $N^{+} \rightarrow$ $M^{+}$. The existence of this second factorization is roughly equivalent to $A$ being the $n$-disk enveloping algebra of a Lie algebra.

# 2.6 Filtrations 

In this section, we establish two filtrations of factorization homology: in the manifold variable, one can filter by bounding the cardinality of the number of embedded disks; in the algebra variable, one can filter by bounding the number of multiplications allowed by elements of the algebra. Filtrations of the first kind generalize the Goodwillie-Weiss embedding calculus [59]; filtrations of the second kind are an instance of the Goodwillie functor calculus [24]. These filtrations are exchanged under Koszul duality, as is described in the following section. For simplicity, we have written these sections for the case of framed $n$-manifolds - see [5] and [4] for the case of unoriented $n$-manifolds, and the case of $B$-framed $n$-manifolds is analogous.

For the rest of this section, we fix a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$ which is stable and $\otimes$-presentable.

### 2.6.1 Cardinality filtrations

Definition 2.6.1. The $\infty$-category $\mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }}$ is the $\infty$-subcategory of $\mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ whose objects are nonempty framed $n$-manifolds and whose morphisms consist of those embeddings which induce surjections on the set of connected components. $\mathcal{M f l d}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}, \leq k} \subset \mathcal{M f l d}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }}$ is the full $\infty$-subcategory whose objects have at most $k$ components. The $\infty$-categories $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }}$ and $\mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}, \leq k}$ are the further $\infty$-subcategories of $\mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }}$ whose objects are nonempty finite disjoint unions of Euclidean spaces.

That is, an embedding $f: M \hookrightarrow N$ belongs to $\mathcal{M} \mathrm{ffd}_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }}$ if and only if $\pi_{0} f: \pi_{0} M \rightarrow \pi_{0} N$ is surjective.

Definition 2.6.2. For a functor $A: \mathcal{D}$ isk $_{n}^{\mathrm{fr}} \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$, the $k$ th truncation of factorization homology is the colimit of the composite functor

$$
\tau_{\leq k} \int_{M} A:=\operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{D} \operatorname{isk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \leq k} \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}\right)
$$

The difference between the subsequent truncations has a concrete description in terms of configuration spaces:

Lemma 2.6.3. [5] Let $A$ be an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra in $\mathcal{V}$. For each closed framed $n$-manifold $M$, there is a canonical cofiber sequence in $\mathcal{V}$ :

$$
\tau_{\leq k-1} \int_{M} A \longrightarrow \tau_{\leq k} \int_{M} A \longrightarrow \operatorname{Conf}_{k}(M)^{+} \bigotimes_{\Sigma_{k}} A^{\otimes k}
$$

Here, $\operatorname{Conf}_{k}(M)^{+} \in$ Spaces $_{*}$ is the 1-point compactification of $\operatorname{Conf}_{k}(M)$, regarded as a based $\Sigma_{k}$-space; the cofiber is the reduced tensor with this based $\Sigma_{k}$-space.

Example 2.6.4. Consider the case that $\mathcal{V}=\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}$ and $n=1$, so that $\int_{S^{1}} A \simeq \mathrm{HC}_{*}(A)$ is the Hochschild chain complex of the associative algebra $A$. After Lemma 2.6.3, Poincaré

duality applied to the the framed $k$-manifold $\operatorname{Conf}_{k}\left(S^{1}\right)$ with coefficients in the local system $A^{\otimes k}$, identifies, for $k>0$, the cofibers of the cardinality filtration as

$$
\operatorname{Conf}_{k}\left(S^{1}\right)^{+} \bigotimes_{\Sigma_{k}} A^{\otimes k} \simeq \operatorname{clnd}_{\mathrm{C}_{k}}^{\mathbb{T}}\left(A[1]^{\otimes k}\right)
$$

Here, $A[1]$ is chain complex over $\mathbb{k}$ which is the suspension of $A ; \mathrm{C}_{k}$ is the cyclic group of order $k$, regarded as the closed subgroup of $k$ th roots of unity in the Lie group $\mathbb{T}$ of unit complex numbers; $\operatorname{clnd}_{\mathrm{C}_{k}}^{\mathbb{T}}$ is the coinduction from the standard action of $\mathrm{C}_{k}$ on the $k$-fold tensor product $A[1]^{\otimes k}$.

The next series of results lead to the proof of Proposition 2.6.9, that factorization homology can be computed as a sequential colimit of its truncated values. To do this, we will use a comparison of our disk categories with the Ran space $\operatorname{Ran}(M)$. This is the space of finite subsets of $M$, topologized so that points can collide.

Definition 2.6.5. Fin ${ }^{\text {surj }}$ is the category of finite nonempty sets and surjections among them. The Ran space of a topological space $M$ is the topological space

$$
\operatorname{Ran}(M):=\operatorname{colim}\left(\operatorname{Fin}^{\text {surj,op }} \xrightarrow{M} \text { Top }\right)
$$

which is the colimit of the diagram sending a set $J$ to the space $M^{J}$, and a surjection $J \rightarrow I$ to the diagonal map $M^{I} \hookrightarrow M^{J}$. For finite subset $S \subset M$, the topological space

$$
\operatorname{Ran}(M)_{S} \subset \operatorname{Ran}(M)
$$

is the subspace consisting of those finite subsets of $M$ which contain $S$. The cardinality stratification of $\operatorname{Ran}(M)_{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ sends a finite subset $T$ to its cardinality $|T|$.

We will make use of the exit-path $\infty$-category of a stratified space: see [43] or [7].
Lemma 2.6.6. [5] There is contravariant equivalence

$$
\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \simeq \operatorname{Exit}(\operatorname{Ran}(M))^{\mathrm{op}}
$$

with the opposite of the exit-path $\infty$-category of the Ran space of $M$. More generally, fix an embedding $S \subset \coprod_{S} \mathbb{R}^{n} \hookrightarrow M$ for $S \subset M$. Then there is an equivalence

$$
\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \underset{\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \prod_{S}} \mathbb{R}^{n / \infty}}{\times} \operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \prod_{S}} \simeq \operatorname{Exit}\left(\operatorname{Ran}(M)_{S}\right)^{\mathrm{op}}
$$

where $\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \prod_{S}} \mathbb{R}^{n / \infty}$ is the $\infty$-subcategory of $\left(\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}\right)^{\prod_{S}} \mathbb{R}^{n /}$ whose objects are those $\coprod_{S} \mathbb{R}^{n} \hookrightarrow U \hookrightarrow M$ such that $S \rightarrow \pi_{0} U$ is injective.

Lemma 2.6.7 (Lemma 2.3.2 [5]). The functor

$$
\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \longrightarrow \operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}}
$$

is final.

Proof. By Quillen's Theorem A, it suffices to show that for each $g: \coprod_{k} \mathbb{R}^{n} \hookrightarrow M$, an object of $\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}$, the $\infty$-undercategory

$$
\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \underset{\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{b}}}{\times}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}}\right)^{\coprod_{k} \mathbb{R}^{n} /}
$$

has a contractible classifying space. There exists an adjunction

$$
\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \underset{\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{b}}}{\times} \operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \coprod_{k}} \mathbb{R}^{n / \mathrm{nj}} \leftrightarrows \operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \underset{\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{b}}}{\times}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}}\right)^{\coprod_{k} \mathbb{R}^{n} /}
$$

hence an equivalence between their classifying spaces. By Lemma 2.6.7, we obtain

$$
\mathrm{B}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \underset{\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{b}}}{\times} \mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \coprod_{k}} \mathbb{R}^{n / \mathrm{nj}}\right) \simeq \operatorname{BExit}\left(\operatorname{Ran}(M)_{S}\right) \simeq \operatorname{Ran}(M)_{S}
$$

The result now follows from the contractibility of this form of the Ran space-to see this, we use a now standard argument from [9]: the Ran space carries a natural H-space structure, given by taking unions of subsets, for which the composition of the diagonal and the H-space multiplication is the identity. Consequently, its homotopy groups must be zero.

Remark 2.6.8. Combining the equivalence

$$
\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \simeq \operatorname{Exit}(\operatorname{Ran}(M))^{\mathrm{op}}
$$

together with the finality of Lemma 2.6.7, we obtain that factorization homology (or any colimit indexed by $\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}}$ ) is equivalent to the global sections of an associated cosheaf on the Ran space of $M$.

Together with Lemma 2.6.3, the following is the main conclusion of this section, describing a complete filtration of factorization homology with layers given by twisted homologies of configuration spaces.
Proposition 2.6.9. The natural map from the sequential colimit of truncations

$$
\varliminf_{k} \tau_{\leq k} \int_{M} A \longrightarrow \int_{M} A
$$

is an equivalence.
Proof. The finality of Lemma 2.6.7 implies the equivalence

$$
\int_{M} A:=\operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}} \xrightarrow{\int A} \mathcal{V}\right) \simeq \operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}\right)
$$

There is then a sequence of equivalences

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \text { surj }} \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}\right) & \simeq \operatorname{colim}\left(\left(\varliminf_{k} \mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \leq k}\right) \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}\right) \simeq \varliminf_{k} \operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{D i s k}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{fr}, \leq k} \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}\right) \\
& =\varliminf_{k} \tau_{\leq k} \int_{M} A
\end{aligned}
$$

from which the result follows.

A dual result holds for factorization cohomology with coefficients in an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-coalgebra.
Definition 2.6.10. For $C$ an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-coalgebra in $\mathcal{V}$ (i.e., an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra in $\mathcal{V}^{\text {op }}$ ), the factorization cohomology of $M$ with coefficients in $C$ is the limit

$$
\int^{M} C:=\lim \left(\operatorname{Disk}_{n / M}^{\mathrm{op}} \xrightarrow{C} \mathcal{V}\right)
$$

Proposition 2.6.11. For $M$ a closed framed n-manifold and $C$ an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-coalgebra in $\mathcal{V}$, there exists a cofiltration of $\int^{M} C$,

$$
\int^{M} C \longrightarrow \tau^{\leq \bullet} \int^{M} C
$$

whose associated graded is

$$
\prod_{k}\left(\left(C^{\otimes k}\right)^{\operatorname{Conf}_{k}(M)^{+}}\right)^{\Sigma_{k}}
$$

The output is a cofiltration of factorization homology whose $k$ th term is the polynomial approximation $P_{k} \int_{M}$.

### 2.7 Poincaré/Koszul duality

Koszul duality, in its most basic form, interchanges two forms of algebra, determined by the form of algebraic structure that the cotangent space at an augmentation naturally

inherits. There are two classical forms of Koszul duality: commutative algebra is Koszul dual to Lie algebra; associative algebra is dual to associative algebra. In particular, associative algebra is Koszul self-dual. This second assertion generalizes to the situation of $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra, where the Koszul self-duality dates to Getzler-Jones [23]. This Koszul duality for $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra can be expressed in terms of factorization homology for manifolds with boundary. See [44] for another treatment of Koszul self-duality of $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra, in terms of twisted arrow categories.

Theorem 2.7.1. ([5], [4]) Let $\mathcal{V}$ be a stable $\otimes$-presentable $\infty$-category. There is a functor

$$
\int_{\mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n}}: \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}(\mathcal{V}) \longrightarrow \operatorname{cAlg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}(\mathcal{V})
$$

sending an augmented $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra $A$ to an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-coalgebra structure on

$$
\int_{\mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n}} A \simeq A \bigotimes \mathbb{1}_{\mathbb{R}}
$$

There is a natural transformation, the Poincaré/Koszul duality map, in Fun( $\mathbb{N}^{\triangleright}, \mathcal{V})$ :

$$
P_{\bullet} \int_{M} A \longrightarrow \tau^{\leq \bullet} \int^{M}\left(\int_{\mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n}} A\right)
$$

$$
\int_{M} A \longrightarrow \int^{M}\left(\int_{\mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n}} A\right)
$$

This map is an equivalence when restricted to $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathbb{N}, \mathcal{V})$.
Remark 2.7.2. The coalgebra structure of $\int_{\mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n}} A$ is given in [4] by showing that factorization homology with coefficients in an augmented $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra is functorial with respect to the fold map

$$
\mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n} \longrightarrow \mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n} \vee \mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n}
$$

More generally, the theory of zero-pointed manifolds of [4] exhibits an additional functoriality for factorization homology of augmented algebras, of extension-by-zero maps.

In particular, the Goodwillie completion $\underline{\lim } P_{\bullet} \int_{M} A$ is equivalent to factorization cohomology with the coefficients in the coalgebra which is Koszul-dual to $A$. The natural map to the completion

$$
\int_{M} A \longrightarrow \underline{\lim } P_{\bullet} \int_{M} A
$$

need not be an equivalence, however. ${ }^{12}$ A generalization of factorization homology, taking coefficients in formal moduli problems, gives a way to correct the failure of Poincaré/Koszul duality to be an equivalence in general.

Definition 2.7.3. Let $\mathcal{V}$ be a $\otimes$-presentable $\infty$-category. Let $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ be a map from a space. Let $X: \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Disk }_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V}) \rightarrow$ Spaces be a functor. Let $M$ be a $B$-framed $n$-manifold $M$. The factorization homology of $M$ with coefficients in $X$ is the object in $\mathcal{V}$

$$
\int_{M} X:=\lim _{A \in \operatorname{Aff}_{X}^{B}} \int_{M} A
$$

where $\mathrm{Aff}:=\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Disk }_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V})^{\text {op }} \subset \operatorname{Fun}\left(\operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Disk }_{n}^{B}}(\mathcal{V})\right.$, Spaces) is the image of the Yoneda embedding.

Remark 2.7.4. Intuitively, the object $\int_{M} X$ is $\Gamma\left(X, \int_{M} \mathcal{O}\right)$, the global sections of the presheaf on $X$ obtained by applying factorization homology of $M$ to the structure sheaf of $X$. We interpret this form of factorization homology as the observables in a topological quantum field theory: a sigma-model with algebraic target $X$.

There is a modification of the above definition for a formal moduli problem, i.e., a space-valued functor on an $\infty$-category of Artin $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebras.

Definition 2.7.5 $\left(\operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}\right)$. The full $\infty$-subcategory $\operatorname{Triv}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}} \subset \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug. } \geq 0}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$ is the essential image of connective perfect $\mathbb{k}$-modules $\operatorname{Perf}_{\mathbb{k}}^{\geq 0}$ under the functor that assigns a complex $V$ the associated square-zero extension $\mathbb{k} \oplus V$. The $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}$ of local Artin $\mathcal{E}_{n^{-}}$ algebras is the smallest full $\infty$-subcategory of $\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug. } \geq 0}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$ that contains $\operatorname{Triv}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}$ and is closed under small extensions. That is:

If $B$ is in $\operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}, \mathbb{k} \oplus V$ is in $\operatorname{Triv}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}$, and the following diagram
![img-40.jpeg](img-40.jpeg)
forms a pullback square in $\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug. } \geq 0}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$, then $A$ is in $\operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}$.
Definition 2.7.6. Fix a field $\mathbb{k}$, and let $X$ : $\operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}} \rightarrow$ Spaces be a functor of local Artin $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebras over $\mathbb{k}$. The factorization homology of $X$ over $M$ is the $\mathbb{k}$-module

$$
\int_{M} X:=\lim _{R \in \operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n} / X}^{B}} \int_{M} R
$$

Such formal moduli problems $X$ are defined by the generalization of the Maurer-Cartan functor from classical Lie theory. In the following definition, we use the Koszul duality functor $\mathbb{D}^{n}$ given as the composite of linear duality with factorization homology of $\mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n}$.

$$
\mathbb{D}^{n}: \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{cAlg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)^{\text {op }}
$$

That is, the Koszul-dual $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra is

$$
\mathbb{D}^{n} A=\left(\int_{\mathbb{D}^{n} / \partial \mathbb{D}^{n}} A\right)^{\vee}
$$

Definition 2.7.7. For an Artin $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra $R$ and an augmented $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra $A$ over a field $\mathbb{k}$, the Maurer-Cartan space

$$
\mathrm{MC}_{A}(R):=\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}\left(\mathbb{D}^{n} R, A\right)
$$

is the space of maps from the Koszul dual of $R$ to $A$. The Maurer-Cartan functor $\mathrm{MC}: \mathrm{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}\right.$, Spaces) is the adjoint of the pairing

$$
\operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}} \times \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right) \xrightarrow{\mathbb{D}^{n} \times \text { id }} \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right)^{\text {op }} \times \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}}^{\text {aug }}\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}\right) \xrightarrow{\operatorname{Map}(-,-)} \text { Spaces. }
$$

MC sends $A$ to the functor $\mathrm{MC}_{A}: \operatorname{Artin}_{\mathcal{E}_{n}} \rightarrow$ Spaces.
The following is the framed version of the main theorem of [5].
Theorem 2.7.8 (Poincaré/Koszul duality [5]). Let $M$ be a closed framed n-manifold; let $A$ be an augmented $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra over a field $\mathbb{k}$ with $\mathrm{MC}_{A}$ the associated formal moduli functor of $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebras. There is a natural equivalence

$$
\left(\int_{M} A\right)^{\vee} \simeq \int_{M} \mathrm{MC}_{A}
$$

between the $\mathbb{k}$-linear dual of the factorization homology of $M$ with coefficients in $A$ and the factorization homology of $M$ with coefficients in the moduli functor $\mathrm{MC}_{A}$.

Remark 2.7.9. One can regard the failure of the duality map in Theorem 2.7.1 to be an equivalence to be related to the non-affineness of the formal moduli problem $\mathrm{MC}_{A}$. Were $\mathrm{MC}_{A}$ to be affine, it would be equivalent to the formal spectrum of the Koszul dual, $\operatorname{Spf}\left(\mathbb{D}^{n} A\right)$, in which the case the duality map of Theorem 2.7.1 would be an equivalence. In terms of topological quantum field theory, we regard $\mathrm{MC}_{A}$ as determining a sigma-model whose target $X=\mathrm{MC}_{A}$ is formal, but not necessarily affine. Theorem 2.7.8 then describes the observables $\int_{M} X$ in this sigma-model in terms of the factorization homology with coefficients in a shift of the cotangent space of the point $\operatorname{Spec}(\mathbb{k}) \rightarrow X$.

# 2.8 Factorization homology for singular manifolds 

We briefly outline an extension of factorization homology to singular manifolds, such as manifolds equipped with defects. The notion of singular manifolds, and structured versions thereof, is developed in [7]. The development of factorization homology of such can be found in $[8]$.

### 2.8.1 Singular manifolds

Heuristically, a singular manifold is a stratified space in which each stratum is endowed with the structure of a smooth manifold, and in which each stratum has a canonically associated link which is itself a singular manifold. Informally, the $\infty$-category $\mathcal{S n g l r}$ of singular manifolds and open (stratified) embeddings among such is minimal with respect to the following features.

1. The empty set $\emptyset$ is a singular manifold.
2. For $L$ a compact singular manifold, the open cone

$$
\mathrm{C}(L):=* \coprod_{L \times\{0\}} L \times[0,1)
$$

is a singular manifold, with the cone-point $*$ a stratum.
3. For $X$ and $Y$ singular manifolds, their product $X \times Y$ is a singular manifold.
4. For $U \subset X$ an open subset of a singular manifold, then $U$ is canonically a singular manifold.
5. For $\mathcal{U}$ an open cover by singular manifolds of a paracompact Hausdorff space $X$, then $X$ is a singular manifold.
6. For $L$ a compact singular manifold, the continuous homomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Aut}(L) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Aut}(\mathrm{C}(L)), \quad f \mapsto \mathrm{C}(f)
$$

is equipped with a deformation retraction whose retraction $D_{*}: \operatorname{Aut}(\mathrm{C}(L)) \rightarrow \operatorname{Aut}(L)$ is a continuous homomorphism.

A rigorous definition of $\mathcal{S} n g \mathrm{lr}$ is given in $\S 1$ of [7]. That definition is distractingly inductive, and so we elect to not spell it out here.

Terminology 2.8.1. In this article, by "singular manifold" we will mean "finitary singular manifold with boundary," in the sense of [7].

Remark 2.8.2. The first two axioms give that $*$ is a singular manifold, and thereafter that $\mathrm{C}(*)=[0,1)$ is a singular manifold with strata $\{0\}$ and $(0,1)$. The third and fifth axiom gives that $(0,1)^{\times n} \cong \mathbb{R}^{n}$ is a singular manifold. The fifth axiom thereafter gives that each manifold is a singular manifold. The second and third axiom then give that $\mathbb{R}^{k} \times \mathrm{C}(L)$ is a singular manifold for each compact manifold $L$. In general, an arbitrary singular manifold is a paracompact Hausdorff topological space that admits a basis for its topology consisting of open embeddings from singular manifolds of the form $\mathbb{R}^{k} \times \mathrm{C}(L)$, where $k$ is an integer and $L$ is a compact singular manifold.

A basic is a singular manifold of the form $\mathbb{R}^{k} \times \mathrm{C}(L)$ for $k$ an integer and $L$ a compact singular manifold.

Remark 2.8.3. We follow up on the previous remark. Namely, the definition of a singular manifold detailed in [7] is in analogy with that of a smooth manifold: it is a paracompact Hausdorff topological space equipped with a maximal atlas by basics.

Remark 2.8.4. The sixth axiom above reflects the regularity of singular manifolds. The retraction map can be interpreted as taking the 'derivative at the cone-point'. A consequence of this structure is that one can 'resolve singularities' of a singular manifold. Specifically, for $X$ a singular manifold, and for $X_{d} \subset X$ a stratum that is closed as a subspace, there

is a well-defined blow-up of $X$ along $X_{d}$, as well as link of $X_{d}$ in $X$, which assemble as the pullback and pushout diagram consisting of singular manifolds and continuous stratified maps among them:
![img-41.jpeg](img-41.jpeg)

This diagram has the feature that the left vertical map is a bundle of singular manifolds, while the right vertical map restricts as a bundle of singular manifolds over each stratum of $X$, and over the complement $X \backslash X_{d}$ the right vertical map is an isomorphism.

Example 2.8.5. Let $\bar{M}$ be an $n$-manifold with boundary. Regard $\bar{M}$ as a stratified space, whose strata are the connected components of the boundary $\partial \bar{M}$ and the connected components of of the interior $M:=\bar{M} \backslash \partial \bar{M}$. As a stratified space, $\bar{M}$ is a singular manifold. Indeed, it admits an atlas by basics of the form $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ and $\mathbb{R}^{n-1} \times \mathrm{C}(*)$.

Example 2.8.6. Let $M$ be an $n$-manifold. Let $W \subset M$ be a properly embedded $d$ submanifold. Consider the stratified space $(W \subset M)$ whose strata are the connected components of $W$ and the connected components of $M \backslash W$. This stratified space $(W \subset M)$ is a singular manifold. Indeed, it admits an atlas by basics of the form $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ and $\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathrm{C}\left(S^{n-d-1}\right)$. A singular manifold of this form is a defect, or refinement, of the manifold $M$. In particular, a knot in a 3-manifold determines a stratified space that refines onto the given 3-manifold.

Example 2.8.7. Following up on Example 2.8.6, consider a sequence $W_{0} \subset W_{1} \subset M$ of properly embedded $d_{0}$-submanifold in a properly embedded $d_{1}$-submanifold in an $n$ manifold. Consider the stratified space $\left(W_{0} \subset W_{1} \subset M\right)$ whose strata are the connected components of $W_{0}$, the connected components of $W_{1} \backslash W_{0}$, and the connected components of $M \backslash W_{1}$. This stratified space $\left(W_{0} \subset W_{1} \subset M\right)$ is a singular manifold. Indeed, it admits an atlas by basics of the form $\mathbb{R}^{n}, \mathbb{R}^{d_{1}} \times \mathrm{C}\left(S^{n-d_{1}-1}\right)$, and $\mathbb{R}^{d_{0}} \times \mathrm{C}\left(\mathbf{S}^{n-d_{0}-1}\right)$ where $\mathbf{S}^{n-d_{0}-1}=\left(S^{d_{1}-d_{0}-1} \subset S^{n-d_{0}-1}\right)$ is the singular manifold of Example 2.8.6 applied to an equatorially embedded sphere.

Example 2.8.8. Let $p \geq 0$, and consider the topological simplex $\Delta^{p}$. Consider the stratification of $\Delta^{p}$ in which the $i$-dimensional strata comprise the connected components of the complement of skeleta $\operatorname{sk}_{i}\left(\Delta^{n}\right) \backslash \operatorname{sk}_{i-1}\left(\Delta^{n}\right)$. This stratified space is a singular manifold. Indeed, it admits an atlas by basics of the form $\mathbb{R}^{n-p} \times \mathrm{C}\left(\Delta^{p-1}\right)$ for $0 \leq p \leq n$. As a consequence, the geometric realization $|Z|$ of a finite simplicial complex is canonically endowed with the structure of a singular manifold.

Example 2.8.9. The Grassmannian $\mathrm{Gr}_{k}(n)$ of $k$-planes in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ admits the Schubert stratification, for which, for each cardinality $k$-subset $S \subset\{1, \ldots, n\}$, the $S$-stratum consists of those $V$ for which $S$ is minimal (in the Schubert poset) for which the linear map $V \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n} \xrightarrow{\text { proj }} \mathbb{R}^{S}$ is an isomorphism. This Schubert stratification of $\mathrm{Gr}_{k}(n)$ is a singular manifold.

Example 2.8.10. The orthogonal group $\mathrm{O}(n)$ admits the Bruhat stratification, for which, for each element $\varphi \in \Sigma_{n} \iota(\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z})=\operatorname{Aut}(n \mathrm{Cube}) \subset \mathrm{O}(n)$ of the group of symmetries of the $n$-cube, the $\varphi$-stratum consists of those orthogonal matrices that, via row elimination and

scaling by positive scalars, have $\varphi$ as its matrix of pivots. This Bruhat stratification of $\mathrm{O}(n)$ is a singular manifold.

Recall from $\S 2.2 .2$ that we classified sheaves on the $\infty$-category $\mathcal{M f l d}_{n}$ as space over $\mathrm{BO}(n)$; for $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ such a thing, the space of sections of the associated sheaf on an $n$-manifold $M$ is the space of lifts of the tangent classifier:
![img-42.jpeg](img-42.jpeg)

This was the context supporting the constant consideration of spaces over $\mathrm{BO}(n)$ in the developments above.

In [7] there appears a similar classification. Namely, consider the full $\infty$-subcategory $\mathcal{B} \mathrm{sc} \subset \mathcal{S} n g \mathrm{lr}$ consisting of the basic singular manifolds.

Theorem 2.8.11. [7] Restriction along the inclusion $\mathcal{B} s \mathrm{~S} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{S} n \mathrm{nglr}$ defines an equivalence between $\infty$-categories

$$
\operatorname{Shv}(\mathcal{S} n g \mathrm{lr}) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{PShv}(\mathcal{B} s c)
$$

Through the straightening-unstraightening equivalence of $\S 2$ of [42], Theorem 2.8.11 gives that a sheaf on $\mathcal{S} n g \mathrm{lr}$ is equivalent data to a right fibration among $\infty$-categories:

$$
\mathcal{B} \longrightarrow \mathcal{B} \mathrm{sc}
$$

a section of the space of sections of the associated sheaf on a singular manifold $X$ is the space of lifts
![img-43.jpeg](img-43.jpeg)
we call such a lift a $\mathcal{B}$-structure. Here, $\operatorname{Exit}(X)$ is the exit-path $\infty$-category of $X$, and the functor $\tau_{X}$ carries a point in $X$ to a basic neighborhood of it. In [7] it is shown that the functor $\operatorname{Exit}(X)^{\text {op }} \xrightarrow{\tau_{X}} \mathcal{B} s c$ is the unstraightening of the presheaf $\mathcal{B} s \mathrm{~s}^{\text {op }} \xrightarrow{U \mapsto \operatorname{Emb}(U, X)}$ Spaces. In particular, $\operatorname{Exit}(X)^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \mathcal{B} s c$ is a right fibration.

Example 2.8.12. Let $B \rightarrow \mathrm{BO}(n)$ be a map from a space. The composite map $B \rightarrow$ $\mathrm{BO}(n) \rightarrow \mathcal{B} s c$ is a right fibration. A singular manifold $X$ admits a $B$-structure if and only if $X$ is an $n$-manifold. Furthermore, should $X$ be an $n$-manifold, the space $B$-structures is the space of $B$-framings on that $n$-manifold.

Example 2.8.13. Let $\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n} \subset \mathcal{B} s c$ be the full $\infty$-subcategory consisting of the two objects $\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{C}\left(S^{n-d-1}\right)$ and $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. The inclusion $\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{B} s c$ is a right fibration. A singular manifold $X$ admits a $\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n}$-structure if and only if the singular manifold is of the form $\left(W^{d} \subset M^{n}\right)$, a properly embedded $d$-submanifold in an $n$-manifold (see Example 2.8.6). Furthermore, if $X$ admits a $\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n}$-structure, then it is unique.

Example 2.8.14. Choose, once and for all, an orientation-preserving diffeomorphism $\mathbb{R} \cong$ $(0,1)$. Consider the right fibration $\mathcal{D}_{n-1, n}^{\mathrm{fr}}:=\{n-1<n\} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ sc that selects out the morphism $\mathbb{R}^{n}=\mathbb{R}^{n-1} \times \mathbb{R} \cong \mathbb{R}^{n-1} \times(0,1) \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n-1} \times \mathrm{C}(*)$, which is the standard open embedding of the complement of the cone-locus. A $\mathcal{D}_{n-1, n}^{\mathrm{fr}}$-manifold is an $n$-manifold with boundary, equipped with a framing of its interior and a splitting of its framing along the boundary for which the last vector field points inward.

Example 2.8.15. Let $\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n}^{\mathrm{fr}} \subset \mathcal{B}$ sc be the right fibration Exit $\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathrm{C}\left(S^{n-d-1}\right)\right)^{\text {op }} \xrightarrow[\rightarrow]{\rightarrow} \mathcal{B}$ sc. A singular manifold $X$ admits a $\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n}^{\mathrm{fr}}$-structure if and only if the singular manifold is of the form $\left(W^{d} \subset M^{n}\right)$, a properly embedded $d$-submanifold in an $n$-manifold (see Example 2.8.6). Furthermore, for $X=(W \subset M)$ such a singular manifold, a $\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n}^{\mathrm{fr}}$-structure on it is a framing of $M$ and a splitting of the framing along $W$ via the first $d$-coordinates.

Example 2.8.16. The representable right fibrations over $\mathcal{B}$ sc are particularly tractable. Let $U=\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathrm{C}(L)$ be a basic. Notate the right fibration $\operatorname{Exit}(U)^{\text {op }} \xrightarrow{\tau_{U}} \mathcal{B}$ sc as $\mathcal{D}_{U} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ sc. A singular manifold $X$ admits a $\mathcal{D}_{U}$-structure if and only if $X$ admits an atlas by open subsets of $U$. Furthermore, for $X$ such a singular manifold, a $\mathcal{D}_{U}$-structure on $X$ determines the structure of a framed $d$-manifold on the lowest-dimensional strata $X_{d}$ of $X$, as well as a trivialization of the link,

$$
\operatorname{Link}_{X_{d}}(X) \underset{\text { over } \mathrm{X}_{\mathrm{d}}}{\cong} X_{d} \times L
$$

and thereafter, upon the choice of a collar-neighborhood of $\operatorname{Link}_{X_{d}}(X)$ in the blow-up $\mathrm{Bl}_{X_{d}}(X)$, an open stratified embedding

$$
X_{d} \times L \times \mathbb{R} \hookrightarrow X \backslash X_{d}
$$

Observation 2.8.17. Let $U=\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathrm{C}(L)$ be a basic. Consider the right fibration $\mathcal{D}_{U} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ sc of Example 2.8.16. Consider the full $\infty$-subcategory $\operatorname{Exit}\left(U \backslash \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)^{\text {op }}:=\mathcal{D}_{>U} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}_{U}$ consisting of those objects, which are points in $U$, that do not belong to the cone-locus $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. The composite functor $\mathcal{D}_{>U} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}_{U} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ sc is again a right fibration. For $X$ a singular manifold equipped with a $\mathcal{D}_{U}$-structure, the complement $X \backslash X_{d}$ of its lowest-dimensional strata is a singular manifold, and it canonically inherits a $\mathcal{D}_{>U}$-structure from the given $\mathcal{D}_{U}$-structure on $X$. Through the conclusion of Example 2.8.16, the product $\mathbb{R}^{d} \times L \times \mathbb{R} \cong \mathbb{R}^{d+1} \times L$ is canonically endowed with a $\mathcal{D}_{>U}$-structure. Thereafter, taking products with Euclidean$(d+1)$-spaces defines a symmetric monoidal functor

$$
\operatorname{Disk}_{d+1}^{\mathrm{fr}} \xrightarrow{-\times L} \mathcal{M} \operatorname{fld}\left(\mathcal{D}_{>U}\right), \quad\left(\mathbb{R}^{d+1}\right)^{\sqcup I} \mapsto\left(\mathbb{R}^{d+1}\right)^{\sqcup I} \times L \cong\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times L \times \mathbb{R}\right)^{\sqcup I}
$$

Definition 2.8.18. Let $\mathcal{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ sc be a right fibration. The $\infty$-category $\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B})$ of $\mathcal{B}$ manifolds is the pullback among $\infty$-categories:
![img-44.jpeg](img-44.jpeg)

The $\infty$-category of $\mathcal{B}$-disks is the full $\infty$-subcategory

$$
\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B}) \subset \mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B})
$$

consisting of those $\mathcal{B}$-structured singular manifolds $X$ for which $X$ is a finite disjoint union of basics. Disjoint union of underlying singular manifolds makes both $\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})$ and $\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B})$ into symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories.

So a $\mathcal{B}$-manifold is a pair $(X, \varphi)$ consisting of a singular manifold together with a $\mathcal{B}$ structure on it. The space of morphisms between two such are open (stratified) embeddings that respect $\mathcal{B}$-structures.
Example 2.8.19. Consider the basic $U=\mathrm{C}\left(\Delta^{n-1}\right)$, where $\Delta^{n-1}$ is the compact singular manifold of Example 2.8.8. A $\mathcal{D}_{U}$-manifold is an $n$-manifold $\bar{M}$ with corners equipped with a framing as well as compatible splittings of the framing along each face. We call an $n$-manifold with corners equipped with such framing data a framed $\langle n\rangle$-manifold. (This notion of $\langle n\rangle$ manifolds, which are $n$-manifolds with corners with certain corner structure, is thoroughly developed in [40].) For this case of $U$, we use the simplified notation:

$$
\mathcal{D}_{\langle n\rangle}^{b}:=\mathcal{D}_{U} \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Disk}_{\langle n\rangle}^{b}:=\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{D}_{\langle n\rangle}^{b}\right)
$$

# 2.8.2 Homology theories for structured singular manifolds 

In analogy with $\S 2.3 .6$, one can define factorization homology of a $\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})$-algebra over a $\mathcal{B}$-manifold, and factorization homology can be characterized as homology theories for $\mathcal{B}$-manifolds.

In this subsection, we fix a right fibration $\mathcal{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ sc, as well as a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{V}$ that is $\otimes$-presentable.
Definition 2.8.20. The $\infty$-category of $\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})$-algebras in $\mathcal{V}$ is

$$
\operatorname{Alg}_{\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})}(\mathcal{V}):=\operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}(\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B}), \mathcal{V})
$$

Remark 2.8.21. Recall the identification with the symmetric monoidal envelope $\operatorname{Env}\left(\mathcal{E}_{n}\right) \simeq$ Disk $_{n}^{b}$. This identification can be read as $\operatorname{Disk}_{n}^{b}$ being initial among symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories equipped with an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra therein. There is a likewise identification $\operatorname{Env}(\mathcal{E}(\mathcal{B})) \simeq \operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})$ where $\mathcal{E}(\mathcal{B})$ is an $\infty$-operad whose underlying $\infty$-category of 1-ary operations is $\mathcal{B}$, and whose space $I$-ary morphisms from $\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I} \in \mathcal{B}^{I}$ to $V \in \mathcal{B}$ is the space of $\mathcal{B}$-structured embeddings from the $I$-fold disjoint union: $\operatorname{Map}_{\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})}\left(\bigsqcup_{i \in I} U_{i}, V\right)$.

The Definition 2.3.7 of factorization homology for $n$-manifolds is adequately formal, defined through a universal property, to imitate for singular manifolds.
Definition 2.8.22. For $A \in \operatorname{Alg}_{\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})}(\mathcal{V})$, and $X$ a $\mathcal{B}$-manifold, the factorization homology of $A$ over $X$ is the colimit in $\mathcal{V}$,

$$
\int_{X} A:=\operatorname{colim}\left(\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})_{/ X} \rightarrow \operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B}) \xrightarrow{A} \mathcal{V}\right)
$$

should it exist.

Restriction along the fully faithful symmetric monoidal functor $\iota: \operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B}) \hookrightarrow \mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B})$ defines a functor

$$
\operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{D i s k}(\mathcal{B})}(\mathcal{V}) \leftarrow \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}(\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B}), \mathcal{V}): \iota^{*}
$$

Proposition 2.8.23. Factorization homology exists, and defines a left adjoint to (2.8.2):

$$
\int: \operatorname{Alg}_{\mathcal{D i s k}(\mathcal{B})}(\mathcal{V}) \rightleftarrows \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}(\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B}), \mathcal{V}): \iota^{*}
$$

Furthermore, the a priori lax-commutative diagram among $\infty$-categories involving a left adjoint $\iota_{!}$of the restriction functor $\iota^{*}$,
![img-45.jpeg](img-45.jpeg)
is in fact a commutative diagram.
The Definition 2.3.25 of a collar-gluing for $n$-manifolds can be imitated for singular manifolds: for $X$ a singular manifold, a collar-gluing of $X$ is a continuous map $f: X \rightarrow$ $[-1,1]$ for which the restriction $f_{\mathrm{i}}: f^{-1}(-1,1) \rightarrow(-1,1)$ is a fiber bundle among singular manifolds. We denote such a collar-gluing as $X_{-} \bigcup_{X_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} X_{+} \cong X$ where we understand that $X_{-}:=f^{-1}[-1,1), X_{+}:=f^{-1}(-1,1]$, and $X_{0}:=f^{-1}(0)$, while $X_{0} \times \mathbb{R} \cong X_{0} \times(-1,1) \cong$ $f^{-1}(-1,1)$. Such a collar-gluing of a $\mathcal{B}$-manifold $X$ determines an algebra in the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B})$ over the multi-category Assoc ${ }^{\mathrm{RL}}$ :

$$
\left(X_{0} ; X_{+}, X_{-}\right) \in \operatorname{Alg}_{\text {Assoc } \mathrm{RL}}(\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B}))
$$

Thereafter, each symmetric monoidal functor $\mathcal{F}: \mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B}) \rightarrow \mathcal{V}$ determines, for each such collar-gluing, a canonical morphism in $\mathcal{V}$ from the 2 -sided bar construction:

$$
\mathcal{F}\left(X_{-}\right) \underset{\mathcal{F}\left(X_{0}\right)}{\otimes} \mathcal{F}\left(X_{+}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{F}(X)
$$

Definition 2.8.24. The $\infty$-category of homology theories for $\mathcal{B}$-manifolds is the full $\infty$ subcategory

$$
\mathbf{H}(\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B}), \mathcal{V}) \subset \operatorname{Fun}^{\otimes}(\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B}), \mathcal{V})
$$

consisting of those symmetric monoidal functors $\mathcal{F}$ that are $\otimes$-excisive:
For which, for each collar-gluing $X_{-} \bigcup_{X_{0} \times \mathbb{R}} X_{+} \cong X$ of a $\mathcal{B}$-manifold, the canonical morphism in $\mathcal{V}$,

$$
\mathcal{F}\left(X_{-}\right) \underset{\mathcal{F}\left(X_{0}\right)}{\otimes} \mathcal{F}\left(X_{+}\right) \xrightarrow{(2.8 .3)} \mathcal{F}(X)
$$

is an equivalence.

The following foundational characterizing factorization homology is result is proved in $[8]$.

Theorem 2.8.25. Factorization homology defines an equivalence between $\infty$-categories,

$$
\int: \operatorname{Alg}_{\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})}(\mathcal{V}) \simeq \mathbf{H}(\mathcal{M f l d}(\mathcal{B}), \mathcal{V})
$$

with inverse given by restriction.

# 2.8.3 Characterizing some $\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{D}_{U}\right)$-algebras 

Recall from $\S 2.2 .5$ that, for $B=*$ so that a $B$-framing on an $n$-manifold is a framing thereof, then a $\mathcal{D i s k}_{n}^{f r}$-algebra was precisely an $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra, which is a rather algebraic entity. In the same spirit, we characterize some $\operatorname{Disk}(\mathcal{B})$-algebras in algebraic terms. Through Theorem 2.8.25, this gives algebraic input for invariants of $\mathcal{B}$-manifolds.

In this subsection, we fix a commutative ring spectrum $\mathbb{k}$, and consider its symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$ of $\mathbb{k}$-modules and tensor product over $\mathbb{k}$ among them.

The next result is an immediate consequence of the main result of [57] after the observation that $\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{D}_{n-1, n}^{f r}\right)$ is the symmetric monoidal envelope of the Swiss cheese operad. To state the result, recall that, for $B$ a $\mathcal{E}_{k}$-algebra in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$, its (derived) center is

$$
\mathrm{Z}(B):=\operatorname{Hom}_{\int_{S^{k-1}} B}(B, B)
$$

the endomorphisms of $B$ as a module over the $\mathcal{E}_{1}$-algebra $\int_{S^{k-1}} B$. Deligne's conjecture, as stated and proved in $\S 5$ of [43], endows $\mathrm{Z}(B)$ with a canonical structure of a $\mathcal{E}_{k+1}$-algebra structure in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$.

Proposition 2.8.26. Recall from Example 2.8.5 the right fibration $\mathcal{D}_{n-1, n}^{f r} \rightarrow \mathcal{B s c}$. A $\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{D}_{n-1, n}^{f r}\right)$-algebra in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$ is equivalent to the following data.

1. An $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra $A$ in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$.
2. An $\mathcal{E}_{n-1}$-algebra $B$ in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$.
3. An action of $A$ on $B$, instantiated as a morphism between $\mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebras

$$
A \longrightarrow \mathrm{Z}(B)
$$

to the (derived) center of $B$.
The above result is typical of its kind. The next result appears in [8].
Proposition 2.8.27. Consider the right fibration $\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n}^{f r} \rightarrow \mathcal{B s c}$ of Example 2.8.15. A $\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{D}_{d \subset n}^{f r}\right)$-algebra in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$ is equivalent to the following data.

1. $A \mathcal{E}_{n}$-algebra $A$ in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$.
2. $A \mathcal{E}_{d}$-algebra $B$ in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathbb{k}}, \otimes_{\mathbb{k}}\right)$.

3. An action of $\int_{S^{n-d-1}} A$ on $B$, instantiated as a morphism between $\mathcal{E}_{d+1}$-algebras

$$
\int_{S^{n-d-1}} A \longrightarrow \mathrm{Z}(B)
$$

Example 2.8.28. Consider the case $(d, n)=(1,3)$. A compact $\mathcal{D}_{1 \subset 3}^{\mathrm{fr}}$-manifold is a link in a 3-manifold, equipped with a framing of the 3-manifold and a splitting of this framing along the link via the first coordinate. A $\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{D}_{1 \subset 3}^{\mathrm{fr}}\right)$-algebra is an $\mathcal{E}_{3}$-algebra $A$, a $\mathcal{E}_{1}$-algebra $B$, and a morphism between $\mathcal{E}_{2}$-algebras

$$
\alpha: \mathrm{HH}_{\bullet}(A) \longrightarrow \mathrm{HH}^{\bullet}(B)
$$

from the Hochschild chains to the Hochschild cochains. Through Theorem 2.8.25, such algebraic data determines, via factorization homology, a k-module associated to each framed link in a framed 3-manifold, $L \subset M$ :

$$
\int_{(L \subset M)}(A, B, \alpha) \in \operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}
$$

The above two results are specific instances of a more general paradigm.
Proposition 2.8.29. Let $U=\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathrm{C}(L)$ be a basic. Consider the right fibration $\mathcal{D}_{U} \rightarrow \mathcal{B s c}$ from Example 2.8.16. Consider the right fibration $\mathcal{D}_{>U} \rightarrow \mathcal{B s c}$ from Observation 2.8.17. A $\operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{D}_{U}\right)$-algebra in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \otimes_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ is equivalent to the following data.

1. $A \operatorname{Disk}\left(\mathcal{D}_{>U}\right)$-algebra $A$ in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \otimes_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$.

Note how restriction along (2.8.1) in Observation 2.8.17, followed by factorization homology, defines an $\mathcal{E}_{d+1}$-algebra in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \otimes_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$ :

$$
\int_{L} A: \operatorname{Disk}_{d+1}^{\mathrm{fr}} \xrightarrow[(\text { 2.8.1) }]{\times L} \operatorname{Affld}\left(\mathcal{D}_{>U}\right) \xrightarrow{\int A} \operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}
$$

2. $A \mathcal{E}_{d}$-algebra $B$ in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \otimes_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$.
3. An action of $\int_{L} A$ on $B$, instantiated as a morphism between $\mathcal{E}_{d+1}$-algebras

$$
\int_{L} A \longrightarrow \mathrm{Z}(B)
$$

The next result references Example 2.8.19, notably the right fibration $\mathcal{D}_{(n)}^{\mathrm{fr}} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ sc for which a $\mathcal{D}_{(n)}^{\mathrm{fr}}$-manifold is a framed $\langle n\rangle$-manifold.

Corollary 2.8.30. The following data canonically determines a $\operatorname{Disk}_{(n)}^{\mathrm{fr}}$-algebra in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \otimes_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$.

1. For each $0 \leq i \leq n$, a $\mathcal{E}_{i}$-algebra $A_{i}$ in $\left(\operatorname{Mod}_{\mathrm{k}}, \otimes_{\mathrm{k}}\right)$.
2. For each $0<i \leq n$, a morphism between $\mathcal{E}_{i}$-algebras

$$
\alpha_{i}: A_{i} \longrightarrow \mathrm{Z}\left(A_{i-1}\right)
$$

Remark 2.8.31. Suppose $\mathbb{k}$ is an algebraically closed field whose characteristic is 0 . Recall from [49] the notions of a shifted symplectic algebraic stack over $\mathbb{k}$, and of a Lagrangian map to one. We also use the result therein which states that the derived intersection of two Lagrangian maps to an $n$-shifted symplectic stack canonically inherits the structure of a $(n-1)$-shifted symplectic stack. We expect that the data of Corollary 2.8.30 can be supplied through a parametrized version of deformation quantization from the following input.

- A sequence

$$
L_{0} \longrightarrow L_{1} \longrightarrow \cdots \longrightarrow L_{n}
$$

of morphisms between algebraic stacks over $\mathbb{k}$.

- Now, denote $X_{n}:=L_{n}$, and for each $0<i<n$, inductively denote the derived intersection $X_{i}:=L_{i} \times_{X_{i+1}} L_{i}$.
- $L_{n}$ is equipped with an $n$-shifted structure.
- For each $0 \leq i<n$, the diagonal map

$$
L_{i-1} \longrightarrow L_{i} \underset{X_{i+1}}{\times} L_{i}
$$

is equipped with a Lagrangian structure.

# 3 

## Polyhedral products and features of their homotopy theory

Anthony Bahri, Martin Bendersky, and Frederick R. Cohen

### 3.1 Introduction

A polyhedral product is a natural topological subspace of a Cartesian product, determined by a simplicial complex $K$ and a family of pointed pairs of spaces $\left(X_{i}, A_{i}\right)$, one for each vertex of $K$. As noted in [126], in the special case that $A_{i}$ is a basepoint for $X_{i}$, the polyhedral product mediates between the product $X_{1} \times X_{2} \times \cdots \times X_{m}$ when $K$ is the full $(m-1)$-simplex, and the wedge $X_{1} \vee X_{2} \vee \cdots \vee X_{m}$ when $K$ consists of $m$ discrete points.

We begin with a brief historical note. The development of the theory of polyhedral products was guided by their inextricable link to spaces known as moment-angle manifolds which arose within the subject of toric topology. This subject, which incorporates ideas from geometry, symplectic geometry, combinatorics and commutative algebra, has now swelled well beyond its original confines as a topological generalization of toric geometry.

Toric topology has precipitated investigations into new areas of manifold and orbifold theory, centered around toric actions, $[53,38,40,61,10,69,75,48,112,93,21,20]$, and the unpublished notes of N. Strickland, [123]. An excellent overview by V. Buchstaber and N. Ray is to be found in [41].

The study of polyhedral products in particular has matured to the point that it extends now into a wide variety of fields of mathematics distant from its origin, as detailed in the table below. Consequently, the development of their homotopy theory has become useful in this context.

In order to be more specific, it is now necessary to give a definition. Begin by setting $[m]=\{1,2, \ldots, m\}$ and define a category $\mathcal{C}([\boldsymbol{m}])$ whose objects are pairs $(\underline{X}, \underline{A})$ where

$$
(\underline{X}, \underline{A})=\left\{\left(X_{1}, A_{1}\right),\left(X_{2}, A_{2}\right), \ldots,\left(X_{m}, A_{m}\right)\right\}
$$

is a family of based CW-pairs. A morphism

$$
\underline{f}:(\underline{X}, \underline{A}) \longrightarrow(\underline{Y}, \underline{B})
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    2010 Mathematics Subject Classification. primary: 55P42, 55Q15, 52C35, 52B11, 35S22, 13F55. secondary: 14M25, 14F45, 55U10, 55R20, 55N10.
    Key words and phrases. polyhedral product, moment-angle complex, cohomology, arrangements, stable splitting, simplicial wedge, Davis-Januszkiewicz space, Golodness, monomial ideal ring.

consists of $m$ continuous maps $f_{i}: X_{i} \longrightarrow Y_{i}$ satisfying $f_{i}\left(A_{i}\right) \subset B_{i}$. Next, let $K$ be a simplicial complex on the vertex set $[m]$. We consider $K$ to be a category where the objects are the simplices of $K$ and the morphisms $d_{\sigma, \tau}$ are the inclusions $\sigma \subset \tau$.

Definition 3.1.1. Let $K$ be a simplicial complex on the vertex set $[m]$ as above. A polyhedral product is a functor $Z(K ;-): \mathcal{C}([m]) \longrightarrow$ Top satisfying

$$
Z(K ;(\underline{X}, \underline{A})) \subseteq \prod_{i=1}^{m} X_{i}
$$

that is given as the colimit of a diagram $D: K \rightarrow C W_{*}$, where at each $\sigma \in K$, we set

$$
D(\sigma)=\prod_{i=1}^{m} W_{i}, \quad \text { where } \quad W_{i}=\left\{\begin{array}{lll}
X_{i} & \text { if } & i \in \sigma \\
A_{i} & \text { if } & i \in[m]-\sigma
\end{array}\right.
$$

Though here, the colimit is a union given by

$$
Z(K ;(\underline{X}, \underline{A}))=\bigcup_{\sigma \in K} D(\sigma)
$$

the full colimit structure is used heavily in the development of the elementary theory of polyhedral products. Notice that when $\sigma \subset \tau$ then $D(\sigma) \subseteq D(\tau)$. In the case that $K$ itself is a simplex,

$$
Z(K ;(\underline{X}, \underline{A}))=\prod_{i=1}^{m} X_{i}
$$

Remark 3.1.2. When all the pairs $\left(X_{i}, A_{i}\right)$ are the same pair $(X, A)$, the family $(\underline{X}, \underline{A})$ is written simply as $(X, A)$. Notice that in this case $\operatorname{Aut}(K)$ acts naturally on $Z(K ;(X, A))$.

In a way entirely similar to that above, a related space $\widehat{Z}(K ;(\underline{X}, \underline{A}))$, called the smash polyhedral product, is defined by replacing the Cartesian product everywhere in Definition 3.1.1 by the smash product. That is,

$$
\widehat{D}(\sigma)=\bigwedge_{i=1}^{m} W_{i} \quad \text { and } \quad \widehat{Z}(K ;(\underline{X}, \underline{A}))=\bigcup_{\sigma \in K} \widehat{D}(\sigma)
$$

with

$$
\widehat{Z}(K ;(\underline{X}, \underline{A})) \subseteq \bigwedge_{i=1}^{m} X_{i}
$$

Polyhedral products generalize the spaces called moment-angle complexes which were developed by V. Buchstaber and T. Panov [37] and correspond to the case

$$
\left(X_{i}, A_{i}\right)=\left(D^{2}, S^{1}\right), \quad i=1,2, \ldots, m
$$

As mentioned above, the construction of moment-angle complexes originated within the subject of toric topology. Specifically, M. Davis and T. Januszkiewicz [53] constructed spaces $\mathcal{Z}$ as quotients of a product of an $m$-dimensional torus and an $n$-dimensional polytope that

is simple, meaning that it satisfies a certain homogeneity condition. (See Section 3.2.) They were able to realize a class of toric manifolds as quotients of $\mathcal{Z}$ by free torus actions. The space $\mathcal{Z}$ was then reformulated as a moment-angle manifold by V. Buchstaber and T. Panov [37].

The moment-angle complex construction (3.3.2) was extended to pairs $(X, A)$ replacing $\left(D^{2}, S^{1}\right)$ by V. Buchstaber and T. Panov [37], N. Strickland (unpublished), V. Baskakov [23], G. Denham and A. Suciu [56] and T. Panov [109]. The construction in the generality of Definition 3.1.1 appeared in [11].

The table below lists a selection of current applications of polyhedral products.

| $(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{A})$ | $\boldsymbol{Z}(\boldsymbol{K} ;(\boldsymbol{X}, \boldsymbol{A}))$ |
| :-- | :-- |
| $\left(D^{2}, S^{1}\right)$ | toric geometry and topology, arachnid mechanisms |
| $\left(D^{1}, S^{0}\right)$ | surfaces, number theory, representation theory, linear programming |
| $\left(S^{1}, *\right)$ | right-angled Artin groups, robotics |
| $\left(\mathbb{RP}^{\infty}, *\right)$ | right-angled Coxeter groups |
| $\left(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C}^{*}\right)$ | complements of coordinate arrangements |
| $\left(\mathbb{R}^{n},\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)^{*}\right)$ | complements of certain non-coordinate arrangements |
| $\left(\mathbb{C P}^{\infty}, \mathbb{C P}^{k}\right)$ | monomial ideal rings |
| $(\underline{E G}, \underline{G})$ | free groups and monodromy |
| $(\underline{B G}, \star)$ | combinatorics, aspherical spaces |
| $(\underline{P X}, \underline{\Omega X})$ | homotopy theory, Whitehead products |
| $\left(S^{2 k+1}, *\right)$ | graph products, quadratic algebras |

By way of motivation, we illustrate the Hopf map and the Whitehead product from the point of view of polyhedral products. The 3 -sphere $S^{3}$ is realized as a polyhedral product by taking $K$ to be the simplicial complex consisting of two discrete points,

$$
\partial\left(D^{2} \times D^{2}\right) \cong S^{1} \times D^{2} \cup_{S^{1} \times S^{1}} D^{2} \times S^{1}=Z\left(K ;\left(D^{2}, S^{1}\right)\right) \subset D^{2} \times D^{2} \subset \mathbb{C} \times \mathbb{C}
$$

The action of the compact two-torus $T^{2}$ on the product $D^{2} \times D^{2}$ leaves invariant the component pieces: $S^{1} \times D^{2}, S^{1} \times S^{1}$ and $D^{2} \times S^{1}$, which comprise the basic building blocks of the polyhedral product, moment-angle complex, structure in this case. The Hopf map

$$
S^{3} \simeq S^{1} \times D^{2} \cup_{S^{1} \times S^{1}} D^{2} \times S^{1} \longrightarrow D^{2} \cup_{S^{1}} D^{2} \simeq S^{2}
$$

is the quotient by the diagonal subgroup $S^{1}$ in $T^{2}$ acting in a natural way.
Consider next the Whitehead product $[f, g]$ defined by

$$
S^{3} \xrightarrow{\omega} S_{\alpha}^{2} \vee S_{\beta}^{2} \xrightarrow{f \vee g} X
$$

where $\omega$ is a map attaching the top cell of $S^{2} \times S^{2}$ and $f: S_{\alpha}^{2} \longrightarrow X$ and $g: S_{\beta}^{2} \longrightarrow X$ are two basepoint preserving maps, [74, page 381]. The particular case $X=S_{\alpha}^{2} \vee S_{\beta}^{2}$ and $f=\iota_{\alpha}, g=\iota_{\beta}$, being the respective inclusions of $S_{\alpha}^{2}$ and $S_{\beta}^{2}$ into $S_{\alpha}^{2} \vee S_{\beta}^{2}$, gives the Whitehead product $\left[\iota_{\alpha}, \iota_{\beta}\right]$. (Note here that $\iota_{\alpha} \vee \iota_{\beta}$ is the identity map.) From the point of

view of polyhedral products ${ }^{1},\left[\iota_{\alpha}, \iota_{\beta}\right]$ is induced by the map of pairs $\left(D^{2}, S^{1}\right) \longrightarrow\left(S^{2}, *\right)$ that collapses $S^{1} \subset D^{2}$ to a point,

$$
S^{3} \simeq D_{\alpha}^{2} \times S_{\beta}^{1} \cup_{S_{\alpha}^{1} \times S_{\beta}^{1}} S_{\alpha}^{1} \times D_{\beta}^{2} \longrightarrow\left(S_{\alpha}^{2} \times *\right) \cup_{* \times *}\left(* \times S_{\beta}^{2}\right) \simeq S_{\alpha}^{2} \vee S_{\beta}^{2}
$$

Here, the space on the right-hand side is the polyhedral product $Z\left(K ;\left(\underline{S}^{2}, *\right)\right)$ where again, $K$ consists of two discrete points. Within this subject, wedge products appear often, thus Whitehead products appear in profusion. These topics are discussed in more detail in Section 3.14.

# Organization 

This paper is organized as follows. A brief technical discussion of the origin of polyhedral products as moment-angle complexes in Sections 3.2 and 3.3, includes the original topological construction of toric manifolds by M. Davis and T. Januszkiewicz [53] and the reformulation of one of their main spaces as a moment-angle complex by V. Buchstaber and T. Panov $[37,38]$.

A discussion follows in Section 3.4 about the independent discovery of moment-angle complexes as intersections of certain quadrics. We describe briefly the work of S. López de Medrano [100], S. López de Medrano and A. Verjovsky [101], F. Bosio and L. Meersseman [31], followed by that of S. López de Medrano and S. Gitler [65]. This approach has proved effective in identifying classes of moment-angle manifolds that are connected sums of products of spheres. This is followed in Section 3.5 by a sketch of the computation of the cohomology ring of moment-angle complexes.

We begin our focus on more general polyhedral products in Section 3.6, by describing their behaviour with respect to the exponentiation of CW-pairs. This has led to an application to the study of toric manifolds [58, 128, 129, 124, 71, 68, 47], and orbifolds [19]. An application to topological joins is included as an example of the utility of this property with respect to exponentiation.

The behaviour of polyhedral products with respect to fibrations, due to G. Denham and A. Suciu [56], is surveyed briefly in Section 3.7. We take advantage of the formalism to describe briefly the early work in this area by G. Porter [117, 118], T. Ganea [64] and A. Kurosh [92]. and G. W. Whitehead. Instances of polyhedral products appear also in the work of D. Anick [6].

In Section 3.8, we review the various fundamental unstable and stable splitting theorems for the polyhedral product. These theorems give access to the homotopy type of the polyhedral product in many of the most important cases and drive a number of applications. The identification of the various wedge summands which appear in the stable decompositions, occupies the second part of this section.

A fine theorem of A. Al-Raisi [3] shows that, in certain cases, the stable splitting of the polyhedral product can be chosen to be equivariant with respect to the action of $\operatorname{Aut}(K)$. This and other related results, described in Section 3.9, represent the first foray of the
