We use the latter model in the next section, when we explain a graph complex description of the rational homotopy type of mapping spaces of $E_{n}$-operads.

In order to apply the methods of rational homotopy theory, we take $\mathbb{k}=\mathbb{Q}$ as a ground ring for our categories of modules from now on, and we also consider the cohomology with coefficients in this field $\mathrm{H}^{*}(-)=\mathrm{H}^{*}(-, \mathbb{Q})$. We similarly take $\mathrm{H}_{*}(-)=\mathrm{H}_{*}(-, \mathbb{Q})$ for the homology.

# 11.2.1 Recollections on the Sullivan rational homotopy theory of spaces 

Recall that we call 'upper graded dg-module' the structure formed by a module $M$ equipped with a decomposition such that $M=\bigoplus_{n \in \mathbb{Z}} M^{n}$ and with a differential $\delta: M \rightarrow M$ such that $\delta\left(M^{*-1}\right) \subset M^{*}$. We say that such a dg-module $M$ is nonnegatively graded when we have $M^{n}=0$ for $n<0$. Let $d g^{*} \mathcal{C} o m$ be the category of commutative algebras in upper nonnegatively graded dg-modules (the category of commutative cochain dg-algebras for short). The Sullivan model for the rational homotopy of a space takes values in this category $d g^{*} \mathcal{C} o m$ and is obtained by applying the Sullivan functor of PL differential forms, a version of the de Rham cochain complex that is defined over $\mathbb{Q}$ (instead of $\mathbb{R}$ ) and on the category of simplicial complexes (or simplicial sets), instead of the category of smooth manifolds (see [52]). For our purpose, we consider the simplicial set variant of this functor:

$$
\mathfrak{a}^{*}: s \mathcal{S} e t^{o p} \rightarrow d g^{*} \mathcal{C} o m
$$

In the particular case of a simplex $\Delta^{n}=\left\{0 \leq x_{1} \leq \cdots \leq x_{n} \leq 1\right\}$, we explicitly have:

$$
\Omega^{*}\left(\Delta^{n}\right)=\mathbb{Q}\left[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}, d x_{1}, \ldots, d x_{n}\right]
$$

where $d x_{1}, \ldots, d x_{n}$ represents the differential of the variables $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}$ in this commutative cochain dg-algebra.

The Sullivan functor $\Omega^{*}: s \mathcal{S e t}^{o p} \rightarrow d g^{*} \mathcal{C o m}$ has a left adjoint

$$
\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}: d g^{*} \mathcal{C} o m \rightarrow s \mathcal{S e t}^{o p}
$$

which is given by the formula $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(A)=\operatorname{Mor}_{d g^{*}} \mathcal{C o m}\left(A, \Omega^{*}\left(\Delta^{\bullet}\right)\right)$, for any commutative cochain dg-algebra $A \in d g^{*} \mathcal{C}$ om, and this pair of adjoint functors $\left(\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}, \Omega\right)$ defines a Quillen adjunction. (We refer to [12] for this application of the formalism of model categories to Sullivan's constructions.) Then we set:

$$
\langle A\rangle:=\text { derived functor of } \mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(A)=\operatorname{Mor}_{d g^{*}} \mathcal{C o m}\left(R_{A}, \Omega^{*}\left(\Delta^{\bullet}\right)\right)
$$

where $R_{A} \xrightarrow{\sim} A$ is any cofibrant resolution of $A$ in $d g^{*} \mathcal{C o m}$. If $X$ satisfies reasonable finiteness and nilpotence assumptions, then the space

$$
X^{\mathbb{Q}}:=\left\langle\Omega^{*}(X)\right\rangle
$$

defines a rationalization of the space $X$ in the sense that we have the identities

$$
\pi_{*}\left(X^{\mathbb{Q}}\right):= \begin{cases}\pi_{*}(X) \otimes_{\mathbb{Z}} \mathbb{Q}, & \text { for } * \geq 2 \\ \pi_{1}(X)_{\mathbb{Q}}, & \text { for } *=1\end{cases}
$$

where we again use the notation $(-)_{\mathbb{Q}}^{*}$ for the Malcev completion functor on groups. Besides, one can prove that the unit of the derived adjunction relation between the functors $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}$ and $\Omega^{*}$ defines a map $\eta: X \rightarrow X^{\mathbb{Q}}$ which corresponds to the usual rationalization map at the level of these homotopy groups.

# 11.2.2 The category of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads 

To extend the Sullivan model to operads, the idea is to consider cooperads in the category of commutative cochain dg-algebras, where a cooperad is a structure that is dual to an operad in the sense of the theory of categories.

In general, a cooperad in a symmetric category $\mathcal{C}$ consists of a collection of objects $C=\{C(r), r \in \mathbb{N}\}$, together with an action of the symmetric group $\Sigma_{r}$ on $C(r)$, for each $r \in \mathbb{N}$, and composition coproducts

$$
\circ_{i}^{*}: C(k+l-1) \rightarrow C(k) \otimes C(l)
$$

defined for all $k, l \in \mathbb{N}, i \in\{1, \ldots, k\}$, and which satisfy equivariance, unit and coassociativity relations dual to the equivariance, unit and coassociativity axioms of operads. To handle difficulties, we consider a subcategory of cooperads such that $C(0)=C(1)=\mathbb{1}$ where $\mathbb{1}$

is the unit object of our base category, and we use the notation $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$ for this category of cooperads. This restriction enables us to simplify some constructions, because the composition coproducts are automatically conilpotent when we put the component of arity zero apart and we assume $C(1)=\mathbb{1}$. In some cases, we consider a category of cooperads $\mathcal{O} p_{* N}^{c}$ such that we still have $C(0)=\mathbb{1}$, but where $C(1)$ may not reduce to the unit object. More care is necessary in this case, and we actually assume an extra conilpotence condition for the composition coproducts that involve the component of arity one. (We refer to [27] for the precise expression of this conilpotence condition.)

In [26, §II.12] the author considers a category of $\Lambda$-cooperads, whose objects have no term in arity zero, but a diagram structure over the category of finite ordinals and injective maps that extends the action of the symmetric groups on ordinary operads. This category of $\Lambda$-cooperads is isomorphic to the category of cooperads that we consider in this paragraph $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$, so that the results of this reference [26] can immediately be transposed to our setting. (The structure of a $\Lambda$-cooperad is used to overcome technical difficulties that occurs in the construction of the Sullivan model of operads, but we can neglect these issues in this overview.)

We use the name 'Hopf cochain dg-cooperad' for the category of cooperads in the category of commutative cochain dg-algebras $\mathcal{C}=d g^{*} \mathcal{C} o m$ and we also adopt the notation $d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$ for this category of cooperads. We also consider a category of operads in simplicial sets satisfying $P(0)=P(1)=*$ in order to deal with the restrictions imposed by the definition of our category of cooperads in our model. We use the notation $s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}$ for this category of operads. We have the following statement:

Theorem 11.2.1 (B. Fresse [26, §II.10, §II.12]).

- The letf adjoint of the Sullivan functor $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}: d g^{*} \mathcal{C o m} \rightarrow s \mathcal{S}$ et $^{o p}$ induces a functor $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}: d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c} \rightarrow s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{o p}$ from the category of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads $d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$ to the category of operads in simplicial sets $s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{o p}$. For an object $A \in d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$, we set

$$
\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(A)(r)=\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(A(r))
$$

and we use the fact that $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(-)$ is strongly symmetric monoidal to equip the collection of these simplicial sets $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(A)=\left\{\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(A(r)), r \in \mathbb{N}\right\}$ with the structure of an operad.

- This functor $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}: d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c} \rightarrow s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{o p}$ admits a right adjoint

$$
\mathrm{G}_{\sharp}^{*}: s \mathcal{S} e t \mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{o p} \rightarrow d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}
$$

and the pair of functors $\left(\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}, \mathrm{G}_{\sharp}^{*}\right)$ defines a Quillen adjunction.

- For a cofibrant operad $P \in s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}$ such that $\mathrm{H}^{*}(P(r))$ forms a finite dimensional $\mathbb{Q}$-module in each arity $r \in \mathbb{N}$ and in each degree $* \in \mathbb{N}$, we have a weak equivalence

$$
\mathrm{G}_{\sharp}^{*}(P)(r) \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathrm{G}^{*}(P(r))
$$

between the component of arity $r$ of the Hopf cochain dg-cooperad $\mathrm{G}_{\sharp}^{*}(P) \in d g^{*} \mathcal{H}$ opf $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$ and the image of the space $P(r)$ under the Sullivan functor $\Omega^{*}(-)$, for any $r \in \mathbb{N}$.

The first claim of this theorem follows from the observation that the functor $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(-)$ is strongly symmetric monoidal. The functor $\Omega^{*}(-)$, on the other hand, is only weakly monoidal. To be more precise, in the case of this functor, we have a Künneth morphism $\nabla: \Omega^{*}(X) \otimes \Omega^{*}(Y) \rightarrow \Omega^{*}(X \times Y)$ which is a quasi-isomorphism but not an isomorphism. Hence, for an operad in simplicial sets $P$, we only get that the composition product $\circ_{i}$ : $P(k) \times P(l) \rightarrow P(k+l-1)$ induces a morphism that fits in a zigzag of morphisms of commutative cochain dg-algebras $\Omega^{*}(P(k+l-1)) \stackrel{\circ_{i}^{*}}{\rightarrow} \Omega^{*}(P(k) \times P(l)) \stackrel{\sim}{\leftarrow} \Omega^{*}(P(k)) \otimes \Omega^{*}(P(l))$. The idea is to use the adjoint lifting theorem (see for instance [11, §4.5]) to produce the functor of the second claim of the theorem $\Omega_{2}^{*}: s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow d g^{*} \mathcal{H}$ opf $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$ and to fix this problem. Then the crux lies in the verification of the third claim, for which we refer to the cited reference.

For an operad in simplicial sets $P \in s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}$, we now set :

$$
P^{\mathbb{Q}}:=\left\langle\mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}(P)\right\rangle
$$

where we use the notation $\mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}(-)$ for the right derived functor of the functor of the previous theorem $\Omega_{2}^{*}: s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow d g^{*} \mathcal{H}$ opf $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$, and we again use the notation $\langle-\rangle$ for the left derived functor of the Sullivan realization on operads $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}: d g^{*} \mathcal{H}$ opf $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c} \rightarrow s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{\text {op }}$. The equivalence $\Omega_{2}^{*}(P)(r) \sim \Omega^{*}(P(r))$ implies that we have the following result at the level of this realization:

Theorem 11.2.2 (B. Fresse [26, Theorem II.10.2.1 and Theorem II.12.2.1]). For any operad $P \in s \mathcal{S}$ et $\mathcal{O} p_{* 1}$ such that $\mathrm{H}^{*}(P(r))=\mathrm{H}^{*}(P(r), \mathbb{Q})$ forms a finite dimensional $\mathbb{Q}$-module in each arity $r \in \mathbb{N}$ and in each degree $* \in \mathbb{N}$, we have:

$$
P^{\mathbb{Q}}(r) \sim P(r)^{\mathbb{Q}}
$$

where we consider the component of arity $r$ of the operad $P^{\mathbb{Q}}$ on the left-hand side and the Sullivan rationalization of the space $P(r)$ on the right-hand side.

For the operad of little $n$-discs $D_{n}$, we now set $\mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)=\Omega_{2}^{*}\left(E_{n}\right)$, where $E_{n}$ is any cofibrant model of $E_{n}$-operad in simplicial sets such that $E_{n}(0)=E_{n}(1)=*$, and we still write $D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}=\left\langle\mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)\right\rangle$. To apply the rational homotopy theory to the class of $E_{n}$-operads, we aim to determine the model of these objects $\mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)$.

Recall that we have a homotopy equivalence $D_{n}(r) \sim F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right)$ between the underlying spaces of the operad of little $n$-discs $D_{n}(r)$ and the configuration spaces of the Euclidean space $F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right)$. (In $\S 11.1 .1$, we use an equivalent homotopy equivalence $D_{n}(r) \sim F\left(\overline{\mathbb{D}}^{n}, r\right)$, where we take the open disc $\overline{\mathbb{D}}^{n} \cong \mathbb{R}^{n}$ rather than the Euclidean spaces $\mathbb{R}^{n}$.) In a first step, we recall the following result about the cohomology algebras of these spaces:

Theorem 11.2.3 (V.I. Arnold [2], F. Cohen [20]). Let $n \geq 2$. For each $r \in \mathbb{N}$, the graded commutative algebra $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(r)\right) \simeq \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right)\right)$ has a presentation of the form:

$$
\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right)\right)=\frac{\bigwedge\left(\omega_{i j}, 1 \leq i<j \leq r\right)}{\left(\omega_{i j}^{2}, \omega_{i j} \omega_{i k}-\omega_{i j} \omega_{j k}+\omega_{i k} \omega_{j k}\right)}
$$

where the elements $\omega_{i j}$ correspond to cohomology classes of degree $n-1$.

In the expression of this theorem, the notation $\bigwedge(-)$ represents the free graded commutative algebra generated by the variables $\omega_{i j}$. The result established by V.I. Arnold in [2] concerns the case $n=2$ of this statement. The already cited work of F. Cohen [20] gives the general case $n \geq 2$. We also refer to Sinha's survey [51] for a gentle introduction to the computation of this theorem. The classes $\omega_{i j} \in \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right)\right)$ represent the pullbacks of the fundamental class of the $n-1$-sphere $\omega \in \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(\mathbb{S}^{n-1}\right)$ under the maps $\pi_{i j}: F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right) \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{n-1}$ such that $\pi_{i j}\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{r}\right)=\left(a_{j}-a_{i}\right) /\left\|a_{j}-a_{i}\right\|$. We can also consider unordered pairs $\{i, j\}$ in this definition. We just have $\omega_{i j}=(-1)^{n} \omega_{j i}$ in this case, since $\omega_{i j}$ corresponds to the image of $\omega_{j i}$ under the action of the antipodal map on the sphere. In what follows, we refer to these cohomology classes $\omega_{i j}$ as the Arnold classes, we refer to the identity $\omega_{i j} \omega_{i k}-\omega_{i j} \omega_{j k}+\omega_{i k} \omega_{j k}=0$ as the Arnold relation, and we refer to the presentation of the above theorem as the Arnold presentation.

The homology of the operad $D_{n}$ now inherits the structure of an operad in graded modules. The cohomology $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)$ inherits a dual cooperad structure, because the homology of the spaces $D_{n}(r)$ has a finite dimension as a $\mathbb{Q}$-module in each arity and in each degree, so that we have the arity-wise duality relation $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(r)\right)=\operatorname{Hom}_{g r} \mathcal{M o d}\left(\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}(r)\right), \mathbb{Q}\right)$ in the category of graded modules. Note that we have $D_{n}(0)=* \Rightarrow \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(0)\right)=\mathbb{Q}$ and $D_{n}(1) \sim * \Rightarrow \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(1)\right)=\mathbb{Q}$, so that the collection $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)=\left\{\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(r), r \in \mathbb{N}\right\}\right.$ satisfies our connectedness condition in the definition of a cooperad. One can easily check that this cooperad structure is compatible with the graded commutative algebra structure of the cohomology, so that the object $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)$ actually forms a Hopf cooperad in the category of graded modules.

We aim to determine this cooperad structure. We use the following identity, already mentioned in the introduction of this chapter:

Theorem 11.2.4 (F. Cohen [20]). For $n \geq 2$, we have an isomorphism of operads in graded modules $\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}\right) \simeq$ Pois $_{n}$, where Pois $_{n}$ is the operad that governs the category of $n$-Poisson algebras.

Recall that the structure of an $n$-Poisson algebra refers to a graded version of Poisson structure where we have a commutative product $\mu\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=x_{1} x_{2}$ of degree 0 and a Poisson bracket $\lambda\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\left[x_{1}, x_{2}\right]$ of degree $n-1$. This Poisson bracket satisfies the symmetry relation $\lambda\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=(-1)^{n} \lambda\left(x_{2}, x_{1}\right)$, a graded version of the Jacobi identity and of the Poisson distribution relation. The $n$-Poisson operad $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}$ is defined by the corresponding presentation by generators and relations in the category of operads. Equivalently, we can represent an element of the graded module $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}(r)$ as a Poisson polynomial $\pi=\pi\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\right)$ of degree one in each variable $x_{i}$.

For our purpose, we actually consider a unitary version of the $n$-Poisson operad, where we have an extra arity zero operation $e \in \operatorname{Pois}(0)$ such that $\mu \circ_{1} e=1=\mu \circ_{2} e$ and $\lambda \circ_{1} e=0=\lambda \circ_{2} e$. This operation corresponds to a unit in the structure of an $n$-Poisson algebra and reflects the identity $D_{n}(0)=*$ at the level of the topological operad $D_{n}$.

We get the following result when we pass to the cohomology:
Proposition 11.2.5. The cohomology algebras $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(r)\right), r \in \mathbb{N}$, form a Hopf cooperad in graded modules such that $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right) \cong$ Pois $_{n}^{c}$, where Pois ${ }_{n}^{c}$ denotes the cooperad dual to Pois $_{n}$ in graded modules.

The $n$-Poisson cooperad $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}$ is explicitly defined by taking the dual graded modules of the components of the $n$-Poisson operad $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}(r)=\operatorname{Hom}_{\text {gr } \mathcal{M o d}}\left(\operatorname{Pois}_{n}(r), \mathbb{Q}\right)$. We take the adjoint morphisms of the composition products of the $n$-Poisson operad to provide this collection of graded modules $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}(r)$ with a cooperad structure. Therefore, the relation of this proposition $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right) \cong \operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}$ follows from the result of the previous theorem $\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}\right) \cong \operatorname{Pois}_{n}$ and the duality between the homology and the cohomology $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(r)\right)=\operatorname{Hom}_{\text {gr } \mathcal{M o d}}\left(\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}(r)\right), \mathbb{Q}\right)$.

Let $\langle-,-\rangle: \operatorname{Pois}_{n}(r) \otimes \mathrm{H}^{*}(D(r)) \rightarrow \mathbb{Q}$ denote the duality pairing that we obtain by using this relation $\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}\right) \cong \operatorname{Pois}_{n}$. For a Poisson monomial $\pi\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\right) \in \operatorname{Pois}_{n}(r)$, we have the formula:

$$
\left\langle\omega_{i j}, \pi\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\right)\right\rangle= \begin{cases}1, & \text { if } \pi\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\right)=x_{1} \cdots\left[x_{i}, x_{j}\right] \cdots \widehat{x_{j}} \cdots x_{r} \\ 0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

where we consider the generating classes $\omega_{i j} \in \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right)\right)=\mathrm{H}^{*}(D(r))$ of the Arnold presentation of Theorem 11.2.3. This duality relation is immediate in arity 2, because the Poisson bracket operation $\lambda=\lambda\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ corresponds to the fundamental class of the $n-1$ sphere in the homology of $D_{n}(2)$, where we use the relation $D_{n}(2) \sim F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right) \sim \mathbb{S}^{n-1}$. The general formula follows from the fact that the maps $\pi_{i j}: F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right) \rightarrow F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, 2\right)$ in the definition of the classes $\omega_{i j}$ correspond to composites with the zero-ary operation $* \in D_{n}(0)$, which represents our algebra unit $e \in \operatorname{Pois}_{n}(0)$ when we pass to the $n$-Poisson operad $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}$. We refer to the paper [51] for a more thorough study of this duality relation between the $n$ Poisson polynomials and the elements of the cohomology algebras $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(r)\right)=\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(F\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}, r\right)\right)$ in the Arnold presentation.

We can now regard the object $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c} \simeq \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)$ as a Hopf cochain dg-cooperad equipped with a trivial differential. We have to make explicit a cofibrant resolution of this object for the applications of our methods of the rational homotopy theory of operads. In the next paragraphs, we explain a first definition of such a resolution by using graded analogues of the Drinfeld-Kohno Lie algebra operad of the previous section.

# 11.2.3 The graded Drinfeld-Kohno Lie algebra operads and the associated Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain complexes 

The graded analogues of the Drinfeld-Kohno Lie algebra operad, which we define for every value of the parameter $n \geq 2$, are denoted by $\mathfrak{p}_{n}$. The ungraded Drinfeld-Kohno Lie algebra operad of $\S 11.1 .4$ corresponds to the case $n=2$. Thus, we have $\mathfrak{p}=\mathfrak{p}_{2}$ with the notation of $\S 11.1 .4$.

To define the Lie algebras $\mathfrak{p}_{n}(r)$, we use the same presentation as in Eqn. 11.1.21:

$$
\mathfrak{p}_{n}(r)=\mathbb{L}\left(t_{i j},\{i, j\} \subset\{1, \ldots, r\}\right) /<\left[t_{i j}, t_{k l}\right],\left[t_{i j}, t_{i k}+t_{j k}\right]>
$$

but we now take $\operatorname{deg}\left(t_{i j}\right)=n-2$ and we assume the graded symmetry relation $t_{j i}=(-1)^{n} t_{i j}$, for every pair $\{i, j\} \subset\{1, \ldots, r\}$. Then we take the same construction as in $\S 11.1 .4$ to provide these Lie algebras with an action of the symmetric groups and with additive composition

products $\circ_{i}: \mathfrak{p}_{n}(k) \oplus \mathfrak{p}_{n}(l) \rightarrow \mathfrak{p}_{n}(k+l-1)$, so that the collection $\mathfrak{p}_{n}=\left\{\mathfrak{p}_{n}(r), r \in \mathbb{N}\right\}$ inherits the structure of an operad in the category of graded Lie algebras.

Note that the graded Lie algebras $\mathfrak{p}_{n}(r)$ still inherit a weight grading from the free Lie algebra, and hence, form weight graded objects in the category of graded modules. Besides, we can form a completed version of the operads $\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}$, as in the case $n=2$ in $\S 11.1 .4$, but for $n \geq 3$, we trivially have $\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}=\mathfrak{p}_{n}$ because the components of homogeneous weight $m \geq 1$ of the Lie algebras $\mathfrak{p}_{n}(r)$ are concentrated in a single degree $*=m(n-2)$ and we have $m(n-2) \rightarrow \infty$ when $n \geq 3$.

We consider the Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain complexes $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}(\hat{\mathfrak{g}})$ associated to the complete Lie algebras $\hat{\mathfrak{g}}=\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(r)$. The cofibrant objects of the category of commutative cochain dg-algebras are retracts of dg-algebras of the form $R=(\mathbb{S}(V), \partial)$, where $\mathbb{S}(V)$ is the symmetric algebra on an upper graded dg-module $V$ equipped with a filtration $\mathrm{F}_{1} V \subset \mathrm{~F}_{2} V \subset \cdots \supset \mathrm{~F}_{m} V \subset \cdots \subset V$ and where we have a differential $\partial$ such that $\partial\left(\mathrm{F}_{m} V\right) \subset \mathbb{S}\left(\mathrm{F}_{m-1} V\right)$. The Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain complex is precisely defined by an expression of this form $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}(\mathfrak{g})=\left(\mathbb{S}(\mathbb{Q}[-1] \otimes \hat{\mathfrak{g}}^{\vee}), \partial\right)$, where $\mathbb{Q}[-1]=\mathbb{Q}$ denotes the graded module generated by a single element in lower degree -1 (equivalently, in upper degree one) and $\hat{\mathfrak{g}}^{\vee}$ denotes the (continuous) dual of the completed Lie algebra $\hat{\mathfrak{g}}=\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(r)$. The differential $\partial$ is induced by the dual map of the Lie bracket $[-,-]$ on $\hat{\mathfrak{g}}$.

The commutative cochain dg-algebras $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(r)\right)$ inherit an action of the symmetric groups by functoriality of the Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain complex, as well as composition coproducts $\circ_{i}^{*}: \mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(k+l-1)\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(k)\right) \otimes \mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(l)\right)$, which are given by the composites of the morphisms $\circ_{i}^{*}: \mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(k+l-1)\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(k) \oplus \hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(l)\right)$ induced by the composition products of the operad $\mathfrak{p}_{n}$ with the Künneth isomorphisms $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(k) \oplus \hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(l)\right) \simeq$ $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(k)\right) \otimes \mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(l)\right)$. Hence, we get that the collection $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}\right)=\left\{\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(r)\right), r \in \mathbb{N}\right\}$ inherits the structure of a Hopf cochain dg-cooperad. In addition, one can prove that this Hopf cochain dg-cooperad is cofibrant (see [26, Theorem II.14.1.7]).

Then we have the following statement:
Theorem 11.2.6 (T. Kohno [40]). We have a quasi-isomorphism of commutative cochain dg-algebras

$$
\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(r)\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(F\left(\hat{\mathbb{D}}^{n}, r\right)\right)
$$

such that $t_{i j}^{\vee} \mapsto \omega_{i j}$ for each pair $\{i, j\} \subset\{1, \ldots, r\}$ and $p^{\vee} \mapsto 0$ when $p^{\vee}$ is the dual basis element of a homogeneous Lie polynomial $p \in \mathfrak{p}_{n}(r)_{m}$ of weight $m>1$.

The cited reference gives the case $n=2$ of this statement. The general result can be deduced from the observation that the cohomology algebra $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(F\left(\hat{\mathbb{D}}^{n}, r\right)\right.$ forms a Koszul algebra with the enveloping algebra of the Lie algebra $\mathfrak{p}_{n}(r)$ as dual associative algebra. We refer to [26, Theorem II.14.1.14] for further explanations on this approach.

Now we can easily check that the quasi-isomorphisms of this theorem preserve cooperad structures. Hence, we get the following statement:

Proposition 11.2.7. The quasi-isomorphisms of Theorem 11.2.6 define a weak equivalence of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads

$$
\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)=\text { Pois }_{n}^{\circ}
$$

where we regard the cohomology of the little n-discs operad $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)$ as a Hopf cochain dgcooperad equipped with a trivial differential.

We deduce from this proposition that the object $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}\right)$ defines a cofibrant resolution of the object $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}=\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)$ in the category of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads. In our constructions, we actually consider a second cofibrant resolution, which is given by a Hopf cochain dg-cooperad of graphs $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}$, and we explain the definition of this object in the next paragraph.

# 11.2.4 The graph cooperad 

The Hopf cochain dg-cooperad $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}$ precisely consists of graphs $\gamma \in \operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)$ with unnumbered internal vertices $\bullet$ and external vertices indexed by $1, \ldots, r$, as in the following picture:

$$
\gamma=\text { (1) (2) (3) }
$$

The degree of such a graph is determined by assuming that each internal vertex $\bullet$ contributes to the degree by $\operatorname{deg}(\bullet)=n$ and that each edge contributes to the degree by $\operatorname{deg}(-)=1-n$ (in the lower grading convention). Thus, we have $\operatorname{deg}(\gamma)=(1-n) v+n e$ (in the lower grading convention again), where $v$ denotes the number of internal vertices and $e$ denotes the number of edges in the graph $\gamma \in \operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)$. In fact, we can regard our graphs as tensor products of symbolic elements given by the internal vertices and by the edges of our objects. In particular, we assume that graphs equipped with odd symmetries vanish in $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)$. We also assume that each edge is oriented and that a reversal of orientation is equivalent to the multiplication by a sign $(-1)^{n}$ in $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)$. For our purpose, we allow graphs with double edges, but not loops (edges with the same origin and endpoint) and we assume that each internal vertex is at least trivalent though the latter conditions are not essential. Besides, we assume that each connected component of our graph contains at least one external vertex.

The differential of graphs is defined by contracting edges in order to merge internal vertices together or in order to merge internal vertices with external vertices, as shown schematically in the following picture:
![img-124.jpeg](img-124.jpeg)

For instance, we have the formula:

$$
\delta_{\text {(1) (2) (3) }}= \\
\text { (1) (2) (3) } \pm \text { (1) (2) (3) } \pm \text { (1) (2) (3) }
$$

in $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(3)$. The product is given by the amalgamated sum of graphs along external vertices. For instance, we have the formula:

$$
\text { (1) (2) (3) }=(1) \text { (2) (3) } \cdot \text { (1) (2) (3) }
$$

The cooperad coproduct $\circ_{i}^{*}: \operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(k+l-1) \rightarrow \operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(k) \otimes \operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(l)$, where we fix $k, l \in \mathbb{N}, i \in\{1, \ldots, k\}$, has the form $\circ_{i}^{*}(\gamma)=\sum_{\alpha \subset \gamma} \gamma / \alpha \otimes \alpha$, where the sum runs over all the subgraphs $\alpha \subset \gamma$ that contain the external vertices indexed by $i, \ldots, i+l-1$, and $\gamma / \alpha$ denotes the graph obtained by collapsing this subgraph to a single external vertex (which we index by $i$ in the result of the operation, while we shift the index of the vertices such that $j>i$ by $j \mapsto j-l+1$ ). Note that we have $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(1) \neq \mathbb{Q}$ in general, so that our object $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}$ belongs to the extended category of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads $d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* N}^{c}$ but not to the category of connected Hopf cochain dg-cooperads $d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* 1}^{c}$.

We easily see that the commutative cochain dg-algebras of graphs defined in this paragraph $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)$ have a structure of the form $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)=(\mathbb{S}(\mathbb{Q}[-1] \otimes \operatorname{ICGraphs}_{n}^{c}(r)), \partial)$ (like the Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain dg-algebras of the previous paragraph), where ICGraphs ${ }_{n}^{c}(r)$ is a complex of graphs which are connected when we remove the external vertices inside $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)$. (In what follows, we refer to such graphs as internally connected graphs.) We just perform an extra degree shift in the definition of this complex of internally connected graphs in order to get a $\mathbb{Q}[-1]$ factor on the generating dg-module of our symmetric algebra (as in the definition of the Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain complex of a Lie dg-algebra). We can actually use this expression to identify the object ICGraphs ${ }_{n}^{c}(r)$ with the dual of an $L_{\infty}$-algebra (a strongly homotopy Lie algebra). We can use this symmetric algebra structure $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)=\left(\mathbb{S}(\mathbb{Q}[-1] \otimes \operatorname{ICGraphs}_{n}^{c}(r)\right), \partial)$ to prove that $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}$ forms a cofibrant object in the category $d g^{*} \mathcal{H} o p f \mathcal{O} p_{* N}^{c}$, and we also have the following proposition:
Proposition 11.2.8 (M. Kontsevich [43]). We have a quasi-isomorphism of Hopf dgcooperads

$$
\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c} \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)=\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}
$$

that carries the graph $\gamma_{i j} \in \operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)$ with a single edge to the Arnold class $\omega_{i j}$ and that cancel the internally connected graphs with a nonempty set of internal vertices.

The assignment of this proposition determines the map $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r) \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(r)\right)$ as a morphism of graded commutative algebras since the internally connected graphs generate the object $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r)$ as a graded commutative algebra. (Note that the graphs $\gamma_{i j}$ of the proposition represent the internally connected graphs with an empty set of internal vertices.) We just check that this map preserves differentials (and hence, gives a well-defined morphism of commutative cochain dg-algebras in each arity $r \in \mathbb{N}$ ), as well as the cooperad structures, so that our collection of maps define a morphism of Hopf dg-cooperads. We refer to the cited reference [43] and to [46] for a proof that this morphism defines a quasi-isomorphism. Observe simply that the differential identity of Eqn. 11.2.11 is carried to the Arnold relation in $\mathrm{H}^{*}\left(D_{n}(3)\right)$.

Recall that we set $\mathrm{RG}_{\sharp}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)=\mathrm{G}_{\sharp}^{*}\left(E_{n}\right)$ for the topological operad of little $n$-discs $D_{n}$, where $E_{n}$ is any cofibrant model of $E_{n}$-operad in simplicial sets such that $E_{n}(0)=E_{n}(1)=*$. We have the following result:

Theorem 11.2.9 (B. Fresse and T. Willwacher [29, Theorem A’]). We have the relation

$$
\text { Pois }_{n}^{c} \sim \mathrm{RG}_{\sharp}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)
$$

in the category of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads.

This theorem asserts that the operad of little $n$-discs is formal in the sense of our operadic counterpart of the Sullivan rational homotopy theory of spaces. The cited reference [29, Theorem $\mathrm{A}^{\prime}$ ] proves an intrinsic formality theorem which implies this operadic formality result in the case $n \geq 3$. (In the next statement, we will explain that the case $n=2$ of this theorem follows from the existence of Drinfeld's associators.)

The result of this theorem can also be deduced from Kontsevich's proof of the formality of $E_{n}$-operads when we pass to real coefficients (see [43]). Indeed, the construction of Kontsevich can be used to define a collection of quasi-isomorphisms $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}(r) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \Omega_{s a}^{*}\left(F M_{n}(r)\right)$, where $F M_{n}$ is a model of $E_{n}$-operad given a real oriented analogue of the Fulton-MacPherson compactification of the configuration spaces (see [33]) and $\Omega_{s a}^{*}(-)$ denotes a cochain dgalgebra functor of semi-algebraic forms (see [36, 46]). One can observe that these morphisms can be associated to a strict morphism of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c} \xrightarrow{\sim} \Omega_{2}^{*}\left(F M_{n}\right)$ (by using a general coherence statement of [26, Proposition II.12.1.3]).

The approach of the cited reference [29] does not use this construction and gives a formality quasi-isomorphism that is defined over the rationals by using obstruction theory methods. The claim of this reference is that the $E_{n}$-operads are intrinsically rationally formal for $n \geq 3$ in the sense that every Hopf cochain dg-cooperad $A_{n}$ that satisfies $\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(A_{n}\right) \simeq \operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}$ and is equipped with an extra-involution operad $J: A_{n} \rightarrow A_{n}$ such that $J(\lambda)=-\lambda$ in the case $4 \mid n$ satisfies $A_{n} \sim \operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}$. We apply this claim to the Hopf cochain dg-cooperad $A_{n}=\mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)$ to get the statement of the theorem. We have an extension of this formality result for the morphisms $D_{m} \rightarrow D_{n}$ that link the operads of little discs when $n-m \geq 2$ (see $[29$, Theorem C]).

Recall that we set

$$
D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}:=\left\langle\mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)\right\rangle
$$

to define a model for the rationalization of the little $n$-discs operad in topological spaces. The result of the previous theorem has the following corollary:

Corollary 11.2.10. We have $D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}=\left\langle\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}\right\rangle$, for any $n \geq 2$, where we consider the image of the dual cooperad of the $n$-Poisson operad $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}$ under the operadic upgrading of the Sullivan realization functor $\langle-\rangle$.

We just use the implication $\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c} \sim \mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right) \Rightarrow\left\langle\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}\right\rangle \sim\left\langle\mathrm{R} \Omega_{2}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right)\right\rangle$ to get the result of this corollary. This result, together with the observations of Proposition 11.2.7 and Proposition 11.2.8, implies that we can take either $\left\langle\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}\right\rangle=\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}\left(\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}\right)\right)$ or $\left\langle\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}\right\rangle=\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}\left(\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}\right)$ to get a model of the rationalization $D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}$.

We have an identity $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}\left(\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(r)\right)\right)=\mathrm{MC}_{\bullet}\left(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(r)\right)$, for each $r \in \mathbb{N}$, where we consider a Maurer-Cartan space associated to the complete Lie algebra $\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}(r)$ (we review the definition of this construction in the next sections). Hence, the results of this section gives a simple algebraic model of the rational homotopy type of $E_{n}$-operads. In the case $n=2$, we have an identity $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}(\hat{\mathfrak{p}}) \sim \mathrm{B}\left(C D_{\mathbb{Q}}^{*}\right)$, where we consider the chord diagram operad of $\S 11.1 .5$ (recall also that we use the notation $\hat{\mathfrak{p}}=\hat{\mathfrak{p}}_{2}$ for the ungraded Drinfeld-Kohno Lie algebra operad which occurs in this case $n=2$ ). Thus, since we have on the other hand $D_{2}^{\mathbb{Q}}=\mathrm{B}\left(\operatorname{PaB}_{\mathbb{Q}}^{-}\right)$ (see $\S 11.1$ ), we can deduce the existence of a weak equivalence $D_{2}^{\mathbb{Q}} \sim\left\langle\operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}\right\rangle$ from the operadic interpretation of Drinfeld's associators given in $\S 11.1 .5$ (see [26, §II.14.2]).

We now examine a counterpart of the formality result of Theorem 11.2.9 in the category of dg-modules $d g^{*} \mathcal{M}$ od. We use the notation $\mathrm{C}_{*}(-)$ for both the singular complex functor from the category of topological spaces to the category of dg-modules and for the standard normalized chain complex functor on simplicial sets. These functors are lax symmetric monoidal and therefore carry operads in topological spaces (respectively, in simplicial sets) to operads in dg-modules. Furthermore, in the case of a cofibrant operad in simplicial sets $R$, we have the duality relation $\Omega_{\sharp}^{*}(R)^{\vee} \sim \mathrm{C}_{*}(R)$ in the category of dg-operads $d g \mathcal{O} p_{*}$ when we consider the dual in dg-modules of the Hopf cochain dg-cooperad $\Omega_{\sharp}^{*}(R)$ of Theorem 11.2.9. Therefore, the result of Theorem 11.2.9 implies the following statement, which was also obtained by the authors cited in this statement by other method:

Theorem 11.2.11 (D. Tamarkin [54], M. Kontsevich [43]). We have the relation

$$
\text { Pois }_{n} \sim \mathrm{C}_{*}\left(D_{n}\right)
$$

in the category of dg-operads.
This result is exactly the formality theorem mentioned in the introduction of this chapter for the class of $E_{n}$-operads in dg-modules. Tamarkin's proof of this theorem, which works in the case $n=2$, relies on the correspondence between formality equivalences and associators, whereas Kontsevich's proof, which works for every $n \geq 2$ but requires to pass to real coefficients, relies on the definition of semi-algebraic forms associated to graphs (as we explain in our survey of Theorem 11.2.9). In [9], Boavida and Horel have given a new proof of the formality result of this theorem by using a generalization of classical formality criterion of mixed Hodge theory in the context of operads (see also [48] for an application of this approach in the case $n=2$ ).

# 11.3 The rational homotopy of mapping spaces on the operads of little discs 

We now tackle the main objective of this chapter, namely the computation of the homotopy of the mapping spaces $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op } \mathcal{O}_{p}}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$ and of the homotopy automorphism spaces $\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathcal{O}_{p}}^{h}\left(D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$, for all $n \geq 2$. Thus, we aim to generalize the computation carried out in $\S 11.1$ in the case of the automorphism space $\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathcal{O}_{p}}^{h}\left(D_{2}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$. In the case of the mapping spaces $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op } \mathcal{O}_{p}}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$, we are also going to check that we have the relation $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op } \mathcal{O}_{p}}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right) \sim \operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op } \mathcal{O}_{p}}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}\right)^{\mathbb{Q}}$ when $n-m \geq 3$, so that the results explained in this section gives a full computation of the rational homotopy of the mapping spaces $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op } \mathcal{O}_{p}}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}\right)$ that occur in the operadic description of the introduction for the embedding spaces $\overline{\operatorname{Emb}}_{c}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m}, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.

To carry out these computations, we use the graph complex model Graphs ${ }_{n}^{c}$ of the rational homotopy of the operad $D_{n}$. Hence, we naturally obtain, as a main outcome, a graph complex description of the homotopy type of the spaces $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op } \mathcal{O}_{p}}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathcal{O}_{p}}^{h}\left(D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$. In the case of the mapping spaces $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op } \mathcal{O}_{p}}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$, we express the result

as the Maurer-Cartan space $\mathrm{MC}_{\bullet}\left(H G C_{m n}\right)$ associated to a Lie dg-algebra of hairy graphs $H G C_{m n}$. We explain the definition of this object first and we explain our computation afterwards.

In the case of the automorphism spaces $\operatorname{Aut}_{C p}^{h}\left(D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$, we get that our object is homotopy equivalent to a Cartesian product of Eilenberg-Mac Lane spaces (like any $H$-group in rational homotopy theory). Thus, we can focus on the computation of the homotopy groups in this case. We give a description of these groups in terms of the homology of a non-hairy graph complex $G C_{n}$ of which we also explain the definition beforehand. This graph complex $G C_{n}$ is a graded version of a complex introduced by Kontsevich in [41], and therefore, this complex is usually called the Kontsevich graph complex in the literature.

# 11.3.1 The hairy graph complex 

The hairy graph complex $H G C_{m n}$ explicitly consists of formal series of connected graphs with internal vertices $\bullet$, internal edges $\bullet \bullet$, which link internal vertices together, and external edges $\bullet$ (the hairs), which are open at one extremity, as in the following examples:
![img-125.jpeg](img-125.jpeg)

This complex $H G C_{m n}$ is equipped with a lower grading. The degree of a graph $\gamma \in H G C_{m n}$ is determined by assuming that each vertex contributes by $\operatorname{deg}(\bullet)=n$, that each internal edge contributes by $\operatorname{deg}(\bullet \bullet)=1-n$, that each hair contributes by $\operatorname{deg}(\bullet-)=m-n+1$, and by adding a global degree shift by $-m$. Thus, we have $\operatorname{deg}(\gamma)=n v+(1-n) e+(m-n+1) h-m$, where $v$ denotes the number of internal vertices, the letter $e$ denotes the number of internal edges and $h$ denotes the number of hairs of the graph $\gamma \in H G C_{m n}$. The differential of the hairy graph complex is defined by the blow-up of internal vertices:
![img-126.jpeg](img-126.jpeg)

We equip the hairy graph complex with the Lie bracket such that:
where the first sum runs over the re-connections of a hair of the graph $\gamma_{1}$ to a vertex of the graph $\gamma_{2}$, and similarly in the second sum, with the role of the graphs $\gamma_{1}$ and $\gamma_{2}$ exchanged. In the case $m=1$, we have to consider a deformation of this Lie dg-algebra structure which we call the Shoikhet $L_{\infty}$-structure (a strongly homotopy Lie algebra). We just refer to [59] for the explicit definition of this structure.

In the next theorem, we consider the Maurer-Cartan space $\mathrm{MC}_{\bullet}(L)$ associated to the Lie dg-algebra $L=H G C_{m, n}$. This simplicial set $\mathrm{MC}_{\bullet}(L)$ is defined by the sets of flat $L$-valued PL connections on the simplices $\Delta^{n}, n \in \mathbb{N}$. To be more precise, in the definition of this

object $\mathrm{MC}_{\bullet}(L)$, we generally assume that $L$ forms a complete Lie dg-algebra with respect to a filtration $L=\mathrm{F}_{1} L \supset \mathrm{~F}_{2} L \supset \cdots \supset \mathrm{~F}_{k} L \supset \cdots$ such that $\left[\mathrm{F}_{k} L, \mathrm{~F}_{l} L\right] \subset \mathrm{F}_{k+l} L$. In the case $L=H G C_{m n}$, we assume that $\mathrm{F}_{k} L=\mathrm{F}_{k} H G C_{m n}$ consists of power series of graphs $\gamma \in \mathrm{H}_{m n}$ such that $e-v \geq k$, where $e$ denotes the number of edges and $v$ denotes the number of internal vertices in $\gamma$. Then we explicitly set:

$$
\mathrm{MC}_{n}(L)=\left\{\omega \in\left(L \hat{\otimes} \Omega^{*}\left(\Delta^{n}\right)\right)^{1} \mid \delta(\omega)+\frac{1}{2}[\omega, \omega]=0\right\}\}
$$

for every simplicial dimension $n \in \mathbb{N}$, where $\left(L \hat{\otimes} \Omega^{*}\left(\Delta^{n}\right)\right)^{1}$ denotes the component of upper degree 1 in the completed tensor product of the Lie dg-algebra $L$ with the Sullivan cochain dg-algebra of PL forms $\Omega^{*}\left(\Delta^{n}\right)$. The face and degeneracy operators of this simplicial set are inherited from the simplices. This construction has a natural extension for $L_{\infty}$-algebras (see for instance [32]). We now have the following main result:

Theorem 11.3.1 (B. Fresse, V. Turchin, and T. Willwacher [28, Theorem 1]). For any $n \geq m \geq 2$, we have the relation:

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{T o p \mathcal{O}_{p}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right) \sim \mathrm{MC}_{\bullet}\left(H G C_{m n}\right)
$$

where $H G C_{m n}$ is the hairy graph complex. This relation extends to the case $n>m=1$ when we equip $H G C_{1 n}$ equipped with the Shoikhet $L_{\infty}$-structure.

The results of the previous section imply that we have the following weak-equivalences:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Map}_{T o p \mathcal{O}_{p}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right) & \sim \operatorname{Map}_{d g^{*} \mathcal{H}_{o p f} \mathcal{O}_{p_{*}^{c}}}^{h}\left(\mathrm{RG}_{\sharp}^{*}\left(D_{n}\right), \mathrm{RG}_{\sharp}^{*}\left(D_{m}\right)\right) \\
& \sim \operatorname{Map}_{d g^{*} \mathcal{H}_{o p f} \mathcal{O}_{p_{*}^{c}}}^{h}\left(\text { Pois }_{n}^{c}, \text { Pois }_{m}^{c}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\operatorname{Map}_{d g^{*} \mathcal{H}_{o p f} \mathcal{O}_{p_{*}^{c}}}^{h}(-,-)$ denote a derived mapping space bifunctor in the category of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads, we use the Quillen adjunction between the functors $\mathrm{G}_{\bullet}(-)$ and $\Omega_{\sharp}^{*}(-)$ in the first equivalence (Equation 11.3.5) and the formality result of Theorem 11.2.9 in the second equivalence (Equation 11.3.6). These equivalences reduce the proof of Theorem 11.3.1 to a problem of algebra.

In order to compute the derived mapping space of Hopf cochain dg-cooperads $\operatorname{Map}_{d g^{*} \mathcal{H}_{o p f} \mathcal{O}_{p_{*}^{c}}}^{h}\left(\text { Pois }_{n}^{c}, \text { Pois }_{m}^{c}\right)$, we need to pick a cofibrant resolution of the object Pois ${ }_{n}^{c}$ on the source and a fibrant resolution of the object $P o i s_{m}^{c}$ on the target. For this purpose, we take the cofibrant Hopf cochain dg-cooperad $R_{n}=\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\tilde{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}\right)$ (see $\S 11.2 .3$ ) and we adapt the classical Boardman-Vogt $W$-construction of operads to define a natural fibrant resolution functor $\mathrm{W}^{c}(-)$ on the category of Hopf cochain dg-cooperad (see [28, §5] for a detailed definition of this functor). By analyzing the definition of maps on these Hopf cochain dg-cooperads, one sees that the mapping space $\operatorname{Map}_{d g^{*} \mathcal{H}_{o p f} \mathcal{O}_{p_{*}^{c}}}^{h}\left(\text { Pois }_{n}^{c}, \text { Pois }_{m}^{c}\right)$ is weakly equivalent to the Maurer-Cartan space associated to an $L_{\infty}$-algebra of biderivations $\operatorname{BiDer}\left(\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\tilde{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}\right), \mathrm{W}^{c}\left(\text { Pois }_{m}^{c}\right)\right)$ (see $[28, \S 6]$ ).

The object $\mathrm{C}_{C E}^{*}\left(\tilde{\mathfrak{p}}_{n}\right)$ in this complex of biderivations can be replaced by the graph cooperad model of the $n$-Poisson cooperad $\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c} \sim \operatorname{Pois}_{n}^{c}$. The connection of the derived mapping space $\operatorname{Map}_{d g^{*} \mathcal{H}_{o p f} \mathcal{O}_{p_{*}^{c}}}^{h}\left(\text { Pois }_{n}^{c}, \text { Pois }_{m}^{c}\right)$ with the hairy graph complex of the theorem comes from an ultimate reduction of this $L_{\infty}$-algebra of biderivations, which yields a

relation of the form

$$
H G C_{m n} \sim \operatorname{BiDer}\left(\operatorname{Graphs}_{n}^{c}, \mathrm{~W}^{c}\left(\operatorname{Pois}_{m}^{c}\right)\right)
$$

in the category of $L_{\infty}$-algebras (see $[28, \S 8]$ ).
The result of this theorem has the following corollary:
Corollary 11.3.2. For any $n \geq m \geq 2$ (and for $n>m=1$ ), we have the identity:

$$
\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T o p}_{P}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right), \omega\right)=H_{*-1}\left(H G C_{m n}^{\omega}\right)
$$

for any $\omega \in \mathrm{MC}_{0}\left(H G C_{m n}\right)$, where $H G C_{m n}^{\omega}$ is the complex $H G C_{m n}$ equipped with the twisted differential $\delta_{\omega}=\delta+[\omega,-]+$ (extra terms in the $L_{\infty}$-case).

The identity of this statement follows from the result of Theorem 11.3.1 and from a general result about the homotopy groups of Maurer-Cartan spaces $\mathrm{MC}_{\bullet}(L)$ for which we refer to $[6]$.

A computation of the rational homotopy groups of the embedding spaces $\overline{\operatorname{Emb}}_{c}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m}, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$, analogous to the result established in this corollary, is given in [4] (see also [44] for the case $m=1$ of these computations). These previous computations are based on the interpretation in terms of mapping spaces of operadic bimodules of the Goodwillie-Weiss tower of the embedding spaces $\overline{\operatorname{Emb}}_{c}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m}, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ (or of the equivalent interpretation of the Goodwillie-Weiss tower in terms of Sinha's cosimplicial model in the case $m=1$ ). In [45], the formality of $E_{n}$-operads in chain complexes is also used to get a description of the homology of the embedding spaces $\overline{\operatorname{Emb}}_{c}\left(\mathbb{R}^{1}, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ in terms of a Hochschild cohomology theory for operads (we apply this Hochschild cohomology theory to the $n$-Poisson operad). The graph operad model of the $n$-Poisson can also be used to deduce a graph complex model of the homology of the embedding space $\overline{\operatorname{Emb}}_{c}\left(\mathbb{R}^{1}, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ from this algebraic approach.

In fact, we can use the result of the above corollary and the equivalence between the embedding space $\overline{\operatorname{Emb}}_{c}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m}, \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and the $m+1$-fold iterated loop space of the operadic mapping space $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{o p}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}\right)$ given in the introduction to get applications of the result of Theorem 11.3.1 in the theory embedding spaces. For this purpose, we also use the following theorem:

Theorem 11.3.3 (B. Fresse, V. Turchin, and T. Willwacher [28, Theorem 15]). In the case $n-m \geq 3$, the space $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{o p}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}\right)$ is $n-m-1$ connected, and we moreover have the relation:

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{o p}}^{h}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}\right)^{\mathbb{Q}} \sim \operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{o p}} \mathcal{O}_{p}\left(D_{m}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)
$$

in the homotopy category of spaces.
We refer to the cited reference $[28, \S 10]$ for the detailed proof of this statement, which relies on an analogous result for spaces, established by Haefliger in [35].

We examine the rational homotopy of the spaces of homotopy automorphisms to complete the result of this section. We first explain the definition of the Kontsevich graph complexes $G C_{n}$ which occur in this computation.

# 11.3.2 The Kontsevich graph complex 

The definition of the complex $G C_{n}$ is the same as the definition of the hairy graph complex $H G C_{m n}$, except that we now consider graphs without hairs, as in the following examples:
![img-127.jpeg](img-127.jpeg)

We determine the degree of a graph in $G C_{n}$ by assuming that each vertex contributes by $\operatorname{deg}(\bullet)=n$ and each edge contributes by $\operatorname{deg}(\bullet \bullet)=1-n$ as in the case of hairy graphs. We still assume that every vertex of a graph in $G C_{n}$ is at least trivalent and we do not allow loops (edges with the same origin and endpoint). The differential is defined by the blow-up of vertices again.

The space of homotopy automorphisms $\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op }} \mathcal{O}_{p}}^{h}\left(D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$ is the sum of the connected components of the mapping spaces $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op }} \mathcal{O}_{p}}^{h}\left(D_{n}, D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right)$ associated to the morphisms $\phi$ that are invertible in the homotopy category of operads. Let $h: \operatorname{Aut}_{\mathcal{T}_{\text {op }} \mathcal{O}_{p}}^{h}\left(D_{n}^{\mathbb{Q}}\right) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathcal{H}_{\text {opf }} \mathcal{O}_{p}}\left(\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}, \mathbb{Q}\right)\right)$ be the natural map that carries any such morphism to the associated homology morphism. For $n \geq 2$, we have a bijection $\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathcal{H}_{\text {opf }} \mathcal{O}_{p}}\left(\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}, \mathbb{Q}\right)\right)=\mathbb{Q}^{\times}$ that is determined by taking the action of an automorphism $\phi \in \operatorname{Aut}_{\mathcal{H}_{\text {opf }} \mathcal{O}_{p}}\left(\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}, \mathbb{Q}\right)\right)$ on the representative of the Poisson bracket operation $\lambda \in$ Pois $_{n}$ in the operad Pois $_{n}=\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(D_{n}\right)$. We get the following result:

Theorem 11.3.4 (B. Fresse, V. Turchin, and T. Willwacher [28, Corollary 5]). For each $\lambda \in \mathbb{Q}^{\times}$, we have the identity:

$$
\pi_{*}\left(h^{-1}(\lambda)\right)=\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(G C_{n}\right) \oplus\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\mathbb{Q}, \quad \text { if } * \equiv-n-1(4) \\
0, \quad \text { otherwise }
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $G C_{n}$ denotes the Kontsevich graph complex.
We deduce this statement from the result of Theorem 11.3.1, by using that the identity morphism is represented by the Maurer-Cartan element such that $\omega=|$ in the hairy graph complex $H G C_{n n}$. We just consider versions of the graph complexes $G C_{n}^{2}$ and $H G C_{m n}^{2}$ where bivalent vertices are allowed. We have $H G C_{m n}^{2} \sim H G C_{m n}$ for any $n \geq m \geq 2$, whereas for the graph complex $G C_{n}^{2}$, we have:

$$
\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(G C_{n}^{2}\right)=\mathrm{H}_{*}\left(G C_{n}\right) \oplus\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\mathbb{Q} L_{*}, & \text { if } * \equiv-n-1(4) \\
0, & \text { otherwise }
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $L_{*}$ denotes the homology classes of graphs of the form:
![img-128.jpeg](img-128.jpeg)

We easily see that the operation $[\omega,-]$ in the differential $\delta_{\omega}=\delta+[\omega,-]$ of the twisted complex $\left(H G C_{n n}^{2}\right)^{\omega}$ associated to the Maurer-Cartan element $\omega=|$ is given by the addition of a hair | to any graph $\gamma \in H G C_{n n}^{2}$. We can then use a spectral sequence to check that we have a quasi-isomorphism $\mathbb{Q}|\oplus \mathbb{Q}[-1] \otimes G C_{n}^{2} \xrightarrow{\sim} H G C_{n n}^{2}$ where we consider the mapping $\gamma \mapsto \gamma-$ that associates a graph with one hair $\gamma-\in H G C_{n n}^{2}$ to any graph $\gamma \in G C_{n}$. We refer to [29, Proposition 2.2.9] for the detailed line of arguments.

In the case $n=2$, we have $\mathrm{H}_{0}\left(G C_{n}\right)=\mathfrak{g r t}$ by a result of T. Willwacher, where grt is the graded Grothendieck-Teichmüller Lie algebra (see [60]). Therefore, in this case, the result of Theorem 11.3.4 reflects the relation that we obtained in Theorem 11.1.4.

# 11.4 Outlook 

Throughout this survey, we have focused on the study of the homotopy of $E_{n}$-operads themselves, but one can use variants of the definition of an $E_{n}$-operad to associate operadic right module structures to any $n$-manifold $M$.

For this purpose, we can use again the Fulton-MacPherson operad $F M_{n}$, the model of $E_{n}$-operad, given by a real oriented version of the Fulton-MacPherson compactification of the configuration spaces, which was considered by Kontsevich in his proof of the formality of $E_{n}$-operads (see $\S 11.2$ ). These Fulton-MacPherson compactifications have a natural generalization for the configuration spaces of manifolds $F(M, r)$, and when $M$ is a framed manifold, this construction returns a collection of spaces $F M_{M}=\left\{F M_{M}(r), r \in \mathbb{N}\right\}$ that inherits the structure of a right module (in the operadic sense) over the Fulton-MacPherson operad $F M_{n}$.

This object is equivalent to constructions used by Ayala-Francis in the definition of the factorization homology of manifolds (see Ayala-Francis's chapter, in this handbook volume, for a survey of this subject). In particular, one can use a relative composition product of the object $F M_{M}$ over the operad $F M_{n}$ to compute the factorization homology of any framed manifold $M$. The methods used by Kontsevich to prove the formality of $E_{n}$-operads have been used by several authors to define models of the rational homotopy type of this right module $F M_{M}$, and hence, to tackle the rational homotopy computations in factorization homology theory. To cite a few works on this subject, let us mention that a graph complex model of the object $F M_{M}$, which extends the graph cooperad of $\S 11.2 .4$ when $M$ is a simply connected compact manifold without boundary, is defined by Campos-Willwacher in [17], while an extension of Arnold's presentation is used by Idrissi in [38] to get a small model of the object $F M_{M}$. Idrissi's result provides a generalization of Knudsen's description of the factorization homology for higher enveloping algebras of Lie algebras [39]. The paper [16] provides an extension of the constructions of $[17,38]$ for manifolds with boundary, while the paper [15] addresses an extension of the definition of these operadic module structures by using a framed version of the operads of little discs.

In $\S \S 11.2-11.3$, we entirely focus on the rational homotopy theory framework, but we may wonder which information we may still retrieve by our methods in positive characteristic. For instance, partial formality results have been obtained by Cirici-Horel in [19] when we take an arity-wise truncation of operads below the characteristic of the coefficients (see

also [9] for an improvement of these partial formality results). In fact, the $E_{n}$-operads are not formal as symmetric operads in chain complexes in positive characteristic, because their components are not formal as representations of the symmetric groups. Nevertheless, we may wonder whether $E_{n}$-operads are formal as non-symmetric operads, which is enough for the study of mapping spaces over an $E_{1}$-operad. The case $n>2$ of this question is still open, but Salvatore has proved in [49] that $E_{2}$-operads are not formal as non-symmetric operads over $\mathbb{F}_{2}$.

# 12 

## Moduli spaces of manifolds: a user's guide

Søren Galatius and Oscar Randal-Williams

### 12.1 Introduction

The study of manifolds and invariants of manifolds was begun more than a century ago. In this entry we shall discuss the parametrised setting: invariants of families of manifolds, parametrised by a base manifold $X$. The invariants we look for will be cohomology classes in $X$, characteristic classes.

This article will be structured in the following way.
(i) A discussion of the abstract classification theory. The main content here is the precise definition of the kind of families we consider, and an outline of how a classifying space may be constructed. There is one such classifying space for each pair $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ consisting of a closed manifold $W$ and a tangential structure $\rho_{W}$, see $\S 12.2$. The more general case where $W$ is compact with boundary is briefly discussed in §12.4.6.
(ii) Definition of Miller-Morita-Mumford classes, the main examples of characteristic classes. With this definition in place, we state a first version of the main result of $[14,17,16]$ : a formula (see Theorem 12.3.3) for rational cohomology of the classifying spaces in a range of degrees, for many instances of $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$.
(iii) Statement of the main result of $[14,17,16]$ in their general forms. These statements require a bit more homotopy theory to formulate but apply quite generally, at least for even-dimensional manifolds, see the theorems in $\S 12.4$.
(iv) Examples of calculations and applications. The results surveyed in $\S \S 12.3-12.4$ are quite well suited for explicit calculations. We believe this to be an important feature of the theory, and have included a supply of worked examples of various types to illustrate this aspect, many of which have not previously been published. In $\S 12.5$ we will focus on calculations in rational cohomology, and we include a detailed study of some complete intersections. In $\S 12.6$ we carry out some integral homology calculations, focusing on $H_{1}$.

Our theorems apply in even dimensions $2 n \geq 6$, but were inspired by the breakthrough theorem of Madsen and Weiss [33] in dimension 2, building on earlier ideas of Madsen and Tillmann [32] and Tillmann [47].

# 12.2 Smooth bundles and their classifying spaces 

First, some conventions. By smooth manifold we shall always mean a Hausdorff, second countable topological manifold equipped with a maximal $C^{\infty}$ atlas, and smooth map shall always mean $C^{\infty}$. We shall generally use the letter $\mathcal{M}$ with various decorations for variants of classifying spaces for families of manifolds, and the letter $\mathcal{F}$ with various decorations for the functor it classifies.

### 12.2.1 Smooth bundles

Our notion of "family" of manifolds will be smooth fibre bundle, possibly equipped with extra tangent bundle structure, as follows. If $V$ is a $d$-dimensional real vector bundle we shall write $\operatorname{Fr}(V)$ for the associated frame bundle, which is a principal $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-bundle.

Definition 12.2.1. Let $d$ be a non-negative integer.
(i) A smooth fibre bundle of dimension $d$ consists of smooth manifolds $E$ and $X$ (without boundary) and a smooth proper map $\pi: E \rightarrow X$ such that $D \pi: T E \rightarrow \pi^{*} T X$ is surjective and the vector bundle $T_{\pi} E=\operatorname{Ker}(D \pi)$ has $d$-dimensional fibres. The bundle $T_{\pi} E$ is called the vertical tangent bundle.
(ii) If $\Theta$ is a space with a continuous action of $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$, a smooth fibre bundle with $\Theta$ structure consists of a smooth fibre bundle $\pi: E \rightarrow X$, together with a continuous $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-equivariant map $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$.

Typical choices of $\Theta$ include the terminal one $\Theta=\{*\}$, and $\Theta=\boldsymbol{Z}^{\times}=\{ \pm 1\}$ on which $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ acts by multiplication by the sign of the determinant. In the former case a $\Theta$ structure is no information, and in the latter it is the data of a continuously varying family of orientations of the $d$-manifolds $\pi^{-1}(x)$. (The space of equivariant maps $\operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$ may be modelled in other ways, equivalent up to weak equivalence, see §12.4.5.)

Any smooth map $f: X^{\prime} \rightarrow X$ will be transverse to any smooth fibre bundle $\pi: E \rightarrow X$ as above, and the pullback $\left(f^{*} \pi\right): f^{*} E \rightarrow X^{\prime}$ is again a smooth fibre bundle. Given a $\Theta$-structure $\rho$ on $\pi$, we shall write $f^{*} \rho$ for the induced structure on $\left(f^{*} \pi\right)$.

### 12.2.2 Classifying spaces

The natural equivalence relation between the bundles considered above is concordance, which we recall.

Definition 12.2.2. Let $\pi_{0}: E_{0} \rightarrow X$ and $\pi_{1}: E_{1} \rightarrow X$ be smooth bundles with $\Theta$ structures $\rho_{0}: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi_{0}} E_{0}\right) \rightarrow \Theta$ and $\rho_{1}: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi_{1}} E_{1}\right) \rightarrow \Theta$.
(i) An isomorphism between $\left(\pi_{0}, \rho_{0}\right)$ and $\left(\pi_{1}, \rho_{1}\right)$ is a diffeomorphism $\phi: E_{0} \rightarrow E_{1}$ over $X$, such that the induced map $\operatorname{Fr}\left(D_{\pi} \phi\right): \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi_{0}} E_{0}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi_{1}} E_{1}\right)$ is over $\Theta$.
(ii) A concordance between $\left(\pi_{0}, \rho_{0}\right)$ and $\left(\pi_{1}, \rho_{1}\right)$ is a smooth fibre bundle $\pi: E \rightarrow \mathbf{R} \times X$ with $\Theta$-structure $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$, together with isomorphisms from $\left(\pi_{0}, \rho_{0}\right)$ and

$\left(\pi_{1}, \rho_{1}\right)$ to the pullbacks of $(\pi, \rho)$ along the two embeddings $X \cong\{0\} \times X \subset \mathbf{R} \times X$ and $X \cong\{1\} \times X \subset \mathbf{R} \times X$.

Pulling back is functorial up to isomorphism and preserves being concordant.
Definition 12.2.3. For a smooth manifold $X$ without boundary, let $\mathcal{F}^{\Theta}[X]$ denote the set of concordance classes of pairs $(\pi, \rho)$ of a smooth fibre bundle $\pi: E \rightarrow X$ with $\Theta$-structure $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$. (Note that $X$ is fixed, but $E$ is allowed to vary.)

Theorem 12.2.4. The functor $X \mapsto \mathcal{F}^{\Theta}[X]$ is representable in the (weak) sense that there exists a topological space $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}$ and a natural bijection

$$
\mathcal{F}^{\Theta}[X] \cong\left[X, \mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\right]
$$

where the codomain denotes homotopy classes of continuous maps.
There are various ways to prove this representability statement. In the series $[14,17,16]$ we did this by constructing explicit point-set models in terms of submanifolds of $\mathbf{R}^{\infty}$. Instead of repeating what we said there, let us outline an approach based on simplicial sets and the observation that the functor $\mathcal{F}^{\Theta}$ may be upgraded to take values in spaces, and the natural bijection (12.2.1) may be upgraded to a natural weak equivalence to the mapping space.

Definition 12.2.5. Let $\Delta_{\bullet}^{\bullet}$ be the cosimplicial smooth manifold given by the extended simplices $\Delta_{\varepsilon}^{p}=\left\{t \in \mathbf{R}^{p+1} \mid t_{0}+\cdots+t_{p}=1\right\}$.

For a smooth manifold $X$ let $\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(X)$ denote the simplicial set whose $p$-simplices are all pairs $(\pi, \rho)$ consisting of a smooth fibre bundle $\pi: E \rightarrow \Delta_{\varepsilon}^{p} \times X$ with $\Theta$-structure $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$.

As they stand, these definitions are not quite rigorous: $\mathcal{F}^{\Theta}[X]$ and $\mathcal{F}_{p}^{\Theta}(X)$ are not (small) sets for size reasons, and $\mathcal{F}_{p}^{\Theta}(X)$ is not functorial in $[p] \in \Delta$ because pullback is not strictly associative on the level of underlying sets. This may be fixed in standard ways, e.g. by requiring the underlying set of $E$ to be a subset of $X \times \Omega$ for a set $\Omega$ of sufficiently large cardinality. See e.g. [33, Section 2.1] for more detail.

Proposition 12.2.6. Let Man and sSets be the categories of smooth manifolds and simplicial sets, and let $\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}:$ Man $^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow$ sSets be the functor defined above. Then we have a natural bijection

$$
\mathcal{F}^{\Theta}[X] \cong \pi_{0} \mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(X)
$$

and a natural weak equivalence of simplicial sets

$$
\left.\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(X) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Maps}\left(\operatorname{Sing}(X), \mathcal{F}_{\bullet}(\{*\})\right)\right)
$$

Consequently, we may take $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}:=\left|\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(\{*\})\right|$ in Theorem 12.2.4.
In this statement we take $\operatorname{Sing}(X)$ to mean the smooth singular set, i.e. the simplicial set $[p] \mapsto C^{\infty}\left(\Delta_{\varepsilon}^{p}, X\right)$. It is equivalent to the usual simplicial set made out of all continuous maps $\Delta^{p} \rightarrow X$ by a smooth approximation argument, and in particular the evaluation map $|\operatorname{Sing}(X)| \rightarrow X$ is a homotopy equivalence by Milnor's theorem. The codomain of (12.2.2) is the simplicial set of maps into the Kan complex $\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}(\{*\})$, homotopy equivalent to the space of maps $X \rightarrow\left|\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}(\{*\})\right|$.

Proof sketch. The first claim follows by identifying 1-simplices of $\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(X)$ with concordances between 0 -simplices.

For the second claim, we define the map (12.2.2) by pulling back. To check that it is a weak equivalence one first verifies that both sides send open covers $X=U \cup V$ to homotopy pullback squares and countable increasing unions to homotopy limits. Hence it suffices to check the case $X=\mathbf{R}^{n}$. Then one checks that both sides send $X \times \mathbf{R} \rightarrow X$ to a weak equivalence, so it suffices to check $X=\{*\}$, which is obvious.

The third claim follows by combining the first and the second claim and the homotopy equivalence $|\operatorname{Sing}(X)| \rightarrow X$ given by evaluation. Alternatively it may be quoted directly from $[33$, Section 2.4].

The above proof of Theorem 12.2.4 gives an explicit bijection (12.2.1). Indeed, an element $(\pi, \rho) \in \mathcal{F}_{0}(X)$ gives a morphism of simplicial sets $\operatorname{Sing}(X) \rightarrow \mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(\{*\})$ and hence a canonical zig-zag

$$
X \stackrel{\text { ev }}{\leftarrow}|\operatorname{Sing}(X)| \xrightarrow{(\pi, \rho)} \left|\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(\{*\})\right|=\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}
$$

The map ev : $|\operatorname{Sing}(X)| \rightarrow X$ is a homotopy equivalence, and we may choose a homotopy inverse. For example, a smooth triangulation of $X$ gives such an inverse, which is even a section. The resulting homotopy class of map $X \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\Theta}$ corresponds to $[(\pi, \rho)]$ under the bijection (12.2.1).

For later purposes, let us explain how a universal fibration $\pi^{\Theta}: \mathcal{E}^{\Theta} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\Theta}$ modelling the bundle $\pi: E \rightarrow X$ may be constructed by the same simplicial method. Let $\widehat{\mathcal{F}}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(X)$ be the simplicial set whose $p$-simplices are triples $(\pi, \rho, s)$ where $(\pi, \rho)$ is as before and $s: \Delta_{e}^{p} \times X \rightarrow E$ is a section of $\pi$, and set $\mathcal{E}^{\Theta}:=\left|\widehat{\mathcal{F}}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(\{*\})\right|$. The zig-zag (12.2.3) above associated to an element $(\pi, \rho) \in \mathcal{F}_{0}^{\Theta}(X)$ now extends to a canonical diagram
![img-130.jpeg](img-130.jpeg)
in which both squares are homotopy cartesian, and the top right-hand map is that associated to the data $\left(\operatorname{pr}_{1}: E \times_{X} E \rightarrow E, \rho \circ D \operatorname{pr}_{2}, \operatorname{diag}: E \rightarrow E \times_{X} E\right)$.

Finally, a $p$-simplex $\left(\pi: E \rightarrow \Delta_{e}^{p}, \rho, s\right)$ of $\mathcal{E}^{\Theta}$ gives a map $\ell=\left(\rho / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})\right): E \cong$ $\left(\operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})\right) \rightarrow\left(\Theta / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})\right)$. Composing with the section $\left.s\right|_{\Delta^{p}}: \Delta^{p} \rightarrow E$ then gives rise to a map of simplicial sets

$$
\widehat{\mathcal{F}}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}(\{*\}) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Sing}\left(\Theta / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})\right)
$$

realising to a map $\mathcal{E}^{\Theta} \rightarrow\left|\operatorname{Sing}\left(\Theta / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})\right)\right|$. The orbit space $\Theta / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ need not be well behaved, and we would like to replace it by the homotopy orbit space $B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}):=$ $\left(E \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) \times \Theta\right) / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$. Taking homotopy orbits of the map $\Theta \rightarrow\{*\}$ yields a map $\theta: B \rightarrow B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$. Repeating the construction above with $E \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) \times \Theta$ instead of $\Theta$ allows us to construct a zig-zag

$$
\mathcal{E}^{\Theta} \stackrel{\simeq}{\leftarrow} \mathcal{E}^{E \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) \times \Theta} \xrightarrow{\ell}|\operatorname{Sing}(B)| \xrightarrow{\text { ev }} B \xrightarrow{\theta} B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})
$$

Slightly less precisely, we shall summarise this situation as a diagram
![img-131.jpeg](img-131.jpeg)
where the square is homotopy cartesian. The vector bundle classified by the composition $\theta \circ \ell: \mathcal{E}^{\Theta} \rightarrow B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ is a universal instance of $T_{\pi} E$, and shall be denoted $T_{\pi} \mathcal{E}^{\Theta}$. The factorisation through $\theta$ gives an equivariant map $\rho^{\Theta}: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} \mathcal{E}^{\Theta}\right) \rightarrow \Theta$, a universal instance of $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$.

# 12.2.3 Path connected classifying spaces 

The bundles classified so far are inconveniently general. For example, we have not made any restrictions on the diffeomorphism type of the fibres of $\pi: E \rightarrow X$. Hence, if e.g. $\Theta=$ $\{*\}$, the set $\pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\right)$ is in bijection with the set of diffeomorphism classes of compact smooth $d$-manifolds without boundary, a countably infinite set for any $d \geq 0$. The homotopy type of $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}$ then encodes at once the classification of smooth manifolds up to diffeomorphism and the classification of smooth bundles, because it is the "moduli space" (or " $\infty$-groupoid") of all $d$-manifolds.

We shall often study one path component of $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}$ at a time, which corresponds to fixing the concordance class of the fibres of the classified bundles. We introduce the following notation.

Definition 12.2.7. Let $\Theta$ be a space with $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ action, $W$ be a compact $d$-manifold without boundary, and $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ be an equivariant map. Considering this as a family over a point yields a $\left[\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)\right] \in \pi_{0} \mathcal{M}^{\Theta}$, and we shall write $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) \subset \mathcal{M}^{\Theta}$ for the path component containing $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$. This path component is a classifying space for smooth fibre bundles $\pi: E \rightarrow X$ with structure $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$, whose restriction to any point $\{x\} \subset X$ is concordant to $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$.

Remark 12.2.8. In the special case $\Theta=\{*\}$ the maps $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$ are irrelevant, and in this case we shall write simply $\mathcal{M}(W)$. This space classifies smooth bundles $\pi: E \rightarrow X$ with fibres diffeomorphic to $W$ with no further structure, and we have the weak equivalence

$$
\mathcal{M}(W) \simeq B \operatorname{Diff}(W)
$$

where $\operatorname{Diff}(W)$ is the diffeomorphism group of $W$ in the $C^{\infty}$ topology. Similarly, if $\Theta=\boldsymbol{Z}^{\times}$ with the orientation action and $W$ is given an orientation $\rho_{W}$, we shall write $\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}(W)$ for $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ and there is a weak equivalence

$$
\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}(W) \simeq B \operatorname{Diff}^{\text {or }}(W)
$$

where $\operatorname{Diff}^{\text {or }}(W) \subset \operatorname{Diff}(W)$ is the subgroup of orientation preserving diffeomorphisms. For general $\Theta$, the homotopy type is described as the Borel construction

$$
\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) \simeq \frac{\left\{\rho: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta, \text { equivariantly homotopic to } \rho_{W}\right\}}{\binom{\text { topological group of diffeomorphisms } W \rightarrow W}{\text { preserving the equivariant homotopy class of } \rho_{W}}}
$$

See [14, Definition 1.5], [14, Section 1.1], or [16, Section 1.1] for further discussion of this point of view.

# 12.3 Characteristic classes 

The main topic of this article is the study of characteristic classes of the sort of bundles described above, i.e. the calculation of the cohomology ring of the classifying spaces $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$. We first recall the conclusions in rational cohomology, which are easier to state and often gives an explicit formula for the ring of characteristic classes.

### 12.3.1 Characteristic classes

As before, let $B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ denote the Borel construction. For a smooth bundle $\pi: E \rightarrow X$ with $\Theta$-structure $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$, we may form the Borel construction with $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ and obtain a correspondence, i.e. a diagram

$$
X \stackrel{\pi}{\longleftarrow} E \stackrel{\simeq}{\leftrightarrows} \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) \xrightarrow{\rho / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})} B
$$

We write $\ell: E \rightarrow B$ for the homotopy class of maps associated to $\rho / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$.
