We shall let $\boldsymbol{Z}^{w_{1}}$ denote the coefficient system on $B$ arising from the non-trivial action of $\pi_{0}\left(\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})\right)=$ $\boldsymbol{Z}^{\times}$on $\boldsymbol{Z}$, and let $A^{w_{1}}=A \otimes \boldsymbol{Z}^{w_{1}}$ for an abelian group $A$, and we shall use the same notation for these coefficient systems pulled back to $E$ along (12.3.1). Then we have a homomorphism

$$
\ell^{*}: H^{k+d}\left(B ; A^{w_{1}}\right) \longrightarrow H^{k+d}\left(E ; A^{w_{1}}\right)
$$

We also have a fibre integration homomorphism

$$
\int_{\pi}: H^{k+d}\left(E ; A^{w_{1}}\right) \longrightarrow H^{k}(X ; A)
$$

where $d$ is the dimension of the fibres of $\pi$. It may be defined, e.g. as the composition $H^{k+d}\left(E ; A^{w_{1}}\right) \rightarrow E_{\infty}^{k, d} \subset E_{2}^{k, d}$ in the Serre spectral sequence for the fibration $\pi$, or by a Pontryagin-Thom construction as in $\S 12.4 .2$ below.

Given a class $c \in H^{d+k}\left(B ; A^{w_{1}}\right)$, we may combine (12.3.2) and (12.3.3) and define the Miller-Morita-Mumford classes (or MMM-classes) by the push-pull formula

$$
\kappa_{c}(\pi)=\int_{\pi} \ell^{*} c \in H^{k}(X ; A)
$$

This class is easily seen to be natural with respect to pullback along smooth maps $X^{\prime} \rightarrow X$, and in fact comes from a universal class

$$
\kappa_{c} \in H^{k}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) ; A\right)
$$

for any $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$, any $A$, and any $c \in H^{k+d}\left(B ; A^{w_{1}}\right)$, defined by the analogous push-pull formula in the universal instance (12.2.4).

In the special case $k=0$ and $X=\{*\}$, the definition of $\kappa_{c} \in H^{0}(X ; A)=A$ simply reproduces the usual characteristic numbers, e.f. [35, §16]. For example, if $d=2 n$ and $e$ comes from the Euler class in $H^{d}\left(B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) ; \mathbf{Z}^{w_{1}}\right)$, then $\kappa_{e} \in H^{0}(X ; \mathbf{Z})=\mathbf{Z}$ is the Euler characteristic of $W$. Henceforth we shall mostly be interested in the case $k>0$.

If $A=\mathbf{k}$ is a field, we may combine with cup product to get a map of graded rings

$$
\mathbf{k}\left[\kappa_{c} \mid c \in \text { basis of } H^{>d}\left(B ; \mathbf{k}^{w_{1}}\right)\right] \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) ; \mathbf{k}\right)
$$

whose domain is the free graded-commutative $\mathbf{k}$-algebra on symbols $\kappa_{c}$, one for each element $c$ in a chosen basis (or more invariantly, on a degree-shifted copy of the graded $\mathbf{k}$-vector space $\left.H^{>d}\left(B ; \mathbf{k}^{w_{1}}\right)\right)$.

# 12.3.2 Genus 

All of our results will hold in a range of degrees depending on genus, a numerical invariant that we first introduce.

Assume that $d=2 n$ and let a $\mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})$-space $\Theta$ be given. We shall assume that $n>0$ and that the homotopy orbit space $\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})$ is connected, i.e. that $\pi_{0}\left(\mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})\right)=\boldsymbol{Z}^{\times}$ acts transitively on $\pi_{0}(\Theta)$.

The genus will be defined in terms of the manifold obtained from $S^{n} \times S^{n}$ by removing a point, which plays a special role in this theory. Up to diffeomorphism this manifold may be obtained as a pushout

$$
S^{n} \times \mathbf{R}^{n} \hookleftarrow \mathbf{R}^{n} \times \mathbf{R}^{n} \hookrightarrow \mathbf{R}^{n} \times S^{n}
$$

where the embeddings are induced by a choice of coordinate chart $\mathbf{R}^{n} \hookrightarrow S^{n}$. Following [17, Definition 1.3] a $\Theta$-structure on $S^{n} \times \mathbf{R}^{n}$ shall be called admissible if it "bounds a disk", i.e. is (equivariantly) homotopic to a structure that extends over some embedding $S^{n} \times \mathbf{R}^{n} \hookrightarrow \mathbf{R}^{2 n}$. Note that this is automatic if $\pi_{n}(\Theta)=0$ for some basepoint. A structure on $S^{n} \times S^{n} \backslash\{*\}$ is admissible if the restriction to each piece of the gluing (12.3.5) is admissible.
Definition 12.3.1. Assume $d=2 n>0$ and that $W$ is connected. The genus $g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ of a $\Theta$-manifold $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ is the maximal number of disjoint embeddings $j: S^{n} \times S^{n} \backslash\{*\} \rightarrow W$ such that $j^{*} \rho_{W}$ is admissible.

This appeared as [17, Definition 1.3]. For example, when $n=1$ and $\Theta=\pi_{0}\left(\mathrm{GL}_{2}(\mathbf{R})\right)=$ $\mathbf{Z}^{\times}$, this is precisely the usual genus of an oriented connected 2-manifold. The admissibility condition may be illustrated by the case $\Theta=\mathrm{GL}_{2}(\mathbf{R})$, corresponding to framings on 2manifolds. The Lie group framing on $\Sigma=S^{1} \times S^{1}$ satisfies $g\left(\Sigma, \rho_{\text {Lie }}\right)=0$, but there exist other framings $\rho$ for which $g(\Sigma, \rho)=1$.

In $\S 12.3 .4$ below we shall explain how to determine a lower bound on the number $g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ in terms of more accessible invariants.

# 12.3.3 Main theorem in rational cohomology 

The main results of $[14,17,16]$ imply that the ring homomorphism (12.3.4) is often an isomorphism in a range of degrees when $\mathbf{k}=\mathbf{Q}$. We explain the statement.

Definition 12.3.2. Assume $\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})$ is connected. We say $\Theta$ is spherical if $S^{2 n}$ admits a $\Theta$-structure, i.e. if there exists an equivariant map $\operatorname{Fr}\left(T S^{2 n}\right) \rightarrow \Theta$.

The condition is equivalent to existence of an $\mathrm{O}(2 n)$-equivariant map $\mathrm{O}(2 n+1) \rightarrow \Theta$. This obviously holds if the $\mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})$-action on $\Theta$ admits an extension to an action of $\mathrm{GL}_{2 n+1}(\mathbf{R})$ which holds in many cases, e.g. $\Theta=\{ \pm 1\}$ with the orientation action. See [14, Section 5.1] for more information about this condition.

Theorem 12.3.3. Let $d=2 n>4, W$ be a closed simply connected d-manifold, and $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(W) \rightarrow \Theta$ be a $\Theta$-structure which is $n$-connected (or, equivalently, such that the associated $\ell_{W}: W \rightarrow B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ is $n$-connected). Equip $B$ with the local system $\mathbf{Q}^{w_{1}}$ as above, and assume that $H^{k+d}\left(B ; \mathbf{Q}^{w_{1}}\right)$ is finite dimensional for each $k \geq 1$. Then the ring homomorphism

$$
\mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{c} \mid c \in \text { basis of } H^{>d}\left(B ; \mathbf{Q}^{w_{1}}\right)\right] \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)
$$

as in (12.3.4) is an isomorphism in cohomological degrees $\leq\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-4\right) / 3$. If in addition $\Theta$ is spherical, then the range may be improved to $\leq\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-3\right) / 2$.

### 12.3.4 Estimating genus

To apply Theorem 12.3.3 we must calculate the invariant $g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$, or at least be able to give useful lower bounds for it. This section explains a general such lower bound, under the assumptions that $d=2 n>4$, and that the homotopy orbit space $B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ is simply connected. We may then choose an equivariant map $\Theta \rightarrow \boldsymbol{Z}^{\times}$by which any $\Theta$-structure induces an orientation, and we shall assume given such a map.

There is an obvious upper bound for $g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ : it is certainly no larger than the number of hyperbolic summands in $H_{n}(W ; \boldsymbol{Z})$ equipped with its intersection form. For odd $n$ this is in turn no more than $b_{n} / 2$ and for even $n$ it is no more than $\min \left(b_{n}^{+}, b_{n}^{-}\right)$, where we write $b_{n}$ for the middle Betti number of $W$ and in the even case, $b_{n}=b_{n}^{+}+b_{n}^{-}$for its splitting into positive and negative parts. More usefully, [17, Remark 7.16] gives the following lower bound on genus.

Theorem 12.3.4. Assume $d=2 n>4$, that the homotopy orbit space $B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ is simply connected, and that $\ell_{W}: W \rightarrow B$ (or equivalently $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ ) is n-connected. Write $g^{a}(W)=\min \left(b_{n}^{+}, b_{n}^{-}\right)$for $n$ even and $g^{a}(W)=b_{n} / 2$ for $n$ odd. Then

$$
g^{a}(W)-c \leq g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) \leq g^{a}(W)
$$

with $c=1+e$, where $e$ is the minimal number of generators of the abelian group $H_{n}(B ; \boldsymbol{Z})$. If $n$ is even or if $n \in\{3,7\}$ then one may take $c=e$.

Remark 12.3.5. Let us briefly point out that the estimate (12.3.6) may be expressed using characteristic numbers. Indeed, writing $b_{i}=b_{i}(B)=b_{i}(W)$ for $i=1, \ldots, n-1$, we have

$$
g^{a}(W)=(-1)^{n}\left(\chi(W) / 2-\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}(-1)^{i} b_{i}\right)-|\sigma(W)| / 2
$$

where $\chi(W)=\int_{W} e(T W)$ is the Euler characteristic and $\sigma(W)=\int_{W} \mathcal{L}(T W)$ is the signature (where we write $\sigma(W)=0$ when $n$ is odd).

# 12.4 General versions of main results 

For some purposes, the rational cohomology statement in Theorem 12.3.3 suffices, but there are several homotopy theoretic strengthenings and variations given in [16], which we now explain.

### 12.4.1 Stable homotopy enhancement

To state a more robust version of Theorem 12.3.3 above, we must first introduce a space $\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$ associated to the $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-space $\Theta$. The map $B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) \rightarrow B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ classifies a $d$-dimensional real vector bundle over $B$, and we shall write $M T \Theta$ for the Thom spectrum of its virtual inverse and $\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$ for the corresponding infinite loop space. The following result is a restatement of [16, Corollary 1.7].

Theorem 12.4.1. Let $d=2 n>4, W$ be a closed simply connected d-manifold, and $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(W) \rightarrow \Theta$ be an $n$-connected equivariant map. Then there is a map

$$
\alpha: \mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) \longrightarrow \Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta
$$

inducing an isomorphism in integral homology onto the path component that it hits, in degrees $\leq\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-4\right) / 3$.

If in addition $\Theta$ is spherical, then (12.4.1) induces an isomorphism in homology in degrees $\leq\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-3\right) / 2$.

The statement proved in [16] is in fact stronger: the map $\alpha$ induces an isomorphism in homology with local coefficients in degrees up to $\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-4\right) / 3$. We say that the map is acyclic in this range of degrees. (The induced map in $\pi_{1}$ is of course far from an isomorphism.)

Remark 12.4.2. Let us also briefly recall why Theorem 12.3.3 is a consequence of Theorem 12.4.1: under the Thom isomorphism $H^{k+d}\left(B ; \mathbf{Q}^{w_{1}}\right) \cong H^{k}(M T \Theta ; \mathbf{Q})$ each class $c \in H^{k+d}\left(B ; \mathbf{Q}^{w_{1}}\right)$ may be represented by a spectrum map $M T \Theta \rightarrow \Sigma^{k} H \mathbf{Q}$. If we choose a rational basis $\mathcal{B}_{k} \subset H^{k+d}\left(B ; \mathbf{Q}^{w_{1}}\right) \cong H^{k}(M T \Theta ; \mathbf{Q})$ and represent each basis element by a

spectrum map $M T \Theta \rightarrow \Sigma^{k} H \mathbf{Q}$, we obtain

$$
M T \Theta \longrightarrow \prod_{k=1}^{\infty} \prod_{c \in \mathcal{B}_{k}} \Sigma^{k} H \mathbf{Q}
$$

which induces isomorphisms in rational homology and hence in rationalised homotopy in positive degrees, at least if each $\mathcal{B}_{k}$ is finite in which case the product in the codomain may be replaced by the wedge. It follows that the induced map of infinite loop spaces

$$
\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta \longrightarrow \prod_{k=1}^{\infty} \prod_{\mathcal{B}_{k}} K(\mathbf{Q}, k)
$$

induces an equivalence in rationalised homotopy groups in positive degrees, hence in rational cohomology when restricted to any path component of its domain.

# 12.4.2 MMM-classes in generalised cohomology 

There is a preferred map (12.4.1) in Theorem 12.4.1. Following [32], in [14, Remark 1.11] we gave an explicit point-set model. Here we shall explain the map in a conceptual but somewhat informal way. It is obtained from the following two ingredients.
(i) A smooth $d$-manifold $W$ and an equivariant map $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ induces a continuous map

$$
\ell_{W}=\rho_{W} / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}): W \simeq \operatorname{Fr}(T W) / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) \longrightarrow B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})
$$

under which the canonical bundle $\gamma$ on $B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})=* / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ is pulled back to $T W$. By passing to Thom spectra of inverse bundles one gets a map

$$
W^{-T W} \longrightarrow B^{-\gamma}=M T \Theta
$$

in the stable homotopy category.
(ii) If $W$ is a closed manifold there is a canonical map

$$
S^{0} \longrightarrow W^{-T W}
$$

which is Spanier-Whitehead dual to the canonical map $W \rightarrow\{*\}$ under Atiyah duality $D\left(W_{+}\right) \simeq W^{-T W}$. The actual map of spectra depends on certain choices, but in the right setup these choices form a contractible space. (For example, one may choose an embedding $W \hookrightarrow \mathbf{R}^{\infty}$ and get the map (12.4.3) by the Pontryagin-Thom collapse construction.)

If $W$ is a smooth closed $d$-manifold and $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ is an equivariant map, we may compose (12.4.3) and (12.4.2) to get a map of spectra $S^{0} \rightarrow M T \Theta$, i.e. a point in $\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$. We shall write $\alpha\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) \in \Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$ for this point, and write

$$
\Omega_{\left[W, \rho_{W}\right]}^{\infty} M T \Theta \subset \Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta
$$

for the path component containing $\alpha\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$. This is the path component that the map (12.4.1) lands in.

The map (12.4.1) is given by a parametrised version of this construction: given a family $\left(\pi: E \rightarrow X, \rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta\right)$ as in Definition 12.2.1 over some base manifold $X$, it associates a continuous map $\alpha: X \rightarrow \Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$. Said differently, it comes from a composition of spectrum maps, the parametrised analogues of (12.4.3) and (12.4.2) respectively,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma_{+}^{\infty} X & \longrightarrow E^{-T_{\pi} E} \\
E^{-T_{\pi} E} & \longrightarrow M T \Theta
\end{aligned}
$$

In any case, (12.4.1) is a universal version of this construction.
Remark 12.4.3. Applying spectrum homology and the Thom isomorphism to the first map in (12.4.4), we get precisely the fibre integration homomorphism (12.3.3), while the second gives (12.3.2). This explains the connection to the characteristic classes in §12.3.1.

Remark 12.4.4. There is an improvement to Theorem 12.4.1, in which the domain of (12.4.1) is replaced by a disconnected space $\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta}$ containing $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ as one of its path components, cf. $\S 12.4 .4$ below and [16, Section 8]. In this improved formulation, the number $g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) \in \mathbf{N}$ appearing in Theorem 12.4.1 is replaced by a function

$$
\pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta}\right) \xrightarrow{\alpha_{*}} \pi_{0}(M T \Theta) \xrightarrow{g^{\Theta}} \mathbf{Z}
$$

whose value on the path component $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ is the stable genus, defined in [17, Section 5] and [16, Section 1.3]. It is at least $g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$.

If we write $\chi: \pi_{0}(M T \Theta) \rightarrow \boldsymbol{Z}$ and $\sigma: \pi_{0}(M T \Theta) \rightarrow \boldsymbol{Z}$ be the homomorphisms arising from the Euler class and (for even $n$ ) the Hirzebruch class, then (12.3.7) defines a function $g^{a}: \pi_{0}(M T \Theta) \rightarrow \mathbf{N}$. In terms of this function, the estimate (12.3.6) also holds for $\bar{g}^{\Theta}$.

# 12.4.3 General tangential structures 

The requirement in Theorems 12.3.3 and 12.4.1 that $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ be $n$-connected appears quite restrictive at first sight. For example, it usually rules out the interesting special cases $\Theta=\{*\}$ and $\Theta=\{ \pm 1\}$ from Remark 12.2.8, so that the cohomology of $B \operatorname{Diff}(W)$ and $B \operatorname{Diff}^{\text {or }}(W)$ are not immediately calculated by Theorem 12.4.1.

A more generally useful version of Theorem 12.4.1, which holds without the connectivity assumption, may be deduced by a rather formal homotopy theoretic trick, based on the observation that the map (12.4.1) is functorial in the $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-space $\Theta$.

In particular, any map $\Theta \rightarrow \Theta$ induces a self-map of $\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$. The following result is [16, Corollary 1.9].

Theorem 12.4.5. For $d=2 n>4$ and $\Lambda$ a $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-space, let $W$ be a closed simply connected smooth d-dimensional manifold, and $\lambda_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Lambda$ be an equivariant map. Choose an equivariant Moore-Postnikov n-stage

$$
\lambda_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \xrightarrow{\rho_{W}} \Theta \xrightarrow{u} \Lambda
$$

i.e. a factorisation where $u$ is $n$-co-connected equivariant fibration and $\rho_{W}$ is an $n$-connected equivariant cofibration, and write $\mathrm{hAut}(u)$ for the group-like topological monoid consisting of equivariant weak equivalences $\Theta \rightarrow \Theta$ over $\Lambda$.

This topological monoid acts on $\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$, and there is a continuous map

$$
\alpha: \mathcal{M}^{\Lambda}\left(W, \lambda_{M}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta\right) / / \mathrm{hAut}(u)
$$

which, when regarded as a map onto the path component that it hits, induces an isomorphism in homology with local coefficients in degrees $\leq\left(g\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right)-4\right) / 3$, and if $\Theta$ is spherical it induces an isomorphism in integral homology in degrees $\leq\left(g\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right)-3\right) / 2$.

We emphasise that the homotopy orbit space is formed in the category of spaces, not of infinite loop spaces (there is a comparison map $\left(\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta\right) / / \mathrm{hAut}(u) \rightarrow$ $\left.\Omega^{\infty}((M T \Theta) / / \mathrm{hAut}(u)\right)$ but it is not a weak equivalence and we shall not need its codomain). Equivariant factorisations (12.4.5) always exist, and are unique up to contractible choice.

Let us also point out that the group $\pi_{0}(\operatorname{hAut}(u))$ likely acts non-trivially on $\pi_{0}(M T \Theta)$. The construction of the map (12.4.6), outlined in $\S 12.4 .4$ below, together with the orbitstabiliser theorem, lets us re-write the relevant path component of the codomain of (12.4.6) in the following way, which is how the theorem above is typically used in practice.

Corollary 12.4.6. Let $d, \Lambda, W, \lambda_{W}, \Theta, \rho_{W}$, and $u$ be as in Theorem 12.4.5, and write

$$
\operatorname{hAut}(u)_{\left[W, \rho_{W}\right]} \subset \operatorname{hAut}(u)
$$

for the submonoid stabilising the element $\left[W, \rho_{W}\right] \in \pi_{0}(M T \Theta)$ defined in $\S 12.4 .2$. The action of this submonoid on $\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$ restricts to an action on the path component $\Omega_{\left[W, \rho_{W}\right]}^{\infty} M T \Theta$ defined in $\S 12.4 .2$, and (12.4.6) factors through a map of path connected spaces

$$
\alpha: \mathcal{M}^{\Lambda}\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\Omega_{\left[W, \rho_{W}\right]}^{\infty} M T \Theta\right) / /\left(\operatorname{hAut}(u)_{\left[W, \rho_{W}\right]}\right)
$$

which induces an isomorphism on homology in a range, as in Theorem 12.4.5.
Remark 12.4.7. In both Theorem 12.4.5 and Corollary 12.4.6 above, the range is expressed in terms of $g\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right)$ but as explained in [16, Lemma 9.4] this is equal to $g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ when $\lambda_{W}$ is factored equivariantly as an $n$-connected map $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ followed by an $n$ co-connected map $u: \Theta \rightarrow \Lambda$. Hence the estimates in $\S 12.3 .4$ apply, when $e$ is the minimal number of generators for the abelian group $H_{n}\left(\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})\right)$. The value of $e$ likely depends on the map $\lambda_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Lambda$, even if $W$ and $\Lambda$ are fixed.

Remark 12.4.8. The fact that $u$ is $n$-co-connected implies that $\operatorname{hAut}(u)$ is an $(n-1)$-type. Hence it is in some sense a finite problem to determine and describe hAut $(u)$ : finitely many homotopy groups $\pi_{0}, \ldots, \pi_{n-1}$ and finitely many $k$-invariants.

This finiteness is one of the conceptual advantages of our approach to $\mathcal{M}(W) \simeq$ $B \operatorname{Diff}(W)$, over the more classical method which at first gives a formula for the structure space $\mathcal{S}(W) \simeq G(W) / \widetilde{\operatorname{Diff}}(W)$, where $G(W)$ is the monoid of homotopy equivalences from $W$ to itself and $\widetilde{\operatorname{Diff}}(W)$ is the block diffeomorphism group. In that method, one subsequently has to study the difference between $\operatorname{Diff}(W)$ and $\operatorname{Diff}(W)$, but also has to take

homotopy orbits by the monoid $G(W)$ of homotopy automorphisms of $W$. While this last step is in some sense "purely homotopy theory", it is in practice very difficult to get a good handle on $G(W)$, even when $W$ is relatively simple and even when one is working up to rational equivalence. See the work of Berglund and Madsen $[1,2]$ for a recent example.

# 12.4.4 Two fibre sequences 

In [16, Section 9], Theorem 12.4.5 is deduced from the special case given in Theorem 12.4.1 by a rather formal argument: the homology equivalence in Theorem 12.4.1 is natural in the $\mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})$-space $\Theta$, and hence induces a homology equivalence by taking homotopy colimit over any diagram in $\mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})$-spaces; in particular one may form homotopy orbits by $\operatorname{hAut}(u: \Theta \rightarrow \Lambda)$, and Theorem 12.4.5 is deduced by identifying the resulting map of homotopy orbit spaces with (12.4.6). The two fibre sequences arising from these homotopy orbit constructions, see diagram (12.4.8) below, are important for carrying out calculations in concrete examples, and hence we recall this story in slightly more detail.

Definition 12.4.9. Let $u: \Theta \rightarrow \Lambda$ be an equivariant $n$-co-connected fibration.
(i) Let $\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta} \subset \mathcal{M}^{\Theta}$ be the union of those path components $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ for which $\rho_{W}$ : $\operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ is $n$-connected.
(ii) Let $\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Lambda} \subset \mathcal{M}^{\Lambda}$ be the union of those path components $\mathcal{M}^{\Lambda}\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right)$ for which $\lambda_{W}$ admits a factorisation through an $n$-connected equivariant map $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$.

There is an obvious forgetful map $\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{u}^{\Lambda}$ given by composing $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow$ $\Theta$ with $u$. The monoid $\operatorname{hAut}(u)$ has the correct homotopy type when $\Theta$ is equivariantly cofibrant, which we shall assume. It acts on $\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta}$ by postcomposing $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ with self-maps of $\Theta$. This action commutes with the forgetful map, and induces a map

$$
\left(\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta}\right) / / \operatorname{hAut}(u) \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}_{u}^{\Lambda}
$$

The following lemma is proved by elementary homotopy theoretic methods, cf. [16, Section 9].

Lemma 12.4.10. The map (12.4.7) is a weak equivalence. Hence there is an induced fibre sequence of the form

$$
\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta} \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}_{u}^{\Lambda} \longrightarrow B(\operatorname{hAut}(u))
$$

The map $\mathcal{M}_{u}^{\Theta} \rightarrow \Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$ explained in $\S 12.4 .2$ commutes with the actions of $\operatorname{hAut}(u)$ and induces a map of fibre sequences
![img-132.jpeg](img-132.jpeg)

In the setup of Theorem 12.4.5, $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ is one path component of $\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta}$, and similarly $\mathcal{M}^{\Lambda}\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right)$ is one path component of $\mathcal{M}_{u}^{\Lambda}$. A slightly stronger version of Theorem 12.4.1,

which is the statement actually proved in [16, Section 8], shows that the left-most vertical map is acyclic in the range of degrees indicated in Remark 12.4.4. Theorem 12.4.5 is then deduced by a spectral sequence comparison argument.

Remark 12.4.11. This formulation has content even at the level of path components. Suppose that $W$ is a simply connected $2 n$-manifold for $2 n \geq 6, \rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ is $n$-connected, and $g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) \geq 3$. If $\left(W^{\prime}, \rho_{W^{\prime}}\right)$ is another such $\Theta$-manifold and

$$
\alpha\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)=\alpha\left(W^{\prime}, \rho_{W^{\prime}}\right) \in \pi_{0}\left(\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta\right)=\pi_{0}(M T \Theta)
$$

then it follows that $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ and $\left(W^{\prime}, \rho_{W^{\prime}}\right)$ lie in the same path-component of $\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta}$, i.e. there is a diffeomorphism from $W$ to $W^{\prime}$ which pulls back $\rho_{W^{\prime}}$ to $\rho_{W}$ up to homotopy. This recovers a theorem of Kreck [28, Theorem D], though our requirement on genus is slightly stronger than Kreck's.

In practice, one usually calculates the cohomology of $\Omega_{\left[W, \rho_{W}\right]}^{\infty} M T \Theta$ first, and then uses a spectral sequence to calculate the homology or cohomology of the Borel construction in Corollary 12.4.6, or equivalently (for $g\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right) \geq 3$ ) one calculates the cohomology of $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ and then uses the spectral sequence for the fibre sequence

$$
\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\Lambda}\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right) \longrightarrow B\left(\operatorname{hAut}(u)_{\left[W, \rho_{W}\right]}\right)
$$

We shall see examples of such calculations in $\S 12.5 .2, \S 12.5 .3$, and $\S 12.5 .4$.

# 12.4.5 $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-spaces versus spaces over $B \mathrm{O}(d)$ 

It is well known that the homotopy theory of spaces with action of $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ is equivalent to the homotopy theory of spaces over $B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) \simeq B \mathrm{O}(d)$, where the weak equivalences are the equivariant maps that are weak equivalences of underlying spaces, respectively fibrewise maps that are weak equivalences of underlying spaces. The translation goes via the space $E \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ which simultaneously comes with an action of $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ and a map to $B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$. Explicitly, given a $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-space $\Theta$, the Borel construction $B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ comes with a map $B \rightarrow B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$; conversely, given a space $B$ and a map $\theta: B \rightarrow B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ the fibre product $\Theta=E \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R}) \times_{B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})} B$ comes with an action; these processes are inverse up to (equivariant/fibrewise) weak equivalence, as $E \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ is contractible.

Therefore all of the theorems above that depend on a $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-space $\Theta$ may be stated in equivalent ways taking as input a space $B$ and a map $\theta: B \rightarrow B \mathrm{O}(d)$. In the papers $[14,17,16]$ we have taken the latter point of view. In this picture, a $\theta$-structure on a manifold $W$ is a (fibrewise linear) vector bundle map $\tilde{\ell}_{W}: T W \rightarrow \theta^{*} \gamma$, where $\gamma$ denotes the universal vector bundle on $B \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$. As in those papers, we shall use the notation

$$
M T \theta=M T \Theta
$$

when $\theta: B \rightarrow B \mathrm{O}(d)$ is the map corresponding to the $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-space $\Theta$; i.e., $M T \theta=B^{-\theta}$ is the Thom spectrum of the virtual inverse of the vector bundle classified by $\theta: B \rightarrow B \mathrm{O}(d)$.

We have already seen definitions which may be stated more directly in terms of $(B, \theta)$ than of ( $\Theta$,action), e.g. the characteristic classes $\kappa_{c}$ from $\S 12.3 .1$. The constructions in

Theorem 12.4.5 form another such example, which we shall now explain. Given $\Lambda$ and $\lambda_{W}$ as in the theorem, set $B^{\prime}=\Lambda / / G L_{d}(\mathbf{R})$. Up to contractible choice, $\lambda_{W}$ induces a map $W \rightarrow B^{\prime}$, which one then Moore-Postnikov factors as

$$
W \longrightarrow B \longrightarrow B^{\prime}
$$

into an $n$-connected cofibration followed by an $n$-co-connected fibration. In this picture, $\operatorname{hAut}(u)$ is simply the group-like monoid of those self-maps of $B$ over $B^{\prime}$ that are weak equivalences. For this to have to the correct homotopy type $B$ should be fibrant and cofibrant in the category of spaces over $B^{\prime}$.

In $\S 12.5$ and $\S 12.6$ we will exclusively adopt this point of view.

# 12.4.6 Boundary 

A further generalisation, also proved in [16, Section 9], allows the compact manifolds $W$ to have nonempty boundary. The boundary should then be a closed $(2 n-1)$-manifold $P$, which should be equipped with an equivariant map $\rho_{P}: \operatorname{Fr}\left(\varepsilon^{1} \oplus T P\right) \rightarrow \Theta$. The pair $\left(P, \rho_{P}\right)$ should be fixed and every compact $2 n$-manifold in sight should come with a specified diffeomorphism $\partial W \cong P$ compatible with a structure $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$.

In terms of classified bundles as in $\S 12.2 .1$ and $\S 12.2 .2, \mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta}$ should be replaced with the functor $\mathcal{F}_{\bullet}^{\Theta, P, \rho_{P}}$ whose value on a smooth manifold $X$ (without boundary, possibly noncompact) has 0 -simplices the smooth proper maps $\pi: E \rightarrow X$ equipped with equivariant maps $\rho: \operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E\right) \rightarrow \Theta$ and a diffeomorphism $\partial E=X \times P$ such that the restriction of $\rho$ to $\operatorname{Fr}\left(T_{\pi} E \mid \partial E\right)=X \times \operatorname{Fr}(T P)$ is equal to the map arising from $\rho_{P}$.

This kind of bundle also admits a classifying space, denoted $\mathcal{N}^{\Theta}\left(P, \rho_{P}\right)$ and called the moduli space of null bordisms of $\left(P, \rho_{P}\right)$. The subspace defined by the condition that $\rho_{W}$ : $\operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$ be $n$-connected is denoted $\mathcal{N}_{n}^{\Theta}\left(P, \rho_{P}\right)$ and is the moduli space of highly connected null bordisms. The path component of $\mathcal{N}^{\Theta}\left(P, \rho_{P}\right)$ containing $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$ shall be denoted $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$, as before. Notice that $\left(P, \rho_{P}\right)$ is determined by $P=\partial W$ and $\rho_{W}$ by restricting $\rho_{W}$ to $\left.T W\right|_{P} \cong \varepsilon^{1} \oplus T P$. These classifying spaces are introduced in [16, Definition 1.1] using a similar notation.

Theorem 12.4.1 then has the following direct generalisation, also stated as [16, Corollary 1.8 and Section 8.4].

Theorem 12.4.12. Let $d=2 n>4$, let $\Theta$ be a $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-space, let $P$ be a closed smooth $(d-1)$-manifold and $\rho_{P}: \operatorname{Fr}\left(\varepsilon^{1} \oplus T P\right) \rightarrow \Theta$ be a $\mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$-equivariant map. Then there is a map (canonical up to homotopy, see below)

$$
\alpha: \mathcal{N}_{n}^{\Theta}\left(P, \rho_{P}\right) \longrightarrow \Omega_{\alpha\left(P, \rho_{P}\right), 0}\left(\Omega^{\infty-1} M T \Theta\right)
$$

where $\Omega_{\alpha\left(P, \rho_{P}\right), 0}$ denotes the space of paths starting at a certain point $\alpha\left(P, \rho_{P}\right) \in \Omega^{\infty-1} M T \Theta$ and ending at the basepoint, with the following property.

When restricted to the path component containing a particular $\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$, it is a homology equivalence onto the path component it hits, in degrees up to $\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-4\right) / 3$ and possibly with twisted coefficients. If in addition $\Theta$ is spherical, then (12.4.10) induces an isomorphism in homology with constant coefficients in degrees up to $\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-3\right) / 2$.

Both the point $\alpha\left(P, \rho_{P}\right)$ and the map (12.4.10) are constructed by the procedure in $\S 12.4 .2$. If the codomain of (12.4.10) is nonempty, it is of course non-canonically homotopy equivalent to $\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta$, but the map most naturally takes values in the path space. In the special case $P=\emptyset$ we have $\mathcal{N}_{n}^{\Theta}(\emptyset)=\mathcal{M}_{n}^{\Theta}$, and the map (12.4.10) is the same as the map appearing in (12.4.8).

As in $\S 12.4 .4$, a version for a general tangential structure $\Lambda$ may be deduced by taking homotopy orbits with respect to the monoid

$$
\operatorname{hAut}(u \operatorname{rel} P)=\left\{\phi \in \operatorname{hAut}(u) \mid \phi \circ \rho_{P}=\rho_{P}\right\}
$$

provided $\rho_{P}: \operatorname{Fr}\left(\varepsilon^{1} \oplus T P\right) \rightarrow \Theta$ is an equivariant cofibration and $u: \Theta \rightarrow \Lambda$ is an equivariant $n$-co-connected fibration, as can be arranged. Homotopy equivalently, factor the induced map $W \rightarrow B^{\prime}=\Lambda / / G L_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ as an $n$-connected cofibration $W \rightarrow B$ followed by an $n$-coconnected fibration $B \rightarrow B^{\prime}$, and define $\operatorname{hAut}(u \operatorname{rel} P)$ as the homotopy equivalences of $B$ over $B^{\prime}$ and under $P$. We formulate the conclusion.

Theorem 12.4.13. Let $n, d, \Lambda$ and $\lambda_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Lambda$ be as in Theorem 12.4.5, but allow $W$ to be a compact manifold with boundary $P=\partial W$. Let $\Theta, \rho_{W}$, and $u$ be as in Theorem 12.4.5, and $\rho_{P}$ denote the restriction of $\rho_{W}$ to $P$. Then there is a map

$$
\alpha: \mathcal{M}^{\Lambda}\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\Omega_{\alpha\left(P, \rho_{P}\right), 0} \Omega^{\infty-1} M T \Theta\right) / / \operatorname{hAut}(u \operatorname{rel} P)
$$

which, when regarded as a map onto the path component that it hits, induces an isomorphism in homology in a range of degrees, exactly as in Theorem 12.4.5.

This is [16, Theorem 9.5], and the three lines following its proof. The relevant path component may again be re-written using the orbit-stabiliser theorem, as in Corollary 12.4.6.

Remark 12.4.14. As in Remark 12.2.8, in the special case $\Theta=\{*\}$ a $\Theta$-structure contains no information and we can simply write $\mathcal{M}(W)$ for $\mathcal{M}^{\Theta}\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)$. This space classifies smooth fibre bundles with fibres diffeomorphic to $W$ and trivialised boundary, and we have a weak equivalence

$$
\mathcal{M}(W) \simeq B \operatorname{Diff}_{\partial}(W)
$$

where $\operatorname{Diff}_{\partial}(W)$ denotes the group of diffeomorphisms of $W$ which fix an open neighbourhood of the boundary, with the $C^{\infty}$ topology.

There are no connectivity assumptions imposed on $\rho_{P}: \operatorname{Fr}\left(\varepsilon^{1} \oplus T P\right) \rightarrow \Theta$, but if it happens to be $(n-1)$-connected then the monoid $\operatorname{hAut}(u \operatorname{rel} P)$ is contractible. More generally we have the following.

Lemma 12.4.15. If the pair $(W, P)$ is c-connected for some $c \leq n-1$, then the monoid $\operatorname{hAut}(u \operatorname{rel} P)$ is a (nonempty) $(n-c-2)$-type. In particular, it is contractible if $(W, P)$ is $(n-1)$-connected.

A familiar special case of this observation is the fact that if a diffeomorphism of an oriented surface with nonempty boundary is the identity on the boundary, then the diffeomorphism is automatically orientation preserving.

Proof. As before, let us write $B=\Theta / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$ and $B^{\prime}=\Lambda / / \mathrm{GL}_{d}(\mathbf{R})$. We are then asking for homotopy automorphisms of $B$ over $u: B \rightarrow B^{\prime}$ and under $\ell_{P}: P \hookrightarrow B$. By adjunction, to give a nullhomotopy of a map $f: S^{k} \rightarrow \operatorname{hAut}(u$ rel $P)$ is to solve the relative lifting problem
![img-133.jpeg](img-133.jpeg)

The map $\ell_{P}: P \rightarrow B$ is $c$-connected because both $P \subset W$ and $\ell_{W}: W \rightarrow B$ are (the latter is even $n$-connected). Thus the pair

$$
\left(D^{k+1} \times B,\left(S^{k} \times B\right) \cup_{S^{k} \times P}\left(D^{k+1} \times P\right)\right)
$$

is $(c+k+1)$-connected. But the map $u: B \rightarrow B^{\prime}$ is $n$-co-connected, so there are no obstructions to solving this lifting problem if $c+k+1 \geq n$, i.e. $k \geq n-c-1$. This proves that $\operatorname{hAut}(u$ rel $P)$ is an $(n-c-2)$-type, and it is nonempty because it contains the identity map.

Remark 12.4.16. Formulating a statement which is valid for manifolds with nonempty boundaries is not purely for the purpose of added generality: it is essential for the strategy of proof in all three papers [14], [17], [16]. For example, the homological stability results in [17] are proved by a long handle induction argument, in which a compact manifold is decomposed into finitely many handle attachments; even if one is mainly interested in closed manifolds, this process will create boundary. Similarly, an important role in both [14] and [16] is played by cobordism categories as studied in [13], whose morphisms are manifolds with boundary and composition is gluing along common boundary components. For example, given a $\Theta$-cobordism $\left(K, \rho_{K}\right):\left(P, \rho_{P}\right) \leadsto\left(Q, \rho_{Q}\right)$ there is a continuous map

$$
\left(K, \rho_{K}\right) \cup-: \mathcal{N}^{\Theta}\left(P, \rho_{P}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{N}^{\Theta}\left(Q, \rho_{Q}\right)
$$

given by gluing on $\left(K, \rho_{K}\right)$.

# 12.4.7 Fundamental group 

The main theorem in either of the three forms given above (Theorems 12.3.3, 12.4.1, and 12.4.5) assumed the manifolds $W$ were simply connected, but in fact it suffices that the fundamental groups $\pi=\pi_{1}(W, w)$ be virtually polycyclic, i.e. has a subnormal series with finite or cyclic quotients. In this case the Hirsch length $h(\pi)$ is the number of infinite cyclic quotients in such a series. The only price to pay is that the ranges of homology equivalence become offset by a constant depending on $h(\pi)$ : the homology isomorphisms Theorems 12.4.1 and 12.4.5 hold in degrees $\leq\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-(h(\pi)+5)\right) / 2$ with integral coefficients if $\Theta$ is spherical, and in degrees $\leq\left(g\left(W, \rho_{W}\right)-(h(\pi)+6)\right) / 3$ with local coefficients. This generalisation was established by Friedrich [11].

For arbitrary $\pi$ there is a sense in which the theorems hold in "infinite genus": certain maps become acyclic after taking a colimit over forming connected sum with $S^{n} \times S^{n}$

infinitely many times. In this form the assumption $2 n>4$ is also unnecessary. See [16, Sections 1.2 and 7] for the statement and proof.

# 12.4.8 Outlook 

We have attempted to give an overview of the methods developed in [14], [17], [16], with an emphasis on the main results from there as they may be applied in calculations in practice. This is by no means a survey of everything known; let us briefly mention some recent developments and applications that we have not covered:
(i) These results - in the form of the calculation described in Theorem 12.5.1 below-have been used by Weiss [50] to prove that $p_{n} \neq e^{2} \in H^{4 n}(B \operatorname{STop}(2 n) ; \mathbf{Q})$ for large enough $n$. These methods were later used by Kupers [30] to establish the finite generation of homotopy groups of $\operatorname{Diff}_{\partial}\left(D^{d}\right)$ for $d \neq 4,5,7$.
(ii) These results have been used by Botvinnik, Ebert, and Randal-Williams [3], Ebert and Randal-Williams [10], and Botvinnik, Ebert, and Wraith [4] to study the topology of spaces of Riemannian metrics of positive scalar, or Ricci, curvature.
(iii) These results have been used by Krannich [24] to show that if $\Sigma$ is a homotopy $2 n$ sphere then $B \operatorname{Diff}(M)$ and $B \operatorname{Diff}(M \# \Sigma)$ have the same homology in the stable range with $\mathbf{Z}_{[k]}^{11}$-coefficients, where $k$ is the order of $\Sigma$ is the group of homotopy spheres.
(iv) Progress towards a similar understanding for manifolds of odd dimension has been made by Perlmutter [42, 43, 44], Botvinnik and Perlmutter [6] and Hebestreit and Perlmutter [22].
(v) Progress towards versions for topological and piecewise linear manifolds has been made by Gomez-Lopez [19], Kupers [29], and Gomez-Lopez and Kupers [20].
(vi) Progress towards versions for equivariant smooth manifolds has been made by Galatius and Szücs [18].
(vii) There are analogues of many of the theorems above, when the topological group $\operatorname{Diff}(W)$ is replaced by its underlying discrete group, by Nariman [39, 40, 38].
(viii) Progress towards understanding the homotopy equivalences of high genus manifolds have been obtained by Berglund and Madsen [2]. At present their results seem to be qualitatively quite different from the results described here.

### 12.5 Rational cohomology calculations

We have already advertised the feature that the general theory surveyed in $\S 12.3$ and $\S 12.4$ above is amenable to explicit calculations. In this section and the next, we back up this claim with some examples, while simultaneously illustrating how the abstract homotopy theory in $\S 12.4$ plays out in concrete examples.

In practice, given a manifold $W$ and a structure $\lambda_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(W) \rightarrow \Lambda$, one typically first estimates the genus of $\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right)$. This step is trivial for the manifolds considered in $\S 12.5 .1$ and $\S 12.5 .2$ below, which are defined to have high genus, but is quite interesting for the complete intersections considered in $\S 12.5 .3$. The next step would typically be to determine the associated highly connected structure $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(W) \rightarrow \Theta$ and the space $B \mathrm{hAut}(u$ rel $P)$. This step is mostly resolved by Lemma 12.4.15 for the example given in $\S 12.5 .1$, but is again interesting for the examples in $\S 12.5 .2$ and especially $\S 12.5 .3$. For calculations in rational cohomology, the last step would then typically be to understand the Serre spectral sequence associated to (12.4.9). The complete intersections in $\S 12.5 .3$ again provide an interesting and very non-trivial illustration.

# 12.5.1 The manifolds $W_{g, 1}$ 

Recall that we write $W_{g}=g\left(S^{n} \times S^{n}\right)$ for the $g$-fold connected sum, and $W_{g, 1}=$ $D^{2 n} \# W_{g} \cong W_{g} \backslash \operatorname{int}\left(D^{2 n}\right)$. These manifolds play a distinguished role in the theory described above, as they are used to measure the genus of arbitrary $2 n$-manifolds: in this sense $W_{g, 1}$ is the simplest manifold of genus $g$. In the case $2 n=2$ the solution by Madsen and Weiss [33] of the Mumford Conjecture gave a description of $H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g, 1}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ in terms of Miller-Morita-Mumford classes in a stable range of degrees. In this section we wish to explain how the analogue of Madsen and Weiss' result in dimensions $2 n \geq 6$ follows from the theory described above.

The Moore-Postnikov $n$-stage

$$
\tau_{W_{g, 1}}: W_{g, 1} \xrightarrow{\ell_{W_{g, 1}}} B \xrightarrow{\theta} B \mathrm{O}(2 n)
$$

of a map classifying the tangent bundle of $W_{g, 1}$ has the cofibration $\ell_{W_{g, 1}} n$-connected and the fibration $\theta n$-co-connected. As $W_{g, 1}$ is $(n-1)$-connected and the map $\tau_{W_{g, 1}}$ is nullhomotopic - because $W_{g, 1}$ admits a framing-we may identify $\theta$ with the $n$-connected cover of $B \mathrm{O}(2 n)$, which we write as

$$
\theta_{n}: B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle \xrightarrow{\theta_{n}^{\mathrm{or}}} B \mathrm{SO}(2 n) \xrightarrow{\text { or }} B \mathrm{O}(2 n)
$$

As the pair $\left(W_{g, 1}, \partial W_{g, 1}\right)$ is $(n-1)$-connected, by Lemma 12.4 .15 we find that $\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}, \ell_{\partial W_{g, 1}}\right)$ is contractible. Thus by Theorem 12.4.13 there is a map

$$
\alpha: \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g, 1}\right) \simeq \mathcal{M}^{\theta_{n}}\left(W_{g, 1}, \ell_{W_{g, 1}}\right) \longrightarrow \Omega^{\infty} M T \theta_{n}
$$

which is a homology equivalence onto the path component that it hits, in degrees $* \leq \frac{g-3}{2}$, as long as $2 n \geq 6$. The rational cohomology of a path component of $\Omega^{\infty} M T \theta_{n}$ is calculated as described in Remark 12.4.2, in terms of $H^{*}(B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle ; \mathbf{Q})$. To work this out we identify $B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle=B \mathrm{SO}(2 n)\langle n\rangle$. As

$$
H^{*}(B \mathrm{SO}(2 n) ; \mathbf{Q})=\mathbf{Q}\left[e, p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{n-1}\right]
$$

is a free graded-commutative algebra the effect of taking the $n$-connected cover on cohomology groups is a simple as possible: it simply eliminates all free generators of degree $\leq n$.

Thus

$$
H^{*}(B \mathrm{SO}(2 n)\langle n\rangle ; \mathbf{Q})=\mathbf{Q}\left[e, p_{\left\lceil\frac{n+1}{2}\right\rceil}, \ldots, p_{n-1}\right]
$$

Combining all the above, we obtain the following.
Theorem 12.5.1. For $2 n \geq 6$, let $\mathcal{B}$ denote the set of monomials in the classes $e, p_{n-1}$, $p_{n-2}, \ldots, p_{\left[\frac{n+1}{2}\right]}$. Then the map

$$
\mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{c} \mid c \in \mathcal{B},|c|>2 n\right] \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{or}}\left(W_{g, 1}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)
$$

is an isomorphism in degrees $* \leq \frac{g-3}{2}$.
This is [17, Corollary 1.8]. As we mentioned above, for $2 n=2$ the same statement (with a slightly different range) was earlier proved by Madsen and Weiss.

# 12.5.2 The manifolds $W_{g}$ 

For $2 n=2$ it is a theorem of Harer [21] that the map

$$
\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{or}}\left(W_{g, 1}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{or}}\left(W_{g}\right)
$$

given by attaching a disk induces an isomorphism on homology in a stable range of degrees. On the other hand $\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right)$ is the homotopy type of the stack $\mathbf{M}_{g}$ of genus $g$ Riemann surfaces, and it is in this way that Madsen and Weiss' topological result determines $H^{*}\left(\mathbf{M}_{g} ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ in a stable range.

In dimensions $2 n \geq 6$ it is no longer true that the map (12.5.1) induces an isomorphism on homology in a stable range of degrees. In this section we shall explain why, by using the theory described above to calculate $H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ in a stable range.

Continuing to write

$$
\theta_{n}: B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle \xrightarrow{g \text { or }} B \mathrm{SO}(2 n) \xrightarrow{\text { or }} B \mathrm{O}(2 n)
$$

as in the previous section, this tangential structure is also the Moore-Postnikov $n$-stage of the map classifying the tangent bundle of $W_{g}$. By Theorem 12.4.5 there is a map

$$
\alpha: \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\Omega^{\infty} M T \theta_{n}\right) / / \mathrm{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)
$$

that induces an isomorphism on homology, onto the path component that it hits, in degrees $* \leq \frac{g-3}{2}$ as long as $2 n \geq 6$.

In order to calculate the rational cohomology of $\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right)$ in a range of degrees we could try to calculate the rational cohomology of the relevant path component of $\left(\Omega^{\infty} M T \theta_{n}\right) / / \mathrm{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)$, but instead we shall use the fibre sequence (12.4.9). Choosing a $\theta_{n}$-structure $\ell_{W_{g}}$ on $W_{g}$, this is a fibre sequence

$$
\mathcal{M}^{\theta_{n}}\left(W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) \xrightarrow{\xi} B\left(\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)_{\left[W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right]}\right)
$$

As $\ell_{W_{g}}: W_{g} \rightarrow B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle$ is $n$-connected, we may apply Theorem 12.3.3, giving that

$$
\mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{c} \mid c \in \mathcal{B},|c|>2 n\right] \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\theta_{n}}\left(W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)
$$

is an isomorphism in degrees $* \leq \frac{g-3}{2}$. All the classes $\kappa_{c}$ are defined on the total space $\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right)$ of the fibration (12.5.2), which implies that this fibration satisfies the LerayHirsch property in the stable range. Thus the Leray-Hirsch map

$$
\mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{c} \mid c \in \mathcal{B},|c|>2 n\right] \otimes H^{*}\left(B\left(\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)_{\left[W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right]}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right) \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)
$$

is an isomorphism in degrees $* \leq \frac{g-3}{2}$.
To complete this calculation we must calculate the rational cohomology of the space $B\left(\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)_{\left[W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right]}\right.$, and describe the map

$$
\xi^{*}: H^{*}\left(B\left(\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)_{\left[W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right]}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right) \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)
$$

in terms that we understand.

# 12.5.2.1 Identifying $\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)$ 

The map $\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}: B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle \rightarrow B \mathrm{SO}(2 n)$ is a principal fibration for the group-like topological monoid $\mathrm{SO}[0, n-1]$, the truncation of SO , so is classified by the map $B \mathrm{SO}(2 n) \rightarrow$ $B \mathrm{SO} \rightarrow B(\mathrm{SO}[0, n-1])$, and hence there is a homomorphism

$$
\iota: \mathrm{SO}[0, n-1] \longrightarrow \operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)
$$

given by the principal group action.
Lemma 12.5.2. The map $\iota$ is a weak homotopy equivalence.
Proof. If we fix a basepoint $* \in B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle$, which identifies the fibre through $*$ with $\mathrm{SO}[0, n-1]$, then there is a map

$$
\begin{aligned}
e v: \operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right) & \longrightarrow \mathrm{SO}[0, n-1] \\
\varphi & \longmapsto \varphi(*)
\end{aligned}
$$

and it is clear that $e v \circ \iota$ is the identity. Thus it is enough to show that $e v$ is a weak homotopy equivalence. Suppose we are given a map $(f, g):\left(D^{k+1}, S^{k}\right) \rightarrow\left(\mathrm{SO}[0, n-1], \operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)\right)$. This determines a relative lifting problem

$$
\left(S^{k} \times B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle\right) \cup_{S^{k} \times\{*\}}\left(D^{k+1} \times\{*\}\right) \xrightarrow{g \cup f} B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle
$$

and finding a nullhomotopy of $(f, g)$ is the same as solving this relative lifting problem. The obstructions for doing so lie in the groups

$$
\widetilde{H}^{i-k}(B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle ; \pi_{i+1}(B \mathrm{SO}(2 n), B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle))
$$

but these groups are zero if $i-k \leq n$ or if $i \geq n$, so always vanish.
In particular, the submonoid $\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)_{\left[W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right]} \leq \operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)$ is in fact the whole of $\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)$, so we may identify the cohomology of its classifying space with

$$
H^{*}\left(B \operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)=H^{*}(B \mathrm{SO}[0, n] ; \mathbf{Q})=\mathbf{Q}\left[p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{\left\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\right\rfloor}\right]
$$

# 12.5.2.2 Miller-Morita-Mumford class interpretation 

Combining (12.5.3) and (12.5.4) gives a formula for $H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ in a range of degrees. In fact the classes obtained by pulling back $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{\left\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\right\rfloor}$ along the map

$$
\xi: \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) \longrightarrow B \operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)
$$

may be re-interpreted as Miller-Morita-Mumford classes. We shall use the following lemma to explain this.
Lemma 12.5.3. Let $\pi^{\text {or }}: \mathcal{E}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right)$ denote the the path component of the fibration (12.2.4) modelling the universal oriented $W_{g}$-bundle, and $\tau: \mathcal{E}^{\text {or }}\left(W_{g}\right) \rightarrow B \mathrm{SO}(2 n)$ denote the map classifying the vertical tangent bundle. Then the square
![img-134.jpeg](img-134.jpeg)
commutes up to homotopy.
Proof. Let $\pi^{\theta_{n}}: \mathcal{E}^{\theta_{n}}\left(W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\theta_{n}}\left(W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right)$ denote the path component of the fibration modelling the universal $W_{g}$-bundle with $\theta_{n}$-structure, which as in (12.2.4) comes with maps

$$
\tau: \mathcal{E}^{\theta_{n}}\left(W_{g}, \ell_{W_{g}}\right) \xrightarrow{\ell} B \mathrm{O}(2 n)\langle n\rangle \xrightarrow{\theta_{n}^{\text {or}}} B \mathrm{SO}(2 n)
$$

whose composition classifies the (oriented) vertical tangent bundle. This gives a commutative square
![img-135.jpeg](img-135.jpeg)
of $\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)$-spaces and $\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right)$-equivariant maps. Taking homotopy orbits, and replacing the spaces at each corner with homotopy equivalent models, we obtain the homotopy

commutative square
![img-136.jpeg](img-136.jpeg)

Here the right-hand map is the truncation $B \mathrm{SO}(2 n) \rightarrow B \mathrm{SO}(2 n)[0, n]$ followed by the identification $B \mathrm{SO}(2 n)[0, n] \xrightarrow{\sim} B \mathrm{SO}[0, n]$, as required.

Now we may calculate as follows: by this lemma we have

$$
\left(\pi^{\mathrm{or}}\right)^{*} \xi^{*}\left(p_{i}\right)=\tau^{*}\left(p_{i}\right)
$$

and so by the projection formula (and commutativity of the cup product)

$$
\kappa_{e p_{i}}=\int_{\pi^{\mathrm{or}}} \tau^{*}\left(e \cdot p_{i}\right)=\left(\int_{\pi^{\mathrm{or}}} \tau^{*} e\right) \cdot \xi^{*}\left(p_{i}\right)=\chi\left(W_{g}\right) \cdot \xi^{*}\left(p_{i}\right)
$$

and hence, for $\chi\left(W_{g}\right)=2+(-1)^{n} 2 g \neq 0$, we have $\xi^{*}\left(p_{i}\right)=\frac{1}{\chi\left(W_{g}\right)} \kappa_{e p_{i}}$.
Combined with the previous discussion, we obtain the following.
Theorem 12.5.4. For $2 n \geq 6$, let $\mathcal{B}$ denote the set of monomials in the classes $e, p_{n-1}$, $p_{n-2}, \ldots, p_{\left\lceil\frac{n+1}{4}\right\rceil}$, and $\mathcal{C}$ denote the set of the remaining Pontryagin classes $p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{\left\lfloor\frac{n}{4}\right\rfloor}$. Then the map

$$
\mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{c} \mid c \in(\mathcal{B} \sqcup e \cdot \mathcal{C}),|c|>2 n\right] \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{or}}\left(W_{g}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)
$$

is an isomorphism in degrees $* \leq(g-3) / 2$.
For $2 n=2$ the same statement (with a slightly different range) holds by the theorem of Madsen and Weiss, and in this case the set $\mathcal{C}$ is empty and the result is the same as that of Theorem 12.5.1. For $2 n \geq 6$ we have $\operatorname{hAut}\left(\theta_{n}^{\text {or }}\right) \simeq \mathrm{SO}[0, n-1] \not \equiv *$ and so it follows from the discussion in this section that the map (12.5.1) is not an isomorphism on integral cohomology in any range of degrees (though for $2 n=6$ it is still an isomorphism on rational cohomology in a stable range, as $\mathrm{SO}[0,2] \simeq K(\mathbf{Z} / 2,1)$ is rationally acyclic; in Theorem 12.5.4 this corresponds to the fact that $\mathcal{C}$ is empty in this case).

Remark 12.5.5. In the statement of Theorem 12.5.4 we do not assert that $\kappa_{c}=0$ for monomials $c \notin \mathcal{B} \sqcup e \cdot \mathcal{C}$. Indeed a further consequence of the homotopy commutativity of (12.5.5) is the following description of $\kappa_{c}$ for a general monomial $c=e^{i} \cdot p_{1}^{j_{1}} \cdots p_{n-1}^{j_{n-1}}$ in terms of the generators of Theorem 12.5.4:

$$
\kappa_{c}=\left(\frac{\kappa_{e \cdot p_{1}}}{\chi\left(W_{g}\right)}\right)^{j_{1}} \cdot\left(\frac{\kappa_{e \cdot p_{2}}}{\chi\left(W_{g}\right)}\right)^{j_{2}} \cdots\left(\frac{\kappa_{e \cdot p_{k}}}{\chi\left(W_{g}\right)}\right)^{j_{k}} \cdot \kappa_{\left(e^{i} \cdot p_{k+1}^{k_{k+1}} \cdots p_{n-1}^{j_{n-1}}\right)}
$$

where we write $k=\left\lfloor\frac{n}{4}\right\rfloor$. This follows immediately from the observation that $p_{i}\left(T_{\pi}\right)=$ $\pi^{*} \xi^{*}\left(p_{i}\right)=\pi^{*}\left(\frac{\kappa_{e} \cdot p_{i}}{\chi\left(W_{g}\right)}\right)$ for $i \leq k$.

# 12.5.3 Hypersurfaces in $\mathrm{CP}^{4}$ 

If $V \subset \mathbf{C P}^{r+1}$ is a smooth hypersurface, determined by a homogeneous complex polynomial of degree $d$, then it is an observation of Thom that its diffeomorphism type depends only on the degree $d$, and not on the particular polynomial: we call the resulting $2 r$-manifold $V_{d}$. As we shall explain in $\S 12.5 .3 .2$, these interesting manifolds tend to have large genus. More generally, for smooth complete intersections of such hypersurfaces the diffeomorphism type depends only on the degrees, and much is understood about the classification up to diffeomorphism of such manifolds in terms of these degrees, by Libgober and Wood [31], Kreck [28], and others.

We shall explain how the theory described above applies in the non-trivial example of a hypersurface $V_{d} \subset \mathbf{C P}^{4}$ of degree $d$, and determine a formula for the rational cohomology of $\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right)$ in a range of degrees. Let us start with outlining the steps again, and state the conclusions in this example.
(i) Determine the genus of $V_{d}$ : it turns out to be $\frac{1}{2}\left(d^{4}-5 d^{3}+10 d^{2}-10 d+4\right)$.
(ii) Determine the Moore-Postnikov 3 -stage $V_{d} \xrightarrow{\ell_{V_{d}}} B_{d} \xrightarrow{\theta_{d}} B \mathrm{SO}(6)$ of a map classifying the oriented tangent bundle of $V_{d}$.
(iii) Calculate the ring $H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\theta_{d}}\left(V_{d}, \ell_{V_{d}}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ in the stable range. It turns out to be the Q-algebra

$$
A=\mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{t^{n} c} \mid c \in \mathcal{B}, n \geq 0,|c|+2 n>6\right]
$$

where $\mathcal{B}$ is the set of monomials in classes $p_{1}, p_{2}$, and $e$ of degree $\left|p_{1}\right|=4,\left|p_{2}\right|=8$, and $|e|=6$, and $t$ is a class of degree 2 .
(iv) Use the spectral sequence arising from Corollary 12.4.6 to determine the cohomology of $\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right)$ from that of $\mathcal{M}^{\theta_{d}}\left(V_{d}, \ell_{V_{d}}\right)$ in a stable range. The result is a short exact sequence

$$
0 \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right) \longrightarrow A \xrightarrow{d_{3}} A \longrightarrow 0
$$

where $d_{3}: A \rightarrow A$ is the unique derivation satisfying $d_{3}\left(\kappa_{t^{n} c}\right)=n \kappa_{t^{n-1} c}$. (The result is a scalar when $\left|t^{n-1} c\right|=6$; this scalar is a characteristic number of $V_{d}$ and therefore the derivation $d_{3}$ depends on the degree $d$.)

### 12.5.3.1 Algebraic topology of $V_{d}$

By the Lefschetz hyperplane theorem the inclusion $i: V_{d} \rightarrow \mathbf{C P}^{4}$ is 3 -connected. This first implies that $V_{d}$ is simply connected. Writing $H^{*}\left(\mathbf{C P}^{4} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)=\mathbf{Z}[x] /\left(x^{5}\right)$ for $x=c_{1}(\mathcal{O}(1))$ and $t=i^{*}(x)$, we have

$$
H^{0}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)=\mathbf{Z} \quad H^{1}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)=0 \quad H^{2}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)=\mathbf{Z}\{t\}
$$

and hence by Poincaré duality we have

$$
H^{4}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)=\mathbf{Z}\{s\} \quad H^{5}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)=0 \quad H^{6}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)=\mathbf{Z}\{u\}
$$

where $\left\langle\left[V_{d}\right], u\right\rangle=1$ and $s \cdot t=u$. We also have $\left\langle i_{*}\left[V_{d}\right], x^{3}\right\rangle=d$, obtained by intersecting $V_{d}$ with a generic $\mathbf{C P}^{1} \subset \mathbf{C P}^{4}$, giving $t^{3}=d \cdot u$ and hence $t^{2}=d \cdot s$. By definition, $V_{d}$ is the zero locus of a transverse section of $\mathcal{O}(d) \rightarrow \mathbf{C P}^{4}$, so its normal bundle in $\mathbf{C P}^{4}$ is $i^{*}(\mathcal{O}(d))$ and hence as complex vector bundles we have

$$
T V_{d} \oplus i^{*}(\mathcal{O}(d)) \oplus \underline{\mathbf{C}}=i^{*}\left(T \mathbf{C P}^{4}\right) \oplus \underline{\mathbf{C}}=i^{*}(\mathcal{O}(1))^{\oplus 5}
$$

so taking total Chern classes yields $c\left(T V_{d}\right)=i^{*}\left(\frac{(1+x)^{5}}{(1+d x)}\right)$. We can therefore extract

$$
c_{3}\left(T V_{d}\right)=\left(\binom{5}{3}-\binom{5}{2} d+\binom{5}{1} d^{2}-d^{3}\right) t^{3}
$$

and so compute the Euler characteristic of $V_{d}$ as $\left\langle\left[V_{d}\right], c_{3}\left(T V_{d}\right)\right\rangle$ to be

$$
\chi\left(V_{d}\right)=d \cdot\left(10-10 d+5 d^{2}-d^{3}\right)
$$

We therefore find that $H^{3}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)$ is free of rank $4-\chi\left(V_{d}\right)=d^{4}-5 d^{3}+10 d^{2}-10 d+4$, which finishes our calculation of the cohomology of $V_{d}$.

For later use we record two further characteristic classes of $V_{d}$, namely

$$
\begin{aligned}
w_{2}\left(T V_{d}\right) & =(5-d) t \bmod 2 \\
p_{1}\left(T V_{d}\right) & =\left(5-d^{2}\right) t^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

obtained from the identities $w_{2} \equiv c_{1} \bmod 2$ and $p_{1}=c_{1}^{2}-2 c_{2}$ among characteristic classes of complex vector bundles.

# 12.5.3.2 Genus of $V_{d}$ 

The genus of $V_{d}$ may be estimated from below by the methods of $\S 12.3 .4$, but in this case it turns out that an exact formula is possible. It is a theorem of Wall [49] that any simply connected smooth 6-manifold $W$ has a decomposition $W \cong M \# g\left(S^{3} \times S^{3}\right)$ with $H_{3}(M ; \mathbf{Z})=0$, and so the genus of such a $W$ is given by half its third Betti number. Thus we have

$$
g\left(V_{d}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(d^{4}-5 d^{3}+10 d^{2}-10 d+4\right)
$$

Similar formulae are known for higher dimensional smooth complex complete intersection varieties, see e.g. $[51,37,7]$.

Remark 12.5.6. More generally, if $\mathcal{L}$ is an ample line bundle over a smooth projective complex manifold $M$ of complex dimension $n+1$ then for all $d \gg 0$ we may consider the smooth manifolds $U_{d}$ arising as the zeroes of generic holomorphic sections of $\mathcal{L}^{\otimes d}$. Writing $x:=c_{1}(\mathcal{L})$, as $\mathcal{L}$ is ample we have $N:=\int_{M} x^{n+1} \neq 0$. Writing $i: U_{d} \hookrightarrow M$ for the inclusion, and using that $i_{*}\left[U_{d}\right]$ is Poincaré dual to $e\left(\mathcal{L}^{\otimes d}\right)=d x$, it follows that $\int_{U_{d}} i^{*}(x)^{n}=d \cdot N \neq 0$. The analogue of the calculation above gives that $c\left(T U_{d}\right)=i^{*}\left(\frac{c(T M)}{(1+d x)}\right)$ and hence we have $\chi\left(U_{d}\right)=(-1)^{n} d^{n+1} N+O\left(d^{n}\right)$ and so $b_{n}=d^{n+1} N+O\left(d^{n}\right)$. If $n$ is odd then by the discussion in $\S 12.3 .4$ we have

$$
g\left(U_{d}\right)=\frac{1}{2} d^{n+1} N+O\left(d^{n}\right)
$$

If $n$ is even, then the analogous calculation with the total Hirzebruch $\mathcal{L}$-class gives that $\mathcal{L}\left(T U_{d}\right)=i^{*}\left(\frac{\mathcal{L}(T M)}{d x / \tanh (d x)}\right)$ so $\sigma\left(U_{d}\right)=\frac{2^{n+2}\left(2^{n+2}-1\right) B_{n+2}}{(n+2)!} d^{n+1} N+O\left(d^{n}\right)$, where $B_{i}$ denote the Bernoulli numbers. Hence, by the discussion in $\S 12.3 .4$, we have

$$
g\left(U_{d}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\frac{2^{n+2}\left(2^{n+2}-1\right)\left|B_{n+2}\right|}{(n+2)!}\right) d^{n+1} N+O\left(d^{n}\right)
$$

The term $\frac{2^{n+2}\left(2^{n+2}-1\right)\left|B_{n+2}\right|}{(n+2)!}$ does not matter much for large $n$ : the fact that the Taylor series for $\tanh (z)$ has convergence radius $\pi / 2$ implies that that term is asymptotically smaller than $(2 / \pi)^{n+\varepsilon}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$, for any $\varepsilon>0$; in particular it quickly becomes much smaller than 1 . In the relevant cases $n \geq 4$ it is at most $2 / 15$.

# 12.5.3.3 Moore-Postnikov 3-stage of $V_{d}$ 

Let us write

$$
\tau: V_{d} \xrightarrow{\ell_{V_{d}}} B_{d} \xrightarrow{\theta_{d}} B \mathrm{SO}(6)
$$

for the Moore-Postnikov 3 -stage of a map $\tau$ classifying the oriented tangent bundle of $V_{d}$, so $\ell_{V_{d}}$ is 3 -connected and $\theta_{d}$ is 3 -co-connected. From this we easily calculate the homotopy groups of $B_{d}$, as

$$
\begin{aligned}
0=\pi_{1}\left(V_{d}\right) & \xrightarrow{\sim} \pi_{1}\left(B_{d}\right) \\
\mathbf{Z}=\pi_{2}\left(V_{d}\right) & \xrightarrow{\sim} \pi_{2}\left(B_{d}\right) \\
& \pi_{3}\left(B_{d}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} \pi_{3}(B \mathrm{SO}(6))=0 \\
& \pi_{i}\left(B_{d}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} \pi_{i}(B \mathrm{SO}(6)) \text { for all } i \geq 4
\end{aligned}
$$

To understand the map $\theta_{d}$ on homotopy groups, it remains to understand the composition

$$
\tau_{*}: \mathbf{Z}=\pi_{2}\left(V_{d}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} \pi_{2}\left(B_{d}\right) \longrightarrow \pi_{2}(B \mathrm{SO}(6))=\mathbf{Z} / 2
$$

The latter group is detected by the Stiefel-Whitney class $w_{2}$, so this map is non-zero if and only if the class $w_{2}\left(T V_{d}\right) \in H^{2}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z} / 2\right) \cong \operatorname{Hom}\left(\pi_{2}\left(V_{d}\right), \mathbf{Z} / 2\right)$ is non-zero. We have seen that $w_{2}\left(T V_{d}\right)=(5-d) t$, so (12.5.8) is surjective if and only if $d$ is even.

Let us abuse notation by writing $t \in H^{2}\left(B_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)$ for the unique class which pulls back to $t$ along $\ell_{V_{d}}$. If $d$ is even, then $t$ satisfies $t \equiv w_{2}\left(\theta_{d}^{*} \gamma\right) \bmod 2$. Thus there is a $\operatorname{Spin}^{c}$-structure on the bundle $\theta_{d}^{*} \gamma$ with $c_{1}=t$, and choosing one provides a commutative diagram
![img-137.jpeg](img-137.jpeg)

It may be directly checked using the above calculations that the map $f$ induces an isomorphism on all homotopy groups, so is a weak equivalence (over $B \mathrm{SO}(6)$ ).

If $d$ is odd then we have $w_{2}\left(\theta_{d}^{*} \gamma\right)=0$, so we may choose a Spin-structure on the bundle $\theta_{d}^{*} \gamma$, which provides a commutative diagram
![img-138.jpeg](img-138.jpeg)

It may be directly checked using the above calculations that the map $h \times t: B_{d} \rightarrow B \operatorname{Spin}(6) \times$ $K(\mathbf{Z}, 2)$ induces an isomorphism on all homotopy groups, so is a weak equivalence (over $B \mathrm{SO}(6))$.

In either case, the map

$$
\theta_{d} \times t: B_{d} \longrightarrow B \mathrm{SO}(6) \times K(\mathbf{Z}, 2)
$$

is a rational homotopy equivalence (over $B \mathrm{SO}(6)$ ), so we have

$$
H^{*}\left(B_{d} ; \mathbf{Q}\right)=\mathbf{Q}\left[t, p_{1}, p_{2}, e\right]
$$

Writing as in the previous examples $\mathcal{B}$ for the set of monomials in $p_{1}, p_{2}$, and $e$, by Theorem 12.3.3 the map

$$
\mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{t^{i} c} \mid c \in \mathcal{B}, i \geq 0,|c|+2 i>6\right] \longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\theta_{d}}\left(V_{d}, \ell_{V_{d}}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)
$$

is an isomorphism in degrees $* \leq \frac{d^{4}-5 d^{3}+10 d^{2}-10 d+4}{4}$, establishing (12.5.6).

# 12.5.3.4 Change of tangential structure 

We wish to use the above to compute the rational cohomology of $\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right)$ in a range of degrees, so must analyse the forgetful map $\mathcal{M}^{\theta_{d}}\left(V_{d}, \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right)$. We shall do this in two stages, given by the maps of tangential structures
![img-139.jpeg](img-139.jpeg)

The space of $\theta_{d}$-structures on $V_{d}$ refining the $\mu$-structure $u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}$ is homotopy equivalent to the space of lifts
and $\pi_{0}(\operatorname{hAut}(u))$ acts on the set of homotopy classes of such lifts. If $G \leq \operatorname{hAut}(u)$ is the submonoid of those path components that preserve the $\theta_{d}$-structure $\ell_{V_{d}}$ up to diffeomorphisms of $V_{d}$ preserving the $\mu$-structure $u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}$, then there is a fibration sequence

$$
\mathcal{M}^{\theta_{d}}\left(V_{d}, \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \longrightarrow B G
$$

By the discussion in Remark 12.4.11, $G=\operatorname{hAut}(u)_{\left[V_{d}, \ell_{V_{d}}\right]}$ as long as $g\left(V_{d}, \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \geq 3$, and this fibration sequence is an instance of (12.4.9).

As we have seen above, the map $u$ is a rational homotopy equivalence, and it is immediate from this that $\pi_{i}(\operatorname{hAut}(u)) \otimes \mathbf{Q}=0$ for $i>0$, so $G$ has no higher rational homotopy groups.

We claim that $\pi_{0}(G)$ is also trivial, and in fact we shall show that $\pi_{0}(\operatorname{hAut}(u))$ is trivial (so $G=\operatorname{hAut}(u)$ ). To see this, let $\phi \in \operatorname{hAut}(u)$, and we must then show that the following lifting problem admits a solution:
![img-140.jpeg](img-140.jpeg)

By consideration of the cases $B_{d}=B \operatorname{Spin}^{c}(6)$ and $B_{d}=B \operatorname{Spin}(6) \times K(\mathbf{Z}, 2)$, we see that the homotopy fibre of $u$ is a $K(\mathbf{Z} / 2,1)$, so there is a unique obstruction to finding the required lift, lying in

$$
H^{2}\left([0,1] \times B_{d}, \partial[0,1] \times B_{d} ; \mathbf{Z} / 2\right) \cong H^{1}\left(B_{d} ; \mathbf{Z} / 2\right)=0
$$

It follows that $B G$ is simply connected and has trivial higher rational homotopy groups, so $\mathcal{M}^{\theta_{d}}\left(V_{d}, \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right)$ is a rational homotopy equivalence.

Analogously to the above, if $H \leq \operatorname{hAut}(\mu)$ is the submonoid of those path components that preserve the $\mu$-structure $u \circ \ell=\tau \times t$ up to orientation-preserving diffeomorphism of $V_{d}$, then there is a fibration sequence

$$
\mathcal{M}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) \longrightarrow B H
$$

Again, by Remark 12.4.11, $H=\operatorname{hAut}(\mu)_{\left[V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right]}$ as long as $g\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \geq 3$, and this fibration sequence is an instance of (12.4.9). As the fibration $\mu$ is trivial, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{hAut}(\mu) & \simeq \operatorname{map}(B \mathrm{SO}(6), \operatorname{hAut}(K(\mathbf{Z}, 2))) \\
& \simeq \mathbf{Z}^{\times} \ltimes \operatorname{map}(B \mathrm{SO}(6), K(\mathbf{Z}, 2)) \\
& \simeq \mathbf{Z}^{\times} \ltimes K(\mathbf{Z}, 2)
\end{aligned}
$$

The non-trivial path component of this monoid acts on $H^{2}(B \mathrm{SO}(6) \times K(\mathbf{Z}, 2) ; \mathbf{Z})=\mathbf{Z}\{t\}$ as -1 , but any orientation-preserving diffeomorphism of $V_{d}$ fixes $t^{3} \in H^{6}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)$ so acts as +1 on $H^{2}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Z}\right)=\mathbf{Z}\{t\}$. Thus the non-trivial path component of $\operatorname{hAut}(\mu)$ does not lie in $H$, so $H \simeq K(\mathbf{Z}, 2)$. Thus the fibration sequence is of the form

$$
\mathcal{M}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) \longrightarrow K(\mathbf{Z}, 3)
$$

The Serre spectral sequence for this fibration, in rational cohomology, has two columns and so a single possible non-zero differential. In the stable range, using the above, it has the form

$$
E_{2}^{*, *}=\Lambda\left[\iota_{3}\right] \otimes \mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{t^{i} c} \mid c \in \mathcal{B}, i \geq 0,|c|+2 i>6\right] \Longrightarrow H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)
$$

It remains to determine the $d_{3}$-differential, which by the Leibniz rule is done by the following lemma.

Lemma 12.5.7. We have $d_{3}\left(\kappa_{t^{n} c}\right)=\iota_{3} \otimes n \cdot \kappa_{t^{n-1} c}$.
Proof. We have $d_{3}\left(\kappa_{t^{n} c}\right)=\iota_{3} \otimes x$ for some $x$. The action map

$$
a: K(\mathbf{Z}, 2) \times \mathcal{M}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right)
$$

classifies the following data: the $V_{d}$-bundle

$$
\pi: K(\mathbf{Z}, 2) \times \mathcal{E}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \rightarrow K(\mathbf{Z}, 2) \times \mathcal{M}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right)
$$

pulled back by projection to the second factor, equipped with the $\mu$-structure

$$
K(\mathbf{Z}, 2) \times \mathcal{E}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right) \xrightarrow{\tau \times \tilde{t}} B \mathrm{SO}(6) \times K(\mathbf{Z}, 2)
$$

where $\tau$ is given by projection to $\mathcal{E}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right)$ and its vertical tangent bundle, and $\tilde{t}=$ $\iota_{2} \otimes 1+1 \otimes t$.

The class $x$ is related to this action by the formula

$$
a^{*}\left(\kappa_{t^{n} c}\right)=1 \otimes \kappa_{t^{n} c}+\iota_{2} \otimes x+\cdots
$$

Using the description above we calculate $a^{*}\left(\kappa_{t^{n} c}\right)$ as

$$
\pi_{!}\left(\left(\iota_{2} \otimes 1+1 \otimes t\right)^{n} \cdot \tau^{*}(c)\right)=\pi_{!}\left(\sum_{i=0}^{n}\binom{n}{i} \iota_{2}^{i} \otimes\left(t^{n-i} \cdot \tau^{*} c\right)\right)
$$

and the Künneth factor in $H^{2}(K(\mathbf{Z}, 2) ; \mathbf{Z}) \otimes H^{\left|\kappa_{t^{n} c}\right|-2}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\mu}\left(V_{d}, u \circ \ell_{V_{d}}\right) ; \mathbf{Z}\right)$ is $\iota_{2} \otimes\left(n \cdot \kappa_{t^{n-1} c}\right)$. It follows that $x=n \cdot \kappa_{t^{n-1} c}$, as required.

It follows from this lemma that the differential $d_{3}$ is a surjection from the first column to the third column, so that

$$
H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\mathrm{or}}\left(V_{d}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right) \cong \operatorname{Ker}\left(d_{3} \diamond \mathbf{Q}\left[\kappa_{t^{n} c} \mid c \in \mathcal{B}, i \geq 0,|c|+2 n>6\right]\right)
$$

in degrees $* \leq \frac{d^{4}-5 d^{3}+10 d^{2}-10 d+4}{4}$, establishing (12.5.7).
It may at first appear that this ring does not depend on $d$, but this formula is to be understood carefully. If $\left|\kappa_{t^{n} c}\right|=2$ then $d_{3}\left(\kappa_{t^{n} c}\right) \in \mathbf{Q}$ is a scalar, and must be evaluated: this is a boundary condition for the derivation $d_{3}$, and is a characteristic number of $V_{d}$. The $\kappa_{t^{n} c}$ of degree 2 are given by the $t^{i} c$ of degree 8 , so are $p_{2}, p_{1}^{2}$, te, $t^{2} p_{1}$, and $t^{4}$, and these

have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d_{3}\left(\kappa_{p_{2}}\right) & =0 \\
d_{3}\left(\kappa_{p_{1}^{2}}\right) & =0 \\
d_{3}\left(\kappa_{t e}\right) & =\kappa_{e}=\chi\left(V_{d}\right)=d \cdot\left(10-10 d+5 d^{2}-d^{3}\right) \\
d_{3}\left(\kappa_{t^{2} p_{1}}\right) & =2 \kappa_{t p_{1}}=2 d\left(5-d^{2}\right) \\
d_{3}\left(\kappa_{t^{4}}\right) & =4 \kappa_{t^{3}}=4 \cdot d
\end{aligned}
$$

For the penultimate one we use the calculation of the first Pontryagin class of $V_{d}$. As an example, $H^{2}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ is 4-dimensional and is spanned by the classes

$$
\kappa_{p_{2}}, \quad \kappa_{p_{1}^{2}}, \quad \kappa_{t e}-\frac{10-10 d+5 d^{2}-d^{3}}{4} \kappa_{t^{4}}, \quad \text { and } \quad \kappa_{t^{2} p_{1}}-\frac{5-d^{2}}{2} \kappa_{t^{4}}
$$

Remark 12.5.8. In the Serre spectral sequence for the fibration $\pi: \mathcal{E}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right)$ modelling the universal oriented $V_{g}$-bundle as in (12.2.4), the class $t \in H^{2}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Q}\right)=E_{2}^{0,2}$ must be a permanent cycle. (This may be seen as the Euler class of the vertical tangent bundle $T_{\pi} \mathcal{E}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right)$ restricts to $e\left(T V_{d}\right) \in H^{6}\left(V_{g} ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$, so this must be a permanent cycle, and this is a non-zero multiple of $t^{3}$. As $d_{3}\left(t^{3}\right)=3 t^{2} \cdot d_{3}(t)$, if $d_{3}(t) \neq 0$ then $t^{3}$ would not by a permanent cycle, a contradiction.) Thus there exists a class $\bar{t} \in H^{2}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ restricting to $t \in H^{2}\left(V_{d} ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$. We may therefore construct the class $\kappa_{\bar{t}^{n} c}:=\pi_{!}\left(\bar{t}^{n} c\right) \in H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$.

However, the class $\bar{t}$ is not uniquely determined by the above discussion: if $\delta t \in$ $H^{2}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ is any class then $\tilde{\bar{t}}=\bar{t}+\pi^{*}(\delta t)$ is another possible choice, and we then have

$$
\kappa_{\tilde{t}^{n} c}=\pi_{!}\left(\left(\bar{t}+\pi^{*}(\delta t)\right)^{n} c\right)=\kappa_{\bar{t}^{n} c}+(\delta t)\left(n \cdot \kappa_{\bar{t}^{n-1} c}\right)+(\delta t)^{2} \cdots
$$

a potentially different cohomology class.
By the formula in Lemma 12.5.7, we may think of the derivation $d_{3}$ as being $\frac{\partial}{\partial t}$. From this point of view the polynomials in the classes $\kappa_{t^{n} c}$ that lie in the kernel of $d_{3}=\frac{\partial}{\partial t}$ are precisely those that are independent of the choice of $\bar{t}$ when evaluated in $H^{*}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}\left(V_{d}\right) ; \mathbf{Q}\right)$ as described above.

# 12.5.4 Another $\operatorname{Spin}^{c}(6)$ example 

For a simply connected manifold $W$ of dimension $2 n \geq 6$, the formula of Theorem 12.4.5 for the homology of $\mathcal{M}^{\text {or }}(W)$ in a range of degrees seems at first glance as though it only depends on the equivariant homotopy type of the $\mathrm{GL}_{2 n}(\mathbf{R})$-space $\Theta$ having an $n$-co-connected equivariant map $u: \Theta \rightarrow \mathbf{Z}^{\times}$and an $n$-connected equivariant map $\rho_{W}: \operatorname{Fr}(T W) \rightarrow \Theta$. However, the codomain of the map (12.4.6) is the disconnected space $\left(\Omega^{\infty} M T \Theta\right) / / \mathrm{hAut}(u)$, and the different path-components of this space can have different cohomology, even rationally. In this section we give an example of this behaviour.

Construction 12.5.9.
