It follows that we have a forgetful functor $\operatorname{CAlg}\left(\mathcal{C}^{\otimes}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Alg}\left(\mathcal{C}^{\otimes}\right):=\left.\operatorname{Alg}\left(\mathcal{C}^{\otimes}\right|_{\Delta^{\text {op }}}\right)$.

# 13.2.4 Presentable $\infty$-categories 

Definition 13.2.33. Given a small $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$, we write $\operatorname{Ind}_{\kappa}(\mathcal{C}) \subset \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{C})$ for the full subcategory consisting of those functors $f: \mathcal{C}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}$ such that the source $\mathcal{D}$ of the unstraightening $p: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ of $f$ is $\kappa$-filtered.

Proposition 13.2.34. [26, Proposition 5.3.5.10] Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a small $\infty$-category and $\mathcal{D}$ an $\infty$-category with $\kappa$-filtered colimits. There is an equivalence of $\infty$-categories

$$
\operatorname{Fun}^{\kappa \text {-filt }}\left(\operatorname{Ind}_{\kappa}(\mathcal{C}), \mathcal{D}\right) \simeq \operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D})
$$

and hence by 13.2.11 an equivalence $\operatorname{Ind}_{\kappa}(\mathcal{C}) \simeq \mathcal{P}_{\kappa-\text { fin }}(\mathcal{C})$.
Definition 13.2.35. An object $A$ of an $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is $\kappa$-compact if the corepresentable $\operatorname{functor} \operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,-): \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}$ commutes with $\kappa$-filtered colimits. We write $\mathcal{C}^{\kappa} \subset \mathcal{C}$ for the full subcategory of $\mathcal{C}$ consisting of the $\kappa$-compact objects.

Definition 13.2.36. An $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is $\kappa$-compactly generated if $\mathcal{C}$ admits all small colimits and, writing $\mathcal{C}^{\kappa} \subset \mathcal{C}$ for the full subcategory consisting of the $\kappa$-compact objects, the canonical map $\operatorname{Ind}_{\kappa}\left(\mathcal{C}^{\kappa}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is an equivalence. A presentable $\infty$-category is an $\infty$-category that is $\kappa$-compactly generated for some infinite regular cardinal $\kappa$.

There are dual notions of morphism of presentable $\infty$-category: namely, those functors which are left (respectively, right) adjoints. We write LPr (respectively, RPr) for these $\infty$ categories. A key point [26, Proposition 5.5.3.13 and Theorem 5.5.3.18] is that the inclusion of subcategories $\mathrm{LPr} \subset \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ and $\mathrm{RPr} \subset \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ preserves limits: in fact, given a functor $\mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathrm{LPr}$, a cone $\mathcal{D}^{\triangleleft} \rightarrow \mathrm{LPr}$ is limiting in LPr (respectively, RPr ) if and only if the induced cone is limiting in $\mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$.

Remark 13.2.37. For each infinite regular cardinal $\kappa$ we have subcategories (again not full) $\mathrm{LPr}_{\kappa} \subset \mathrm{LPr}$ (respectively, $\mathrm{RPr}_{\kappa} \subset \mathrm{RPr}$ ) consisting of the $\kappa$-compactly generated $\infty$-categories and those left (respectively, right) adjoint functors that preserve $\kappa$-compact objects (respectively, $\kappa$-filtered colimits).

Definition 13.2.38. A presentable fibration is a cartesian fibration $p: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ such that the straightening $\operatorname{St}_{\mathcal{C}}(p): \mathcal{C}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ factors through the subcategory $\mathrm{RPr} \subset \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ of presentable $\infty$-categories and right adjoint functors.

Remark 13.2.39. The adjoint functor theorem [26, Corollary 5.5.2.9] states that any colimit preserving functor $L: \mathcal{A} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ of presentable $\infty$-categories admits a right adjoint $R: \mathcal{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}$ (this is even true more generally, for instance if $\mathcal{B}$ is only assumed to be cocomplete). Hence LPr can be equivalently described as the subcategory of presentable $\infty$-categories and left adjoint functors. Dually, writing $\mathrm{RPr} \subset \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ for the subcategory consisting of the presentable $\infty$-categories and right adjoint functors, uniqueness of adjoints allows us to construct a canonical equivalence $\mathrm{LPr}^{\text {op }} \simeq \mathrm{RPr}$.

Definition 13.2.40. A presentable symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category is a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $p: \mathcal{C}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fin}_{*}$ such that the underlying $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C} \simeq \mathcal{C}_{(1)}^{\otimes}$ is presentable and any choice of tensor product bifunctor $\otimes: \mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ commutes with colimits separately in each variable.

Theorem 13.2.41. [25, Proposition 4.8.1.17] Let $\mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{D}$ be presentable $\infty$-categories. The subfunctor

$$
\operatorname{Fun}^{\prime}(\mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D},-) \subset \operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D},-): \mathrm{LPr} \longrightarrow \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}
$$

whose value at $\mathcal{E} \in \mathrm{LPr}$ consists of those functors $f: \mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{E}$ that preserve colimits separately in each variable, is corepresented by an object $\mathcal{C} \otimes \mathcal{D} \in \mathrm{LPr}$.

Remark 13.2.42. It is straightforward to check, with the definition of $\mathcal{C} \otimes \mathcal{D}$ as above, that for a presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{E}$, there is a canonical equivalence

$$
\operatorname{LFun}(\mathcal{C} \otimes \mathcal{D}, \mathcal{E}) \simeq \operatorname{LFun}(\mathcal{C}, \operatorname{LFun}(\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{E}))
$$

where $\operatorname{LFun}(\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{E})$ denotes the $\infty$-category of left adjoint functors $\mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{E}$, which is presentable by [25]. Dually, we write $\operatorname{RFun}(\mathcal{E}, \mathcal{D})$ for the $\infty$-category of right adjoint functors $\mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$, and note that $\operatorname{LFun}(\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{E}) \simeq \operatorname{RFun}(\mathcal{E}, \mathcal{D})^{\mathrm{op}}$.

Proposition 13.2.43. [25, Lemma 4.8.1.16] Let $\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}$ be presentable $\infty$-categories. Then $\operatorname{RFun}\left(\mathcal{D}^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathcal{C}\right)$ is a presentable $\infty$-category, and

$$
\mathcal{C} \otimes \mathcal{D} \simeq \operatorname{RFun}\left(\mathcal{D}^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathcal{C}\right)
$$

Theorem 13.2.44. [25, Corollary 4.8.1.12] The functor $\mathcal{P}: \mathrm{Cat}_{\infty} \rightarrow \mathrm{LPr}$ extends to a symmetric monoidal functor $\mathcal{P}^{\otimes}: \mathrm{Cat}_{\infty}^{\times} \rightarrow \mathrm{LPr}^{\otimes}$.

Remark 13.2.45. The symmetric monoidality of the presheaves functor is an $\infty$-categorical generalization of the Day convolution product. If $\mathcal{C}^{\otimes}$ is a small symmetric monoidal $\infty$ category, then $\mathcal{P}^{\otimes}(\mathcal{C})$ inherits a convolution symmetric monoidal structure [25, Remark 4.8.1.13], given by the formula

$$
\left(X_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes X_{n}\right)(A) \simeq \operatorname{colim}_{\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{n}\right) \in \mathcal{C}_{/ A}^{\times n}} X_{1}\left(B_{1}\right) \times \cdots \times X_{n}\left(B_{n}\right)
$$

Here the colimit is taken over the $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}_{/ A}^{\times n} \simeq \mathcal{C}^{\times n} \times_{\mathcal{C}} \mathcal{C}_{/ A}$.
Remark 13.2.46. The fact that $\mathcal{P}^{\otimes}$ is symmetric monoidal implies that the canonical map $\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{C}) \otimes \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{D}) \rightarrow \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D})$ is an equivalence.

Definition 13.2.47. A space $X \in \mathcal{S}$ is said to be $n$-truncated if $\pi_{m}(X, x) \cong 0$ for all $m>n$ and $x \in X$. By convention, a space is said to be $(-2)$-truncated if it is contractible and $(-1)$-truncated if it is empty or contractible.

Definition 13.2.48. An object $A$ of an $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is said to be $n$-truncated, $n \in \mathbf{N}$, if the associated representable functor $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{C}}(-, A): \mathcal{C}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}$ factors through the full subcategory $\tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{S} \subset \mathcal{S}$ spanned by the $n$-truncated spaces.

Proposition 13.2.49. [26, Proposition 5.5.6.18] Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a presentable $\infty$-category. The inclusion of the full subcategory of $n$-truncated objects $\tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}$ is stable under limits and admits a left adjoint $\tau_{\leq n}: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{C}$.

Proposition 13.2.50. [25, Example 4.8.1.22] As an endofunctor of $\mathrm{LPr}, \tau_{\leq n}: \mathrm{LPr} \rightarrow \mathrm{LPr}$ is idempotent. It therefore determines a localization of LPr with essential image the presentable $n$-categories. In particular, for any presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$, we have a canonical equivalence $\mathcal{C} \otimes \tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{S} \simeq \tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{C}$.

For any presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$, the left adjoints of the inclusions $\tau_{\leq m} \mathcal{C} \subset \tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{C}$ for $m<n$ result in a tower $\cdots \rightarrow \tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \cdots \rightarrow \tau_{\leq 0} \mathcal{C}$ of truncations of $\mathcal{C}$ in $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathcal{C} /}$, and consequently a comparison map

$$
\mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \lim \left\{\cdots \rightarrow \tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \cdots \rightarrow \tau_{\leq 0} \mathcal{C}\right\}
$$

Definition 13.2.51. Let $A$ be an object of a presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$. The Postnikov tower of $A$ is the tower of truncations $\cdots \rightarrow \tau_{\leq n} A \rightarrow \cdots \rightarrow \tau_{\leq 0} A$ of $A$, regarded as a diagram in $\mathcal{C}_{A /}$.

Definition 13.2.52. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a presentable $\infty$-category. We say that Postnikov towers converge in $\mathcal{C}$ if the map $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \lim \left\{\cdots \rightarrow \tau_{\leq n} \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \cdots \rightarrow \tau_{\leq 0} \mathcal{C}\right\}$ is an equivalence of $\infty$ categories.

More concretely, Postnikov towers converge in $\mathcal{C}$ if, for each object $A$, the map $A \rightarrow$ $\lim \tau_{\leq n} A$ from $A$ to the limit of its Postnikov tower is an equivalence.

Example 13.2.53. Postnikov towers converge in the $\infty$-categories $\mathcal{S}$ and $\mathcal{S}_{*}$.

# 13.2.5 Stable $\infty$-categories 

Definition 13.2.54. A zero object of an $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is an object that is both initial and final. An $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is pointed if $\mathcal{C}$ admits a zero object.

Definition 13.2.55. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a pointed $\infty$-category. A triangle in $\mathcal{C}$ is a commutative square $\Delta^{1} \times \Delta^{1} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ of the form
![img-148.jpeg](img-148.jpeg)
where 0 is a zero object of $\mathcal{C}$. We typically write $A \xrightarrow{f} B \xrightarrow{g} C$ for a triangle in $\mathcal{C}$, though it is important to remember that a choice of composite $g \circ f$ and nullhomotopy $g \circ f \simeq$ $0 \in \operatorname{Map}(A, C)$ are also part of the data. We say that a triangle in $\mathcal{C}$ is left exact if it is cartesian (a pullback), right exact if it is cocartesian (a pushout), and exact if it is cartesian and cocartesian.

Remark 13.2.56. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a pointed $\infty$-category with finite limits and colimits, and consider a triangle in $\mathcal{C}$ of the form
![img-149.jpeg](img-149.jpeg)

Then $A \simeq \Omega B$ if the triangle is left exact and $\Sigma A \simeq B$ is the triangle is right exact. If the triangle is exact, we have equivalences $A \simeq \Omega \Sigma A$ and $\Sigma \Omega B \simeq B$.

Definition 13.2.57. A stable $\infty$-category is an $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ with a zero object, finite limits and colimits, and that satisfies the following axiom: a commutative square $\Delta^{1} \times \Delta^{1} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ in $\mathcal{C}$ is cartesian if and only if it is cocartesian (in other words, a pullback if and only if it is a pushout).
Definition 13.2.58. Let $\mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{D}$ be a functor of $\infty$-categories that admits finite limits and colimits. A functor $f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ is left exactif $f$ preserves finite limits, right exactif $f$ preserves finite colimits, and exact if $f$ preserves finite limits and finite colimits. We write $\mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}^{\text {st }} \subset \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ for the (not full) subcategory consisting of the stable $\infty$-categories and the exact functors.

Proposition 13.2.59. [25, Corollary 1.4.2.11] Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a pointed $\infty$-category. The following conditions are equivalent:
(1) $\mathcal{C}$ is stable.
(2) $\mathcal{C}$ admits finite colimits and $\Sigma: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is an equivalence.
(3) $\mathcal{C}$ admits finite limits and $\Omega: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is an equivalence.

Theorem 13.2.60. [25, Lemma 1.1.2.13] The homotopy category of a stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ admits the structure of a triangulated category such that:
(1) The shift functor is induced from the suspension functor $\Sigma: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.
(2) A triangle $A \xrightarrow{f} B \xrightarrow{g} C \xrightarrow{h} \Sigma A$ in the homotopy category is exact if and only if there exist exact triangles
![img-150.jpeg](img-150.jpeg)
in $\mathcal{C}$ such that $f^{\prime}, g^{\prime}$, and $h^{\prime}$ are representatives of $f, g$ and $h$ composed with the equivalence $\Sigma A \rightarrow D$, respectively.
Definition 13.2.61. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an $\infty$-category with finite limits. A functor

$$
F: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}
$$

is said to be excisive (respectively, reduced) if $F$ sends cocartesian squares to cartesian squares (respectively, sends initial objects to final objects). We write

$$
\operatorname{Exc}_{*}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }}, \mathcal{C}\right) \subset \operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }}, \mathcal{C}\right)
$$

for the full subcategory of reduced excisive functors $\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.
Definition 13.2.62. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an $\infty$-category with finite limits. The $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Sp}(\mathcal{C})$ of spectrum objects in $\mathcal{C}$ is the $\infty$-category

$$
\operatorname{Sp}(\mathcal{C})=\operatorname{Exc}_{*}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }}, \mathcal{C}\right)
$$

of reduced excisive functors from finite spaces to $\mathcal{C}$.

The reason for the terminology "spectrum object" is that a reduced excisive functor determines, and is determined by, its value on any infinite sequence $\left\{S^{n_{0}}, S^{n_{1}}, S^{n_{2}}, \ldots\right\}$ of spheres of strictly increasing dimension. The most canonical choice is the sequence of all spheres $\left\{S^{0}, S^{1}, S^{2}, \ldots\right\}$, so that evaluation on this family of spheres induces a map

$$
\operatorname{Exc}_{*}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }}, \mathcal{C}\right) \longrightarrow \lim \left\{\cdots \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{C}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{C}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{C}_{*}\right\}
$$

which sends the excisive functor $F$ to the sequence of pointed objects $\left\{F\left(S^{n}\right)\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$ and equivalences $F\left(S^{n}\right) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \Omega F\left(\Sigma S^{n}\right) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \Omega F\left(S^{n+1}\right)$.

Proposition 13.2.63. [25, Remark 1.4.2.25] Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an $\infty$-category with finite limits. The functor

$$
\operatorname{Sp}(\mathcal{C})=\operatorname{Exc}_{*}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }}, \mathcal{C}\right) \longrightarrow \lim \left\{\cdots \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{C}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{C}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{C}_{*}\right\}
$$

induced by evaluation on spheres is an equivalence of $\infty$-categories.
Remark 13.2.64. Since $\mathcal{C}$ has finite limits, it has a final object pt, and so it makes sense to consider the $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}_{*} \simeq \mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{pt} /}$ of pointed objects in $\mathcal{C}$. There is a canonical equivalence $\operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C}_{*}\right) \simeq \operatorname{Sp}(\mathcal{C})$.

The main examples of stable $\infty$-categories are either presentable or embed fully faithfully inside a stable presentable $\infty$-category as the subcategory of $\kappa$-compact objects for some infinite regular cardinal $\kappa$. Let $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}} \subset \mathrm{LPr}$ denote the full subcategory spanned by the stable presentable $\infty$-categories.

Proposition 13.2.65. [25, Proposition 4.8.2.18] The inclusion of the full subcategory $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}} \subset \mathrm{LPr}$ admits a left adjoint $\mathrm{LPr} \rightarrow \mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}$.

Remark 13.2.66. The left adjoint "stabilization" functor is given by tensoring with the $\infty$-category of spectra. By virtue of the equivalence $\mathcal{C} \otimes \mathrm{Sp} \simeq \mathrm{Sp}(\mathcal{C})$, the $\infty$-category of spectrum objects in $\mathcal{C}$ is a description of its stabilization.

Corollary 13.2.67. Let $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ be presentable $\infty$-categories such that $\mathcal{A}$ is stable. Then $\mathcal{A} \otimes \mathcal{B}$ is stable.

Corollary 13.2.68. The symmetric monoidal structure $\mathrm{LPr}^{\otimes}$ on LPr induces a symmetric monoidal structure $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\otimes}$ on the full subcategory $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}} \subset \mathrm{LPr}$ consisting of the stable presentable $\infty$-categories.

We write $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\otimes} \subset \mathrm{LPr}^{\otimes}$ for this symmetric monoidal subcategory. Note that this inclusion is lax symmetric monoidal and right adjoint to the symmetric monoidal stabilization functor $\mathrm{Sp}(-): \mathrm{LPr}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\otimes}$.

Corollary 13.2.69. The forgetful functor $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}} \subset \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ extends to a lax symmetric monoidal functor $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}^{<}$. In particular, it carries (commutative) algebra objects of $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\otimes}$ to (symmetric) monoidal $\infty$-categories.

Example 13.2.70. The $\infty$-category Sp of spectra is a unit of the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LPr}_{\text {st }}^{\otimes}$ of stable presentable $\infty$-categories. It therefore admits a presentable symmetric monoidal structure, called the smash product. We will write $\otimes^{n}: \mathrm{Sp}^{ \times n} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ for any choice of smash product multifunctor.

Remark 13.2.71. Given spectra $A$ and $B$, their smash product is usually written $A \wedge B$ is the literature. We follow the convention of [25] and write $A \otimes B$ instead, emphasizing the analogy with the tensor product of abelian groups (or more precisely the derived tensor product of chain complexes).

Remark 13.2.72. By construction, the symmetric monoidal structure on the $\infty$-category of spectra is compatible with the cartesian symmetric monoidal structure on the $\infty$-category of spaces via the suspension spectrum functor

$$
\Sigma_{+}^{\infty}: \mathcal{S} \longrightarrow \mathrm{Sp}
$$

This means that, for spaces $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}$, there is a canonical equivalence

$$
\left(\Sigma_{+}^{\infty} X_{1}\right) \otimes \cdots \otimes\left(\Sigma_{+}^{\infty} X_{n}\right) \simeq \Sigma_{+}^{\infty}\left(X_{1} \times \cdots \times X_{n}\right)
$$

Proposition 13.2.73. [25, Corollary 1.4.4.2] A stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is $\kappa$-compactly generated if and only if $\mathcal{C}$ admits small coproducts, a $\kappa$-compact generator for some regular cardinal $\kappa$, and (the homotopy category of) $\mathcal{C}$ is locally small.

Definition 13.2.74. A Verdier sequence is a cocartesian square
![img-151.jpeg](img-151.jpeg)
in $\mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}^{\text {st }}$ such that 0 is a zero object and the top horizontal map $\mathcal{A} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ is fully faithful. A semi-orthogonal decomposition is a Verdier sequence such that the functors $\mathcal{A} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ and $\mathcal{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ admit right adjoints. It is common to simply write $\mathcal{A} \rightarrow \mathcal{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ for a Verdier sequence, leaving implicit the requirement that $\mathcal{A} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ be fully faithful with cofiber $\mathcal{C}$.

Remark 13.2.75. Given a Verdier sequence $\mathcal{A} \xrightarrow{i} \mathcal{B} \xrightarrow{j} \mathcal{C}$, the fact that $i$ is fully faithful implies that the left adjoint functor $i_{!}: \operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{A}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{B})$ is fully faithful with right adjoint $i^{*}$, and the right adjoint $j^{*}: \operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{B})$ of the functor $j_{!}: \operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{B}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{C})$ is also fully faithful. Thus the Verdier sequence $\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{A}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{B}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{C})$ is actually a semi-orthogonal decomposition.

# 13.2.6 Homotopy groups and t-structures 

Unfortunately, the notion of truncation (see 13.2.48 above) considered earlier is poorly behaved in stable $\infty$-categories $\mathcal{C}$, even if $\mathcal{C}$ happens to be presentable. This is because it is a direct consequence of stability that an object $A$ of $\mathcal{C}$ is $n$-truncated if and only if it is $(n-1)$-truncated, so that the only finitely truncated objects at all are the zero objects, all of which are canonically equivalent to one another. Thus any attempt to study $\mathcal{C}$ itself via the standard obstruction theoretic truncation type methods is doomed to fail.

The notion of a t-structure on a stable $\infty$-category remedies this situation, providing all kinds of other interesting and potentially effective ways of (co)filtering objects of $\mathcal{C}$ - ideally

even $\mathcal{C}$ itself — as limits of "Postnikov type" towers of truncation functors $\tau_{\leq n}: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$, or dually as colimits of "Whitehead type" telescopes of connective cover functors $\tau_{\geq n}: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$. We emphasize that while a t-structure is structure, it is encoded as innocuously as possible, via a choice of "orthogonal" full subcategories of $\mathcal{C}$ in the sense made precise below.

First we need some notation. If $\mathcal{C}$ is a stable $\infty$-category and $A$ is an object of $\mathcal{C}$, we also write $A[n]$ for a choice of $n$-fold suspension $\Sigma^{n} A$ of $A, n \in \mathbf{Z}$. If $\mathcal{D} \subset \mathcal{C}$ is a full subcategory of $\mathcal{C}$, we write $\mathcal{D}[n] \subset \mathcal{C}$ for the full subcategory consisting the objects of the form $B[n]$, where $B$ is an object of the full subcategory $\mathcal{D}$. Finally, for any pair of objects $A$ and $B$ of $\mathcal{C}$, we write $\operatorname{Ext}^{n}(A, B)$ for the abelian group $\pi_{0} \operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B[n])$.

Definition 13.2.76. A $t$-structure on a stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ consists of a pair of full subcategories $\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0} \subset \mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{\leq 0} \subset \mathcal{C}$ satisfying the following conditions:
(1) $\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}[1] \subset \mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{\leq 0} \subset \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}[1]$;
(2) If $A \in \mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ and $B \in \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}$, then $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B[-1])=0$;
(3) Every $A \in \mathcal{C}$ fits into an exact triangle of the form $\tau_{\geq 0} A \rightarrow A \rightarrow \tau_{\leq-1} A$ with $\tau_{\geq 0} A \in \mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ and $\tau_{\leq-1} A \in \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}[-1]$.

Definition 13.2.77. An exact functor $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ between stable $\infty$-categories equipped with t-structures is left $t$-exact (respectively, right $t$-exact if it sends $\mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}$ to $\mathcal{D}_{\leq 0}$ (respectively, $\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ to $\mathcal{D}_{\geq 0}$ ). An exact functor is $t$-exact if is both left and right $t$-exact. We set $\mathcal{C}_{\geq n}=\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}[n]$ and $\mathcal{C}_{\leq n}=\mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}[n]$.

Remark 13.2.78. The data of a t-structure on a stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is equivalent to the data of a t-structure on its triangulated homotopy category $\operatorname{Ho}(\mathcal{C})$ in the sense originally defined and studied by Beilinson-Bernstein-Deligne [9].

Example 13.2.79. If $\mathcal{A}$ is a small abelian category, then the bounded derived $\infty$-category $\mathcal{D}^{b}(\mathcal{A})$ admits a canonical t-structure, where $\mathcal{D}^{b}(\mathcal{A})_{\geq n}$ consists of the complexes $A$ such that $\mathrm{H}_{i}(A)=0$ for $i<n$, and similarly for $\mathcal{D}^{b}(\mathcal{A})_{\leq n}$. If $\mathcal{A}$ is a Grothendieck abelian category, then the unbounded derived $\infty$-category $\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{A})$ admits a t-structure with the same description as the previous example. This stable $\infty$-category and its t-structure are studied in [25, Section 1.3.5].

Example 13.2.80. If $R$ is a connective associative ring spectrum, then the stable presentable $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$ of left $R$-module spectra admits a t-structure with $\mathrm{LMod}_{R \geq 0} \simeq$ $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}^{\text {cn }}$, the $\infty$-category of connective left $R$-module spectra. We call this the Postnikov $t$-structure.

Remark 13.2.81. The mapping space $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B[-1])$ is actually contractible for $A \in \mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ and $B \in \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}$. This is not the case for the mapping spectra, as $\pi_{0} \operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{A})}(A[-n], B[-1]) \cong$ $\operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{A}}^{n-1}(A, B)$ for any pair of objects $A$ and $B$ in a Grothendieck abelian category $\mathcal{A}$ (see [25, Proposition 1.3.5.6]).

Proposition 13.2.82. [25, Remark 1.2.1.12 and Warning 1.2.1.9] The intersection $\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0} \cap \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}$ is an abelian category equivalent to the full subcategory of $\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ consisting of the discrete objects (that is, 0-truncated in the sense of 13.2.48).

Definition 13.2.83. The abelian category $\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0} \cap \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}$ is called the heart of the t-structure $\left(\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}, \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}\right)$ on $\mathcal{C}$, and is denoted $\mathcal{C}^{\odot}$.

Example 13.2.84. The hearts of the t-structures in 13.2.79 are both equivalents to the abelian category $\mathcal{A}$ itself. The heart of the t-structure in 13.2 .80 is $\mathrm{LMod}_{\pi_{0} R}^{\odot}$, the abelian category of left $\pi_{0} R$-modules.

Remark 13.2.85. It turns out that the truncations $\tau_{\geq n}$ and $\tau_{\leq n}$ are functorial in the sense that the inclusions $\mathcal{C}_{\geq n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{\leq n} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ admit right and left adjoints, respectively, by [25, Corollary 1.2.1.6].

Definition 13.2.86. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a stable $\infty$-category equipped with a t-structure $\left(\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}, \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}\right)$ and let $A$ be an object of $\mathcal{C}$. There is an equivalence of functors $\tau_{\geq 0} \tau_{\leq 0} \simeq \tau_{\leq 0} \tau_{\geq 0}: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\odot}$ [25, Proposition 1.2.1.10]. The homotopy groups $\pi_{n} A, n \in \mathbf{Z}$, are defined via the formula $\pi_{n} A=\tau_{\geq 0} \tau_{\leq 0} A[-n] \in \mathcal{C}^{\odot}$.

Remark 13.2.87. In the stable setting, passing to homotopy groups is a homological functor in the sense that there are long exact sequences

$$
\cdots \rightarrow \pi_{n+1} C \rightarrow \pi_{n} A \rightarrow \pi_{n} B \rightarrow \pi_{n} C \rightarrow \pi_{n-1} A \rightarrow \cdots
$$

in $\mathcal{C}^{\odot}$ whenever $A \rightarrow B \rightarrow C$ is an exact triangle in $\mathcal{C}$.
Definition 13.2.88. A t-structure $\left(\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}, \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}\right)$ on a stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is left complete if the full subcategory of infinitely connected objects $\mathcal{C}_{\geq \infty}=\bigcap_{n \in \mathbf{Z}} \mathcal{C}_{\geq n} \subset \mathcal{C}$ consists only of zero objects. Right complete t-structures are defined similarly.

Definition 13.2.89. A t-structure $\left(\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}, \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}\right)$ on a stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is bounded if the inclusion of the full subcategory of bounded objects $\mathcal{C}^{b}=\bigcup_{n \in \mathbf{N}} \mathcal{C}_{\geq-n} \cap \mathcal{C}_{\leq n} \subset \mathcal{C}$ is an equivalence. There are analogous notions of right and left bounded.

Many of the most important examples of stable $\infty$-categories may already be familiar from homological algebra. If $\mathcal{A}$ is an abelian category with enough projectives, the derived $\infty$-category $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$ of bounded below chain complexes in $\mathcal{A}$ admits a universal property that characterizes the stable $\infty$-categories that arise in this way. We will suppose that $\mathcal{A}$ has enough projective and write $\mathcal{A}^{\text {proj }} \subset \mathcal{A}$ for the full subcategory consisting of the projective objects.

Definition 13.2.90. Let $\mathcal{A}$ be an abelian category with enough projectives. The bounded below derived $\infty$-category of $\mathcal{A}$ is the homotopy coherent nerve $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A}):=\mathbb{N}\left(\mathrm{Ch}^{-}(\mathcal{A})\right)$ of the differential graded category $\mathrm{Ch}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$ (viewed as a simplically enriched category as in 13.1.7) of bounded below chain complexes in $\mathcal{A}$ (those complexes $A \in \operatorname{Ch}(\mathcal{A})$ such that $\mathrm{H}_{n}(A)=0$ for $n \ll 0$.

Proposition 13.2.91. [25, Corollary 1.3.2.18 and Proposition 1.3.2.19] Let $\mathcal{A}$ be an abelian category with enough projectives. Then $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$ is a stable $\infty$-category, and the full subcategories $\mathcal{D}_{\geq 0}^{-}(\mathcal{A}) \subset \mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$ and $\mathcal{D}_{\leq 0}^{-}(\mathcal{A}) \subset \mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$ consisting of those complexes $A$ such that $\mathrm{H}_{n}(A)=0$ for $n<0$ and $\mathrm{H}_{n}(A)=0$ for $n>0$, respectively, comprise a right bounded and left complete t-structure on $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$.

Theorem 13.2.92. [25, Theorem 1.3.4.4] Let $\mathcal{A}$ be an abelian category with enough projectives and $W \subset \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathrm{Ch}^{-}(\mathcal{A})\right)$ the class of quasi-isomorphisms. There is a canonical equivalence of $\infty$-categories $\mathcal{A}\left[W^{-1}\right] \simeq \mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$.

Remark 13.2.93. $\mathcal{A}$ sits inside $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$ as the full subcategory of complexes concentrated in degree zero. Moreover, straightforward homological algebra arguments show that $\pi_{0}$ : $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A}) \rightarrow \mathcal{A}$ restricts to an equivalence $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})^{\nabla} \simeq \mathcal{A}$.

Remark 13.2.94. Let $\mathcal{A}$ be a small abelian category with enough projectives. The category $\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{A})$ of inductive objects of $\mathcal{A}$ is again an abelian category with enough projective objects and is equivalent to the large abelian category $\operatorname{Fun}^{\Pi}\left(\left(\mathcal{A}^{\text {proj }}\right)^{\text {op }}\right.$, Set) of product preserving functors from $\left(\mathcal{A}^{\text {proj }}\right)^{\text {op }}$ to Set.

Theorem 13.2.95. [25, Theorem 1.3.3.8] Let $\mathcal{A}$ be an abelian category with enough projectives, let $\mathcal{C}$ be an $\infty$-category that admits geometric realizations, and let $\operatorname{Fun}^{\text {geom }}\left(\mathcal{D}_{\geq 0}^{-}(\mathcal{A}), \mathcal{C}\right) \subset \operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathcal{D}_{\geq 0}^{-}(\mathcal{A}), \mathcal{C}\right)$ denote the full subcategory consisting of those functors that preserve geometric realizations. Then restriction along the embedding $\mathcal{A}^{\text {proj }} \subset$ $\mathcal{D}_{\geq 0}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$ induces an equivalence of $\infty$-categories

$$
\operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathcal{A}^{\mathrm{proj}}, \mathcal{C}\right) \stackrel{\simeq}{\leftarrow} \operatorname{Fun}^{\prime}\left(\mathcal{D}_{\geq 0}^{-}(\mathcal{A}), \mathcal{C}\right) \subset \operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathcal{D}_{\geq 0}^{-}(\mathcal{A}), \mathcal{C}\right)
$$

between realization preserving functors $\mathcal{D}_{\geq 0}^{-}(\mathcal{A}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ and functors $\mathcal{A}^{\text {proj }} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.
Theorem 13.2.96. [25, Theorem HA.1.3.3.2] Let $\mathcal{A}$ be an abelian category with enough projectives, let $\mathcal{C}$ be a stable $\infty$-category with a left complete t-structure, and let $\operatorname{Fun}^{\prime}\left(\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A}), \mathcal{C}\right) \subset \operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A}), \mathcal{C}\right)$ denote the full subcategory of functors $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ that are right t-exact and send projective objects of $\mathcal{A}$ to $\mathcal{C}^{\nabla}$. Then restriction along $i: \mathcal{A} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A})$ induces an equivalence of $\infty$-categories

$$
\operatorname{Fun}^{\mathrm{rex}}\left(\mathcal{A}, \mathcal{C}^{\nabla}\right) \stackrel{\simeq}{\leftarrow} \operatorname{Fun}^{\prime}\left(\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A}), \mathcal{C}\right) \subset \operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A}), \mathcal{C}\right)
$$

between right t-exact functors $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathcal{A}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ that send $\mathcal{A}^{\text {proj }} \subset \mathcal{A}$ to $\mathcal{C}^{\nabla} \subset \mathcal{C}$ and right exact functors $\mathcal{A} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\nabla}$.

# 13.3 Ring theory 

### 13.3.1 Spectra

So far we have considered the $\infty$-category of spectra from two seemingly different but equivalent perspectives: on the one hand, as reduced excisive functors $\mathrm{Sp}=\mathrm{Sp}(\mathcal{S})=$ $\operatorname{Exc}_{*}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathrm{fin}}, \mathcal{S}\right)$, and on the other, as a unit object $\mathrm{Sp} \in \mathrm{LP}_{\mathrm{at}}^{\otimes}$ of the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category of presentable stable $\infty$-categories. The former is more explicit and yields lots of examples, while the latter is more abstract and suggests a universal property.

Remark 13.3.1. The reader may be wondering what any of this has to do with the classical notion of spectrum in algebraic topology. By definition, $\mathrm{Sp}=\operatorname{Exc}_{*}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }}, \mathcal{S}\right)$, but evaluation on the family of spheres $\left\{S^{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$ induces an equivalence of $\infty$-categories

$$
\mathrm{Sp} \simeq \lim \left\{\cdots \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{S}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{S}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Omega} \mathcal{S}_{*}\right\}
$$

Remark 13.3.2. Our convention is that we work in the $\infty$-category $\mathcal{S}$ of spaces and its pointed variant $\mathcal{S}_{*}$, so that all (pointed) spaces have the homotopy type of cell complexes. If we wish to model a spectrum, however, it is often convenient to work in a category $\mathcal{C}$ equipped with a class of weak equivalences $W$ and functor $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}$ that sends the maps in $W$ to equivalences in $\mathcal{S}_{*}$, such as the category $\mathrm{Top}_{*}$ of pointed topological spaces. In such models we need only ask that the maps $\eta_{n}: A_{n} \rightarrow \Omega A_{n+1}$ are weak equivalences, a structure that is often referred to as an $\Omega$-spectrum in the literature. In the case $\mathcal{C}=\mathrm{Top}_{*}$ we can even require the $\eta_{n}: A_{n} \rightarrow \Omega A_{n+1}$ to be homeomorphisms.
Remark 13.3.3. The forgetful functor $\mathrm{RPr} \rightarrow \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ preserves limits, meaning we may also form this limit in RPr. Equivalently, Sp is given as the colimit

$$
\mathrm{Sp} \simeq \operatorname{colim}\left\{\mathcal{S}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Sigma} \mathcal{S}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Sigma} \mathcal{S}_{*} \xrightarrow{\Sigma} \cdots\right\}
$$

in LPr , by virtue of the antiequivalence $\mathrm{LPr} \simeq \mathrm{RPr}^{\text {op }}$ that takes the adjoint.
Remark 13.3.4. The forgetful functor $\mathrm{LPr} \rightarrow \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ does not commute with filtered colimits; nevertheless, the $\infty$-category of finite - or equivalently, in this case, compact spectra $\mathrm{Sp}^{\text {fin }} \simeq \mathrm{Sp}^{\omega}$ is computed as the filtered colimit of the suspension functor on finite pointed spaces $\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }}$. This equivalence

$$
\mathrm{Sp}^{\text {fin }} \simeq \operatorname{colim}\left\{\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \xrightarrow{\Sigma} \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \xrightarrow{\Sigma} \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \xrightarrow{\Sigma} \cdots\right\}
$$

in Cat $_{\infty}$ is the $\infty$-categorical analogue of the Spanier-Whitehead category.
Remark 13.3.5. We have taken the "coordinate free" convention that spectra are reduced excisive functors. Nevertheless, it is often the case in practice that a spectrum $A$ is given in terms of an infinite delooping of its infinite loop space $\Omega^{\infty} A$, in which case the associated excisive functor is given by the formula

$$
T_{A}(-):=\Omega^{\infty}(-\otimes A): \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \longrightarrow \mathcal{S}
$$

Here, $\otimes$ refers to the fact that Sp , as a commutative $\mathcal{S}_{*}$-algebra in LPr , is canonically left tensored over $\mathcal{S}_{*}$, and hence over the symmetric monoidal subcategory $\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \subset \mathcal{S}_{*}$ as well. Alternatively, this tensor is computed by first applying $\Sigma^{\infty}: \mathcal{S}_{*} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ and then tensoring with $A$ in $\mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}$.

Remark 13.3.6. The $\infty$-category Sp of spectra admits a left and right complete t-structure with heart $\mathrm{Sp}^{\nabla} \simeq \mathrm{Ab}$ the category of abelian groups. The identity functor $\mathrm{Ab} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ab}$ is right exact and so determines a right t-exact functor $\mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathbf{Z}) \simeq \mathcal{D}^{-}(\mathrm{Ab}) \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ with image the Eilenberg-Mac Lane spectra. Strictly speaking, these are the generalized Eilenberg-Mac Lane spectra: an Eilenberg-Mac Lane spectrum is a generalized Eilenberg-Mac Lane spectrum

that has homotopy concentrated in a single degree, or equivalently is the image of a chain complex with homology concentrated in a single degree.

Definition 13.3.7. A cohomology theory $\left\{F^{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{Z}}$ is a $\mathbf{Z}$-graded family of functors $F^{n}$ : $\operatorname{Ho}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathrm{op}}\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{Ab}$ and natural isomorphisms $\sigma^{n}: F^{n} \rightarrow F^{n+1} \circ \Sigma$ satisfying the following exactness conditions:
(1) For any cofiber sequence $X \rightarrow Y \rightarrow Z$ integer $n$ the sequence of abelian groups $F^{n}(Z) \rightarrow$ $F^{n}(Y) \rightarrow F^{n}(X)$ is exact.
(2) For any (possibly infinite) wedge decomposition $X \simeq \bigvee_{i \in I} X_{i}$ and integer $n$, the homomorphism $F^{n}(X) \rightarrow \prod_{i \in I} F^{n}\left(X_{i}\right)$ is an isomorphism.

Remark 13.3.8. These are the Eilenberg-Steenrod axioms [15] for a (generalized) cohomology theory. The original formulation included the dimension axiom, which required that $F^{n}\left(S^{0}\right)=0$ for all $n \neq 0$. One can show without much difficulty that the cohomology theories $F$ that satisfy the dimension axiom are necessarily of the form $F^{n}(X) \cong H^{n}\left(X ; F^{0}\left(S^{0}\right)\right)$, which is to say cohomology with coefficients in the abelian group $F^{0}\left(S^{0}\right)$. This axiom was disregarded as interesting "generalized" cohomology theories were discovered.

Remark 13.3.9. The Brown representability theorem [12] asserts that any suitably left exact functor $F: \mathcal{S}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow$ Set $_{*}$ is representable. In particular,

$$
F^{n} \cong \pi_{0} \operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{S}_{*}}\left(-, A_{n}\right): \mathcal{S}^{\mathrm{op}} \longrightarrow \mathrm{Ab}
$$

for some pointed space $A_{n}$, and the resulting sequence of pointed spaces $\left\{A_{n}\right\}$ can be chosen so that the suspension isomorphisms $\sigma^{n}: F^{n} \rightarrow F^{n+1} \circ \Sigma$ are induced by equivalences $\eta_{n}: A_{n} \rightarrow \Omega A_{n+1}$ in $\mathcal{S}_{*}$ (in fact the loop space structure induces the group structure on the represented functor, and any such group structure arises in this way). This is how spectra arose in practice.

Remark 13.3.10. By choosing a representing spectrum, any cohomology theory $F=\left\{F^{n}\right\}$ in the classical sense as above gives rise to a cohomological functor in the $\infty$-categorical sense, by which we mean a limit preserving functor $F: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow$ Sp. One can show that any such functor is necessarily a right adjoint, so that the $\infty$-categories of spectra and cohomological functors are canonically equivalent:

$$
\mathrm{Sp} \simeq \mathcal{S}_{*} \otimes \mathrm{Sp} \simeq \operatorname{RFun}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathrm{Sp}\right)
$$

Similarly, $\mathrm{Sp} \simeq \operatorname{RFun}\left(\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathrm{Sp}\right)$, so that any cohomological functor of pointed spaces extends uniquely to a cohomological functor of spectra.

Remark 13.3.11. A cohomological functor $F: \mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ induces a functor $\pi_{0} F$ : $\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ab}$ which necessarily factors through the triangulated homotopy category of spectra. There is a version of Brown representability for triangulated categories that are compactly generated in the appropriate sense, due to Neeman [30]. This is not a corollary of the corresponding formal result for compactly generated stable $\infty$-categories, namely that $\operatorname{Sp}(\mathcal{C}) \subset \operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathcal{C}^{\text {op }}, \mathrm{Sp}\right)$ is the full subcategory consisting of the cohomological functors. Indeed, triangulated categories aren't always homotopy categories of stable $\infty$-categories

and don't necessarily even admit finite limits or colimits; rather, the requisite exactness properties are encoded by the triangulated structure.

Remark 13.3.12. Much of the classical algebraic topology literature models spectra as a full subcategory of local objects inside of a larger category. Our definition of spectra $\mathrm{Sp} \subset \operatorname{Fun}_{*}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }}, \mathcal{S}_{*}\right)$ is as the full subcategory of (reduced) excisive functors. The excisive approximation [26, Example 6.1.1.28] $\partial F: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}$ of a reduced functor $F: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}$ is given by the formula

$$
(\partial F)(T) \simeq \operatorname{colim}_{n \rightarrow \infty} \Omega^{n} F\left(\Sigma^{n} T\right)
$$

As any finite space admits a cell decomposition, a reduced excisive functor is determined by its values on spheres; in fact, any sequence of spheres $\left\{S^{n_{0}}, S^{n_{1}}, \ldots\right\}$ with $n_{i}>n_{j}$ whenever $i>j$. Moreover, for any reduced $F: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {fin }} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}$, we have maps

$$
S^{1} \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{*}\left(S^{n}, S^{n+1}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{*}\left(F\left(S^{n}\right), F\left(S^{n+1}\right)\right)
$$

and hence maps $S^{1} \wedge F\left(S^{n}\right) \rightarrow F\left(S^{n+1}\right)$. This motivates the next definition.
Definition 13.3.13. A prespectrum consists of an $\mathbf{N}$-indexed collection of pointed spaces $\left\{Z_{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$ and structure maps $\left\{\varepsilon_{n}: \Sigma Z_{n-1} \rightarrow Z_{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$.

To organize prespectra into an $\infty$-category PSp , it will be useful to write

$$
\Sigma[1]: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}} \longrightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}} \quad \text { and } \quad \Omega[-1]: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}} \longrightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}}
$$

for the "shifted" suspension and loops functors $\Sigma[1](X)_{n}=\Sigma\left(X_{n-1}\right)$ and $\Omega[-1](X)_{n}=$ $\Omega\left(X_{n+1}\right)$, where we take the convention that $X_{-1} \simeq \mathrm{pt}$ is contractible. Then $\Sigma[1]$ is left adjoint to $\Omega[-1]$, and the $\infty$-category of prespectra is defined by forming either of following the pullbacks $\mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ :
![img-152.jpeg](img-152.jpeg)

Remark 13.3.14. A prespectrum $Z=\left\{Z_{n}\right\}$ gives rise to a sequence of representable functors $\operatorname{Map}\left(-, Z_{n}\right): \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}$ which collectively represent a cohomology theory if and only if the map $Z \rightarrow \Omega[-1] Z$ is an equivalence. The "diagonal" map $\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}}\right)$ identifies $\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}}$ with the full subcategory of $\operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}}\right)$ consisting of the equivalences, and the iterated pullback square
![img-153.jpeg](img-153.jpeg)

exhibits $\mathrm{Sp} \subset \mathrm{PSp}$ as the equalizer of the endofunctors id, $\Omega[-1]: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathbf{N}}$.
Remark 13.3.15. This inclusion admits a left adjoint spectrification functor $\mathrm{PSp} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$. Indeed, if $Z=\left\{Z_{n}\right\}$ is a prespectrum, the $n^{\text {th }}$-space of the associated spectrum $A$ is given by the formula

$$
A_{n} \simeq \operatorname{colim}_{m \rightarrow \infty} \Omega^{m} Z_{m+n}
$$

The equivalence $A_{n} \xrightarrow{\sim} \Omega A_{n+1}$ is induced by the maps $Z_{n+m} \rightarrow \Omega Z_{n+m+1}$, which becomes the equivalence $\operatorname{colim} \Omega^{m} Z_{n+m} \simeq \Omega^{m+1} Z_{n+m+1}$ after passing to the colimit. This is essentially the same formula as in 13.3.12.

Remark 13.3.16. The $\infty$-category of prespectra is quite useful in practice. As a source of examples, a pointed space $X$ evidently determines a suspension presprectrum $\left\{\Sigma^{n} X\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$ whose associated spectrum is $\Sigma^{\infty} X$. Since the spectrification functor preserves colimits, the $\infty$-category of prespectra can be used as a tool for computing colimits and smash products of spectra.

# 13.3.2 The smash product 

The construction of a symmetric monoidal model category of spectra was a major foundational problem in the subject for quite some time. One issue is that there isn't an obvious candidate for the smash product of prespectra; instead, given prespectra $A=\left\{A_{m}\right\}$ and $B=\left\{B_{n}\right\}$, their smash product $A \otimes B$ is most naturally indexed on the poset $\mathbf{N} \times \mathbf{N}$; that is, $(A \otimes B)_{m, n}=A_{m} \wedge B_{n}$. Adams' theory of "handicrafted smash products" [1] shows that any cofinal choice of poset $\mathbf{N} \subset \mathbf{N} \times \mathbf{N}$ results in a prespectrum representing the smash product, and verifies that this procedure descends to a symmetric monoidal structure on the homotopy category of spectra. However this is insufficient for many purposes, especially as the homotopy category doesn't admit even the most basic sorts of limits and colimits like pullbacks and pushouts.

Another more significant issue is already apparent in homological algebra: in the derived $\infty$-category of chain complexes of modules over a commutative ring, the derived tensor product is really only defined up to quasi-isomorphism, so there's no philosophical reason to expect this to lift to a symmetric monoidal structure on the ordinary category of chain complexes. The first resolutions of this problem in homotopy theory were the symmetric spectra of Hovey-Shipley-Smith [20] and the S-modules of Elmendorf-Kriz-Mandell-May [16].

There are morphisms of $\otimes$-idempotent objects of LPr

$$
\mathcal{S} \longrightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*} \longrightarrow \operatorname{CMon}(\mathcal{S}) \longrightarrow \operatorname{CMon}^{\mathrm{gp}}(\mathcal{S}) \longrightarrow \mathcal{S}
$$

necessarily symmetric monoidal, which enable us to calculate the tensor product in these presentable $\infty$-categories. Specifically, writing $\Sigma^{\infty}: \mathcal{S}_{*} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ for unique symmetric monoidal left adjoint functor, we deduce that

$$
\left(\Sigma^{\infty} X_{1}\right) \otimes \cdots \otimes\left(\Sigma^{\infty} X_{n}\right) \simeq \Sigma^{\infty}\left(X_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge X_{n}\right)
$$

for any finite collection of pointed spaces $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}$. The analogous result remains true for unpointed spaces by addition of a disjoint basepoint.

Remark 13.3.17. Using the description of spectra as the limit of tower associated to the endofunctor $\Omega: \mathcal{S}_{*} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}$, we obtain maps

$$
\Omega^{\infty-n}: \mathrm{Sp} \longrightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}
$$

by projection to the $n^{\text {th }}$ factor. The reason for this notation is that we have equivalences $\Omega^{\infty} \simeq \Omega^{n} \Omega^{\infty-n}$; indeed, if $A$ is a spectrum, $\Omega^{\infty} A \simeq A_{0} \simeq \Omega^{n} A_{n} \simeq \Omega^{n} \Omega^{\infty-n} A$. The collection of functors $\left\{\Omega^{\infty-n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$, or any infinite subset thereof, form a conservative family of functors $\mathrm{Sp} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}$ in RPr. They admit left adjoints $\Sigma^{\infty-n}: \mathcal{S}_{*} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ which factor through $\mathrm{PSp} \rightarrow$ Sp.

Remark 13.3.18. By [26, Proposition 6.3.3.6], any spectrum $A$ admits a canonical presentation by desuspended suspension spectra

$$
A \simeq \operatorname{colim}_{n \rightarrow \infty} \Sigma^{\infty-n} \Omega^{\infty-n} A \simeq \operatorname{colim}_{n \rightarrow \infty} \Sigma^{-n} \Sigma^{\infty} A_{n}
$$

in which the maps $\Sigma^{\infty-n} A_{n} \rightarrow \Sigma^{\infty-n-1} A_{n+1}$ correspond to the composites

$$
A_{n} \rightarrow \Omega^{\infty} \Sigma^{n} \Omega^{n} \Sigma^{\infty} A_{n} \rightarrow \Omega^{\infty} \Sigma^{n} \Omega^{n+1} \Sigma^{\infty} A_{n+1} \simeq \Omega^{\infty-n} \Sigma^{\infty-n-1} A_{n+1}
$$

Using the fact that $\Sigma^{\infty-m} X \otimes \Sigma^{\infty-n} Y \simeq \Sigma^{\infty-m-n} X \wedge Y$, we can write down explicit formulas for the spaces in the smash product of any finite sequence of spectra.

Remark 13.3.19. Another characterization of the $n$-fold smash product functor $\otimes^{n}$ : $\mathrm{Sp}^{\times n} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ is as the derivative of the $n$-fold cartesian product functor $\times^{n}: \mathcal{S}^{\times n} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}$ or its coreduction, the $n$-fold smash product functor $\wedge^{n}: \mathcal{S}_{*}^{\times n} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{*}$. See [25, Example 6.2.3.28] for further details.

Remark 13.3.20. If $B$ is a fixed spectrum, the functor $\mathrm{Sp} \xrightarrow{(\mathrm{id}, B)} \mathrm{Sp} \times \mathrm{Sp} \xrightarrow{\otimes^{2}} \mathrm{Sp}$ that sends $A$ to $A \otimes B$ preserves colimits and therefore, according to the adjoint functor theorem, admits a right adjoint. This right adjoint is the mapping spectrum functor $\mathcal{F}(B,-): \mathrm{Sp} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$, which admits the following description: if $A$ is a spectrum, then $\mathcal{F}(B, A)$ is the spectrum given by the formula

$$
\mathcal{F}(B, A)_{n} \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{Sp}}\left(B, \Sigma^{n} A\right)
$$

with structure maps

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{Sp}}\left(B, \Sigma^{n} A\right) \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{Sp}}\left(B, \Omega \Sigma^{n+1} A\right) \simeq \Omega \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{Sp}}\left(B, \Sigma^{n+1} A\right)
$$

where the first equivalence uses the fact that Sp is a stable $\infty$-category and therefore that the composite functor $\Omega \Sigma$ is equivalent to the identity.

In order to be able to work effectively with spectra, we need ordinary algebraic invariants such as homotopy groups. One way to obtain the homotopy groups of a spectrum is via the Postnikov t-structure, defined as follows.

Definition 13.3.21. Let $\mathrm{Sp}_{\leq-1} \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ denote the full subcategory of spectra consisting of those objects $A$ such that $\Omega^{\infty} A$ is contractible.

Remark 13.3.22. The functor $\Omega^{\infty}: \mathrm{Sp} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}$ is corepresented by the unit object $\mathbf{S}$ of Sp , which is compact. It therefore preserves limits and filtered colimits; furthermore, limits and filtered colimits of contractible spaces are contractible. Hence the inclusion $\mathrm{Sp}_{\leq-1} \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ preserves limits and filtered colimits and therefore, by the adjoint functor theorem, it admits a left adjoint. We write $\tau_{\leq-1}: \mathrm{Sp} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ for the left adjoint followed by the right adjoint, so that any spectrum $A$ admits a natural unit map $A \rightarrow \tau_{\leq-1} A$. The fiber of the unit map then determines an endofunctor $\tau_{\geq 0}: \mathrm{Sp} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$, the connective cover. We write $\mathrm{Sp}_{\geq 0}$ for the essential image of $\tau_{\geq 0}$ and $\mathrm{Sp}_{\leq 0}=\mathrm{Sp}_{\leq-1}[1]$.

Proposition 13.3.23. [25, Proposition 1.4.3.6] The pair of full subcategories $\mathrm{Sp}_{\geq 0} \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ and $\mathrm{Sp}_{\leq 0} \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ are the connective and coconnective parts of a t-structure on Sp. Moreover, this t-structure is left and right complete, and its heart $\mathrm{Sp}^{\bigotimes} \simeq \mathrm{Ab}$ is canonically equivalent to the category of abelian groups.

Remark 13.3.24. The spectra that lie in the full subcategory $\mathrm{Sp}_{\geq 0} \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ are called the connective spectra, and we will often write $\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{cn}}$ in place of $\mathrm{Sp}_{\geq 0}$.

Remark 13.3.25. The homotopy groups of a spectrum $A$, defined via the t-structure on Sp , collectively form a Z-graded abelian group

$$
\pi_{*} A=\bigoplus_{m \in \mathbf{Z}} \pi_{m} A
$$

Viewing $A$ as a sequence of pointed spaces $\left\{A_{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$ equipped with equivalences $A_{n} \simeq$ $\Omega A_{n+1}$, we can also obtain the homotopy groups of $A$ via the homotopy groups of the pointed spaces $\left\{A_{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$. Specifically, the nonnegative homotopy groups of $A$ are the homotopy groups of the underlying infinite loop space; that is, for $m \geq 0$,

$$
\pi_{m} A \cong \pi_{m} A_{0} \cong \pi_{m+1} A_{1} \cong \pi_{m+2} A_{2} \cong \cdots
$$

The negative homotopy groups of $A$, on the other hand, are the homotopy groups of a sufficiently high delooping; that is, for $m<0$,

$$
\pi_{m} A \cong \pi_{0} A_{-m} \cong \pi_{1} A_{-m+1} \cong \pi_{2} A_{-m+2} \cong \cdots
$$

More generally, $\pi_{m} A \cong \operatorname{colim} \pi_{n} A_{n-m}$, where for $m>n$ we take $A_{n-m}$ to mean the homotopy type of the space $\Omega^{m-n} A_{0} \simeq \Omega^{m-n+1} A_{1} \simeq \Omega^{m-n+2} A_{2} \simeq \cdots$.

Definition 13.3.26. Let $A$ and $B$ be spectra. The $A$-homology of $B, A_{*}(B)$, is the graded abelian group $\pi_{*}(A \otimes B)$. Dually, the $A$-cohomology of $B, A^{*}(B)$, is the graded abelian group $\pi_{*} \mathcal{F}(B, A)$.

Remark 13.3.27. If $X$ is a pointed space, we write $A_{*}(X)=A_{*}\left(\Sigma^{\infty} X\right)$ and $A^{*}(X)=$ $A^{*}\left(\Sigma^{\infty} X\right)$. If $A$ is a spectrum representing a generalized cohomology theory, this recovers the $A$-cohomology groups of the pointed space $X$.

# 13.3.3 Associative and commutative algebras 

Definition 13.3.28. An associative ring spectrum is an algebra object of the monoidal $\infty$-category of spectra. A commutative ring spectrum is a commutative algebra object of the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category of spectra.

We write $\mathrm{Alg}=\operatorname{Alg}\left(\mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}\right)$ and $\mathrm{CAlg}=\operatorname{CAlg}\left(\mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}\right)$ for the $\infty$-categories of associative and commutative ring spectra, respectively.

Remark 13.3.29. As the notation suggests, we often refer to associative or commutative ring spectra as associative or commutative algebra spectra, or just associative or commutative algebras when the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category of spectra is clear from context. The latter terminology is especially convenient in relative contexts, such as when we wish to work over ${ }^{5}$ a fixed base commutative ring spectrum $R$, where the corresponding notion is that of an associative or commutative $R$-algebra (spectrum here is implicit).

Remark 13.3.30. Recall that a commutative algebra object of the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category of spectra is a section

$$
A\langle-\rangle: \operatorname{Fin}_{*} \longrightarrow \mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}
$$

of the cocartesian fibration $p: \mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \mathrm{Fin}_{*}$ such that $A\langle m\rangle \rightarrow A\langle n\rangle \in \mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}$ is cocartesian whenever $\langle m\rangle \rightarrow\langle n\rangle \in \operatorname{Fin}_{*}$ is inert. We will typically write $A$ in place of $A\langle 1\rangle \in \operatorname{Sp}_{\langle 1\rangle}^{\otimes} \simeq \mathrm{Sp}$ and abusively refer the underlying spectrum $A$ as the algebra object. The value of $A\langle-\rangle$ on the active map $\langle 2\rangle \rightarrow\langle 1\rangle$, pushed forward to the fiber over $\langle 1\rangle$ via this map, is the multiplication $\mu: A^{\otimes 2} \rightarrow A$.

Similarly, an associative algebra object $A \in \operatorname{Alg}\left(\mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}\right)$ is a section

$$
A[-]: \Delta^{\mathrm{op}} \longrightarrow \mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes} \times_{\mathrm{Fin}_{*}} \Delta^{\mathrm{op}}
$$

of the restricted (along the cut map $\Delta^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fin}_{*}$ ) fibration that carries inert arrows to cocartesian arrows. We will typically also write $A=A[1]$ for the underling spectrum of $A[-]$ and refer to $A$ as the associative ring spectrum.

Remark 13.3.31. A section $A[-]: \Delta^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes} \times_{\mathrm{Fin}_{*}} \Delta^{\mathrm{op}}$ amounts to a diagram of the form

$$
A[0] \longleftrightarrow A[1] \longleftrightarrow A[2] \longleftrightarrow
$$

in $\mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}$. If it is an algebra object, the $n$ inert maps $[1] \rightarrow[n]$ in $\Delta$ force $A[n]$ to decompose as the $n$-fold product $(A[1], \ldots, A[1])$ of $A[1]$ under the equivalence $\mathrm{Sp}_{(n)}^{\otimes} \simeq \mathrm{Sp}^{\times n}$, where we identify Sp with $\mathrm{Sp}_{(1)}^{\otimes}$ as usual. Restricting to the active maps and pushing everything forward to the the fiber over $[1] \in \Delta$ via the inert maps, and writing $\mathbf{S}, A, A \otimes A$ for the images of $A[0], A[1], A[2]$, we obtain a diagram

$$
\mathbf{S} \longrightarrow A \longleftrightarrow A \otimes A \longleftrightarrow
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ Over $R$ means over $\operatorname{Spec} R$, reversing the direction of the arrows. Algebraically this means working under $R$, but the terminology is influenced by geometric intuition.

in Sp, encoding exactly the maps one would expect from an algebra object. The commutative case is similar but more complex due to the permutations.

In certain situations, some of which we will encounter later, it is convenient to work with only the connective spectra. Recall that $\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{cn}} \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ denotes the full subcategory consisting of the spectra $A$ whose negative homotopy groups $\pi_{n} A$ vanish for all $n<0$. In other words, $\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{cn}}=\mathrm{Sp}_{\geq 0}$ as full subcategory of spectra, where $\mathrm{Sp}_{\geq 0}$ is defined via the standard Postnikov t-structure. Since the tensor product of connective spectra is again connective, we actually obtain $\mathrm{Sp}_{\geq 0}^{\otimes} \subset \mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}$ as a symmetric monoidal subcategory. Thus we have $\infty$-categories $\mathrm{Alg}^{\mathrm{cn}}=\operatorname{Alg}\left(\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{cn}}\right)$ and $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}=\operatorname{CAlg}\left(\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{cn}}\right)$ of connective associative and commutative algebra spectra.

Proposition 13.3.32. [25, Proposition 7.1.3.19] Postnikov towers converge in the presentable $\infty$-categories $\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{cn}}, \mathrm{Alg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$, and $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$.

Definition 13.3.33. An $\infty$-monoid is an algebra object of the symmetric monoidal $\infty$ category $\mathcal{S}^{\times}$of spaces. An abelian $\infty$-monoid is a commutative algebra object of $\mathcal{S}^{\times}$. An $\infty$-monoid, or abelian $\infty$-monoid, $G$ is said to an $\infty$-group, or abelian $\infty$-group, if the ordinary discrete monoid $\pi_{0} G$ is a group.

Remark 13.3.34. We have $\infty$-categories $\operatorname{Mon}_{\infty}=\operatorname{Mon}\left(\mathcal{S}^{\times}\right)=\operatorname{Alg}\left(\mathcal{S}^{\times}\right)$and $\mathrm{Gp}_{\infty} \subset$ $\operatorname{Mon}_{\infty}$ of $\infty$-monoids and $\infty$-groups, as well as their abelian variants $\mathrm{AbMon}_{\infty}=$ $\operatorname{CMon}\left(\mathcal{S}^{\times}\right)=\operatorname{CAlg}\left(\mathcal{S}^{\times}\right)$and $\mathrm{AbGp}_{\infty} \subset \mathrm{AbMon}_{\infty}$. The group completion of an $\infty$-monoid $M$ is the left adjoint of the fully faithful inclusion $\mathrm{Gp}_{\infty} \subset \mathrm{Mon}_{\infty}$, and is given by the formula $G \simeq \Omega \mathrm{~B} M$.

Remark 13.3.35. The reader might be wondering why we did not define associative and commutative ring spectra as homotopy coherently associative and commutative ring objects in the $\infty$-category of spaces. The primary reason is that this only yields the connective ring spectra, and nonconnective spectra, even ring spectra, such as topological K-theory, are among our most important examples. Nevertheless it is true, and a good sanity check, that we have an equivalence $\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{cn}} \simeq \mathrm{AbGp}_{\infty}$, which induces equivalences $\mathrm{Alg}^{\mathrm{cn}} \simeq \operatorname{Ring}_{\infty}$ and $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}} \simeq \operatorname{CRing}_{\infty}$, where the latter notions are defined as in [17] (among other algebraic theories, such as semirings and their $\mathbf{E}_{n}$ variants).

Definition 13.3.36. A homotopy associative ring spectrum is an associative algebra object in the monoidal homotopy category of spectra. A homotopy commutative ring spectrum is a commutative algebra object in the symmetric monoidal homotopy category of spectra.

Remark 13.3.37. Homotopy categories are ordinary categories. Hence there are no coherences to specify, and a homotopy associative ring spectrum is the data of a ring spectrum $R$ equipped with a unit map $\eta: \mathbf{S} \rightarrow R$ and a multiplication map $\mu: R \otimes R \rightarrow R$ that are associative and unital in the sense that the diagrams
![img-154.jpeg](img-154.jpeg)

commute up to homotopy (a choice of homotopy is not part of the data). As in ordinary algebra, commutativity in this case is a property of a homotopy associative ring spectrum $R$. While the theory of homotopy associative or commutative ring spectra plays an important role in algebraic topology, the categories of left (or right) modules over homotopy associative ring spectra are poorly behaved, lacking basic structure such as finite limits and colimits.

Proposition 13.3.38. [25, Proposition 7.2.4.27] The $\infty$-categories $\mathrm{Alg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$ and $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$ are compactly generated. Moreover, they are generated under sifted colimits by compact projective objects.

Definition 13.3.39. A connective associative ring spectrum $A$ is said to be locally of finite presentation if $A$ is compact as an object of $\mathrm{Alg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$. A connective commutative ring spectrum $A$ is said to be locally of finite presentation if $A$ is a compact as an object of $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$.

# 13.3.4 Left and right modules 

An associative (respectively, commutative) algebra $A$ is something that exists in a monoidal (respectively, symmetric monoidal) $\infty$-category $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$. Classically it was common to take $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ to be the symmetric monoidal category of abelian groups, or (left) $R$-modules for a commutative ring $R$. Recall that a monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ can be regarded as a cocartesian fibration over $\Delta^{\text {op }}$ (equivalently a functor $\Delta^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ ) satisfying the Segal condition, the underlying category $\mathcal{A}$ of $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ is the value $\mathcal{A}_{[1]}^{\otimes}$ at the ordinal [1], and the simplicial object $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ can be regarded as a categorical bar construction on $\mathcal{A}$, using its monoidal structure.

The ordinary bar construction generalizes as follows: if $\mathcal{M}$ admits a left $\mathcal{A}$-action and $\mathcal{N}$ admits a right $\mathcal{A}$-action, then we may form a simplicial object that in degree $n$ is equivalent to $\mathcal{N} \times \mathcal{A}^{\times n} \times \mathcal{M}$. The $\infty$-categories $\mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{N}$ that arise in this way are said to be left and right tensored over $\mathcal{A}$, respectively; this is the structure that, when given an algebra object $A$ of $\mathcal{A}$, allows us to define the notions of left and right $A$-module object of $\mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{N}$. Such $\infty$-categories are themselves cocartesian fibrations over $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$, and hence over $\Delta^{\text {op }}$, but they satisfy a slight variant of the Segal condition.

Definition 13.3.40. Let $p: \mathcal{A}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \Delta^{\text {op }}$ be a monoidal $\infty$-category. Let $p: \mathcal{A}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \Delta^{\text {op }}$ be a monoidal $\infty$-category. An $\infty$-category left tensored over $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ is a cocartesian fibration $q: \mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \Delta^{\text {op }}$ together with a morphism of cocartesian fibrations $f: \mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ over $\Delta^{\text {op }}$ that satisfies the following relative version of the Segal condition: for each natural number $n$, the map

$$
\mathcal{M}_{[n]}^{\otimes} \longrightarrow \mathcal{A}_{[n]}^{\otimes} \times \mathcal{M}_{\{n\}}^{\otimes}
$$

induced by $f$ and the inclusion of the final vertex $\{n\} \subset[n]$ is an equivalence.
Remark 13.3.41. The morphism of cocartesian fibrations $f: \mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ over $\Delta^{\text {op }}$ is an example of a left action object of $\mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$. More precisely, we write $\operatorname{LMon}\left(\mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}\right) \subset$ $\operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty / \Delta^{\mathrm{op}}}\right)$ for the full subcategory consisting of those morphisms of cocartesian fibrations $f: \mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ that satisfy the relative Segal condition of 13.3.40. As in [25, Notation 4.2.2.5], there is a functor $\operatorname{LMon}\left(\mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Mon}\left(\mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}\right)$ that sends the left action object $f: \mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ to the monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$.

Remark 13.3.42. The underlying $\infty$-category of the left tensored $\infty$-category $q: \mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \rightarrow$ $\Delta^{\mathrm{op}}$ is the fiber $\mathcal{M}_{[0]}^{\otimes}$ over $[0]$, which we will typically denote $\mathcal{M}$. There are equivalences $\mathcal{M}_{\{n\}} \simeq \mathcal{M}$ for all $n$. The Segal condition at $n=1$ gives an equivalence $\mathcal{M}_{[1]}^{\otimes} \simeq \mathcal{A} \times \mathcal{M}$ and the inclusion $[0] \rightarrow[1]$ of the initial vertex induces a left action morphism $\mathcal{A} \times \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$.

Remark 13.3.43. Dually, there is an entirely analogous notion of right tensored $\infty$-category whose definition instead involves the inclusions of the initial vertices, with the action coming from the inclusion of the final vertices.

Remark 13.3.44. A monoidal $\infty$-category $p: \mathcal{A}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \Delta^{\text {op }}$ is canonically left (respectively, right) tensored over itself. Roughly, restricting the cocartesian fibration $p$ along the right (respectively, left) cone functor ${ }^{\triangleright}: \Delta \rightarrow \Delta$ that sends $[n]$ to $[n] \star[0]$ (respectively, $[n]$ to $[0] \star[n])$ yields a cocartesian fibration $q: \mathcal{A}^{\triangleright \otimes} \rightarrow \Delta^{\text {op }}$ whose fiber over $[n]$ is equivalent to $\mathcal{A}^{\times n+1}$. The morphism of cocartesian fibrations $f: \mathcal{A}^{\triangleright \otimes} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ is obtained as in [25, Example 4.2.2.4]. See [25, Variant 4.2.2.11] for details and a comparison to the operadic approach.

Definition 13.3.45. Let $p: \mathcal{A}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \Delta^{\text {op }}$ be a monoidal $\infty$-category and let $f: \mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ be an $\infty$-category left tensored over $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$. A left module object of $\mathcal{M}^{\otimes}$ is a map $s: \Delta^{\text {op }} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{\otimes}$ such that the composite $f \circ s$ is an algebra object of $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ and, if $i:[m] \rightarrow[n]$ is an inert map in such that $i(m)=n, f(i)$ is a cocartesian morphism of $\mathcal{M}^{\otimes}$.

We write

$$
\operatorname{LMod}\left(\mathcal{M}^{\otimes}\right) \subset \operatorname{Fun}_{\Delta^{\mathrm{op}}}\left(\Delta^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathcal{M}^{\otimes}\right)
$$

for the full subcategory consisting of the left module objects of $\mathcal{M}^{\otimes}$.
Remark 13.3.46. In the special case in which $\mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \simeq \mathcal{A}^{\triangleright \otimes}$ is equivalent to $\mathcal{A}$, regarded as being left tensored over itself via $f: \mathcal{A}^{\triangleright \otimes} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$, we simply write $\operatorname{LMod}\left(\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}\right)$ in place of $\operatorname{LMod}\left(\mathcal{A}^{\triangleright \otimes}\right)$.

In the special case in which $\mathcal{M}^{\otimes} \simeq \mathcal{A}^{\triangleright \otimes}$ is $\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$ regarded as left tensored over itself via $f: \mathcal{A}^{\triangleright \otimes} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}^{\otimes}$, we simply write $\operatorname{LMod}\left(\mathcal{A}^{\otimes}\right)$ in place of $\operatorname{LMod}\left(\mathcal{A}^{\triangleright \otimes}\right)$.

Remark 13.3.47. There is an evident notion of right module object of an $\infty$-category right tensored over a monoidal $\infty$-category.

Definition 13.3.48. A left module spectrum is a left module object of the monoidal $\infty$ category $\mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes} \times_{\text {Fin } \iota} \Delta^{\text {op }}$ of spectra.

We write $\operatorname{LMod}=\operatorname{LMod}\left(\mathrm{Sp}^{\otimes}\right)$ for the $\infty$-category of left module spectra.
Remark 13.3.49. The $\infty$-category LMod of left module spectra comes equipped with a forgetful functor $\mathrm{LMod} \rightarrow$ Alg that returns the algebra object in the definition of a left module object. Given an associative algebra spectrum $A$, we write $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ for the fiber over $A$ of the forgetful functor. We also have a forgetful functor $\mathrm{LMod} \times_{\text {Alg }} \mathrm{CAlg} \rightarrow \mathrm{CAlg}$ obtained by pulling back along the forgetful functor $\mathrm{CAlg} \rightarrow$ Alg. We will sometime simply write $\mathrm{LMod} \rightarrow$ CAlg for this forgetful functor, when it is clear from context that we are only considering left modules over commutative algebra spectra.

# 13.3.5 Localization 

In this section we briefly review the theory of localization of ring spectra. Recall that a multiplicatively closed subset $S$, containing the unit, of an associative ring $R$ is said to satisfy the left Ore condition if, for or every pair of elements $r \in R$ and $s \in S$ there exist elements $r^{\prime} \in R$ and $s^{\prime} \in S$ such that $s^{\prime} r=r^{\prime} s$, and if $r \in R$ is an element such that $r s=0$ for some element $s \in S$ then there exists an element $s^{\prime} \in S$ such that $s^{\prime} r=0$.

Remark 13.3.50. If $A$ is an associative algebra spectrum, any homogeneous element $s \in$ $\pi_{n} A$ can be represented by a "degree $n$ " left $A$-module map $\Sigma^{n} A \rightarrow A$ which is unique up to homotopy.

Definition 13.3.51. Let $A$ be an associative algebra spectrum and $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ a set of homogeneous elements satisfying the left Ore condition. A left $A$-module spectrum $M$ is $S$-local if, for every element $s \in S$, left multiplication by $s$ induces an isomorphism $\pi_{*} M \rightarrow$ $\pi_{*} M$. We write $S^{-1} \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \subset \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ for the full subcategory consisting of the $S$-local left $A$-module spectra.

Proposition 13.3.52. [25, Remark 7.2.3.18] The inclusion of the full subcategory $S^{-1} \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \subset \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ of $S$-local objects admits a left adjoint $S^{-1}: \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \rightarrow S^{-1} \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$, the $S$-localization functor.

Remark 13.3.53. The theory of Bousfield localization generalizes that of Ore localization. In the stable setting, this is the data of a left adjoint functor $L: \mathcal{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ of stable presentable $\infty$-categories such that the right adjoint $R: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$ is fully faithful. The kernel of $L: \mathcal{B} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is the stable presentable subcategory $\mathcal{A} \subset \mathcal{B}$ consisting of those objects $A \in \mathcal{B}$ such that $L(A) \simeq 0$ in $\mathcal{C}$. An instance of this construction is the localization of the $\infty$-category $\mathcal{B} \simeq \mathrm{Sp}$ of spectra at a fixed spectrum $E$ : in this case, a spectrum $N$ is $E$-acyclic if $E \otimes N \simeq 0$ and a spectrum $M$ is $E$-local if every map $N \rightarrow M$ from an $E$-acyclic object $M$ is null. While it turns out that Bousfield localization preserves (commutative) algebra structures [25, Proposition 2.2.1.9], it is quite difficult to control the localization in this generality, which is why we focus on the Ore localization instead.

Remark 13.3.54. It is possible to use the left Ore condition to give a reasonable explicit description of the homotopy groups of the left Ore localization $S^{-1} M$, for $M \in \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ and $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ a set of homogeneous elements satisfying the left Ore condition. See [25, Construction 7.2.3.19 and Proposition 7.2.3.20] for details.

Definition 13.3.55. Let $A$ be an associative algebra spectrum and $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ a set of homogeneous elements. A map of associative algebra spectra $\eta: A \rightarrow A^{\prime}$ exhibits $A^{\prime}$ as the left Ore localization of $A$ at $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ if, for every associative algebra spectrum $B$, $\eta^{*}: \operatorname{Map}_{\text {Alg }}\left(A^{\prime}, B\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{\text {Alg }}(A, B)$ is fully faithful with image those $f: A \rightarrow B$ such that $f(s)$ is invertible in $\pi_{*} B$ for all $s \in S$.

Theorem 13.3.56. [25, Proposition 7.2.3.27] Let $A$ be an associative algebra spectrum and $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ a set of homogeneous elements satisfying the left Ore condition. The localization $S^{-1} A$ admits the structure of an associative algebra $A\left[S^{-1}\right]$ equipped with an algebra map

$\eta: A \rightarrow A\left[S^{-1}\right]$ such that, for any associative algebra spectrum $B$, precomposition with $\eta$ is a fully faithful functor

$$
\eta^{*}: \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{Alg}}\left(A\left[S^{-1}\right], B\right) \subset \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{Alg}}(A, B)
$$

with image those $f: A \rightarrow B$ such that $f(s) \in \pi_{*} B$ is invertible for all $s \in S$.
Remark 13.3.57. If $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ is a set of homogeneous elements satisfying the left Ore condition, the canonical map $S^{-1} \pi_{*}(A) \rightarrow \pi_{*}\left(S^{-1} A\right)$ is an isomorphism of graded rings, where $S^{-1} \pi_{*} A$ denotes the localization as graded rings.

Remark 13.3.58. If $A$ is an associative algebra spectrum such that the graded ring $\pi_{*} A$ is graded commutative, then the left Ore condition on a multiplicative subset $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ is automatically satisfied.

There is an analogous statement for commutative algebra spectra.
Definition 13.3.59. Let $A$ be a commutative algebra spectrum and $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ a set of homogeneous elements. A map of commutative algebra spectra $\eta: A \rightarrow A^{\prime}$ exhibits $A^{\prime}$ as the localization of $A$ at $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ if, for every commutative algebra spectrum $B, \eta^{*}$ : $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}\left(A^{\prime}, B\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}(A, B)$ is fully faithful with image those $f: A \rightarrow B$ such that $f(s)$ is invertible in $\pi_{*} B$ for all $s \in S$.

Theorem 13.3.60. [25, Example 7.5.0.7] Let $A$ be a commutative algebra spectrum and $S \subset \pi_{*} A$ a multiplicative set of homogeneous elements. The localization $S^{-1} A$ admits the structure of a commutative algebra $A\left[S^{-1}\right]$ equipped with a commutative algebra map $A \rightarrow$ $A\left[S^{-1}\right]$ such that, for any commutative algebra specrum $B$, precomposition with $\eta$ is fully faithful

$$
\eta^{*}: \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}\left(A\left[S^{-1}\right], B\right) \subset \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}(A, B)
$$

with image those $f: A \rightarrow B$ such that $f(s) \in \pi_{*} B$ is invertible for all $s \in S$.
Remark 13.3.61. Given a commutative algebra spectrum $A$ and an arbitrary subset $T \subset$ $\pi_{*} A$ of homogeneous elements of $A$, we often write $A\left[T^{-1}\right]$ in place of $A\left[S^{-1}\right]$, where $S$ denotes the multiplicative closure of $T$ in $\pi_{*} A$.
