Indexing the elements of $T$ by some ordinal $I$, so that $T=\left\{t_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$, we have equivalences of commutative algebra spectra $\bigotimes_{i \in I} A\left[t_{i}^{-1}\right] \simeq$ $A\left[T^{-1}\right]$, where the infinite tensor product is defined to be the filtered colimit of the finite tensor products.

A map of ordinary commutative rings $f: A \rightarrow B$ is a Zariski localization if there exists a finite collection of elements $x_{i} \in \pi_{0} A$, defining basic Zariski open sets $A \rightarrow A\left[x_{i}^{-1}\right]$, such that $f$ is isomorphic to the product map $A \rightarrow \Pi_{i} A\left[x_{i}^{-1}\right]$ as objects of $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A}$. There is a similar notion for ring spectra.

Example 13.3.62. Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum and suppose given an element $f \in \pi_{0} R$, which we regard as an $R$-linear map $f: R \rightarrow R$ via the equivalence $R \simeq \operatorname{End}_{R}(R)$. Then the filtered colimit

$$
R\left[f^{-1}\right] \simeq \operatorname{colim}\left\{R \xrightarrow{f} R \xrightarrow{f} R \xrightarrow{f} \cdots\right\}
$$

is a $\otimes$-idempotent left $R$-module: that is, the relative tensor product (see 13.4.2) is an equivalence $R\left[f^{-1}\right] \otimes_{R} R\left[f^{-1}\right] \simeq R\left[f^{-1}\right]$. If follows that the associated Bousfield localization of $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$ is given the formula $M \mapsto M\left[f^{-1}\right] \simeq M \otimes_{R} R\left[f^{-1}\right]$, and that $R\left[f^{-1}\right] \in \operatorname{CAlg}_{R}$ has the following universal property: $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}_{R}}\left(R\left[f^{-1}\right], A\right)$ is contractible if $f \in \pi_{0}(A)^{\times}$ and empty otherwise.

Example 13.3.63. Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum and consider the affine scheme $X=\operatorname{Spec} \pi_{0} R$. The structure sheaf $\mathcal{O}_{X}$ is determined by its values $\mathcal{O}_{X}\left(U_{f}\right)=\pi_{0} R\left[f^{-1}\right]$ on the basic open sets $U_{f}=\operatorname{Spec} \pi_{0} R\left[f^{-1}\right], f \in \pi_{0} R$. Localizing $R$ at elements of $\pi_{0} R$ allows us to enhance $\mathcal{O}_{X}$ to a sheaf of commutative ring spectra $\mathcal{O}_{\text {Spec } R}$ on (the topological space of) $X$ by the formula $\mathcal{O}_{\text {Spec } R}\left(U_{f}\right)=R\left[f^{-1}\right]$. This is the affine spectral scheme Spec $R$.

Definition 13.3.64. Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum. Then $R$ is local if $\pi_{0} R$ is local, in the sense that there exists a unique maximal ideal $\mathfrak{m} \subset \pi_{0} R$. Equivalently, $R$ is local if, for any $f \in \pi_{0} R$, either $f$ or $1-f$ is a unit.

# 13.4 Module theory 

### 13.4.1 Monads

Given an $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$, the $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C})$ of endofunctors of $\mathcal{C}$ is canonically a monoidal $\infty$-category with respect to composition. Viewing $\mathcal{C}$ as a simplicial set and $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C})$ as simplicial sets, where composition is already a functor on the nose, we obtain a simplicial model for this monoidal $\infty$-category, which moreover comes equipped with a strict left action on $\mathcal{C}$ via the evaluation pairing $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C}) \times \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.

Definition 13.4.1. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be an $\infty$-category. A monad $T$ on $\mathcal{C}$ is an algebra object of the monoidal $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C})$ of endofunctors of $\mathcal{C}$.

Remark 13.4.2. We write $T: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ for the underlying endofunctor of the monad. The unit and multiplication maps are usually denoted $\eta: \operatorname{id}_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow T$ and $\mu: T \circ T \rightarrow T$. There are also homotopy coherent higher multiplications.

Remark 13.4.3. Let $T$ be a monad on an $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$. As $\mathcal{C}$ is left tensored over $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C})$ via the evaluation map $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C}) \times \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$, it makes sense to consider left $M$-module objects in $\mathcal{C}$ (these are often referred to instead as $M$-algebras, especially in ordinary category theory). We write $\operatorname{LMod}_{T}(\mathcal{C})$ for the $\infty$-category of left $T$-modules.

Example 13.4.4. Let $g: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ be a functor of $\infty$-categories that admits a left adjoint $f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$. Then the composite functor $g \circ f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ admits a canonical structure of a monad on $\mathcal{C}$. Here, the unit $\eta: \mathrm{id} \rightarrow g \circ f$ is the unit of the adjunction, and the multiplication $\mu: g \circ f \circ g \circ f \rightarrow g \circ f$ is induced by the counit $\varepsilon: f \circ g \rightarrow$ id. The formalism of adjunctions allows one to fill in all the coherences in a unique (up to a contractible space of choices) way.

Remark 13.4.5. Let $g: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ be a functor of $\infty$-categories that admits a left adjoint $f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ and let $T=g \circ f$ denote the resulting monad on $\mathcal{C}$, as in the example above. Then $g: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ factors as the composite $g=p \circ g^{\prime}$, where $g^{\prime}: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \operatorname{LMod}_{T}(\mathcal{C})$ is the functor that sends the object $B$ to the left $T$-module $\varepsilon: T B \rightarrow B$, and $p: \operatorname{LMod}_{M}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is the forgetful functor.

Definition 13.4.6. Let $g: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ be a functor of $\infty$-categories that admits a left adjoint $f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ and let $T=g \circ f$ be the resulting monad on $\mathcal{C}$. Then $g$ is monadic over $\mathcal{C}$ if the induced map $g^{\prime}: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \operatorname{LMod}_{T}(\mathcal{C})$ is an equivalence.

Knowing when a functor is monadic is quite important: for instance, monadic functors are conservative, and they exhibit the source as a kind of $\infty$-category of modules in the target. Fortunately there is a recognition principle for monadic functors. To state it we'll need the following notions.

Definition 13.4.7. The category $\Delta_{-\infty}$ has an object $[n]$ for each integer $n \geq-1$ and an arrow $\alpha:[m] \rightarrow[n]$ for each nondecreasing function $[m] \cup\{-\infty\} \rightarrow[n] \cup\{-\infty\}$ with $\alpha(-\infty)=\infty$ which compose in the obvious way. The subcategory $\Delta_{+} \subset \Delta_{-\infty}$ has the same objects but only those arrows $\alpha:[m] \rightarrow[n]$ such that $\alpha^{-1}(-\infty)=\{-\infty\}$. Note that we may identify $\Delta$ with the full subcategory of $\Delta_{+}$consisting of those objects $[n]$ with $n \geq 0$; in fact, the category $\Delta_{+}$parametrizes augmented simplicial objects.

Definition 13.4.8. An augmented simplicial object $A_{\bullet}: \Delta_{+}^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is split if $A_{\bullet}$ extends to a functor $\Delta_{-\infty}^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$. A simplicial object $A_{\bullet}: \Delta^{\mathrm{op}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is split if it extends to a split augmented simplicial object. Finally, given a functor $g: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$, an (augmented) simplicial object $A_{\bullet}$ of $\mathcal{D}$ is $g$-split if $g \circ A_{\bullet}$ is split as an (augmented) simplicial object of $\mathcal{C}$.

The monadicity theorem is a higher categorical analogue of the Barr-Beck Theorem. The result plays a considerably more important role higher categorically due to the difficulty of producing explicit constructions in this context.

Theorem 13.4.9. [25, Theorem 4.7.3.5] Let $g: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ be a functor of $\infty$-categories that admits a left adjoint $f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$. Then $g$ is monadic over $\mathcal{C}$ if and only if $g$ is conservative, $\mathcal{D}$ admits colimits of $g$-split simplicial objects, and $g$ preserves colimits of $g$-split simplicial objects.

# 13.4.2 Relative tensor products 

We now consider the $\infty$-category of left modules over a base commutative ring spectrum $R$ (which could be the sphere itself, in the absolute case). To generalize ordinary algebra, we'd like to have a notion of (commutative) $R$-algebra spectrum. In order to make this notion precise, we need a (symmetric) monoidal structure on the $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$ of left $R$-modules.

Remark 13.4.10. Using the language of $\infty$-operads, these results can be refined to produce $\mathbf{E}_{n}$-monoidal $\infty$-categories of left $R$-modules when $R$ is only an $\mathbf{E}_{n+1}$-algebra spectrum. See [25] for the details of this approach.

As in ordinary algebra, the $\infty$-category of (either left or right) modules for an associative ring spectrum $A$ will not carry a symmetric monoidal structure, which has $A$ as the unit and commutes with colimits in each variable, unless the algebra structure on $A$ extends to commutative algebra structure. Nevertheless, given a left $A$-module $M$ and a right $A$-module $N$, we may form the iterated tensor products

$$
N \otimes A \otimes \cdots \otimes A \otimes M
$$

The algebra structure on $A$ and the left and right module structures on $M$ and $N$ organize these into a simplicial spectrum $\operatorname{Bar}_{A}(M, N)$ with

$$
\operatorname{Bar}_{A}(M, N)_{n} \simeq N \otimes A^{\otimes n} \otimes M
$$

Definition 13.4.11. The relative tensor product $N \otimes_{A} M$ is a spectrum equivalent to the geometric realization of the simplicial spectrum $\operatorname{Bar}_{A}(M, N)$ :

$$
N \otimes_{A} M \simeq\left|\operatorname{Bar}_{A}(M, N)\right|
$$

Remark 13.4.12. No noncanonical choices were involved in this construction, and indeed the relative tensor product can be shown to extend to a functor

$$
-\otimes_{A}-: \mathrm{RMod}_{A} \times \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \longrightarrow \mathrm{Sp}
$$

that preserves colimits separately in each variable. We therefore obtain a morphism $\operatorname{LMod}_{A^{\mathrm{op}} \otimes A} \simeq \mathrm{RMod}_{A} \otimes \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ in LPr. By Morita theory, such a map is determined by a left $A \otimes A^{\text {op }}$-module, which in this case is $A$ itself.

Left adjoint functors between $\infty$-categories of modules determine, and are determined by, bimodules. More precisely, if $A$ and $B$ are associative ring spectra, an $(A, B)$-bimodule $M$ determines a functor $\mathrm{LMod}_{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{B}$ via the relative tensor product, and conversely. We will avoid the theory of $(A, B)$-bimodules by simply using the equivalent $\infty$-category $\operatorname{LMod}_{A^{\mathrm{op}} \otimes B}$.

Theorem 13.4.13. [25, Theorem 7.1.2.4] Let $A, B$ be associative algebra spectra. The relative tensor product induces an equivalence of $\infty$-categories

$$
\mathrm{LMod}_{A^{\mathrm{op}} \otimes B} \simeq \operatorname{LFun}\left(\mathrm{LMod}_{A}, \mathrm{LMod}_{B}\right)
$$

Remark 13.4.14. The above equivalence sends the left $A^{\mathrm{op}} \otimes B$-module $N$ to the functor $M \mapsto N \otimes_{A} M$ and a left adjoint functor $f: \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{B}$ to $f(A)$, viewed as a left $A^{\text {op }} \otimes B$-module via its right $A$-action.

Remark 13.4.15. The right adjoint of the left adjoint functor $N \otimes_{A}-: \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{B}$ is $\operatorname{Map}_{B}(N,-): \mathrm{LMod}_{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$.

The following version of Morita theory, originally due to Schwede-Shipley [35], is a convenient recognition principle for $\infty$-categories of modules.

Theorem 13.4.16. [25, Theorem 7.1.2.1] Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a stable presentable $\infty$-category and let $P$ be an object of $\mathcal{C}$. Then $\mathcal{C}$ is compactly generated by $P$ if and only if the functor $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{C}}(P,-): \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{RMod}_{\operatorname{End}_{\mathcal{C}}(P)}$ is an equivalence.
Remark 13.4.17. If $f: A \rightarrow B$ is a map of associative ring spectra, then we may view $B$ as a left $A^{\text {op }} \otimes B$-module, in which case the resulting left adjoint functor $B \otimes_{A}-: \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \rightarrow$ $\mathrm{LMod}_{B}$ is the basechange functor, with right adjoint $\operatorname{Map}_{B}(B,-): \mathrm{LMod}_{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ the forgetful functor. Note that the forgetful functor preserves colimits, as they are detected on underlying spectra, so that this is the same as tensoring with the left $B^{\text {op }} \otimes A$-module $B$, i.e. $\operatorname{Map}_{B}(B,-) \simeq B \otimes_{B}-$. In particular, there is a further right adjoint $\operatorname{Map}_{A}(B,-)$ : $\operatorname{Mod}_{A} \rightarrow \operatorname{Mod}_{B}$.
Example 13.4.18. Suppose that $B \simeq A\left[S^{-1}\right]$ is a localization of $A$. Then the forgetful functor $\mathrm{LMod}_{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is fully faithful with essential image the $S$-local left $A$-module spectra, namely those $M$ such that $M \simeq S^{-1} M$.

# 13.4.3 Projective, perfect and flat modules 

We now study the $\infty$-categories $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ for $A$ an associative ring spectrum.
Remark 13.4.19. The Morita theory of the previous section can be used to identify stable $\infty$-categories $\mathcal{C}$ of the form $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ for an associative algebra spectrum $A$, where now $A \simeq \operatorname{End}_{\mathcal{C}}(P)^{\text {op }}$ for some compact generator $P$ of $\mathcal{C}$. It follows that $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is compactly generated. Moreover, a stable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is of the form $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ if and only if $\mathcal{C}$ admits a compact generator, and $\mathrm{LMod}_{A} \simeq \operatorname{Ind}\left(\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{\omega}\right)$ is the Ind-completion of its full subcategory $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{\omega}$ of compact objects.
Definition 13.4.20. Let $A$ be an associative ring spectrum. A left $A$-module $M$ is perfect if $M$ is a compact object of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$.
Definition 13.4.21. Let $A$ be an associative ring spectrum. A left $A$-module $M$ is free if $M$ is a (possibly infinite) coproduct of (unshifted) copies of $A$, viewed as a left module over itself.

Definition 13.4.22. A free left $A$-module $M$ is finitely generated if it is equivalent to a finite coproduct of copies of $A$.

Just as in ordinary algebra, there are other notions of "freeness" corresponding to various forgetful-free adjunctions. For instance, if $M$ is a left $A$-module and $f: A \rightarrow B$ to a ring map, then $B \otimes_{A} M$ is often referred to as the "free" left $B$-module associated to the left $A$-module $M$, even though $B \otimes_{A} M$ is rarely a free $B$-module (although it will be of course if $M$ was actually a free left $A$-module).

Using the long exact sequence on homotopy groups, it is straightforward to check that a map $f: M \rightarrow N$ of connective left $A$-modules (over a connective associative ring $A$ ) is surjective if and only if $\operatorname{fib}(f)$ is connective.
Definition 13.4.23. Let $A$ be a connective associative ring spectrum. A left $A$-module $P$ is projective if it is connective and projective as object of the $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{\mathrm{cn}}$ of connective left $A$-modules, in the sense that the corepresented functor $\operatorname{Map}(P,-) \mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{\mathrm{cn}} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}$ preserves geometric realizations (that is, colimits of simplicial diagrams). See [26, Definition 5.5.8.18] for details.

Remark 13.4.24. It is unreasonable to ask for a left $A$-module to be projective as an object of the $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ itself, as the only projective objects of this $\infty$-category are the zero objects. Indeed, suppose that $M$ is a projective object of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$. For any $A$-module N , we can write the suspension of $N$ as the geometric realization of the simplicial $A$-module

$$
\Sigma N \simeq|0 \leftarrow N \leftarrow N \oplus N \stackrel{\llbracket \rightarrow}{=} \cdots| .
$$

But

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{A}}\left(\Sigma^{-1} M, N\right) \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{A}}(M, \Sigma N) \simeq B \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{A}}(M, N)
$$

so $\pi_{0} \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{A}}\left(\Sigma^{-1} M, N\right) \simeq 0$ for all left $A$-modules $N$ and therefore $M \simeq 0$.
Proposition 13.4.25. [25, Proposition 7.2.2.6] Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a stable $\infty$-category with a left complete t-structure $\left(\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}, \mathcal{C}_{\leq 0}\right)$ and let $P \in \mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ be an object. The following conditions are equivalent:
(1) $P$ is projective (as an object of $\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ ).
(2) For every $M \in \mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}, \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{C}}^{1}(P, M) \cong 0$.
(3) For every $M \in \mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$ and every integer $n>0, \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{C}}^{n}(P, M) \cong 0$.
(4) For every $M \in \mathcal{C}^{\ominus}$ and every integer $n>0, \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{C}}^{n}(P, M) \cong 0$.
(5) For every exact triangle $L \rightarrow M \rightarrow N$ in $\mathcal{C}_{\geq 0}$, the map $\operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{C}}^{0}(P, M) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ext}_{\mathcal{C}}^{0}(P, N)$ is surjective.

Proposition 13.4.26. [25, Corollary 7.2.2.19] Let $f: A \rightarrow B$ be a map of connective associative algebra spectra such that $\pi_{0} f: \pi_{0} A \rightarrow \pi_{0} B$ is an isomorphism. The basechange functor $f^{*}=(-) \otimes_{A} B: \operatorname{Mod}_{A} \rightarrow \operatorname{Mod}_{B}$ restricts to an equivalence

$$
f^{*}: \operatorname{Ho}\left(\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{\mathrm{proj}}\right) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Ho}\left(\mathrm{LMod}_{B}^{\mathrm{proj}}\right)
$$

on homotopy categories of projective objects. In particular, the 0-truncation map $f: A \rightarrow$ $\pi_{0} A$ induces an equivalence $\operatorname{Ho}\left(\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{\mathrm{proj}}\right) \simeq \mathrm{LMod}_{\pi_{0} A}^{\oplus \mathrm{proj}}$.

Proposition 13.4.27. [25, Proposition 7.2.2.7] Let $A$ be a connective associative algebra spectrum and $P$ a projective left $A$-module. Then there exists a free left $A$-module $M$ such that $P$ is a retract of $M$. If additionally $P$ is finitely generated, we may take $M$ to be finitely generated as well.

While the notion of projectivity really only makes sense over connective ring spectra, the notion of flatness makes sense over arbitrary ring spectra.

Definition 13.4.28. Let $A$ be an associative ring spectrum. A left $A$-module spectrum $M$ is said to be flat over $A$ if $\pi_{0} M$ is a flat left $\pi_{0} A$-module, in the sense of ordinary algebra, and for each integer $n$, the canonical map

$$
\pi_{n} A \otimes_{\pi_{0} A} \pi_{0} M \longrightarrow \pi_{n} M
$$

is an isomorphism.

Nevertheless, over a connective associative ring spectrum $A$, the notion of flatness behaves in a manner more similar to that of ordinary algebra. For example we have the following important generalization of Lazard's theorem.

Theorem 13.4.29. [25, Theorem 7.2.2.15] Let $A$ be a connective associative algebra spectrum and $M$ a connective left $A$-module. The following conditions are equivalent:
(1) $M$ is flat.
(2) $M$ is a filtered colimit of finitely generated free left $A$-modules.
(3) $M$ is a filtered colimit of finitely generated projective left $A$-modules.
(4) The functor $\mathrm{RMod}_{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ given by $N \mapsto N \otimes_{A} M$ is left t-exact.
(5) If $N$ is a discrete right $A$-module then $N \otimes_{A} M$ is discrete.

Remark 13.4.30. A free (respectively, projective) left $A$-module $M$ is a filtered colimit of finitely generated free (respectively, projective) left $A$-modules. Thus the statement of Lazard's theorem remains true (albeit less precise) if we disregard finite generation.

Remark 13.4.31. The Tor spectral sequence has $E_{2}$-page

$$
E_{2}^{p, q}=\operatorname{Tor}_{p}^{\pi_{*} A}\left(\pi_{*} M, \pi_{*} N\right)_{q}
$$

and converges to the homotopy groups $\pi_{p+q}\left(M \otimes_{A} N\right)$ of the relative tensor product. If $M$ or $N$ is flat over $A, E_{2}^{p, q}$ vanishes for $p>0$, the spectral sequence degenerates at the $E_{2}$-page, and $\pi_{*}\left(M \otimes_{A} N\right) \cong \pi_{*} M \otimes_{\pi_{*} A} \pi_{*} N$ is calculated as graded tensor product of $\pi_{*} M$ and $\pi_{*} N$ over $\pi_{*} A$.

Remark 13.4.32. As a consequence we observe that if $M$ and $N$ are both flat over $A$, then their tensor product $M \otimes_{A} N$ is again flat over $A$. Since the unit object $A$ of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is flat, we see that the full subcategory $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{9} \subset \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ inherits the structure of a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category.

In order to calculate in the $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ of left $A$-modules, it is useful to have something analogous to a projective resolution. If $A$ is connective, the theory of toramplitude plays this role, giving a means of construct any perfect $A$-module inductively, in a finite number of steps, as an iterated cofiber of maps from shifted finitely projective left $A$-modules.

Definition 13.4.33. Let $R$ be a connective commutative ring spectrum. A left $R$-module $P$ has tor-amplitude contained in the interval $[a, b]$ if for any discrete left $\pi_{0} R$-module $M$, $\pi_{i}\left(P \otimes_{R} M\right)=0$ for $i \notin[a, b]$. If such integers $a$ and $b$ exist, $P$ is said to have finite tor-amplitude.

If $P$ is an $R$-module, then $P$ has tor-amplitude contained in $[a, b]$ if and only if $P \otimes_{R} \pi_{0} R$ is a complex of left $\pi_{0} R$-modules with tor-amplitude contained in $[a, b]$ in the ordinary sense. Note, however, that this definition differs from that in [10, I 5.2] as we work homologically as opposed to cohomologically.

Proposition 13.4.34. [5, Proposition 2.13] Let $A$ be a connective associative algebra spectrum and let $M$ and $N$ be left $A$-module spectra.
(1) If $M$ is perfect then $M$ has finite tor-amplitude.
(2) If $B \in \operatorname{CAlg}_{A}^{\mathrm{cn}}$ and $M$ has tor-amplitude contained in $[a, b]$ then the left $B$-module $B \otimes_{A} M$ has tor-amplitude contained in $[a, b]$.
(3) If $M$ and $N$ have tor-amplitude contained in $[a, b]$ then the fiber and cofiber of a map $M \rightarrow N$ have tor-amplitude contained in $[a-1, b]$ and $[a, b+1]$.
(4) If $M$ is perfect with tor-amplitude contained in $[0, b]$ then $M$ is connective and $\pi_{0} M \cong$ $\pi_{0}\left(\pi_{0} A \otimes_{A} M\right)$.
(5) If $M$ is perfect with tor-amplitude contained in $[a, a]$ then $M$ is equivalent to $\Sigma^{a} P$ for a finitely generated projective left $A$-module $P$.
(6) If $M$ is perfect with tor-amplitude contained in $[a, b]$ then there exists an exact triangle $\Sigma^{a} P \rightarrow M \rightarrow Q$ with $P$ finitely generated projective and $Q$ perfect with tor-amplitude contained in $[a+1, b]$.

Remark 13.4.35. If additionally $A$ is a connective commutative algebra spectrum and $M$ and $N$ are left $A$-modules such that $M$ has tor-amplitude contained in $[a, b]$ and $N$ has tor-amplitude contained in $[c, d]$, then $M \otimes_{A} N$ has tor-amplitude contained in $[a+c, b+d]$.

# 13.4.4 Tensor powers, symmetric powers, and free objects 

Given a map of associative algebra spectra $f: A \rightarrow B$, the basechange functor $f^{*}$ : $\mathrm{LMod}_{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{B}$ (corresponding to the left $A^{\text {op }} \otimes B$-module $B$ ) is left adjoint to the forgetful functor $f_{*}: \mathrm{LMod}_{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ (corresponding to the left $B^{\text {op }} \otimes A$-module $B$ ). Indeed, the counit of the adjunction $f^{*} f_{*} \rightarrow \operatorname{id}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{B}}$ is induced from the left $B$-module action map $B \otimes_{A} N \rightarrow N$, and the unit of the adjunction $\operatorname{id}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{A}} \rightarrow f_{*} f^{*}$ is induced from the left $A$-module unit map $M \simeq A \otimes_{A} M \rightarrow B \otimes_{A} M$. In particular, $f^{*} M \simeq B \otimes_{A} M$ is the free left $B$-module on the left $A$-module $M$, by virtue of the equivalence

$$
\operatorname{Mod}_{B}\left(f^{*} M, N\right) \simeq \operatorname{Mod}_{A}\left(M, f_{*} N\right)
$$

Remark 13.4.36. Observe that $f^{*} M \simeq B \otimes_{A} M$ need not be free as a left $B$-module in the sense of 13.4.21 unless $M$ is free as a left $A$-module.

Remark 13.4.37. The forgetful functor $f_{*}: \mathrm{LMod}_{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is conservative and preserves all small limits and colimits. Hence it is monadic, and exhibits $\mathrm{LMod}_{B}$ as the $\infty$ category of left modules for the monad $T=f_{*} f^{*}$.

The forgetful functors $\mathrm{CAlg} \rightarrow \mathrm{Alg} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ preserve limits, so it is natural to ask whether or not they admit left adjoints. Using presentability and the adjoint functor theorem (see 13.2.39), this is the case if and only if they preserve $\kappa$-filtered colimits for some regular cardinal $\kappa$. As we might expect from algebraic kinds of categories, they preserve all filtered colimits (as well as geometric realizations), so the left adjoints exist, and are instances of free algebra functors [25]. As is ordinary algebra, it is useful to consider the relative situation, so we work over a base commutative ring spectrum $R$.

Proposition 13.4.38. [25, Corollaries 3.2.2.4 and 3.2.3.2] The forgetful functors $\mathrm{CAlg}_{R} \rightarrow$ $\mathrm{Alg}_{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ preserve small limits and sifted colimits.

Basically by construction, these forgetful functors are also conservative, hence monadic by the Barr-Beck-Lurie 13.4.9. This means that the free-forgetful adjunctions exhibit Alg and CAlg as $\infty$-categories of left modules for their respective monads. The underlying endofunctors of these monads are just in ordinary algebra, the tensor and symmetric algebra constructions.

Remark 13.4.39. Straightening the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}^{\otimes}$ to a functor $\mathrm{Fin}_{*} \rightarrow \mathrm{CAT}_{\infty}$ and restricting to the active maps $\langle n\rangle \rightarrow\langle 1\rangle$ for each $n \in \mathbf{N}$, we obtain $n$-fold tensor power functors $\operatorname{Ten}_{R}^{n}: \mathrm{LMod}_{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{R}$. That is, $\operatorname{Ten}_{R}^{n}(M) \simeq M^{\otimes n}$, where the tensor product is taken over $R$.

Proposition 13.4.40. [25, Proposition 4.1.1.18] Let $M$ be a left $R$-module. The free associative $R$-algebra on $M$ is the tensor algebra

$$
\operatorname{Ten}_{R}(M) \simeq \bigoplus_{k \in \mathbf{N}} \operatorname{Ten}_{R}^{k}(M) \simeq \bigoplus_{k \in \mathbf{N}} M^{\otimes k}
$$

Remark 13.4.41. This only describes the underlying left $R$-module of the free associative $R$-algebra on $M$. The multiplication

$$
\bigoplus_{i \in \mathbf{N}} M^{\otimes i} \otimes_{R} \bigoplus_{j \in \mathbf{N}} M^{\otimes j} \simeq \bigoplus_{i, j \in \mathbf{N}} M^{\otimes i+j} \longrightarrow \bigoplus_{k \in \mathbf{N}} M^{\otimes k}
$$

is given by concatenation of tensor powers. This is still only a small, but important, piece of the homotopy coherently associative algebra structure.

The free commutative algebra functor, also known as the symmetric algebra, uses the symmetric power functors $\operatorname{Sym}_{R}^{n}: \mathrm{LMod}_{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{R}$, given by the formula

$$
\operatorname{Sym}_{R}^{n}(M) \simeq \operatorname{Ten}_{R}^{n}(M)_{h \Sigma_{n}} \simeq M_{h \Sigma_{n}}^{\otimes n}
$$

where the tensor product is taken in the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}^{\otimes}$ of left $R$-module spectra. Here the subscript $h \Sigma_{n}$ refers to the homotopy quotient of $M^{\otimes n}$ by the permutation action of the symmetric group $\Sigma_{n}$, which is to say that quotient in the $\infty$ categorical sense. This is to distinguish from more strict versions of quotients by group actions that arise through either ordinary categorical models of the $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$, where it can make sense to ask for an ordinary categorical quotient, or in the context of equivariant homotopy theory, where there are several notions of fixed points.

Proposition 13.4.42. [25, Example 3.1.3.14] Let $M$ be a left $R$-module. The free commutative $R$-algebra on $M$ is the symmetric algebra

$$
\operatorname{Sym}_{R}(M) \simeq \bigoplus_{k \in \mathbf{N}} \operatorname{Sym}_{R}^{n}(M) \simeq \bigoplus_{k \in \mathbf{N}} M_{h \Sigma_{k}}^{\otimes k}
$$

Remark 13.4.43. While it isn't terribly difficult to describe the multiplication on $\operatorname{Sym}_{R}(M)$ explicitly, organizing all of the higher multiplications in a coherent manner seems difficult without abstract machinery. The theory of operadic left Kan extensions [25] is one way to make this precise.

Example 13.4.44. In the case where $M=R$, we have $\operatorname{Ten}_{R}(R) \simeq \bigoplus_{n \in \mathbf{N}} R$. This is often denoted $R[t]$, as we have that $\pi_{*}(R[t]) \cong\left(\pi_{*} R\right)[t]$ on homotopy groups. As the notation suggests, the free tensor algebra on one generator in degree zero, $R[t]$, happens to be a commutative $R$-algebra spectrum, though it is not the free commutative $R$-algebra on one generator in degree zero. Instead we have that $\operatorname{Sym}_{R}(R) \simeq \bigoplus_{n \in \mathbf{N}} \operatorname{Sym}_{R}^{n}(R) \simeq \bigoplus_{n \in \mathbf{N}} R_{h \Sigma_{n}}^{\oplus n}$, which is sometimes denoted $R\{t\}$ in order to distinguish it from $R[t]$. In this case, $\pi_{*}\left(\operatorname{Sym}_{R}(R)\right) \cong \bigoplus_{k \in \mathbf{N}} R_{*}\left(B \Sigma_{n}\right)$ is the coproduct of the $R$-homologies of the symmetric groups $\Sigma_{n}$.
Remark 13.4.45. If $R$ is a $\mathbf{Q}$-algebra then, for all $n \in \mathbf{N}$, the map $R_{*}(\mathrm{pt}) \rightarrow R_{*}\left(B \Sigma_{n}\right)$ is an isomorphism. This follows from the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence $E_{p, q}^{2} \cong$ $H_{p}\left(B \Sigma_{n}, \pi_{q} R\right) \Rightarrow R_{p+q}\left(B \Sigma_{n}\right)$ and the vanishing of group cohomology in characteristic zero by Maschke's theorem. Hence the map

$$
R[t] \simeq \operatorname{Ten}_{R}(R) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Sym}_{R}(R) \simeq R\{t\}
$$

obtained by taking the homotopy quotient is an equivalence.
Remark 13.4.46. Away from characteristic zero the map $R_{*}(\mathrm{pt}) \rightarrow R_{*}\left(B \Sigma_{n}\right)$ is typically not an isomorphism. In particular, the map $\operatorname{Ten}_{R}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Sym}_{R}(R)$ is rarely an equivalence. Nevertheless, the fact that $\operatorname{Ten}_{\mathbf{S}}(\mathbf{S}) \simeq \mathbf{S}[t]$ admits a commutative algebra structure (although it is not free as a commutative algebra) implies, by basechange along the commutative algebra map $\mathbf{S} \rightarrow R$, that there is always a commutative $R$-algebra map $R\{t\} \rightarrow R[t]$, which is an equivalence when $R$ is a $\mathbf{Q}$-algebra and not typically otherwise.

There are other sorts of free algebra functors as well. The forgetful functor $\mathrm{Sp} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}$ fails to be monadic because it isn't conservative; it is, however, monadic on the full subcategory $\mathrm{Sp}^{\mathrm{cn}} \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ of connective spectra, the obvious subcategory on which it is conservative. The resulting monad $Q \simeq \Omega^{\infty} \Sigma_{+}^{\infty}$ is a higher categorical analogue of the free abelian group monad.

Definition 13.4.47. Let $G$ be an $\infty$-group (respectively, $\infty$-monoid). The group ring (respectively, monoid ring) $R[G]$ is the associative ring spectrum $R[G] \simeq R \otimes \Sigma_{+}^{\infty} G$, with $R$ algebra structure induced from that of $G$ via the symmetric monoidal functor $\Sigma_{+}^{\infty}: \mathcal{S} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$.

Remark 13.4.48. Group and monoid rings are a rich source of examples of ring spectra. For instance, toric varieties, which are locally modeled on the group and monoid rings like $R\left[\mathbf{Z}^{\times k}\right]$ and $R\left[\mathbf{N}^{\times k}\right]$, are combinatorial enough that they descend from the integers to the sphere, giving basic examples of spectral schemes such as the projective space $\mathbf{P}_{R}^{n}$ [27, Construction 5.4.1.3].

Definition 13.4.49. The general linear group $\mathrm{GL}_{n}(R)$ of a ring spectrum $R$ is the $\infty$-group $\operatorname{Aut}_{R}\left(R^{\oplus n}\right)$ of left $R$-module automorphisms of $R^{\oplus n}$.

Example 13.4.50. Let $M=\coprod_{n \in \mathbf{N}} B \Sigma_{n}$, the free abelian $\infty$-monoid on one generator. Then $\mathbf{S}[M] \simeq \bigoplus \Sigma_{+}^{\infty} B \Sigma_{n}$ is the free commutative algebra spectrum on one generator in the sense that, via the equivalences

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}(\mathbf{S}[M], A) \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{AbMon}_{\infty}}\left(M, \Omega^{\infty} A\right) \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{S}}\left(\mathrm{pt}, \Omega^{\infty} A\right) \simeq \Omega^{\infty} A
$$

specifying a commutative algebra map $\mathbf{S}[M] \rightarrow A$ is the same as specifying a point of $\Omega^{\infty} A$, the image of the generator $\mathrm{pt} \simeq B \Sigma_{1} \rightarrow M$ of $M$.
Example 13.4.51. Let $G \simeq \Omega^{\infty} \mathbf{S}$ be the abelian $\infty$-group given by the infinite loop space of the sphere $\mathbf{S}$. Under the equivalence between the $\infty$-categories of connective spectra and abelian $\infty$-groups, it follows that $G$ is the free abelian $\infty$-group on one generator, or equivalently the group completion of the free abelian $\infty$-monoid $M \simeq \coprod_{n \in \mathbf{N}} B \Sigma_{n}$ on one generator of the previous example.

By adjunction, for any commutative algebra spectrum $A$, we have equivalences

$$
\operatorname{Map}(\mathbf{S}[G], A) \simeq \operatorname{Map}\left(G, \Omega^{\infty} A\right) \simeq \mathrm{GL}_{1}(A) \subset \Omega^{\infty} A
$$

where the $\infty$-group $\mathrm{GL}_{1}(A) \simeq \operatorname{Aut}_{\mathrm{Mod}_{A}}(A)$ is equivalently the subspace of the $\infty$-monoid $\Omega^{\infty} A \simeq \operatorname{End}_{\operatorname{Mod}_{A}}(A)$ consisting of the invertible components; that is, it fits into the pullback square
![img-155.jpeg](img-155.jpeg)

Since $\mathbf{S}[G]$ corepresents the functor that sends the commutative algebra $A$ to its space of units, the "derived scheme" $\operatorname{Spec} \mathbf{S}[G]$ can be regarded as derived version of the multiplicative group scheme.
Example 13.4.52. Any abelian $\infty$-group $G$ with $\pi_{0} G \cong \mathbf{Z}$ determines a "connective spectral abelian group scheme" with underlying ordinary scheme $\mathbf{G}_{m}$, the multiplicative group. While the previous example represents the functor of units, it is sometimes necessary to consider more "strictly commutative" derived analogues of $\mathbf{G}_{m}$. At the other extreme, one can consider $\mathbf{Z}$ as an $\infty$-group, in which case the spherical group ring $\mathbf{S}[\mathbf{Z}]$ is a flat commutative $\mathbf{S}$-algebra such that, for any commutative ring spectrum $A$,

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}(\mathbf{S}[\mathbf{Z}], A) \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{AbMon}_{\infty}}\left(\mathbf{Z}, \Omega^{\infty} A\right) \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{AbGp}_{\infty}}\left(\mathbf{Z}, \mathrm{GL}_{1}(A)\right)
$$

This space of "strict units" of $A$ plays a central role in elliptic cohomology [24].
Thom spectra $[38,29,2]$ are spectra that occur as quotients of the sphere by the action of a group. Again, it is somewhat more useful to have the version relative to a fixed commutative ring spectrum $R$. By construction the $\infty$-group $\mathrm{GL}_{1}(R)$ is the universal group that acts on $R$ by $R$-linear maps, so any $\infty$-group $G$ over $G L_{1}(R)$ acts as well. The group homomorphism $f: G \rightarrow \mathrm{GL}_{1}(R)$ deloops to a map of pointed spaces $f: \mathrm{B} G \rightarrow \mathrm{BGL}_{1}(R)$.
Example 13.4.53. The equivalence $\mathrm{GL}_{1}(\mathbf{S}) \simeq \operatorname{colim}_{n \rightarrow \infty} \operatorname{Aut}_{*}\left(S^{n}\right)$ and compatible families of $\infty$-group maps $O(n) \rightarrow \operatorname{Aut}_{*}\left(S^{n}\right)$ and $U(n) \rightarrow \operatorname{Aut}_{*}\left(S^{2 n}\right)$ give $\infty$-group maps

$O \rightarrow \mathrm{GL}_{1}(\mathbf{S})$ and $U \rightarrow \mathrm{GL}_{1}(\mathbf{S})$. The Thom spectra $M O$ and $M U$ are the homotopy quotients $M O=\mathbf{S}_{h O}$ and $M U=\mathbf{S}_{h U}$. While defined in an apparently abstract and formal way, there's a surprising connection to geometry: $\pi_{*} M O$ is the bordism ring of unoriented manifolds, $\pi_{*} M U$ is the bordism ring of stably almost complex manifolds. The analogues for other tangential structures hold; for instance, $\pi_{*} \mathbf{S}$ is the stably framed bordism ring.

# 13.4.5 Smooth, proper and dualizable objects 

Definition 13.4.54. A symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $p: \mathcal{C}^{\otimes} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fin}_{*}$ is closed if, for any object $A$ of $\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{C}_{(1)}^{\otimes}$, the right multiplication by $A$ functor $(-) \otimes A: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ admits a right adjoint $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,-): \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.

Remark 13.4.55. This allows for the construction of function objects $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(B, C)$ of $\mathcal{C}$, naturally as a functor $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}: \mathcal{C}^{\mathrm{op}} \times \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$. In particular, there are natural equivalences $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{C}}(A \otimes B, C) \simeq \operatorname{Map}_{\mathcal{C}}\left(A, \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(B, C)\right)$.

Definition 13.4.56. Let $\mathcal{C}^{\otimes}$ be a closed symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category. A dual of an $A$ is an object of the form $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, \mathbf{1})$, where $\mathbf{1}$ denotes a unit object.

As duals are uniquely determined, we will write $\mathrm{D}_{\mathcal{C}} A$, or $\mathrm{D} A$, for a dual of $A$.
Remark 13.4.57. There is a canonical evaluation map

$$
\varepsilon: A \otimes \mathrm{D}_{\mathcal{C}} A \simeq A \otimes \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, \mathbf{1}) \longrightarrow \mathbf{1}
$$

any map corresponding to the identity of $\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, \mathbf{1})$ under the equivalence $\operatorname{Map}(A \otimes$ $\left.\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, \mathbf{1}), \mathbf{1}\right) \simeq \operatorname{Map}\left(\mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, \mathbf{1}), \mathcal{F}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, \mathbf{1})\right)$.

Definition 13.4.58. An object $A$ of a closed symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}^{\otimes}$ is dualizable if there exists a coevaluation map $\eta: \mathbf{1} \longrightarrow \mathrm{D} A \otimes A$ such that the compositions

$$
\begin{gathered}
A \xrightarrow{A \otimes \eta} A \otimes \mathrm{D} A \otimes A \xrightarrow{\varepsilon \otimes A} A \\
\mathrm{D} A \xrightarrow{\eta \otimes \mathrm{D} A} \mathrm{D} A \otimes A \otimes \mathrm{D} A \xrightarrow{\mathrm{D} A \otimes \varepsilon} \mathrm{D} A
\end{gathered}
$$

are equivalent to the identity.
We write $\mathcal{C}^{\text {dual }} \subset \mathcal{C}$ for the full subcategory consisting of the dualizable objects of $\mathcal{C}^{\otimes}$. It always contains at least one object, any unit object 1.

Example 13.4.59. Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum and consider the closed symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}^{\otimes}$ of left $R$-module spectra. Stability forces the full subcategory $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}^{\text {dual }}$ of dualizable objects to be closed under finite limits, colimits, and retracts [19, Theorem 2.1.3]. Since $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$ is compactly generated, it follows that the full subcategories of compact and dualizable objects coincide.

Given a commutative algebra object $\mathcal{T}$ of LPr , we may form the $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{\mathcal{T}}(\mathrm{LPr})$ of left $\mathcal{T}$-module objects of LPr. For instance, $\mathrm{LPr}_{\text {st }} \simeq \mathrm{LMod}_{\text {Sp }}(\mathrm{LPr})$. Of course, $\mathrm{Sp} \simeq$ $\mathrm{LMod}_{\mathbf{S}}$, so $\mathrm{LPr}_{\text {st }} \simeq \mathrm{LMod}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{\mathbf{S}}}(\mathrm{LPr})$. It is useful to consider the relative version of this: given a commutative ring spectrum $R$, the relative tensor product equips the presentable $\infty$-category $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$ with the structure of a commutative algebra object.

Definition 13.4.60. Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum. An $R$-linear $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is a left $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$-module in $\mathrm{LPr}^{\otimes}$.

We write $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}=\mathrm{LMod}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{R}}(\mathrm{LPr})$ for the $\infty$-category of $R$-linear categories and $R$ linear functors (left $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$-module maps).

Remark 13.4.61. Since $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$ is stable, we have $\mathrm{Cat}_{R} \simeq \mathrm{LMod}_{\mathrm{LMod}_{R}}\left(\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}\right)$.
Remark 13.4.62. $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}$ is in fact closed symmetric monoidal: if $\mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{D}$ are $R$-linear $\infty$ categories, the $\infty$-category of $R$-linear functors (that is, $\operatorname{Mod}_{R}$-module morphisms in LPr ) $\operatorname{LFun}_{R}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D})$ from $\mathcal{C}$ to $\mathcal{D}$ is again an $R$-linear $\infty$-category (a $\operatorname{Mod}_{R}$-module in LPr). The dual

$$
\mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C}=\operatorname{LFun}_{R}\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathrm{LMod}_{R}\right)
$$

of $\mathcal{C}$ is the $\infty$-category of $R$-linear functors from $\mathcal{C}$ to $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$. Hence an $R$-linear $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is dualizable if there exists a coevaluation map $\eta: \mathrm{LMod}_{R} \xrightarrow{\eta} \mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C} \otimes_{R} \mathcal{C}$ such that the compositions

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathcal{C} \xrightarrow{\mathcal{C} \otimes_{R} \eta} \mathcal{C} \otimes_{R} \mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C} \otimes_{R} \mathcal{C} \xrightarrow{\varepsilon \otimes_{R} \mathcal{C}} \mathcal{C} \\
\mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C} \xrightarrow{\eta \otimes \mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C}} \mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C} \otimes_{R} \mathcal{C} \otimes_{R} \mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C} \xrightarrow{\mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C} \otimes \varepsilon} \mathrm{D}_{R} \mathcal{C}
\end{gathered}
$$

are equivalent to the identity.
Proposition 13.4.63. Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum. Then $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\otimes}$ is a rigid symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category; that is, all objects are dualizable.

Remark 13.4.64. Consider the subcategory $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\mathrm{eg}} \subset \mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}$ of compactly generated stable presentable $\infty$-category and left adjoint functors that preserve compact objects. Then $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\mathrm{eg}}$ is equivalent, via the functor that restricts to the full subcategories of compact objects, to the $\infty$-category of idempotent complete (that is, all idempotents split) small stable $\infty$ categories and exact functors. The inverse equivalence is given by Ind : Cat $_{\infty} \rightarrow \mathrm{LPr}$, which when restricted to $\mathrm{Cat}_{\infty}^{\mathrm{st}} \subset \mathrm{Cat}_{\infty}$, factors through the subcategory $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\mathrm{eg}} \subset \mathrm{LPr}$. Since stability and idempotent completeness are properties of small $\infty$-categories, and a functor of small stable $\infty$-categories is exact if and only if it is right exact, we deduce that $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\mathrm{eg}}$ is equivalent to a full subcategory of $\mathrm{Cat}_{\infty}^{\mathrm{res}}$ (see [26, Proposition 5.5.7.8] for details). It follows from [25, Proposition 4.8.1.4], using [25, Remark 2.2.1.2], that $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\mathrm{eg}}$ inherits a symmetric monoidal structure that is compatible with the symmetric monoidal structure on $\mathrm{LPr}_{\text {st }}$ or LPr. The $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Mod}_{R}^{\otimes}$ is a commutative algebra object in $\mathrm{LPr}_{\mathrm{st}}^{\mathrm{eg}}$, so we have a subcategory $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\mathrm{eg}} \subset \mathrm{Cat}_{R}$ of compactly generated $R$-linear categories and colimit and compact object preserving functors. Similar arguments show that $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\mathrm{eg}}$ inherits the structure of a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category from $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\otimes}$.

Proposition 13.4.65. [5, Proposition 3.5] An $R$-algebra $A$ is compact in $\mathrm{Alg}_{R}$ if and only if $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is compact in $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\mathrm{eg}}$.

Remark 13.4.66. An object $\mathcal{C}$ is dualizable in $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\mathrm{eg}}$ if and only if it is dualizable in $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}$ and the evaluation and coevaluation morphisms lie in the (not full) subcategory $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\mathrm{eg}} \subset$ $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}$.

Definition 13.4.67. A compactly generated $R$-linear category $\mathcal{C}$ is proper if its evaluation map is in $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\mathrm{cz}}$; it is smooth if it is dualizable in $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}$ and its coevaluation map is in $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\mathrm{cz}}$. An $R$-algebra $A$ is proper if $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is proper; it is smooth if $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is smooth.

Remark 13.4.68. The property of being compact, smooth or proper in $\mathrm{Alg}_{R}$ is invariant under Morita equivalence.

Remark 13.4.69. If $A$ is an $R$-algebra, then $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is proper if and only if $A$ is a perfect $R$-module. Indeed, the evaluation map is the map

$$
\mathrm{LMod}_{A \otimes_{R} A^{\mathrm{op}}} \simeq \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \otimes_{R} \mathrm{LMod}_{A^{\mathrm{op}}} \longrightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{R}
$$

that sends $A \otimes_{R} A^{\text {op }}$ to $A$. Similarly, $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is smooth if and only if the coevaluation map

$$
\mathrm{LMod}_{R} \longrightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A^{\mathrm{op}} \otimes_{R} A}
$$

which sends $R$ to the $A^{\mathrm{op}} \otimes_{R} A$-module $A$, exists and is in $\mathrm{Cat}_{R}^{\mathrm{cz}}$. So we see that $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ is smooth if and only if $A$ is perfect as an $A^{\text {op }} \otimes_{R} A$-module.

Proposition 13.4.70. [5, Lemma 3.9] If $\mathcal{C}$ is a smooth $R$-linear category then $\mathcal{C} \simeq \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ for some $R$-algebra spectrum $A$.

Proposition 13.4.71. [25, Proposition 7.3.5.8] Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum and $A$ an associative $R$-algebra. If $A$ is compact in $\mathrm{Alg}_{R}$ then $A$ is smooth. If $A$ is a smooth and proper then $A$ is compact in $\mathrm{Alg}_{R}$.

Corollary 13.4.72. [25, Corollary 7.3.5.9] Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum and let $A$ be an associative $R$-algebra. Then $A$ is smooth and proper if and only if it is compact as an object of $\mathrm{Alg}_{R}$ and $\mathrm{LMod}_{R}$.

Remark 13.4.73. The noncommutative cotangent complex is the fiber

$$
\Omega_{A / R} \longrightarrow A \otimes_{R} A^{\mathrm{op}} \longrightarrow A
$$

of the multiplication map. Thus, in the noncommutative setting, $A$ is a smooth $R$-algebra if and only if $\Omega_{A / R}$ is a perfect left $A \otimes_{R} A^{\text {op }}$-module.

# 13.4.6 Nilpotent, local and complete objects 

In this section we fix a commutative ring spectrum $R$ and a finitely generated ideal $I=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{n}\right) \subset \pi_{0} R$. We write $R\left[I^{-1}\right] \simeq \bigotimes_{i=1}^{n} R\left[f_{i}^{-1}\right]$ and, for any left $R$-module $M$, $M\left[I^{-1}\right] \simeq R\left[I^{-1}\right] \otimes_{R} M$, regarded as a left $R$-module via the commutative algebra map $R \rightarrow R\left[I^{-1}\right]$.

Remark 13.4.74. There does not seem to be a good notion of ideal in the $\infty$-category of commutative ring spectra. Rather, it seems that for most part, which is relevant are ideals in the discrete ring $\pi_{0} R$ or graded ring $\pi_{*} R$. The problem is that the cofiber $R / f$ of an $R$-module map $f: R \rightarrow R$ need not admit a commutative multiplication, or even any multiplication at all. A good example is the Moore spectrum $\mathbf{S} / p$ for $p \in \mathbf{Z} \cong \pi_{0} \mathbf{S}$ a prime,

which does not carry an associative algebra structure; in fact, $\mathbf{S} / 2$ doesn't even support a unital binary multiplication map $\mathbf{S} / 2 \otimes \mathbf{S} / 2 \rightarrow \mathbf{S} / 2$ (see [34, Proposition 4]).

Remark 13.4.75. The nilpotence theorem of Devinatz-Hopkins-Smith [13] states that if $R$ is a homotopy associative ring spectrum, then the kernel of the map $\pi_{*}(R) \rightarrow \pi_{*}(M U \otimes R)$ consists entirely of nilpotent elements. This generalizes the Nishida nilpotence theorem [31], which states that every element of $\pi_{*} \mathbf{S}$ of positive degree is nilpotent. It is used to show that the only homotopy associative ring spectra $R$ with the property that $\pi_{*} R$ is a graded field are (extensions of) the Morava K-theory spectra $K(n)$ at the prime $p$ (suppressed from the notation) at height $n$. Here $K(0) \simeq \mathbf{Q}, \pi_{*} K(n) \cong \mathbf{F}_{p}\left[v^{ \pm}\right]$for a generator $v$ in degree $2\left(p^{n}-1\right)$, and $K(\infty) \simeq \mathbf{F}_{p}$. By [4], there is an essentially unique associative $\mathbf{S}$-algebra structure on $K(n)$, at least at odd primes.

Remark 13.4.76. Given a left S-module $E$, the Bousfield localization $L_{E} \mathrm{Sp}$ of the $\infty$ category of spectra at $E$ sits in a Verdier sequence

$$
K_{E} \mathrm{Sp} \longrightarrow \mathrm{Sp} \longrightarrow L_{E} \mathrm{Sp}
$$

where $K_{E} \mathrm{Sp} \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ denotes the full subcategory of those spectra $M$ such that $M \otimes E \simeq 0$ (the kernel of the multiplication by $E$ map $\mathrm{Sp} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ ). Since the inclusion of the full subcategory $K_{E}(\mathrm{Sp}) \subset \mathrm{Sp}$ evidently preserves colimits, it follows that this is a semi-orthogonal decomposition. It is a recollement precisely when the right adjoint inclusion $L_{E} \mathrm{Sp} \rightarrow \mathrm{Sp}$ preserves colimits, which implies that the localization is smashing: $L_{E} M \simeq M \otimes L_{E} \mathbf{S}$.

Definition 13.4.77. Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum, let $I \subset \pi_{0} R$ be a finitely generated ideal, and let $A$ be an associative $R$-algebra.
(1) A left $A$-module $M$ is $I$-nilpotent if $M\left[I^{-1}\right] \simeq 0$.
(2) A left $A$-module $M$ is $I$-local if $\operatorname{Map}(N, M) \simeq 0$ for every $I$-nilpotent $N$.
(3) A left $A$-module $M$ is $I$-complete if $\operatorname{Map}(L, M) \simeq 0$ for every $I$-local $L$.

Remark 13.4.78. Taking homotopy groups, we see that $N$ is $I$-nilpotent if each $\pi_{k} N$, $k \in \mathbf{Z}$, is an $I$-nilpotent left $\pi_{0} R$-module. Equivalently, $N$ is $I$-nilpotent if every element of each $\pi_{k} N$ is annihilated by some power of $I$.

Remark 13.4.79. It suffices to test $I$-locality only on those $I$-nilpotent objects that are also compact as left $A$-modules. This is because the fully faithful inclusion $i_{\vee}: \operatorname{LMod}_{A}^{A \text { nil }} \subset$ $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ of the $I$-nilpotent left $A$-modules is a colimit preserving functor of compactly generated stable $\infty$-categories [27, Proposition 7.1.1.12], which implies that it admits a right adjoint $i^{\vee}$. For instance, if $I=(f)$ is principle, then $A / f$ is a compact generator of $\operatorname{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { nil }} \subset \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ and $A\left[f^{-1}\right]$ is generator of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { loc }} \subset \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ which is compact as an object of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{\text {I loc }}$ but not typically as an object of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$. In particular, $\operatorname{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { loc }} \simeq \operatorname{LMod}_{A\left[I^{-1}\right]}$.

Remark 13.4.80. The fully faithful inclusion $j_{*}: \operatorname{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { loc }} \rightarrow \operatorname{LMod}_{A}$ of the $I$-local objects admits both a left adjoint $j^{*}$ and a right adjoint $j^{\times}$. The existence of the left adjoint follows from the fact that $j_{*}$ preserves limits, essentially by definition, and filtered

colimits by the previous remark. The existence of the right adjoint follows from the fact that $j_{*}$ is exact and so it also preserves finite colimits, hence all colimits. It follows that the $I$-localization functor $j^{*}: \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { loc }}$ is given by tensoring with $j^{*} A \simeq A\left[I^{-1}\right]$.

Theorem 13.4.81. [27, Theorem 7.3.4.1] A left $A$-module $M$ is $I$-complete if each homotopy group $\pi_{n} M$ is a derived I-complete left $\pi_{0} A$-module, in the sense that $\operatorname{Ext}_{\pi_{0} A}^{0}\left(\pi_{0} A\left[f^{-1}\right], M\right) \cong 0 \cong \operatorname{Ext}_{\pi_{0} A}^{1}\left(\pi_{0} A\left[f^{-1}\right], M\right)$.

Remark 13.4.82. The inclusion of the $I$-complete objects preserves limits, again by construction, and $\kappa$-filtered colimits for $\kappa \gg 0$. Indeed, this follows from the fact that we need only test completeness on a generator $A\left[I^{-1}\right]$ of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { loc }}$, and this generator is $\kappa$-compact in $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ for some $\kappa \gg 0$.

Proposition 13.4.83. [27, Proposition 7.2.4.4 and Proposition 7.3.1.4] The fully faithful inclusions $i_{\vee}: \operatorname{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { nil }} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ and $j_{*}: \operatorname{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { loc }} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ induce Verdier sequences

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { nil }} \xrightarrow{i_{\vee}} \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \xrightarrow{j^{*}} \mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { loc }} \\
& \mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{I \text { loc }} \xrightarrow{j_{*}} \mathrm{LMod}_{A} \xrightarrow{i^{\wedge}} \mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{I \mathrm{cpl}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which are semi-orthogonal decompositions of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$.
Remark 13.4.84. In the stable setting, a recollement is the data of a fully faithful inclusion of a stable subcategory that admits both a left and a right adjoint [6]. An example is the inclusion $j_{*}: \mathrm{LMod}_{A}^{\text {I loc }} \rightarrow \mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ of the $I$-local objects. The composite $i^{\wedge} i_{\vee}$ is an equivalence of categories with inverse $i^{\vee} i_{\wedge}$. A stable recollement determines a fracture square, a cartesian square
![img-156.jpeg](img-156.jpeg)
of endofunctors of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$. For $A \simeq \mathbf{S}$, the arithmetic square is the cartesian square
![img-157.jpeg](img-157.jpeg)
obtained by completing a spectrum $M$ at all primes $p$ and rationalization.
Theorem 13.4.85. [27, Proposition 7.4.1.1] Let $R$ be a commutative ring spectrum and let $I \subset \pi_{0} R$ be a finitely generated ideal. Suppose given a map of associative $R$-algebras

$f: A \rightarrow B$, and consider the commutative square
![img-158.jpeg](img-158.jpeg)
in LPr. If $f_{I}^{\wedge}: A_{I}^{\wedge} \rightarrow B_{I}^{\wedge}$ is an equivalence, this square is cartesian.

# 13.5 Deformation theory 

### 13.5.1 The tangent bundle and the cotangent complex

The cotangent complex formalism is an instance of the fiberwise stabilization of a presentable fibration. Given a pair of presentable fibrations $p: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ and $q: \mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$, we write $\operatorname{RFun}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathcal{E}, \mathcal{D}) \subset \operatorname{Fun}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathcal{E}, \mathcal{D})$ for the full subcategory of those functors $g: \mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ over $\mathcal{C}$ that admit a left adjoint $f: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{E}$ such that $p(\eta(D))$ is an equivalence in $\mathcal{C}$ for every object $D \in \mathcal{D}$, where $\eta: \operatorname{id}_{\mathcal{D}} \rightarrow g f$ denotes any choice of unit transformation exhibiting the adjunction.

Remark 13.5.1. This is the precise condition needed to ensure that $g: \mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ restricts to a right adjoint on fibers over any object of $\mathcal{C}$, or even after pullback along any morphism $\mathcal{C}^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.

Definition 13.5.2. A stable envelope of a presentable fibration $p: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is a presentable fibration $q: \mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ equipped with a morphism
![img-159.jpeg](img-159.jpeg)
of presentable fibrations over $\mathcal{C}$ that exhibits $\mathcal{E}$ as the fiberwise stabilization of $\mathcal{D}$ over $\mathcal{C}$ in the following sense: if $q^{\prime}: \mathcal{E}^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is a stable presentable fibration, the induced map $g_{*}: \operatorname{RFun}_{\mathcal{C}}\left(\mathcal{E}^{\prime}, \mathcal{E}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{RFun}_{\mathcal{C}}\left(\mathcal{E}^{\prime}, \mathcal{D}\right)$ is an equivalence.

Definition 13.5.3. A tangent bundle $q: T_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ of a presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is a stable envelope of the target fibration $p: \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}(\{1\}, \mathcal{C}) \simeq \mathcal{C}$.

Remark 13.5.4. The fiber of $q: T_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ over the object $A \in \mathcal{C}$ is the stabilization $\operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C}_{/ A}\right)$ of the fiber $\mathcal{C}_{/ A}$ of the target fibration $p: \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.

Remark 13.5.5. The tangent bundle $T_{\mathcal{C}}$ admits an explicit construction as the $\infty$-category of unreduced excisive functors

$$
\mathcal{E} \simeq \operatorname{Exc}\left(\mathcal{S}_{*}^{\mathrm{fin}}, \mathcal{C}\right)
$$

In this case, the morphism of presentable fibrations $g: \mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ over $\mathcal{C}$ is given by evaluating at the arrow $S^{0} \rightarrow \mathrm{pt}$; that is, $g(X)=\left\{X\left(S^{0}\right) \rightarrow X(\mathrm{pt})\right\}$.

Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a presentable $\infty$-category, and consider the commutative triangle
![img-160.jpeg](img-160.jpeg)
where $p$ is the target fibration. A relative version of the adjoint functor theorem implies that $f$ admits a left adjoint, allowing for the following construction.
Definition 13.5.6. The absolute cotangent complex functor $L: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow T_{\mathcal{C}}$ is the composition $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right) \rightarrow T_{\mathcal{C}}$, where the first map is the diagonal (constant) embedding and the second is left adjoint to $g: T_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right)$. We will write $L_{A}$ for the value of $L: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow T_{\mathcal{C}}$ at the object $A$ of $\mathcal{C}$, and refer to $L_{A}$ as the (absolute) cotangent complex of $A$.

Remark 13.5.7. The cotangent complex has a long history. Its first incarnation was as the sheaf of Kähler differentials, and a derived version of this was introduced by Berthelot and Illusie ([10], [21], [22]). Around the same time, Quillen ([32], [33]) and André ([3]) defined a derived version in the context of (simplicial) commutative rings, and later Basterra and Mandell ([7], [8]) developed the theory in the more general context of commutative algebra spectra, where they refer to it as topological André-Quillen homology.

Remark 13.5.8. Let $A$ be an object of $\mathcal{C}$. The identification of the fiber of the tangent bundle $T_{\mathcal{C}}$ over $A \in \mathcal{C}$ with $\operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C}_{/ A}\right)$ is such that $L_{A} \in \operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C}_{/ A}\right)$ corresponds to the image of $\operatorname{id}_{A} \in \mathcal{C}_{/ A}$ under $\Sigma_{+}^{\infty}: \mathcal{C}_{/ A} \rightarrow \operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C}_{/ A}\right)$.
Remark 13.5.9. The diagonal embedding $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right)$ is left adjoint to the evaluation $\operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}(\{0\}, \mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ at $0 \in \Delta^{1}$. Hence the cotangent complex functor $L: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow T_{\mathcal{C}}$ is left adjoint to the composite functor

$$
T_{\mathcal{C}} \longrightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Fun}(\{0\}, \mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \mathcal{C}
$$

Definition 13.5.10. The relative cofiber over $\mathcal{C}$ functor

$$
\operatorname{cof}_{\mathcal{C}}: \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, T_{\mathcal{C}}\right) \rightarrow T_{\mathcal{C}}
$$

is the functor that sends the morphism $f: X \rightarrow Y$ in $T_{\mathcal{C}}$ to the pushout
![img-161.jpeg](img-161.jpeg)
where $Z$ is any zero object of the fiber of $T_{\mathcal{C}}$ over $p(X)$.
Definition 13.5.11. The relative cotangent complex functoris the composition $\operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right) \xrightarrow{L}$ $\operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, T_{\mathcal{C}}\right) \xrightarrow{\operatorname{cof}_{\mathcal{C}}} T_{\mathcal{C}}$.

Remark 13.5.12. A zero object of a fiber of $q: T_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ need not be a zero object of $T_{\mathcal{C}}$ itself. Given a morphism $f: X \rightarrow Y$ in $T_{\mathcal{C}}$, the relative cofiber $\operatorname{cof}_{\mathcal{C}}(f)$ of $f$ is an object of the fiber of $T_{\mathcal{C}}$ over $q(Y)$.

We write $L_{B / A}$ for the value of the relative cotangent complex functor on an object $f: A \rightarrow B$ of the $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathcal{C}\right)$ of arrows in $\mathcal{C}$.

Remark 13.5.13. By construction, the relative cotangent complex of a morphism $f: A \rightarrow$ $B$ fits into a relative cofiber sequence
![img-162.jpeg](img-162.jpeg)
in $T_{\mathcal{C}}$. This induces an actual cofiber sequence $f_{!} L_{A} \rightarrow L_{B} \rightarrow L_{B / A}$ in the $\infty$-category $T_{\mathcal{C}} \times_{\mathcal{C}}\{B\} \simeq \operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C} / B\right)$. Here $f_{!}: \operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C} / A\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C} / B\right)$ is a straightening of the restriction $f^{*} q: T_{\mathcal{C}} \times_{\mathcal{C}} \Delta^{1} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$ of $q: T_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ along $f: \Delta^{1} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.

Remark 13.5.14. It follows that the commutative square in $T_{\mathcal{C}}$
![img-163.jpeg](img-163.jpeg)
associated to a pair of composible morphisms $A \rightarrow B$ and $B \rightarrow C$ in $\mathcal{C}$ is cocartesian, hence a relative cofiber sequence since $L_{B / B} \simeq 0$ in $\operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C} / B\right)$.

Definition 13.5.15. The tangent correspondence of a presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$ is the cocartesian fibration $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$ associated to the cotangent complex functor $L: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow T_{\mathcal{C}}$.

Remark 13.5.16. The tangent correspondence $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$ is also a cartesian fibration since $L: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow T_{\mathcal{C}}$ is a left adjoint.

Remark 13.5.17. The cocartesian fibration $\mathcal{M} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$ associated to a functor $f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ can be constructed as the pushout
![img-164.jpeg](img-164.jpeg)
in which the left vertical map is the inclusion at $\{1\} \subset \Delta^{1}$. The functor $\mathcal{M} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$ has fiber over 0 and 1 the full subcategories $\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$, and over the unique map $\varepsilon: 0 \rightarrow 1$ the functor $f: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$; this is evidently a cocartesian fibration as we can push forward objects of $\mathcal{C}$ along $\varepsilon$ via $f$. Thus a functor $h: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ amounts to the data of a functor $g: \mathcal{D} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ and a natural transformation $\eta: \Delta^{1} \times \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ from $\mathrm{id}_{\mathcal{C}}$ to $g f$. If $\mathcal{M}$ is

also a cartesian fibration, a unit transformation $\eta: \mathrm{id}_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow g f$ induces a canonical functor $h: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$.

Remark 13.5.18. A derivation in $\mathcal{C}$ is a morphism $\Delta^{1} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{C}}$ such that the composite $\Delta^{1} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$ is the identity and $\Delta^{1} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ is constant. More concretely, a derivation in $\mathcal{C}$ is a morphism in $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{C}}$ from an object $A$ in the fiber $\mathcal{C}$ over 0 to an object $M$ in the fiber $\operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathcal{C}_{/ A}\right)$ of $q: T_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ over $A$ (see [25, Remark 7.4.1.2]). The $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Der}(\mathcal{C})$ of derivations in $\mathcal{C}$ is the pullback
![img-165.jpeg](img-165.jpeg)
in which the right vertical map is induced by the functor $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{C}} \rightarrow \Delta^{1} \times \mathcal{C}$ and the bottom horizontal map is adjoint to the identity of $\Delta^{1} \times \mathcal{C}$.

# 13.5.2 Derivations and square-zero extensions 

We now specialize to the case in which $\mathcal{C}$ is the presentable $\infty$-category CAlg of commutative algebra spectra.

Remark 13.5.19. All algebras will be assumed commutative for the remainder of this article. If $A$ is a commutative algebra object there is a canonical equivalence $A \simeq A^{\text {op }}$, hence a canonical equivalence $\mathrm{LMod}_{A} \simeq \mathrm{LMod}_{A^{\text {op }}} \simeq \mathrm{RMod}_{A}$, so we needn't distinguish left and right module structures in the commutative case. We thus write $\operatorname{Mod}_{A}$ in place of $\mathrm{LMod}_{A}$ and $\mathrm{RMod}_{A}$.

Theorem 13.5.20. [25, Corollary 7.3.4.14] The functor $p: \operatorname{Mod} \rightarrow$ CAlg that sends the pair $(A, M) \in \operatorname{Mod}$ to $A \in$ CAlg exhibits Mod as a tangent bundle of CAlg. In particular, for any commutative algebra spectrum $A$, we have an equivalence $\operatorname{Mod}_{A} \simeq \operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathrm{CAlg}_{/ A}\right)$.

We will write $\operatorname{Sym}^{\leq 1}: \operatorname{Mod} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathrm{CAlg}\right)$ for a functor that corresponds to $\Omega^{\infty}: T_{\mathrm{CAlg}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathrm{CAlg}\right)$. We use this notation because $\operatorname{Sym}^{\leq 1} \simeq \operatorname{Sym}^{0} \oplus \operatorname{Sym}^{1}$ is the formula for the split square-zero extension in ordinary algebra, though we have obtained its augmented commutative algebra structure through abstract stabilization techniques.

Remark 13.5.21. Let $A$ be a commutative ring spectrum and $M$ an $A$-module. Then the split square-zero augmented commutative $A$-algebra structure on $A \oplus M$ is square-zero in the sense that the compositions

$$
\operatorname{Sym}_{A}^{n}(M) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Sym}_{A}^{n}(A \oplus M) \stackrel{\otimes^{n}}{\longrightarrow} A \oplus M \longrightarrow M
$$

are null whenever $n>1$.
Remark 13.5.22. On homotopy groups, the split square-zero extension is an ordinary split square-zero extension of graded commutative rings. In other words, for any pair of elements

$\left(a_{0}, m_{0}\right)$ and $\left(a_{1}, m_{1}\right)$ of $\pi_{*}(A \oplus M)$, the multiplication on $\pi_{*}(A \oplus M) \cong \pi_{*}(A) \oplus \pi_{*}(M)$ is given by the expected formula

$$
\left(a_{0}, m_{0}\right)\left(a_{1}, m_{1}\right)=\left(a_{0} a_{1}, a_{0} m_{1}+(-1)^{\left|a_{1}\right|\left|m_{0}\right|} a_{1} m_{0}\right)
$$

Remark 13.5.23. Any split square-zero extension $A \oplus M$, viewed as an augmented commutative $A$-algebra, is canonically a spectrum object in the pointed $\infty$-category $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A / A}$. Indeed, in degree $n,(A \oplus M)^{n} \simeq A \oplus \Sigma^{n} M$, and the map

$$
A \oplus \Sigma^{n} M \longrightarrow \Omega\left(A \oplus \Sigma^{n+1} M\right) \simeq A \oplus \Omega \Sigma^{n+1} M \simeq A \oplus \Sigma^{n} M
$$

is an equivalence, as $A$ is a zero object of $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A / A}$ and
![img-166.jpeg](img-166.jpeg)
is a cartesian square of $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A / A}$. Moreover, as $\operatorname{Mod}_{A}$ is stable, the functor $\operatorname{Sym}_{A}^{\leq 1}: \operatorname{Mod}_{A} \rightarrow$ $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A / A}$ factors through $\Omega^{\infty}: \operatorname{Sp}\left(\mathrm{CAlg}_{A / A}\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{CAlg}_{A / A}$. There is even an evident map back in the order direction given by taking the fiber, which sends the spectrum object $\left\{B^{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbf{N}}$ to $\operatorname{fib}\left\{B^{0} \rightarrow A\right\} \in \operatorname{Mod}_{A}$.

In ordinary commutative algebra, a derivation $d: A \rightarrow M$ over $R$ is an $R$-module map satisfying the Leibniz rule

$$
d(a b)=a d(b)+b d(a)
$$

Instead of using elements, we could instead define a derivation $d: A \rightarrow M$ as a section of the projection $A \oplus M \rightarrow A$, taken in the category of commutative $R$-algebras. Replacing $R$ with $\mathbf{S}$ we obtain the following notion.

Definition 13.5.24. Let $A$ be a commutative algebra spectrum and $M$ an $A$-module. A derivation from $A$ to $M$ is a section $A \rightarrow A \oplus M$ in CAlg of the projection $A \oplus M \rightarrow A$.

Remark 13.5.25. This is a special case of the notion of derivation introduced in the previous section. Here we avoid explicit mention of the tangent correspondence by pulling back to the fiber of $\mathcal{M}_{\text {CAlg }} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$ via the split square zero extension functor $T_{\text {CAlg }} \simeq \operatorname{Mod} \rightarrow$ CAlg.

Remark 13.5.26. The space $\operatorname{Der}(A, M)$ of derivations $A \rightarrow A \oplus M$ is the fiber

$$
\operatorname{Der}(A, M) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}(A, A \oplus M) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}(A, A)
$$

over the identity $\operatorname{id}_{A} \in \operatorname{Map}_{\text {CAlg }}(A, A)$. The composite of the commutative algebra map $A \rightarrow A \oplus M$ with the second projection $A \oplus M \rightarrow M$ is a map of spectra $d: A \rightarrow M$ which we will abusively refer to as the derivation.

Remark 13.5.27. For any connective commutative algebra $A$ and left $A$-module $M$, there is an equivalence $\operatorname{Map}_{\operatorname{Mod}_{A}}\left(L_{A}, M\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Der}(A, M)$. That is, the cotangent complex $L_{A}$ corepresents the functor $\operatorname{Der}(A,-): \operatorname{Mod}_{A} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}$.
Remark 13.5.28. Using the tangent correspondence formalism from the previous subsection, the $\infty$-category $\operatorname{Der}=\operatorname{Der}(\mathrm{CAlg})$ of derivations has objects derivations $d: A \rightarrow M$ and morphisms commutative squares of the form
![img-167.jpeg](img-167.jpeg)
with $A \rightarrow B$ a commutative algebra map and $M \rightarrow N$ an $A$-module map.
Let $A$ be a commutative ring spectrum, $M$ an $A$-module, and $\eta: A \rightarrow \Sigma M$ a derivation with associated section $(\mathrm{id}, \eta): A \rightarrow A \oplus \Sigma M$ of the projection $A \oplus \Sigma M \rightarrow A$. By construction, (id, $\eta$ ) is a morphism of commutative algebras.
Definition 13.5.29. A map of commutative algebra spectra $\varepsilon: A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ is a square-zero extension of $A$ by the $A$-module $M$ if there exists a derivation $\eta: A \rightarrow \Sigma M$ and a cartesian square in $\mathrm{CAlg}_{/ A}$ of the form
![img-168.jpeg](img-168.jpeg)

Remark 13.5.30. There is a functor $\Phi: \operatorname{Der} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathrm{CAlg}\right)$ that sends the derivation $\eta: A \rightarrow \Sigma M$ to the map $A^{\eta} \rightarrow A$, where $A^{\eta}$ is a pullback
![img-169.jpeg](img-169.jpeg)
in $\mathrm{CAlg}_{/ A}$, and whose essential image consists of the square-zero extensions.
Remark 13.5.31. Note that, if $f: A^{\eta} \rightarrow A$ is a square-zero extension of $A$ by $M$, then the fiber sequence of $A$-modules $M \rightarrow A \rightarrow A \oplus \Sigma M$ implies that we also have a fiber sequence $M \rightarrow A^{\eta} \rightarrow A$ and hence a canonical equivalence $\operatorname{fib}(f) \simeq M$. Hence derivations $\eta: A \rightarrow \Sigma M$ give rise to square-zero extensions $A^{\eta}$ of $A$ by $M$. This is why we use $\Sigma M$ instead of $M$ itself.
Remark 13.5.32. As the name suggests, square-zero extensions $f: A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ are actually square-zero. That is, the fiber $M \rightarrow A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ has the property that the $n$-fold symmetric power map $\operatorname{Sym}_{A}^{n}(M) \rightarrow M$ is null for any $n>1$.
Definition 13.5.33. A morphism $\varepsilon: A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ in $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$ is an $n$-small extension if $\operatorname{fib}(\varepsilon)$ has homotopy concentrated in degrees $[0,2 n]$ and the multiplication map $\operatorname{fib}(\varepsilon) \otimes_{A^{\prime}} \operatorname{fib}(\varepsilon) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{fib}(\varepsilon)$ is nullhomotopic. A derivation $\eta: A \rightarrow M$ is $n$-small if the associated square-zero extension $A^{\eta} \rightarrow A$ is $n$-small.

Theorem 13.5.34. [25, Theorem 7.4.1.26] The composition

$$
\operatorname{Der}_{n} \subset \operatorname{Der} \xrightarrow{\Phi} \operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}\right)
$$

is fully faithful with essential image the full subcategory of $\operatorname{Fun}\left(\Delta^{1}, \mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}\right)$ consisting of the $n$-small extensions (here $\Phi$ is as in 13.5.30 above).

Corollary 13.5.35. Any n-small extension is a square-zero extension.
One of the primary source of examples of square-zero extensions comes from the Postnikov tower of a connective commutative algebra $A$.

Proposition 13.5.36. [25, Corollary 7.4.1.28] Let $A \in \mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$. For each $n>0$, the map

$$
\tau_{\leq n} A \longrightarrow \tau_{\leq n-1} A
$$

exhibits $\tau_{\leq n} A$ as a square-zero extension of $\tau_{\leq n-1} A$ by $\Sigma^{n} \pi_{n} A$.
Remark 13.5.37. The fact that the Postnikov tower is composed of square-zero extensions is one of the main reasons why the cotangent complex plays such an important role in spectral algebra and geometry. The space of maps

$$
\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}(A, B) \simeq \lim \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}\left(A, \tau_{\leq n} B\right) \simeq \lim \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}\left(\tau_{\leq n} A, \tau_{\leq n} B\right)
$$

between connective commutative algebra spectra $A$ and $B$ decomposes as the limit of the space of maps between their truncations, and for any $n>0$ we have a pullback diagram
![img-170.jpeg](img-170.jpeg)

This implies that the fibers of $\operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}}(A, B) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Map}_{\mathrm{CAlg}^{\circ}}\left(\pi_{0} A, \pi_{0} B\right)$ are accessible via infinitesimal methods: arguing inductively up the Postnikov tower, we are reduced to understanding spaces of derivations from $A \rightarrow \Sigma^{n+1} \pi_{n} B$, an $A$-linear question concerning maps $L_{A} \rightarrow \Sigma^{n+1} \pi_{n} B$.

# 13.5.3 Deformations of commutative algebras 

Given a connective commutative algebra spectrum $A$ and a square-zero extension $A^{\prime} \rightarrow$ $A$ of $A$ by a connective $A$-module $M$, it is natural to study the space of deformations of the square-zero extension $A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ to a connective commutative $A$-algebra $f: A \rightarrow B$. That is, we wish to understand the space of cocartesian squares in $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$ of the form
![img-171.jpeg](img-171.jpeg)

(It turns out that $B^{\prime} \rightarrow B$ is automatically also a square-zero extension.) As in ordinary algebra, this reduces to a module theoretic question concerning the cotangent complex: such a commutative $A^{\prime}$-algebra $B^{\prime}$ exists if and only if the map $B \otimes_{A} L_{A} \rightarrow B \otimes_{A} \Sigma M$ induced by a derivation $\eta: A \rightarrow \Sigma M$ classifying $A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ factors through the absolute cotangent complex $L_{B}$ of $B$.

Definition 13.5.38. Let $A$ be a commutative algebra spectrum, $A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ a square-zero extension of $A$ by an $A$-module $M$, and $B$ a commutative $A$-algebra. A deformation of $B$ to $A^{\prime}$ is a commutative $A^{\prime}$-algebra $B^{\prime}$ equipped with an equivalence $B^{\prime} \otimes_{A^{\prime}} A \rightarrow B$ of commutative $A$-algebras.

Remark 13.5.39. We need not assume that $B^{\prime}$ is flat over $A^{\prime}$, as this is the case if and only if $B$ is flat over $A$. Indeed, if $A^{\prime} \rightarrow B^{\prime}$ is flat, then the basechange $A \rightarrow B \simeq B^{\prime} \otimes_{A^{\prime}} A$ is flat by a spectral sequence argument. Conversely, the fact that any deformation $B^{\prime} \rightarrow B$ of $A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ along a flat map $A \rightarrow B$ results in a flat map $A^{\prime} \rightarrow B^{\prime}$ follows from a tor-amplitude argument.

Remark 13.5.40. In the connective case, just like in ordinary commutative algebra, there are cohomological obstructions to the existence and uniqueness of deformations. Given an $A$-linear map $\eta: L_{A} \rightarrow \Sigma M$ with $M$ a connective $A$-module, the associated squarezero extension $A^{\eta} \rightarrow A$ of $A$ by $M$ is again connective. Given a morphism of connective commutative algebra spectra $A \rightarrow B$, we obtain a map $\eta_{B}: B \otimes_{A} L_{A} \rightarrow B \otimes_{A} \Sigma M$, and a deformation $B^{\prime} \rightarrow B$ of $A^{\prime} \rightarrow A$ along $A \rightarrow B$ exists if and only if $\eta_{B}$ factors as a composite

$$
B \otimes_{A} L_{A} \xrightarrow{\varepsilon_{B}} L_{B} \xrightarrow{\eta^{\prime}} B \otimes_{A} \Sigma M
$$

of $\varepsilon_{B}: B \otimes_{A} L_{A} \rightarrow L_{B}$ and a $B$-module map $\eta^{\prime}: L_{B} \rightarrow B \otimes_{A} \Sigma M$. In this case, the deformation is recovered as the square-zero extension $B^{\prime} \simeq B^{\eta^{\prime}} \rightarrow B$. Notice, though, that such a factorization exists if and only if the composite

$$
\Sigma^{-1} L_{B / A} \longrightarrow B \otimes_{A} L_{A} \longrightarrow B \otimes_{A} \Sigma M
$$

is null, so that a deformation exists if and only if the obstruction class in $\operatorname{Ext}_{B}^{2}\left(L_{B / A}, B \otimes_{A}\right.$ $M)$ corresponding to this map vanishes.
