# 21.2 Notation and conventions 

We will use Hom to denote the set of morphisms between two objects in a category. Sometimes the set of morphisms may have extra structure and, in that case, we will feel free to use it. We will capitalize the first letter, such as in Hom, Level, and Sub, to denote functors. Given a (possibly formal) scheme $X$, we will write $\mathcal{O}_{X}$ to denote the ring of functions on $X$. Given a complete local ring $(R, \mathfrak{m})$, we will write $\operatorname{Spf}(R)$ to denote the functor $\operatorname{Hom}(R,-)$ from the category of complete local rings to sets corepresented by $R$. Thus $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Spf}(R)} \cong R$.

### 21.3 Lubin-Tate theory

In this section we recall the Lubin-Tate moduli problem and describe several wellbehaved moduli problems that live over the Lubin-Tate moduli problem.

We begin with a brief overview of the theory of (1-dimensional, commutative) formal groups over complete local rings. Let CompRings be the category of complete local rings. Objects in this category are local commutative rings $(R, \mathfrak{m})$ such that $R \cong \lim _{k} R / \mathfrak{m}^{k}$ and maps are local homomorphisms of rings. We will denote the quotient map $R \rightarrow R / \mathfrak{m}$ by $\pi$. Note that if $\kappa$ is a field, then $(\kappa,(0))$ is a complete local ring. Given a complete local ring $(R, \mathfrak{m})$, let CompRings ${ }_{R /}$ be the category of complete local $R$-algebras. The formal affine line over $R$,

$$
\hat{\mathbb{A}}_{R}^{1}: \operatorname{CompRings}_{R /} \rightarrow \operatorname{Set}_{*}
$$

is the functor to pointed sets corepresented by the complete local $R$-algebra $\left(R \llbracket x \rrbracket, \mathfrak{m}+(x)\right)$. Thus, for a complete local $R$-algebra $(S, \mathfrak{n})$,

$$
\hat{\mathbb{A}}_{R}^{1}(S, \mathfrak{n})=\operatorname{Hom}_{R \text {-alg }}\left(R \llbracket x \rrbracket, S\right) \cong \mathfrak{n}
$$

where $\operatorname{Hom}_{R \text {-alg }}(-,-)$ denotes the set of morphisms in CompRings ${ }_{R /}$ and the last isomorphism is the map that takes a morphism to the image of $x$ in $S$.

A formal group $\mathbb{G}$ over $R$ is a functor

$$
\mathbb{G}: \text { CompRings }_{R /} \rightarrow \text { Abelian Groups }
$$

that is abstractly isomorphic to $\hat{\mathbb{A}}_{R}^{1}$ when viewed as a functor to pointed sets. A homomorphism of formal groups is a natural transformation of functors.

A coordinate on a formal group $\mathbb{G}$ over $R$ is a choice of isomorphism $\mathbb{G} \xrightarrow{\cong} \hat{\mathbb{A}}_{R}^{1}$. Given a coordinate, the multiplication map

$$
\mu: \mathbb{G} \times \mathbb{G} \rightarrow \mathbb{G}
$$

gives rise to a map

$$
\mu^{*}: R \llbracket x \rrbracket \rightarrow R \llbracket x_{1}, x_{2} \rrbracket
$$

and $\mu^{*}(x)=x_{1}+_{\mathbb{G}} x_{2}$ is the formal group law associated to the coordinate. In other words, given a coordinate, we have an identification of the abelian group $\mathbb{G}(S, \mathfrak{n})$ with $\left(\mathfrak{n},+_{\mathbb{G}}\right)$, the maximal ideal of $S$ with addition given by the formal group law associated to the coordinate.

Example 21.3.1. The additive formal group $\mathbb{G}_{a}$ over $R$ associates to a complete local $R$-algebra $(S, \mathfrak{n})$ the abelian group $\mathfrak{n}$ with its usual additive structure. An isomorphism $\mathbb{G}_{a} \cong \hat{\mathbb{A}}_{R}^{1}$ is given by taking the underlying pointed set and the associated formal group law is

$$
x_{1}+_{\mathbb{G}_{a}} x_{2}=x_{1}+x_{2}
$$

Example 21.3.2. The multiplicative formal group $\mathbb{G}_{m}$ over $R$ associates to a complete local $R$-algebra $(S, \mathfrak{n})$ the set of units of $S$ of the form $1+n$ for $n \in \mathfrak{n}$ with its usual multiplicative structure. An isomorphism $\mathbb{G}_{m} \cong \hat{\mathbb{A}}_{R}^{1}$ is given by sending $1+n$ to $n$ and the associated formal group law is

$$
x_{1}+_{\mathbb{G}_{m}} x_{2}=x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{1} x_{2}
$$

For $i \in \mathbb{N}$, we define the $i$-series of a formal group law $x_{1}+_{\mathbb{G}} x_{2}$ to be the power series

$$
[i]_{\mathbb{G}}(x)=\overbrace{x+_{\mathbb{G}} \ldots+_{\mathbb{G}} x}^{i \text { terms }}
$$

Given a formal group over a complete local ring $R$ and a map of complete local rings $j: R \rightarrow S$, we will write $j^{*} \mathbb{G}$ for the restriction of the functor $\mathbb{G}$ to the category of complete local $S$-algebras.

Let $\kappa$ be a perfect field of characteristic $p$. "Perfect" means that the Frobenius $\sigma: \kappa \rightarrow \kappa$ is an isomorphism of fields. A formal group $\mathbb{F}$ over $\kappa$ is said to be of height $n$ if, after choosing a coordinate, the associated formal group law $x+_{\mathbb{F}} y$ has the property that the $p$-series $[p]_{\mathbb{F}}(x)$ has first term $u x^{p^{\alpha}}$, where $u \in \kappa^{\times}$. The additive formal group over $\kappa$ has height $\infty$ and the multiplicative formal group over $\kappa$ has height 1 .

Fix a formal group $\mathbb{F}$ over $\kappa$ of height $n$. All of the constructions in this section will depend on this choice. Associated to $\mathbb{F} / \kappa$ is a moduli problem (i.e. a functor to groupoids)

# LT: CompRings $\rightarrow$ Groupoids 

studied by Lubin and Tate in [13]. We will take a coordinate-free approach to this moduli problem that is closely related to the description in [20, Section 6]. The functor LT takes values in groupoids. Next we will describe the objects and morphisms of these groupoids.

A deformation of $\mathbb{F} / \kappa$ to a complete local ring $(R, \mathfrak{m})$ is a triple of data

$$
\left(\mathbb{G} / R, i: \kappa \rightarrow R / \mathfrak{m}, \tau: \pi^{*} \mathbb{G} \xrightarrow{\cong} i^{*} \mathbb{F}\right)
$$

where $\mathbb{G}$ is a formal group over $R, i: \kappa \rightarrow R / \mathfrak{m}$ is a map of fields, and $\tau$ is an isomorphism of formal groups over $R / \mathfrak{m}$. We will often use shorthand and refer to a deformation as a triple $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$. The deformations of $\mathbb{F} / \kappa$ to $(R, \mathfrak{m})$ form the objects of $\operatorname{LT}(R, \mathfrak{m})$. The morphisms

of $\operatorname{LT}(R, \mathfrak{m})$ are known as $\star$-isomorphisms. A $\star$-isomorphism $\delta$ between two deformations $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ and $\left(\mathbb{G}^{\prime}, i^{\prime}, \tau^{\prime}\right)$ only exists when $i=i^{\prime}$ and then it is an isomorphism of formal groups $\delta: \mathbb{G} \xrightarrow{\cong} \mathbb{G}^{\prime}$ compatible with the isomorphisms $\tau$ and $\tau^{\prime}$ in the sense that the square
![img-262.jpeg](img-262.jpeg)
commutes.
Given a map of complete local rings $j:(R, \mathfrak{m}) \rightarrow(S, \mathfrak{n})$, there is an induced map of groupoids $\operatorname{LT}(R, \mathfrak{m}) \rightarrow \operatorname{LT}(S, \mathfrak{n})$ defined by sending

$$
(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau) \mapsto\left(j^{*} \mathbb{G}, \kappa \xrightarrow{i} R / \mathfrak{m} \xrightarrow{j / \mathfrak{m}} S / \mathfrak{n},(j / \mathfrak{m})^{*} \tau\right)
$$

This makes LT into a functor to the category of groupoids. Let $W(\kappa)$ be the ring of $p$ typical Witt vectors on $\kappa$. This is a torsion-free complete local ring of characteristic 0 with the property that $W(\kappa) / p \cong \kappa$. When $\kappa=\mathbb{F}_{p}, W(\kappa)=\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ (the $p$-adic integers). Now we are prepared to state the Lubin-Tate theorem.

Theorem 21.3.3. [13] The functor LT takes values in fine groupoids (i.e. groupoids whose objects have no nontrivial automorphisms) and is corepresented by a complete local ring $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$ non-canonically isomorphic to $W(\kappa)\llbracket u_{1}, \ldots, u_{n-1} \rrbracket$ called the Lubin-Tate ring.

This theorem was proved in [13]. The homotopy theorist may be interested in reading [17, Chapters 4 and 5] or [14, Lecture 21].

Part of the content of the Lubin-Tate theorem is that, for any complete local ring $(R, \mathrm{Mod})$, the groupoid $\mathrm{LT}(R, \mathrm{Mod})$ is fine and thus equivalent to the functor to sets obtained by taking the set of isomorphism classes of objects in each groupoid. It follows that the identity map on $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$ classifies the universal deformation $\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}, \mathrm{id}_{\kappa}, \mathrm{id}_{\mathbb{F}}\right)$. This means that, given any deformation $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ over a complete local ring $R$ there exists a map $j: \mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} \rightarrow R$ such that $\left(j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}, j / \mathfrak{m}, \mathrm{id}_{(j / \mathfrak{m})^{* \mathbb{F}}}\right)$ is $\star$-isomorphic to $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$.

It is possible to add various bells and whistles to the Lubin-Tate functor. We will now explain three ways of doing this, in each case we add some additional data to each deformation. First, we will add the choice of a homomorphism from a fixed abelian group to $\mathbb{G}$ to each deformation. Second, we will add the choice of a "level structure" from a fixed abelian group to $\mathbb{G}$. Third, we will add the choice of a subgroup scheme of $\mathbb{G}$ of a fixed order.

We construct a modification of the Lubin-Tate functor depending on a finite abelian group $A$. If $\mathbb{G}$ is a formal group over a complete local ring $(R, \mathfrak{m})$, then a homomorphism $A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}$ over $R$ is a map of abelian groups $A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}(R)$. We will write $\operatorname{Hom}(A, \mathbb{G}(R))$ for this abelian group. Define

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right): \text { CompRings } \rightarrow \text { Groupoids }
$$

to be the functor with $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R, \mathfrak{m})$ equal to the groupoid with objects triples $(f: A \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$, where $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ is a deformation of $\mathbb{F} / \kappa$ to $(R, \mathfrak{m})$ and $f$ is a homomorphism from $A$ to $\mathbb{G}$ over $R$, and morphisms $\star$-isomorphisms that commute with this structure. In other

words, a $\star$-isomorphism from $(f: A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ to $\left(f^{\prime}: A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}^{\prime}, i, \tau^{\prime}\right)$ is a $\star$-isomorphism $\delta$ from $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ to $\left(\mathbb{G}^{\prime}, i, \tau^{\prime}\right)$ such that the diagram
![img-263.jpeg](img-263.jpeg)
commutes.
The functor $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ lives over LT. There is a forgetful natural transformation $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{LT}$ given by sending an object $(f: A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ to $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$. It follows from the definition that the forgetful functor $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R, \mathfrak{m}) \rightarrow \operatorname{LT}(R, \mathfrak{m})$ is faithful. Thus $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R, \mathfrak{m})$ is a fine groupoid.

Corollary 21.3.4. The functor $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ is corepresentable by a complete local ring $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ that is finitely generated and free as a module over $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$.

Proof. The idea of the proof is that we will first construct an $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-algebra with the correct algebraic properties and then use Theorem 21.3.3 to show that the underlying complete local ring corepresents the moduli problem $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$.

Recall that $\operatorname{CompRings}_{\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} /}$ is the category of complete local $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-algebras. Consider the functor

$$
\mathrm{G}_{u}^{A}: \operatorname{CompRings}_{\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} /} \rightarrow \text { Abelian Groups }
$$

that sends a complete local $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-algebra $j: \mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} \rightarrow R$ to the abelian group $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}(R)\right)$, which is isomorphic to $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}(R)\right)$. When $A=C_{p^{k}}$, this functor is corepresented by $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}\llbracket x \rrbracket /\left[p^{k}\right]_{\mathrm{G}_{u}}(x)$, where $\left[p^{k}\right]_{\mathrm{G}_{u}}(x)$ is the $p^{k}$-series for the formal group law associated to a choice of coordinate on $\mathrm{G}_{u}$. This is a complete local ring with maximal ideal $\mathfrak{m}+(x)$, where $\mathfrak{m}$ is the maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$, and it follows from the Weierstrass preparation theorem that it is a free module of rank $p^{k n}$. If $A \cong \prod_{i} C_{p^{k_{i}}}$, then $\mathrm{G}_{u}^{A}$ is corepresented by a tensor product of these sorts of $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-algebras and thus is finitely generated and free as an $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-module. Thus $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{G}_{u}^{A}}$ is a complete local $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-algebra that is finitely generated and free as an $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-module.

We will now show that the functor corepresented by the underlying complete local ring

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{G}_{u}^{A}},-\right): \text { CompRings } \rightarrow \text { Set }
$$

is naturally isomorphic to $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$.
Let $(R, \mathfrak{m})$ be a complete local ring. A map of complete local rings $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{G}_{u}^{A}} \rightarrow R$ is equivalent to the choice of an $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-algebra structure on $R, j: \mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} \rightarrow R$, and a homomorphism $A \rightarrow$ $j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}$. Using this data, we may form the deformation

$$
\left(A \rightarrow j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}, j / \mathfrak{m}, \operatorname{id}_{(j / \mathfrak{m})^{*} \mathbb{F}}\right)
$$

Let $(f: A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ be an object in the groupoid $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R, \mathfrak{m})$. By Theorem 21.3.3, there is a map $j: \mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} \rightarrow R$ and a unique $\star$-isomorphism

$$
(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau) \cong\left(j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}, j / \mathfrak{m}, \operatorname{id}_{(j / \mathfrak{m})^{*} \mathbb{F}}\right)
$$

which includes the data of an isomorphism of formal groups $t: \mathbb{G} \cong j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}$. Thus the deformation $(f, i, \tau)$ is (necessarily uniquely) $\star$-isomorphic to the deformation

$$
\left(A \xrightarrow{f} \mathbb{G} \xrightarrow{t} j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}, j / \mathfrak{m}, \operatorname{id}_{(j / \mathfrak{m})^{*} \mathbb{F}}\right)
$$

Now the data of $j$ and $A \rightarrow j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}$ is equivalent to the data of a map $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{G}_{u}^{A}} \rightarrow R$. These two constructions are clearly inverse to each other.

Let $A$ be a finite abelian $p$-group. Level structures on formal groups were introduced by Drinfeld in [8, Section 4]. A level structure $f: A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}$ is a homomorphism from $A$ to $\mathbb{G}$ over $R$ with a certain property. There is a divisor on $\mathbb{G}$ associated to every homomorphism from $A$ to $\mathbb{G}$ and the idea is that a level structure is a homomorphism over $R$ for which the associated divisor is a subgroup scheme of $\mathbb{G}$. More explicitly, fix a coordinate on $\mathbb{G}$, which provides an isomorphism $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{G}} \cong R \llbracket x \rrbracket$. For $f: A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}(R)$, let $g_{f}(x)=\prod_{a \in A}(x-f(a))$. The divisor associated to $f$ is $\operatorname{Spf}\left(R \llbracket x \rrbracket /\left(g_{f}(x)\right)\right)$ and $f$ is a level structure if this is a subgroup scheme of $\mathbb{G}$ and the rank of $A$ is less than or equal to $n$ (the height). It is useful to think about level structures as injective maps, even though they are not necessarily injective in any sense.

We define

$$
\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right): \text { CompRings } \rightarrow \text { Groupoids }
$$

to be the functor that assigns to a complete local ring $(R, \mathfrak{m})$ the groupoid $\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R, \mathfrak{m})$ with objects triples $(l: A \rightarrow \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$, where $l$ is a level structure, and morphisms $\star$-isomorphisms that commute with the level structures in the same way as in the definition of $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R, \mathfrak{m})$. Again, there is a faithful forgetful natural transformation $\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{LT}$. The proof of the next corollary is along the same lines as the proof of Corollary 21.3.4 with some extra work needed to show that the complete local ring is a domain.

Corollary 21.3.5. [8, Proposition 4.3] The functor $\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ is corepresentable by a complete local domain $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ that is finitely generated and free as a module over $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$.

A particular example of this functor will play an important role. Let $\mathbb{L}$ be a free $\mathbb{Z}_{p^{-}}$ module of rank $n$ and let $\mathbb{T}=\mathbb{L}^{*}$, the Pontryagin dual of $\mathbb{L}$. Thus $\mathbb{L}$ is abstractly isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{\times n}$ and $\mathbb{T}$ is abstractly isomorphic to $\left(\mathbb{Q}_{p} / \mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)^{\times n}$. We use the notation $\mathbb{L}$ to indicate that we have fixed a ( $p$-adic) lattice and $\mathbb{T}$ for the Pontryagin dual indicate that it is ( $p$-adic) torus. Let $\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right]$ be the $p^{k}$-torsion in the torus and let

$$
\mathbb{L}_{p^{k}}=p^{k} \mathbb{L} \subset \mathbb{L}
$$

By construction, there is a canonical isomorphism $\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right] \cong\left(\mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{p^{k}}\right)^{*}$. Both $\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right]$ and $\mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{p^{k}}$ are abstractly isomorphic to $\left(\mathbb{Z} / p^{k}\right)^{\times n}$. The functors $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ will be particularly important.

Finally we introduce one last moduli problem over LT. Define

$$
\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right): \text { CompRings } \rightarrow \text { Groupoids }
$$

to be the functor that assigns to a complete local ring $(R, \mathfrak{m})$ the groupoid $\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R, \mathfrak{m})$ with objects triples $(H \subset \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$, where $H$ is a subgroup scheme of $\mathbb{G}$ of order $p^{k}$. Morphisms are $\star$-isomorphisms that send the chosen subgroup to the chosen subgroup. Just as with the other moduli problems, there is a faithful forgetful natural transformation $\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{LT}$. Once again, the proof of the next corollary is along the same lines as the proof of Corollary 21.3.4 with some extra work needed to show that the complete local ring is finitely generated and free as an $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-module.

Corollary 21.3.6. [20, Theorem 42] The moduli problem $\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ is corepresented by a complete local ring $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ that is finitely generated and free as a module over $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$.

# 21.4 Symmetries of certain moduli problems over Lubin-Tate space 

Besides being corepresentable, the moduli problems described in the last section are highly symmetric. We begin by describing the action of the stabilizer group on each of the moduli problems and then we will explain how to take the quotient of a deformation by a finite subgroup and how a certain limit of these moduli problems picks up extra symmetry. A reference that includes a concise exposition of much of the material in this section is [7, Section 1].

The group $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ of automorphisms of $\mathbb{F}$ over $\kappa$ is known as the (small) Morava stabilizer group. This group acts on the left on all of the moduli problems that we have described in a very simple way. The action of $s \in \operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ is given by

$$
s \cdot(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)=\left(\mathbb{G}, i,\left(i^{*} s\right) \tau\right)
$$

where $i^{*} s: i^{*} \mathbb{F} \rightarrow i^{*} \mathbb{F}$ is the induced isomorphism. This is well-defined: if $\delta$ is a $\star$ isomorphism from $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ to $\left(\mathbb{G}^{\prime}, i, \tau^{\prime}\right)$ then $f$ is still a $\star$-isomorphism between $s \cdot(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ and $s \cdot\left(\mathbb{G}^{\prime}, i, \tau^{\prime}\right)$ since
![img-264.jpeg](img-264.jpeg)
commutes. The actions of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ on $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$, $\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$, and $\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ are defined similarly.

There is a right action of $\operatorname{Aut}(A)$ on both $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ given by precomposition and a left action of $\operatorname{Aut}(A)$ on both $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ given by precomposition with the inverse. Since neither of these actions affects $\mathbb{G}, i$, or $\tau$, the corresponding actions of $\operatorname{Aut}(A)$ on $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ and $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ are by $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$-algebra maps. We mention the left action by precomposition with the inverse because that is the action

that we will generalize and that will play the most important role in our constructions. Specializing to $A=\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right]$, we see that there is a left action of $\operatorname{Aut}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right]\right) \cong \mathrm{GL}_{n}\left(\mathbb{Z} / p^{k}\right)$ on $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ given by precomposition with the inverse.

There is a forgetful natural transformation $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k-1}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ induced by the map sending a level structure $\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{G}$ to the level structure given by the composite $\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k-1}\right] \subset \mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{G}$. Let

$$
\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)=\lim _{k} \operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)
$$

We will refer to the ring of functions $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}=\operatorname{colim}_{k} \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ as the Drinfeld ring. The groupoid $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R, \mathfrak{m})$ can be thought of as follows: It has objects consisting of tuples $\left(l: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{G}, i, \tau\right)$ and morphisms given by $\star$-isomorphisms, where $l$ is a map from $\mathbb{T}$ to $\mathbb{G}$ over $R$ such that, for all $k \geq 0$, the induced map $\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{G}$ is a level structure. If $H \subset \mathbb{T}$ is a subgroup of order $p^{k}$, then $H$ determines a map $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ defined by

$$
(l, i, \tau) \mapsto(l(H) \subset \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)
$$

There is a left action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$ on $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ given by precomposition with the inverse. It turns out that the action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$ on $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ extends to an action of $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$, the monoid of endoisogenies of $\mathbb{T}$, a much larger object! An isogeny $\mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{T}$ is a homomorphism with finite kernel. To describe the action of $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$, we first need to describe the quotient of a deformation by a finite subgroup.

Let $\sigma: \operatorname{Spec}(\kappa) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(\kappa)$ be the Frobenius endomorphism on $\kappa$ and let $\sigma_{\mathbb{F}}: \mathbb{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}$ be the Frobenius endomorphism on the formal group $\mathbb{F}$. Let $\sigma^{*} \mathbb{F}$ be the pullback of $\mathbb{F}$ along $\sigma$. The relative Frobenius is an isogeny of formal groups of degree $p$

$$
\text { Frob: } \mathbb{F} \rightarrow \sigma^{*} \mathbb{F}
$$

It is constructed using the universal property of the pullback:
![img-265.jpeg](img-265.jpeg)

The formal group $\mathbb{F}$ lives over $\kappa$, so there is a canonical map $\mathbb{F} \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(\kappa)$. This fits together with the $\sigma_{\mathbb{F}}$ to produce the map Frob: $\mathbb{F} \rightarrow \sigma^{*} \mathbb{F}$. Using the $k$ th power of the Frobenius $\sigma^{k}$ and $\sigma_{\mathbb{F}}^{k}$ in the diagram above instead of $\sigma$ and $\sigma_{\mathbb{F}}$, we construct the $k$ th relative Frobenius $\operatorname{Frob}^{k}: \mathbb{F} \rightarrow\left(\sigma^{k}\right)^{*} \mathbb{F}$. The kernel of the $k$ th relative Frobenius is a subgroup scheme of $\mathbb{F}$ of order $p^{k}$. A formal group over a field of characteristic $p$ has a unique subgroup scheme of order $p^{k}$ for each $k \geq 0$. Thus $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mathrm{Frob}^{k}\right) \subset \mathbb{F}$ is the unique subgroup scheme of $\mathbb{F}$ of order $p^{k}$.

Let $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ be a deformation of $\mathbb{F} / \kappa$ to a complete local ring $R$ and let $H \subset \mathbb{G}$ be a subgroup scheme of order $p^{k}$. The quotient of $\mathbb{G}$ by $H, \mathbb{G} / H$, was first defined in [12, Section 1]. In [20, Section 5], Strickland shows that the quotient is the formal group

$$
\mathbb{G} / H=\operatorname{Coeq}\left(\mathbb{G} \times H \xrightarrow[\operatorname{proj} .]{\stackrel{\text { act }}{\longrightarrow}} \mathbb{G}\right)
$$

constructed as the coequalizer of the action map and the projection map.
There is a canonical way to extend the quotient formal group $\mathbb{G} / H$ to a deformation of $\mathbb{F}$ to $R$. Let $q: \mathbb{G} \rightarrow \mathbb{G} / H$ be the quotient map. Consider the following diagram of formal groups over $R / m$
![img-266.jpeg](img-266.jpeg)

Since both $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\pi^{*} q\right) \subset \pi^{*} \mathbb{G}$ and $\operatorname{Ker}\left(i^{*} \operatorname{Frob}^{k} \circ \tau\right) \subset \pi^{*} \mathbb{G}$ have the same order, we must have $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\pi^{*} q\right)=\operatorname{Ker}\left(i^{*} \operatorname{Frob}^{k} \circ \tau\right)$. Thus, by the first isomorphism theorem for formal groups [12, Theorem 1.5], there is a unique isomorphism (the dashed arrow) making the diagram commutes. We will call this isomorphism $\tau / H$. Thus, given the deformation $(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$ over $R$ and $H \subset \mathbb{G}$, we may form the deformation

$$
\left(\mathbb{G} / H, i \circ \sigma^{k}, \tau / H\right)
$$

Now we will produce the promised left action of the monoid $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ on $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$. First note that $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ really is much larger than $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$. Pontryagin duality produces an anti-isomorphism between $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$ and $\mathrm{GL}_{n}\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p}\right)$ and an anti-isomorphism between $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ and the monoid of $n \times n$ matrices with coefficients in $\mathbb{Z}_{p}$ and non-zero determinant. Let $H \subset \mathbb{T}$ be a finite subgroup of order $p^{k}$, let $\phi_{H} \in \operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ be an endoisogeny of $\mathbb{T}$ with kernel $H$, and let $q_{H}: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{T} / H$ be the quotient map. Recall that if $l: \mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{G}$ is a level structure and $H \subset \mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right]$, then $l(H) \subset \mathbb{G}$ is a subgroup scheme of order $|H|$. We will abuse notation and refer to $l(H) \subset \mathbb{G}$ as $H$.

For a deformation equipped with level structure

$$
(l: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)
$$

we set

$$
\phi_{H} \cdot(l, i, \tau)=\left(l / H \circ \psi_{H}^{-1}, i \circ \sigma^{k}, \tau / H\right)
$$

where $l / H: \mathbb{T} / H \rightarrow \mathbb{G} / H$ is the induced level structure and $\psi_{H}$ is the unique isomorphism that makes the square
![img-267.jpeg](img-267.jpeg)
commute. We leave it to the reader to check that $\phi_{H}$ preserves $\star$-isomorphisms and to check that the resulting formula does in fact give a left action of $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$.

Proposition 21.4.1. The formula of (21.4.3) defines a left action of $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ on $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$.

One subtlety worth mentioning is that this action is weak: for $\phi, \phi^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$, there is a (necessarily unique) $\star$-isomorphism between $\phi \cdot \phi^{\prime}(l, i, \tau)$ and $\left(\phi \circ \phi^{\prime}\right) \cdot(l, i, \tau)$. This induces a strict action on $\star$-isomorphism classes.

Restricting the above action to the case that $H=e$, the trivial subgroup, we see that $q_{e}$ is the identity map and that $\psi_{e}=\phi_{e}$ so that

$$
\phi_{e} \cdot(l, i, \tau)=\left(l \circ \phi_{e}^{-1}, i, \tau\right)
$$

This shows that the action of $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ on $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ extends the action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$ given by precomposition with the inverse. Since we have a left action of $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ on $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$, we have a right action of $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ on $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$.

# 21.5 Morava $E$-theory 

In this section we construct Morava $E$-theory using the Landweber exact functor theorem, we calculate the $E$-cohomology of finite abelian groups, we describe the Goerss-Hopkins-Miller theorem, and we describe the resulting power operations on $E$-cohomology.

Morava $E$-theory is a cohomology theory that is built using the Landweber exact functor theorem applied to the universal formal group over the Lubin-Tate ring associated to the height $n$ formal group $\mathbb{F} / \kappa$. Theorem 21.3.3 states that there is a non-canonical isomorphism

$$
\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} \cong W(\kappa)\llbracket u_{1}, \ldots, u_{n-1} \rrbracket
$$

It follows from [20, Section 6] that a coordinate can be chosen on the universal deformation formal group $\mathbb{G}_{u}$ such that the associated formal group law has the property that

$$
[p]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x)=u_{i} x^{p^{i}} \quad \bmod \left(p, u_{1}, \ldots u_{i-1}, x^{p^{i}+1}\right)
$$

Since $\left(p, u_{1}, \ldots, u_{n-1}\right)$ is a regular sequence in $W(\kappa) \llbracket u_{1}, \ldots, u_{n-1} \rrbracket$, this property allows the Landweber exact functor theorem to be applied producing a homology theory $E_{*}(-)=$ $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)_{*}(-)$, called Morava $E$-theory, by the formula

$$
E_{*}(X)=\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} \otimes_{M U P_{0}} M U P_{*}(X)
$$

where $M U P$ is the 2-periodic complex cobordism spectrum $\bigvee_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \Sigma^{2 k} M U$. By construction, this spectrum has the property that $\pi_{0} M U P \cong \oplus_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \pi_{2 k} M U$. Good introductions to the Landweber exact functor theorem can be found in [10] and [14, Lecture 16]. For a somewhat different perspective on Morava $E$-theory and a broader explanation of its role in chromatic homotopy theory, see Section 3 of the chapter by Tobias Barthel and Agnès Beaudry in this Handbook.

Example 21.5.1. When $(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)=\left(\mathbb{G}_{m}, \mathbb{F}_{p}\right)$, the formal multiplicative group over the field with $p$ elements, then $\mathbb{G}_{n}=\mathbb{G}_{m}$ over $W(\kappa)=\mathbb{Z}_{p}$. The resulting cohomology theory is precisely $p$-adic $K$-theory.

There is a cohomology theory associated to this homology theory. On spaces equivalent to a finite CW-complex, it satisfies

$$
E^{*}(X)=\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}} \otimes_{M U P_{0}} M U P^{*}(X)
$$

From now on, we will always write $E^{0}$ rather than $\mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{LT}}$ for the Lubin-Tate ring. We will primarily be interested in spaces of the form $B G$ for $G$ a finite group and these are almost always not equivalent to a finite CW complex. To get a grip on the $E$-cohomology of these large spaces, we boot strap from the calculation of $E^{*}\left(B S^{1}\right)$ using the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence, the Milnor sequence, and the Mittag-Leffler condition to control $\lim ^{1}$ as described very clearly in both [15, Chapter 2.2] and [2, Section 2 of Part II].
Proposition 21.5.2. [2, Lemma 2.5 of Part II] There is an isomorphism of $E^{*}$-algebras

$$
E^{*}\left(B S^{1}\right) \cong E^{*} \llbracket x \rrbracket
$$

Hopkins, Kuhn, and Ravenel observe in [11, Lemma 5.7] that the Gysin sequence associated to the circle bundle $S^{1} \rightarrow B C_{p^{k}} \rightarrow B S^{1}$ can be used to calculate $E^{*}\left(B C_{p^{k}}\right)$ from Proposition 21.5.2.
Proposition 21.5.3. The isomorphism of Proposition 21.5.2 induces an isomorphism of $E^{*}$-algebras

$$
E^{*}\left(B C_{p^{k}}\right) \cong E^{*} \llbracket x \rrbracket /\left(\left[p^{k}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x)\right)
$$

Proof. The Gysin sequence associated to the circle bundle $S^{1} \rightarrow B C_{p^{k}} \rightarrow B S^{1}$ is the exact sequence

$$
E^{*} \llbracket x \rrbracket \xrightarrow{ \times\left[p^{k}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x)} E^{*} \llbracket x \rrbracket \longrightarrow E^{*}\left(B C_{p^{k}}\right)
$$

where $\left[p^{k}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x)$ is in degree -2 . Since $E^{*} \llbracket x \rrbracket$ is a domain, multiplication by $\left[p^{k}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x)$ is injective and the result follows.

As we noted in the proof of Corollary 21.3.4, the Weierstrass preparation theorem implies that $E^{*} \llbracket x \rrbracket /\left(\left[p^{k}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x)\right)$ is a finitely generated free module over $E^{*}$. Since $E^{*}\left(B C_{p^{k}}\right)$ is a finitely generated free module, we can use the Künneth isomorphism to boot strap our calculation to finite abelian groups.
Proposition 21.5.4. Let $A \cong \prod_{i=1}^{m} C_{p^{k_{i}}}$, then there is an isomorphism of $E^{*}$-algebras

$$
E^{*}(B A) \cong E^{*} \llbracket x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m} \rrbracket /\left(\left[p^{k_{1}}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x), \ldots,\left[p^{k_{m}}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x)\right)
$$

In this article, we will restrict our attention to the 0th cohomology ring $E^{0}(X)$. Since $E$ is even periodic, this commutative ring contains plenty of information. The isomorphism of Proposition 21.5.4 induces an isomorphism of $E^{0}$-algebras

$$
E^{0}(B A) \cong E^{0} \llbracket x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m} \rrbracket /\left(\left[p^{k_{1}}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x), \ldots,\left[p^{k_{m}}\right]_{\mathbb{G}_{u}}(x)\right)
$$

Given the proof of Corollary 21.3.4, the careful reader may already recognize a close relationship between $E^{0}(B A)$ and $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$.

Now that we have calculated the $E$-cohomology of finite abelian groups we will turn our attention to the multiplicative structure enjoyed by Morava $E$-theory. The most important theorem regarding Morava $E$-theory is due to Goerss, Hopkins, and Miller [9] and we will endeavor to describe it now. Given a pair $(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)$, we have produced a homology theory $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)_{*}(-)$. Let FG denote the category with objects pairs $(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)$ of a perfect field of characteristic $p$ and a finite height formal group over $\kappa$. A morphism from $(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)$ to $\left(\mathbb{F}^{\prime}, \kappa^{\prime}\right)$ is given by a map $j: \kappa \rightarrow \kappa^{\prime}$ and an isomorphism of formal group laws $j^{*} \mathbb{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}^{\prime}$. This category is equivalent to the category called FGL in [9]. Goerss, Hopkins, and Miller produce a fully faithful functor

$$
\mathrm{FG} \xrightarrow{E(-,-)} E_{\infty} \text {-ring spectra }
$$

such that the underlying homology theory of the $E_{\infty}$-ring spectrum $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)$ is $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)_{*}(-)$. Moreover, they show that the space of $E_{\infty}$-ring spectra $R$ such that $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)_{*} R$ an algebra object in graded $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)_{*} E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)$-comodules that is isomorphic to $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)_{*} E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)$ is equivalent to $B \operatorname{Aut}_{\mathrm{FG}}(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)$. Thus the group of automorphisms of $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)$ as an $E_{\infty}$-ring spectrum is the extended Morava stabilizer group $\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathrm{FG}}(\mathbb{F}, \kappa) \cong \operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa) \rtimes \operatorname{Gal}\left(\kappa, \mathbb{F}_{p}\right)$. It follows that $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ acts on $E(\mathbb{F}, \kappa)^{*}(X)$ by ring maps for any space $X$.

In the homotopy category, the $E_{\infty}$-ring structure on Morava $E$-theory gives rise to power operations. For an $E_{\infty}$-ring spectrum $E$, these are constructed as follows: Let $X$ be a space and let $\Sigma_{+}^{\infty} X \rightarrow E$ be a an element of $E^{0}(X)$. Applying the extended powers functor $\left(E \Sigma_{m}\right)_{+} \wedge_{\Sigma_{m}}(-)^{\wedge m}$ to both sides produces a map of spectra

$$
\left(E \Sigma_{m}\right)_{+} \wedge_{\Sigma_{m}}\left(\Sigma_{+}^{\infty} X\right)^{\wedge m} \simeq \Sigma_{+}^{\infty}\left(E \Sigma_{m} \times_{\Sigma_{m}} X^{\times m}\right) \rightarrow\left(E \Sigma_{m}\right)_{+} \wedge_{\Sigma_{m}} E^{\wedge m}
$$

Now the $E_{\infty}$-ring structure on $E$ gives us a map

$$
\left(E \Sigma_{m}\right)_{+} \wedge_{\Sigma_{m}} E^{\wedge m} \rightarrow E
$$

Composing these two maps produces the $m$ th total power operation

$$
\mathbb{P}_{m}: E^{0}(X) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(E \Sigma_{m} \times_{\Sigma_{m}} X^{\times m}\right)
$$

a multiplicative, non-additive map. We will solely be concerned with the case $X=B G$, when $G$ is a finite group. There is an equivalence

$$
E \Sigma_{m} \times_{\Sigma_{m}} B G^{\times m} \simeq B G \imath \Sigma_{m}
$$

where $G \imath \Sigma_{m}=G^{\times m} \rtimes \Sigma_{m}$ is the wreath product. In this case, the total power operation takes the form

$$
\mathbb{P}_{m}: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B G \imath \Sigma_{m}\right)
$$

We will make use of variants of the total power operation, which we will introduce after a brief interlude regarding transfers.

As $E^{*}(-)$ is a cohomology theory, it has a theory of transfer maps for finite covers. For $H \subset G$, the map $B H \rightarrow B G$ is a finite cover and thus there is a transfer map in $E$-cohomology of the form

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{E}: E^{0}(B H) \rightarrow E^{0}(B G)
$$

This is a map of $E^{0}(B G)$-modules for the $E^{0}(B G)$-module structure on the domain coming from the restriction map. We will see that these transfers play an important role in understanding the additive properties of power operations and that they interact nicely with the character maps of Hopkins, Kuhn, and Ravenel. In particular, these transfers can be used to define several important ideals. Assume $i, j>0$ and that $i+j=m$, then there is a transfer map

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{E}: E^{0}\left(B G \imath\left(\Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j}\right)\right) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B G \imath \Sigma_{m}\right)
$$

induced by the inclusion $G \imath\left(\Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j}\right) \subset G \imath \Sigma_{m}$. Summing over these maps as $i$ and $j$ vary gives a map of $E^{0}\left(B G \imath \Sigma_{m}\right)$-modules

$$
\bigoplus_{i, j} \operatorname{Tr}_{E}: \bigoplus_{i, j} E^{0}\left(B G \imath\left(\Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j}\right)\right) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B G \imath \Sigma_{m}\right)
$$

Define the ideal $I_{\operatorname{tr}} \subset E^{0}\left(B G \imath \Sigma_{m}\right)$ by

$$
I_{\mathrm{tr}}=\operatorname{im}\left(\bigoplus_{i, j} \operatorname{Tr}_{E}\right)
$$

When $G$ is trivial, we will still refer to this ideal as $I_{\operatorname{tr}} \subset E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right)$.
Since $\Sigma_{m}$ acts trivially on the image of the diagonal $\Delta: G \rightarrow G^{m}$, we have a map of spaces $B G \times B \Sigma_{m} \rightarrow B G \imath \Sigma_{m}$. Restriction along this map gives us the power operation

$$
P_{m}: E^{0}(B G) \xrightarrow{\mathbb{P}_{m}} E^{0}\left(B G \imath \Sigma_{m}\right) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B G \times B \Sigma_{m}\right)
$$

Since $E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right)$ is a free $E^{0}$-module by [19, Theorem 3.2], we have a Künneth isomorphism

$$
E^{0}\left(B G \times B \Sigma_{m}\right) \cong E^{0}(B G) \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right)
$$

We will also denote the resulting map by

$$
P_{m}: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow E^{0}(B G) \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right)
$$

and refer to it as the power operation as well. Both the total power operation $\mathbb{P}_{m}$ and the power operation $P_{m}$ are multiplicative non-additive maps. Let $\iota: * \rightarrow B \Sigma_{m}$ be the inclusion of base point. The maps $\mathbb{P}_{m}$ and $P_{m}$ are called power operations because the composite

$$
E^{0}(B G) \xrightarrow{P_{m}} E^{0}(B G) \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right) \xrightarrow{\text { id } \otimes \iota^{*}} E^{0}(B G)
$$

is the $m$ th power map $(-)^{m}: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow E^{0}(B G)$.
The failure of the total power operation to be additive is controlled by the ideal $I_{\text {tr }}$ ([6, VIII Proposition 1.1.(vi)]). In other words, $I_{\text {tr }} \subset E^{0}\left(B G \imath \Sigma_{m}\right)$ is the smallest ideal such

that the quotient

$$
\mathbb{P}_{m} / I_{\operatorname{tr}}: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B G \iota \Sigma_{m}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}}
$$

is a map of commutative rings. The same relationship holds for the ideal $I_{\operatorname{tr}}$ and the power operation $P_{m}$, the quotient map

$$
P_{m} / I_{\operatorname{tr}}: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow E^{0}(B G) \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right) / I_{t r}
$$

is a map of commutative rings. Because of this, we will refer to $P_{m} / I_{\operatorname{tr}}$ as the additive $m$ th power operation.

The total power operation and its variants satisfy several identities that hold for any $E_{\infty}$-ring spectrum. These are described in great detail in Chapters I and VIII of [6]. For the purposes of this paper, we will need the following identity, which follows from [6, VIII Proposition 1.1.(i)], that will come in handy for the induction arguments in Section 21.9: Let $i, j>0$ such that $i+j=m$ and let $\Delta_{i, j}: \Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j} \rightarrow \Sigma_{m}$ be the canonical map and also recall that $\Delta: G \rightarrow G \times G$ is the diagonal. The following diagram commutes
![img-268.jpeg](img-268.jpeg)
where $P_{i} \times P_{j}$ is the external product

$$
E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B G \times B \Sigma_{i}\right) \times E^{0}\left(B G \times B \Sigma_{j}\right) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B G \times B \Sigma_{i} \times B G \times B \Sigma_{j}\right)
$$

and $\Delta^{*} \tau^{*}$ is induced by the map of spaces

$$
B G \times B \Sigma_{i} \times B \Sigma_{j} \rightarrow B G \times B G \times B \Sigma_{i} \times B \Sigma_{j} \rightarrow B G \times B \Sigma_{i} \times B G \times B \Sigma_{j}
$$

# 21.6 Character theory 

Since Morava $E$-theory is a well-behaved generalization of $p$-adic $K$-theory, one might wonder if some of the more geometric properties of $K$-theory can be extended to $E$-theory. The character map in classical representation theory is an injective map of commutative rings from the representation ring of $G$ to the ring of class functions on $G$ taking values in $\mathbb{C}$

$$
\chi: R(G) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}(G, \mathbb{C})
$$

It is the map taking a representation $\rho: G \rightarrow \mathrm{GL}_{n}(\mathbb{C})$ to the class function sending $g$ to $\operatorname{Tr}(\rho(g))$, the trace of $\rho(g)$. It has the important property that

$$
\mathbb{C} \otimes \chi: \mathbb{C} \otimes_{\mathbb{Z}} R(G) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}(G, \mathbb{C})
$$

is an isomorphism.

These ideas can be transported to the $K$-cohomology of $B G$. In [1], Adams showed that the $p$-adic $K$-theory of $B G$ also has a well-behaved character theory. His result makes use of Atiyah's completion theorem [4], which states that $K^{0}(B G)$ is isomorphic to the completion of the representation ring $R(G)$ at the augmentation ideal.

In [11], Hopkins, Kuhn, and Ravenel tackled the question of generalizing the character map to Morava $E$-theory. They did not have geometric cocycles (such as $G$-representations) available to them, but they did have a generalization of the representation ring of $G$ : $E^{0}(B G)$.

Following the construction of the classical character map, they produce an $E^{0}$-algebra $C_{0}$ that plays the role of $\mathbb{C}$ above, a ring of "generalized" class functions $\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)$, and a character map

$$
\chi: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)
$$

with the property that the induced map

$$
C_{0} \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)
$$

is an isomorphism. In this section we will give a short exposition of their work on character theory and explain the relationship between their character map and the action of the stablizer group on $E^{0}(B G)$. A longer exposition on character theory can be found in [16, Appendix A.1], written by the author, and of course, the best source is the original [11].

We begin by describing Proposition 5.12 in [11], which draws a connection between the group cohomology calculations of Section 21.5 and the moduli problem $\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ of Section 21.3. Recall that $A^{*}=\operatorname{Hom}\left(A, S^{1}\right)$ is the Pontryagin dual of $A$.

Proposition 21.6.1. [11, Proposition 5.12] Let $A$ be a finite abelian group. There is a canonical isomorphism of $E^{0}$-algebras

$$
E^{0}(B A) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}
$$

compatible with the action of the stabilizer group.
The ring $C_{0}$ is defined to be the rationalization of the Drinfeld ring $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$. It has the property that for all $k \geq 0$, there is a canonical isomorphism of group schemes

$$
\operatorname{Spec}\left(C_{0}\right) \times_{\operatorname{Spec}\left(E^{0}\right)} \mathrm{G}_{u}\left[p^{k}\right] \cong \mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right]
$$

In fact, this can be taken as the defining property of $C_{0}$, but we will not need this fact in this document. Since $C_{0}$ is the rationalization of the Drinfeld ring, it comes equipped with a right action of $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ by ring maps and an action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$ by $\mathbb{Q} \otimes E^{0}$-algebra maps. In fact, $C_{0}$ is an $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$-Galois extension of $\mathbb{Q} \otimes E^{0}$ [11, Propositions 6.5 and 6.6] so there is an isomorphism

$$
C_{0}^{\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})} \cong \mathbb{Q} \otimes E^{0}
$$

Recall that $\mathbb{L} \cong \mathbb{Z}_{p}^{\times n}$ and that $G$ is a finite group. Let $\operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G)$ be the set of continuous homomorphisms from $\mathbb{L}$ to $G$. This set is in bijective correspondence with the set of $n$-tuples

of pairwise commuting $p$-power order elements of $G$. There is an action of $G$ on this set by conjugation. We define

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right) & =\left\{C_{0} \text {-valued functions on the set } \operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim\right\} \\
& \cong \prod_{\operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim} C_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim$ is the set of conjugacy classes of maps from $\mathbb{L}$ to $G$. Thus $\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)$ is the ring of conjugation invariant functions on $\operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G)$ taking values in $C_{0}$.

The character map is defined as follows: Given a conjugacy class $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow G$, there exists a $k \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $\alpha$ factors through $\mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{p^{k}}$. Applying the classifying space functor to this map gives a map of spaces

$$
B \mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{p^{k}} \rightarrow B G
$$

Applying $E$-cohomology to this map gives a map of $E^{0}$-algebras

$$
\alpha^{*}: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B \mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{p^{k}}\right)
$$

By Proposition 21.6.1, the codomain is canonically isomorphic to $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$, which is the ring corepresenting $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$. Recall that there are canonical forgetful natural transformations $\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ over LT that induce maps of $E_{0}$-algebras

$$
\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow C_{0}
$$

Composing these gives an $E^{0}$-algebra map

$$
\begin{aligned}
\chi_{[\alpha]}: E^{0}(B G) \xrightarrow{\alpha^{*}} E^{0}\left(B \mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{p^{k}}\right) & \cong \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \\
& \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow C_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

Putting these together for all of the conjugacy classes in $\operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G)$ gives the character map

$$
\chi: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)
$$

Example 21.6.2. Let $A$ be a finite abelian group and let $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow A$ be a map. In this case, $\chi_{[\alpha]}$ admits an interpretation completely in terms of the moduli problems in Section 21.3. The map in (21.6.1) implies that we may view $\chi_{[\alpha]}$ as landing in $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$. Proposition 21.6.1 implies that the domain is canonically isomorphic to $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$. Putting these observations together, $\chi_{[\alpha]}$ gives us a map

$$
\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}
$$

or on the level of moduli problems, a map

$$
\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)
$$

Unwrapping the definition of $\chi_{[\alpha]}$, when this map is applied to a complete local ring $(R, m)$, it sends a deformation with level structure

$$
(l: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)
$$

to the deformation equipped with homomorphism

$$
\left(A^{*} \xrightarrow{\alpha^{*}} \mathbb{T} \xrightarrow{i} \mathbb{G}, i, \tau\right)
$$

There is a left action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$ on $\operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim$ given by precomposition with the Pontryagin dual. Combining this with the right action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$ on $C_{0}$, there is a right action on the set of $C_{0}$-valued functions on $\operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim\left(\right.$ ie. $\left.\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)\right)$. Explicitly this action is defined as follows: Let $\phi \in \operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$, let $f \in \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)$, and let $[\alpha] \in \operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim$ then

$$
(f \phi)([\alpha])=\left(f\left(\left[\alpha \phi^{*}\right]\right)\right) \phi
$$

To see that this is an action note that, for $\phi, \tau \in \operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$,

$$
((f \phi) \tau)([\alpha])=(f \phi)\left(\left[\alpha \tau^{*}\right]\right) \tau=f\left(\left[\alpha \tau^{*} \phi^{*}\right]\right) \phi \tau=f\left(\left[\alpha(\phi \tau)^{*}\right]\right) \phi \tau
$$

It turns out that the base change of the character map $\chi$ to $C_{0}$

$$
C_{0} \otimes \chi: C_{0} \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)
$$

is equivariant with respect to the right $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$-action on the source given by the action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$ on the left tensor factor and the right $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$-action on the target given above.
Theorem 21.6.3. [11, Theorem C] The character map induces an isomorphism

$$
C_{0} \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}(B G) \xrightarrow{\cong} \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)
$$

and taking $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})$-fixed points gives an isomorphism

$$
\mathbb{Q} \otimes E^{0}(B G) \xrightarrow{\cong} \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)^{\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{T})}
$$

The primary goal of this document is to give an exposition of the relationship between the power operations of Section 21.5 and the character map above. However, we are already in the position to explain the relationship between the stabilizer group action on $E^{0}(B G)$ and the character map, so we will do that now.

Since the stabilizer group $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ acts on $E$ by $E_{\infty}$-ring maps, it acts on the function spectrum $E^{X}$ by $E_{\infty}$-ring maps for any space $X$ and given a map of spaces $X \rightarrow Y$, the induced map of $E_{\infty}$-ring spectra

$$
E^{Y} \rightarrow E^{X}
$$

is $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$-equivariant. Recall from Section 21.3 that $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ also acts on $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$, $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ and $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ by commutative ring maps and thus there is also an action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ on $C_{0}$. Proposition 21.6.1 implies that the canonical isomorphism

$$
E^{0}\left(B \mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{p^{k}}\right) \cong \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}
$$

is $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$-equivariant. Putting all of this together, we see that the composite of (21.6.1)

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow E^{0}\left(B \mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{p^{k}}\right) & \cong \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \\
& \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}\left[p^{k}\right], \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow C_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

is $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$-equivariant. Since the character map is a product of maps of this form, we may conclude the following proposition.

Proposition 21.6.4. The Hopkins-Kuhn-Ravenel character map

$$
\chi: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)
$$

is $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$-equivariant for the canonical action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ on $E^{0}(B G)$ and the diagonal action of $\operatorname{Aut}(\mathbb{F} / \kappa)$ on $\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)$.

# 21.7 Transfers and conjugacy classes of tuples in symmetric groups 

In keeping with the theme of this article, in this section we will describe the relationship between transfer maps for Morava $E$-theory and the character map. In Theorem D of [11], Hopkins, Kuhn, and Ravenel show that a surprisingly simple function between generalized class functions, inspired by the formula for induction in representation theory, is compatible with the transfer map for Morava $E$-theory.

To describe Theorem D of [11], we need a bit of group-theoretic set-up. Let $H \subset G$ be a subgroup and let $[\alpha] \in \operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim$. The set of cosets $G / H$ has a left action of $G$ and we can take the fixed points for the action of the image of $\alpha$ on $G / H$ to get the set $(G / H)^{\operatorname{im} \alpha}$. We leave the following useful group-theoretic lemma to the reader.

Lemma 21.7.1. Let $H \subset G$ be a subgroup and let $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow G$. An element $g \in G$ has the property that $\operatorname{im}\left(g^{-1} \alpha g\right) \subset H$ if and only if $g H \in(G / H)^{\operatorname{im} \alpha}$.

Let $[\alpha] \in \operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim$ and let $f \in \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(H, C_{0}\right)$ be a generalized class function. Mimicking the formula for the transfer in representation theory, Hopkins, Kuhn, and Ravenel define a transfer map on generalized class functions,

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{C_{0}}: \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(H, C_{0}\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)
$$

for $H \subset G$ by the formula

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{C_{0}}(f)([\alpha])=\sum_{g H \in(G / H)^{\operatorname{im} \alpha}} f\left(\left[g^{-1} \alpha g\right]\right)
$$

Note that this formula is independent of the implicit choice of system of representatives of $G / H$.

Theorem 21.7.2. [11, Theorem D] For any finite group $G$ and subgroup $H \subset G$, there is a commutative diagram
![img-269.jpeg](img-269.jpeg)

Since the additive power operations are ring maps, they are easier to understand than the power operations. To study the additive power operations, we will understand the analogue of the ideal $I_{\operatorname{tr}} \subset E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right)$ in the ring of generalized class functions $\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{p^{k}}, C_{0}\right)$. We will make use of the following calculation.

Given $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow G$, let $1_{[\alpha]} \in \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(G, C_{0}\right)$ be the class function with value 1 on $[\alpha]$ and 0 elsewhere. Applying (21.7.1), we may conclude from Lemma 21.7.1 that if $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow G$ has the property that $\operatorname{im} g^{-1} \alpha g \subset H$, then

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{C_{0}}\left(1_{[g^{-1} \alpha g]}\right)([\alpha])
$$

is a positive natural number, where we are viewing $1_{[g^{-1} \alpha g]}$ as a class function in $\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(H, C_{0}\right)$. Also, if $[\beta] \neq[\alpha] \in \operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{L}, G) / \sim$, then

$$
\operatorname{Tr}_{C_{0}}\left(1_{[g^{-1} \alpha g]}\right)([\beta])=0
$$

Otherwise, $\beta$ would be conjugate to $g^{-1} \alpha g$, which is conjugate to $\alpha$.
Definition 21.7.3. Let

$$
\operatorname{Sum}_{m}(\mathbb{T})=\left\{\oplus_{i} H_{i} \mid H_{i} \subset \mathbb{T}, \sum_{i}\left|H_{i}\right|=m\right\}
$$

be the set of formal sums of subgroups $H_{i} \subset \mathbb{T}$ such that the sum of the orders is $m$. These sums are unordered and repetitions are allowed.
Remark 21.7.4. Another way to describe the set $\operatorname{Sum}_{m}(\mathbb{T})$ is as the set of multisets of finite subgroups of $\mathbb{T}$ whose orders sum to $m$. We prefer the description in the definition above because it suggests that $\operatorname{Sum}_{m}(\mathbb{T})$ consists of certain "effective Weil divisors" on the set of finite subgroups of $\mathbb{T}$.
Proposition 21.7.5. There is a canonical bijection of sets

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{L}, \Sigma_{m}\right) / \sim \cong \operatorname{Sum}_{m}(\mathbb{T})
$$

Proof. Since $\Sigma_{m}=\operatorname{Aut}(\underline{m})$, where $\underline{m}$ is a fixed $m$-element set, a map $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow \Sigma_{m}$ gives $\underline{m}$ the structure of an $\mathbb{L}$-set. Maps $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow \Sigma_{m}$ and $\beta: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow \Sigma_{m}$ are conjugate if and only if the corresponding $\mathbb{L}$-sets are isomorphic. Thus $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{L}, \Sigma_{m}\right) / \sim$ is in bijective correspondence with the set of isomorphism classes of $\mathbb{L}$-sets of size $m$.

Given $\alpha$, decompose $\underline{m}=\coprod_{i} \underline{m}_{i}$, where $\underline{m}_{i}$ is a transitive $\mathbb{L}$-set and let $\mathbb{L}_{i}$ be the stabilizer of any point in $\underline{m}_{i}$. Since $\mathbb{L}$ is abelian, the stabilizer does not depend on the choice of point. We define $H_{i}=\left(\mathbb{L} / \mathbb{L}_{i}\right)^{*} \subset \mathbb{L}^{*}=\mathbb{T}$. This construction only depends on the conjugacy class of $\alpha$, so send $[\alpha]$ to $\oplus_{i} H_{i}$. We leave it to the reader to check that this map is a bijection.

Let $\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{L}, \Sigma_{m}\right)^{\text {trans }}$ be the set of transitive homomorphisms $\mathbb{L} \rightarrow \Sigma_{m}$. Note that $\mathbb{L} \rightarrow$ $\Sigma_{m}$ is transitive if and only if the image is a transitive abelian subgroup of $\Sigma_{m}$. Since $\mathbb{L}=\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{n}$, this can only occur when $m$ is a power of $p$.

Proposition 21.7.6. There is a canonical bijection

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{L}, \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right)^{\text {trans }} / \sim \cong \operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}(\mathbb{T})
$$

where $\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}(\mathbb{T})$ is the set of subgroups $H \subset \mathbb{T}$ of order $p^{k}$.
Proof. Follows immediately from the construction of the bijection of Proposition 21.7.5.
The next lemma will be useful when we try to understand the relation between additive power operations and character theory. Recall the inclusion $\Delta_{i, j}: \Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j} \hookrightarrow \Sigma_{m}$, where $i+j=m$ and $i, j>0$. Proposition 21.7.5 gives an isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(\mathbb{L}, \Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j}\right) / \sim \cong \operatorname{Sum}_{i}(\mathbb{T}) \times \operatorname{Sum}_{j}(\mathbb{T})
$$

We leave the proof of the next lemma to the reader.
Lemma 21.7.7. Assume $i, j>0$ and $i+j=m$, then the map

$$
\operatorname{Sum}_{i}(\mathbb{T}, G) \times \operatorname{Sum}_{j}(\mathbb{T}, G) \rightarrow \operatorname{Sum}_{m}(\mathbb{T}, G)
$$

induced by $\Delta_{i, j}$ sends a pair of sums of subgroups

$$
\left(\oplus_{l} H_{l}, \oplus_{l} K_{l}\right)
$$

to the sum

$$
\left(\oplus_{l} H_{l}\right) \oplus\left(\oplus_{l} K_{l}\right)
$$

Corollary 21.7.8. Let $\sum_{j} a_{j} p^{j}$ be the p-adic expansion of $m$. The inclusion $\prod_{j} \Sigma_{p^{j}} \subseteq \Sigma_{m}$ induces a surjection

$$
\prod_{j} \operatorname{Sum}_{p^{j}}(\mathbb{T})^{\times a_{j}} \rightarrow \operatorname{Sum}_{m}(\mathbb{T})
$$

Proof. Follows from Lemma 21.7.7.
Finally, we use these ideas to give a description $\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right) / I_{\text {tr }}$, where $I_{\text {tr }} \subset$ $\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right)$ is the image of the sum of the transfer maps

$$
\bigoplus_{i, j} \operatorname{Tr}_{C_{0}}: \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j}, C_{0}\right) \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right)
$$

along the inclusions $\Delta_{i, j}$ for all $i, j>1$ with $i+j=m$.
Proposition 21.7.9. There is a canonical isomorphism

$$
\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right) / I_{\mathrm{tr}} \cong \prod_{\operatorname{Sub}_{m}(\mathbb{T})} C_{0}
$$

Idea of the proof. Proposition 21.7.5 implies that we have a canonical isomorphism

$$
\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right) \cong \prod_{\operatorname{Sum}_{m}(\mathbb{T})} C_{0}
$$

We will show that $I_{\operatorname{tr}} \subset \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right)$ consists of the functions supported on the set of sums of subgroups with more than one summand.

First we will show that functions with support not contained in the set of sums of subgroups with more than one summand cannot be hit by the transfer map. The transfer map $\operatorname{Tr}_{C_{0}}$ is a sum over elements that conjugate a conjugacy class $[\mathbb{L} \rightarrow G]$ into the subgroup $H \subset G$. In our case $G=\Sigma_{m}$ and $H=\Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j}$, where $i, j>0$ and $i+j=m$. If $\mathbb{L} \rightarrow \Sigma_{m}$ is transitive then every conjugate of the map is also transitive and so no conjugate can land inside $\Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j}$.

Now let $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow \Sigma_{m}$ be a non-transitive map. Thus $[\alpha]$ corresponds to a sum of subgroups with more than one summand. Therefore there exists $i, j>0$ with $i+j=m$ such that $\alpha$ is conjugate to a map $\beta: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow \Sigma_{m}$ that lands in $\Sigma_{i} \times \Sigma_{j} \subset \Sigma_{m}$. The discussion after Theorem 21.7.2 implies that $\operatorname{Tr}_{C_{0}}\left(1_{[\beta]}\right)$ is concentrated on $[\alpha]$ and there it is a non-zero natural number (which is invertible in $C_{0}$ ). Since the transfer map is a map of $C_{0}$-modules, $I_{\text {tr }}$ contains the factor of $\mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right)$ corresponding to $[\alpha]$.

By Theorem 21.7.2, there is a commutative diagram
![img-270.jpeg](img-270.jpeg)
where the sum is over all $i, j>0$ such that $i+j=m$. Therefore we have an induced map of $E^{0}$-algebras

$$
\chi: E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}} \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}} \cong \prod_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}(\mathbb{T})} C_{0}
$$

that we will continue to call $\chi$. Theorem 21.6.3 above implies that this map gives rise to an isomorphism

$$
C_{0} \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}} \xrightarrow{\cong} \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}}
$$

Finally, we will conclude this section by introducing convenient notation. Assume that $H \in \operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}(\mathbb{T})$ corresponds to the transitive conjugacy class $\left[\beta: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right]$. We define $\chi_{H}$ to be the composite

$$
\chi_{H}: E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{m}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}} \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{m}, C_{0}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}} \xrightarrow{\pi_{H}} C_{0}
$$

# 21.8 A theorem of Ando-Hopkins-Strickland 

An important ingredient in understanding the relationship between power operations and character theory is a result of Ando, Hopkins, and Strickland that gives an algebrogeometric interpretation of a special case of the power operation in terms of Lubin-Tate theory. Their result indicates that there is a connection between power operations and the $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$-action on $C_{0}$.

One starting point for making the connection between algebraic geometry and power operations is Strickland's theorem [19] which gives an algebro-geometric interpretation of $E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right) / I_{\mathrm{tr}}$.

Theorem 21.8.1. [19, Theorem 9.2] There is a canonical isomorphism of $E^{0}$-algebras

$$
E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right) / I_{\mathrm{tr}} \cong \mathcal{O}_{\mathrm{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}
$$

Idea of the proof. It is worth understanding the origin of this isomorphism. Let

$$
\operatorname{Div}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right): \operatorname{CompRings}_{E^{0} /} \rightarrow \operatorname{Set}
$$

be the functor that assigns to $j: E^{0} \rightarrow R$ the set of effective divisors on $j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}$. These divisors are just subschemes of $j^{*} \mathrm{G}_{u}$ of the form

$$
\operatorname{Spf}\left(R \llbracket x \rrbracket /\left(a_{0}+a_{1} x+\cdots+a_{p^{k}-1} x^{p^{k}-1}+x^{p^{k}}\right)\right)
$$

where $a_{i}$ is an element of the maximal ideal of $R$. Since a subgroup scheme has an underlying divisor, $\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$ is a closed subscheme of $\operatorname{Div}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)$. Proposition 8.31 in [21] gives a canonical isomorphism of formal schemes

$$
\operatorname{Div}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \cong \operatorname{Spf} E^{0}\left(B U\left(p^{k}\right)\right)
$$

where $U\left(p^{k}\right)$ is the unitary group.

It is not hard to check that the standard representation $s_{p^{k}}: \Sigma_{p^{k}} \rightarrow U\left(p^{k}\right)$ fits into a commutative diagram
![img-272.jpeg](img-272.jpeg)

The map

$$
\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow \prod_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}(\mathbb{T})} C_{0}
$$

is just the map to the base change

$$
\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow C_{0} \otimes_{E^{0}} \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \cong \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}(\mathbb{T})} \cong \prod_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}(\mathbb{T})} C_{0}
$$

and it is an injection since $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$ is a finitely generated free $E^{0}$-module (Corollary 21.3.6).

The map $E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}} \rightarrow \mathrm{Cl}_{n}\left(\Sigma_{p^{k}}, C_{0}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}}$ is also induced by base change and it is an injection by Theorem 8.6 of [19], which states that $E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}}$ is a free $E^{0}$-module of finite rank.

A diagram chase in the commutative diagram above gives us an injective map

$$
\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \hookrightarrow E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right) / I_{\operatorname{tr}}
$$

Proving that this map is an isomorphism requires some work. We refer the reader to [20] or [18] to see two different ways that this can be accomplished.

The isomorphism in Theorem 21.8.1 is built in such a way that the following diagram commutes
![img-273.jpeg](img-273.jpeg)

The composite of the left vertical arrows is $\chi_{H}$ from (21.7.2). The composite of the right vertical arrows factors through $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u})}$. The resulting map $\mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{\operatorname{Level}(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u})}$, which depends on $H \subset \mathbb{T}$, is the map of moduli problems that sends

$$
(l, i, \tau) \mapsto(l(H) \subset \mathbb{G}, i, \tau)
$$

Recall that the additive power operation applied to $B A$ for $A$ a finite abelian group is the ring map

$$
P_{p^{k}} / I_{\mathrm{tr}}: E^{0}(B A) \rightarrow E^{0}(B A) \otimes_{E^{0}} E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right) / I_{\mathrm{tr}}
$$

The domain and codomain both admit interpretations in terms of moduli problems over Lubin-Tate space. Applying $\operatorname{Spf}(-)$ gives a map

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \times_{\mathrm{LT}} \operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)
$$

There is an obvious guess for what this map might do when applied to a complete local ring $R$. An object in the groupoid

$$
\operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R) \times_{\mathrm{LT}(R)} \operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right)(R)
$$

is a deformation of $\mathbb{F}$ to $R,(\mathbb{G}, i, \tau)$, equipped with a homomorphism $A^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{G}$ and a subgroup scheme of order $p^{k}, H \subset \mathbb{G}$. We need to produce a deformation of $\mathbb{F}$ equipped with a map from $A^{*}$. This can be accomplished by taking the composite

$$
A^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{G} \rightarrow \mathbb{G} / H
$$

and recalling that $\mathbb{G} / H$ is a deformation in a canonical way. This is the content of Proposition 3.21 of [3]:

Theorem 21.8.2. [3, Proposition 3.21] The power operation $P_{p^{k}} / I_{\mathrm{tr}}$ is the ring of functions on the map of moduli problems

$$
\operatorname{Sub}_{p^{k}}\left(\mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \times_{\mathrm{LT}} \operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}\left(A^{*}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)
$$

that, when applied to a complete local ring $(R, m)$, sends a deformation equipped with subgroup of order $p^{k}$ and homomorphism $A^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{G}$

$$
\left(H \subset \mathbb{G}, A^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{G}, i, \tau\right)
$$

to the $\star$-isomorphism class of the tuple

$$
\left(A^{*} \rightarrow \mathbb{G} \rightarrow \mathbb{G} / H, i \circ \sigma^{k}, \tau / H\right)
$$

This theorem can be used to understand the relationship between $P_{p^{k}} / I_{\text {tr }}$ applied to finite abelian groups and the character maps. Recall the construction of $\chi_{[\alpha]}: E^{0}(B G) \rightarrow C_{0}$ in (21.6.1), the construction of $\chi_{H}: E^{0}\left(B \Sigma_{p^{k}}\right) / I_{\text {tr }} \rightarrow C_{0}$ in (21.7.2), and that $\operatorname{Isog}(\mathbb{T})$ acts on $C_{0}$ through ring maps.

Proposition 21.8.3. Let $H \subset \mathbb{T}$ be a subgroup of order $p^{k}$, let $\alpha: \mathbb{L} \rightarrow A$ be a group homomorphism, and let $\phi_{H}: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{T}$ be an isogeny such that $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\phi_{H}\right)=H$. There is a

commutative diagram
![img-274.jpeg](img-274.jpeg)

Proof. Since the image of the character map lands in $\mathcal{O}_{\text {Level }\left(\mathbb{T}, \mathrm{G}_{u}\right)}$, it suffices to prove that
![img-275.jpeg](img-275.jpeg)
commutes. Recall the definition of $\psi_{H}$ from Diagram (21.4.4). Now applying Example 21.6.2 to the maps $\chi_{[\alpha]}$ and $\chi_{\left[\alpha \phi_{H}^{*}\right]}$, applying the discussion around Diagram (21.8.1) to $\chi_{H}$, and applying Theorem 21.8.2 to the top arrow, we just need to check that a certain diagram of moduli problems commutes. Going around the bottom direction gives

$$

and going around the top direction gives

We want to show that the two resulting deformations are equal. Taking the quotient with respect to $H \subset \mathbb{T}$ and its image in $\mathbb{G}$ the level structure $l$ gives the commutative diagram
